post.text:
Ya’ll know I’m a sucker for a good greek mythology re-telling & Ariadne is definitely not disappointing so far
.
Ariadne, princess of Crete is the daughter of King Minos and the sister of Asterion, who is much better known as the Minotaur (half man, half bull). Growing up hearing the growls and hoofbeats of her brother in the labyrinth below the palace, and witnessing those sacrificed to his bloody appetite each year, this book is ultimately the story of Ariadne’s betrayal of her family and Crete when she reveals to her lover, Theseus, how to slay her brother the Minotaur.
.
In a world ruled by ruthless gods, Ariadne knows all too well what drawing their attention can mean for her fate. - I CANNOT WAIT TO FINISH THIS BOOK (& then discuss with @the.lowreylibrary) 🤩
.
If you love Greek mythology definitely pick this one up!

.

.

BOOKSTAGRAM ANNIVERSARY 🎉
.
1 whole year of being a part of this wonderful community! I’ve not only revived my love of reading but I’ve met so many wonderful people who I am now happy to call great book friends 📚
.
Here’s to another year of loving and chatting about books! Hope everyone has a great weekend ☺️

Hey again, bookstagram - it’s been awhile! 📚🦷
.
Life has been crazy to say the least. I officially have 1 more year left of dental school and that brings with it many stresses and challenges - so unfortunately, reading got put on the back burner. I wasn’t feeling creative, motivated or excited to post content. 
.
But, I’m back! What got me out of my reading slump was re-reading one of my favorite books - I needed something familiar and a story I already knew I loved. Plus, I got a brand new edition (bonus it includes both stories!) so I had to do a reread.
.
I also got a brand new order from my friend Abby @bibliopressed and had to show off my new bookish tee. I already have multiple other shirts in my cart on her website just waiting for me to purchase 😂
.
I’ve missed you all! I look forward to catching up! I’ll still be busy throughout the year but I am feeling excited about reading and posting again ♥️

.

.

.
SO now that they are finally here, I think I’m gonna reread the series 😅🤷🏻‍♀️ Middle-earth, here I come!
.
@juniperbooks THANK YOU! ♥️

Do you annotate your books?
.
I typically annotate and use sticky tabs while reading classic or very large books - it helps me easily turn back to quotes/scenes that I enjoyed, new vocabulary, when new characters are introduced, etc! When it’s a very large book (like The Count of Monte Cristo pictured here) I also mark every 100 pages! I find that annotating books makes the story more meaningful to me, and helps me stay engaged/focused while reading.
.
ALSO! @bookishlifeofabby recently made me a rep for her small business @bibliopressed and I couldn’t be more honored/excited to be a part of her team. This small canvas pouch is the perfect size to keep all my book annotating items!!! Plus, the designs she creates are up every book lover’s alley. Definitely go check out Abby’s shop & be ready for new items being released THIS SUNDAY 4/11! If you want to buy everything (like me) don’t forget to take advantage of an extra 10% off using my rep code: TOOTHY10 at checkout! 🦷♥️📚

A very bookish birthday 🥂🍰
.
Told my bf he should get me a book for each year I’ve been alive ... he didn’t think that was very funny 😅
.
Here’s to turning a quarter of a century old, I hope the next 25 are filled with great friends, great memories and of course, great books.

DUNE 🌓 Frank Herbert
.
Set thousands of years in the future, Dune begins the story of young Paul Atreides, heir to a noble family, as he & his family prepare to move to the desert planet, Arrakis (aka Dune), to rule, as declared by the Emperor. 
.
Arrakis is a challenging, inhospitable planet where the only thing more valuable than water is the ‘spice’ melange, an awareness spectrum narcotic that is able to enhance one’s consciousness and extend one’s life. But it is also very addictive making the eyes (iris + sclera) of those who consume it stained blue & has lethal withdrawal symptoms.
.
The spice is fundamental for commerce & is necessary for space travel by enabling navigators to safely guide space ships through warp space. The spice can only be harvested on Arrakis, and therefore is heavily valued, capable of sustaining or destroying the empire.
.
However, Paul & the Atredies family have been brought to Arrakis under false pretenses & are betrayed. The destruction of his family and his people sets Paul along a journey towards his destiny of becoming the mysterious ‘Muad’Dib’ and leading the Arrakis natives, The Fremen.
.
This book is sci-fi gold. I loved it so much. I will say the first couple chapters are extremely dense and therefore slow, as Herbert dumps the reader into a whole new world with strange names, words and hierarchies. You WILL NEED THE APPENDIX! I was so intimidated by the first few chapters because I had no idea what was going on - but I’m so glad I pushed through and continued to read. I also watched a small crash-course on YouTube of how the world of Dune is set up/how it came to be - really helped me out.
.
After pushing through the confusion, this book has so many amazing things about it: a coming of age story that tackles politics, religion, environmentalism and climate change. It is good vs evil & has deep characters that are interesting to explore and love. Plus is has giant sandworms that you can ride (if you’re skilled enough not to die first). This book is the cornerstone of science-fiction. 🏜 can’t wait for the film adaptation!

Currently reading: DUNE 🏜
.
AND LOVING IT! You know what else I’m loving? My “Read A Book” sweatshirt from @inkwellthreads & the fact that it’s sunny & I can feel warm weather coming! I miss reading outside!
.
I have about 100 pages left in Dune & I honestly am so happy I started this series. (Thanks for buddy reading with me @maryhadalittlenook). The detail that went into the world building is incredible and so interesting. I cannot wait to read the other books and see the movie when it comes out this fall! Book review for DUNE will be coming soon!
.
Is it sunny where you all are? Do you enjoy reading outside? 😍

a bookish reminder: 📚❌💣 
.
Hope ya’ll had a great weekend!

ANATOMY OF A MILLENNIAL MIDDLE-SCHOOLER’s BOOK-STACK
.
I am heavily exposing my middle-school self through this post lol, any of you relate? During this time of my life I was also taking AR tests for my classmates in exchange for their cookie at lunchtime - It was a pretty good gig (till I got caught & shut down in 7th grade 👎🏼). 
.
I realize now that my arms were so sore all the time because I was carrying around so many unnecessary books everyday. Oh well, builds character I guess lol (tbh not much has changed - I still carry around more books than I need! 😂)
.
Also, yes this is my middle-school uniform that I put on special just for this picture
A MOOD: my weekend is fully booked 🧖🏻‍♀️📖

Catch-22 ✈️ Joseph Heller
.
“Open your eyes, it doesn’t make a damned bit of difference who wins the war to someone who’s dead.” 
.
This story follows Yossarian, a young bombardier in the United States Army stationed in Italy during WWII. Yossarian is trying to make it through the war alive, and is absolutely furious that there are so many people (most that he doesn’t know) trying to kill him.
.
Yossarian quickly discovers that it is not just the Nazi Germans who are out to get him, but the leaders of his own squadron who continue to raise the number of combat missions men must fly before they can be sent home. Then, of course there is the catch, Catch-22.
.
Catch-22 states that any man that is deemed to be insane can be grounded and not fly anymore combat missions, but concern for one’s own safety in the face of danger is the process of a rational mind.
.
In summary, a soldier who continues to fly into combat of his own accord is considered crazy and is eligible to be grounded, all he has to do is ask. BUT, as soon as that same soldier asks to not fly anymore missions, he would no longer be crazy and would therefore have to fly more missions. 
.
This book is without a doubt one of the most bitterly hilarious, wonderfully witty novels I have ever read. Full of satire and cynicism this book portrays and exposes the insane world of war and the military mindset. This book shows the side of war the general public fails to think about: how it unhinges and flips morals, what’s right and wrong - everything you think you know - upside down. So many important and serious themes emerge through the satire and humor as our narrator, Yossarian, attempts to make sense of the war which in and of itself is senseless. 
.
Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Catch-22. I laughed out loud many times and used tons of stickies to mark notable quotes. While this book isn’t perfect, being repetitive and harder to follow all the characters in the beginning & the flow of the book can be hard to get into at times, I’ve never read a single book like this & I’m very happy to add this American classic novel to my read pile. 4 ⭐️

Introducing the #BigBookLovin challenge 🤩📚
.
So often these thick, beautiful beauties catch our eye in bookstores, but they rarely get off our shelves once we bring them home
.
I want bookstagram to show some lovin to their favorite big books & try and break the intimidation surrounding reading them! Whether it takes you a week, a month or a year to finish one of these doorstoppers, IT DOESN’T MATTER! 
.
I’ve seen a lot of amazing things on bookstagram, but I’ve also seen some disappointing things. Some won’t pick up their large books because they are afraid they won’t make their monthly quota. Why are we making reading into a job?! It’s a hobby & one that shouldn’t involve competition. All the pressure and BS readers put on themselves or others to read a certain amount of books, etc. needs to end. Reading is for everyone no matter how fast/slow you get through books, no matter how many books you read a year - it looks different on each person and that’s 💯 okay.
.
I’m guilty of this too - so many times I’ve skipped over my big books because I think it will take up too much time to read them and I will fall behind on my “goal.” Well I’m tired of that type of thinking & I want to embrace my big books & dive into the wonderful stories I’ve been missing! I challenge everyone to pick up a large book you’ve been avoiding and break the reading stigmas on bookstagram. This challenge is open to ANYONE! 🤩

{that feeling when} you just really want to match your current read 🤩
.
Catch-22 is not disappointing so far! Plus, I’ll take any chance I get to wear my bookish tees from @inkwellthreads highly recommend their book tee subscription! 📖😍
.
.
.

A Thousand Ships 🏺 Natalie Haynes
.
An incredible feminist take on Greek mythology and the classic tales of the Trojan War and The Odyssey. This book gives these women (who we’ve read so much about their husbands) a voice. We get to experience their suffering, their anger, their bravery and their losses..
.
Tales of women like Penelope [wife of Odysseus], Hecabe [wife of Priam & Queen of Troy] and her daughters, Clemnestra [wife of Agamemnon] & many many more women who are typically written in the shadow of men, are now center stage in this story & I loved reading every chapter of it.
.
This book give women dimension, unlike the stoic natures they possess in past books written about the same topic. Natalie Haynes has somehow made reading a well-known story feel brand new. I was very impressed and will definitely be reading more by her in the future. 🏺 this book gets all the ⭐️s from me.
.
This picture is supposed to represent Aphrodite holding the Golden Apple. As the story goes, the goddesses Aphrodite, Hera & Athena commanded Paris, prince of Troy, to choose the most beautiful among them and gift her the golden apple. Aphrodite promised Paris the most beautiful woman in the world [Helen of Sparta] & thus when Paris stole her away to Troy, The Trojan War was initiated.

Pour me a cup of knowledge, I’ve had enough caffeine 📖☕️
.
.

#PaperbackPages challenge 2.0 📖
.
My dear friend @thepaperbackbruncher never ceases to amaze me with her creativity! Her idea for this second round of the paperback pages challenge produced some of my favorite photos yet. I had so much fun with this & love the movement captured in the shots!
.
My floppiest paperback book (and the one pictured in these photos) is The Stand by Stephen King, a recent addition to my all-time favorite books.

Brood 🐣 Jackie Polzin
.
Thank you @doubledaybooks for the ARC in exchange for an honest review! 
.
Brood was a compelling story that reads very smoothly on the surface, almost like private journal entries. However, this story is anything but simple, tackling heavy, emotional topics under the surface. 
.
A woman who has recently experienced a miscarriage, hides her grief by obsessing over the safety and care of her four chickens - seemingly trying to convince herself that she is worthy and capable of caring for another living thing. With her husband oblivious to her inner grieving, our nameless narrator attempts to focus on anything but her great loss. She strives to keep her chickens alive through a bitter Minnesota winter, a summertime tornado & the creatures that hunt at night. She has to prove to herself she can provide for these 4 animals.
.
This is a very realistic & moving story of one trying to pave the way through despair towards hope of new possibilities.

✨ A Saturday spent at bookstores is a Saturday well spent ✨
.

Eenie Meenie Miney Mo,
Choose a book or let it go.
Will this book be friend or foe?
There’s only one way to know.
.
WUTHERING HEIGHTS!! You’ve been chosen as my next classic read! (ignore the subpar poem skills lol).

The Midnight Library ♟ Matt Haig
.
“Life sometimes simply gave you a whole new perspective by waiting around long enough to see it.”
.
In Nora Seed’s opinion, she’d rather be dead. Misery & despair have dominated her years and she can never shake the feeling that she’s repeatedly let everyone in her life down, including herself. On one particularly bad day, Nora decides to end it.
.
However, as Nora comes to find out, between life & death there is a library - The Midnight Library, to be exact, with the librarian being a beloved individual of her past. The Midnight Library houses endless volumes - all different versions of how your life could have been if you’d made different choices.
.
Nora begins to explore the library’s contents firsthand, able to transport directly into these parallel/perpendicular universes, where she attempts to undo each decision she’s ever regretted. But she does not have forever to decide. Before time runs out she must choose: which is the perfect life? What is the best way to live?
.
Okay, this will without a doubt be one of my favorite books in 2021. This story is quick paced (I read in less than 24 hours), heart-felt, and offers very important lessons about your outlook on life. As someone who constantly wonders how my life could’ve turned out differently if I made different choices, this book hit special with me. With nods to great philosophers, Haig explores the meaning of life & provides important insight which the reader can carry forward into his/her own life.
.
“It is easy to mourn lives we aren’t living. Easy to wish we’d developed other talents, said yes to different offers. Easy to wish we’d worked harder, loved better, handled finances more astutely, stayed in the band, said yes to coffee or done more bloody yoga...it’s easy to regret, and keep regretting...until our time runs out.”

The Da Vinci Code 🥀 Dan Brown
.
Robert Langdon, the renowned American symbologist is awoken suddenly in the night from his Paris hotel room where he is currently visiting on business, to some terrible news. The curator of the Louvre has been murdered inside the museum and left a cipher which has the French police absolutely baffled.
.
Joined and aided by the French cryptologist, Sophie Neveu, Langdon begins to reveal a trail of many clues hidden, several in the works of Leonardo Da Vinci right inside the museum. But with Langdon being the prime suspect of the curator’s murder, there is not much time to sit and think.
.
As clue after clue reveals more information, Neveu and Langdon discover that the curator was a member of the Priory of Sion - an ancient secret religious society whose main purpose is to protect an extremely important religious relic - most importantly keeping it out of the hands of the Catholic Church.
.
In a heart-racing chase that leads from Paris to London, Langdon and Neveu work to discover the answers to the puzzle, all the while being hunted by the French authorities & an Opus Dei (Catholic extremist) monk. If the secret falls into the wrong hands, it will be lost forever.
.
So, I figured it was about time I read this controversial book! Growing up in the Christian faith, I was curious to see what had everyone buzzing about this book many years ago. My mom advised me before I began to simply read this book for what it is, which is FICTION. And I personally enjoyed this story tremendously.
.
I absolutely loved the setting: Europe has my heart so I enjoy any book set in that continent. Secondly, I LOVE a good treasure hunt where a series of clues must be solved. As far as how the Catholic faith is portrayed, again, this book is fiction & I don’t think Brown was encouraging readers to go away from the faith. He simply was creating a story of something that could have been, expanding the possibilities of reality and religion.
.
Summed up, this book was witty & extremely fast-paced with short chapters that allowed me to race through & there is a ton of historical, art and religious history that I absolutely loved learning more about.

Hamilton: The Revolution ⭐️ Lin Manuel Miranda & Jeremy McCarter
.
I’ve been obsessed with Hamilton the musical for several years but this book was everything I never knew I needed. Just reading everything that went into the process of creating such a genius masterpiece was mind blowing. Going through each of the songs & reading Lin’s little comments about his particular word choice, his references to other artists, etc. somehow made me feel like I was discovering Hamilton for the first time all over again.
.
If you are already a fan of the show, read this book immediately - It will only fuel your obsession. If you have yet to jump on the Hamilton fan train, definitely listen to some of the music and see how you like it. It’s so carefully and creatively crafted with every single line serving a specific purpose, it’s impossible not to be impressed. I mean, writing ACCURATE United States history into a hip-hop/rap musical while still entertaining people seems like an impossible feat - but Lin Manuel blew that challenge out of the water. A show this incredible comes maybe once a generation.
.
ALSO just realized today is my 2 year anniversary since seeing the show! 😍

The Martian 🚀 Andy Weir
.
So picture Tom Hanks “Castaway” but switch the island setting to planet Mars. When an unexpected dust storm forces the crew of the Ares 3 mission to evacuate the planet early, Mark is presumed to be dead & the rest of the crew start the journey back to Earth. BUT, Mark Watney is miraculously alive & all alone with no way to signal to Earth that he survived.
.
His only chance of rescue are the Ares 4 mission due to land on Mars in 4 years. But his supplies will run out way before that date and he’ll starve...if the unforgiving Mars environment and failing equipment don’t kill him first. Mark is forced to put his mechanical engineering & botany skills to work to stay alive and find some way of communication. This book is the story of his struggle to survive.
.
This book was awesome! Watney’s character was the perfect snarky, sharp-witted and sarcastic narrator & I found myself laughing out loud multiple times throughout this story! While I found Weir to be very scientific and technical throughout this book, I didn’t feel like it went over my head too much that I felt annoyed reading it - I actually quite enjoyed learning much about the realm of space, engineering and physics. I also liked the set up of this book, following Mark’s experience on Mars through his own first-person journal entries.
.
If you want a face-paced story of survival full of drama, problem-solving & a sarcastic botanist astronaut (who becomes the first to cultivate Mars soil by growing potatoes🥔), you will fall in love with Andy Weir’s “The Martian” as I have. Now, time to watch the movie adaptation!

The Stand 🦠 Stephen King
.
Something goes horribly wrong at a biological testing facility & employees hurriedly rush to lockdown the entire area but one guard gets out unknowingly carrying the super-flu virus originally intended for warfare purposes. “Captain Trips” as the sickness comes to be known is an antigen-shifting virus and it is lethal to 99% of people.
.
In a horrifically short amount of time, billions of people are dead, drowned in their own snot & the few immune survivors are stuck with a new problem: where do they go from here?
.
Along with the billion of decaying bodies, miles of car pileups and no electrical power, the surviving individuals are having dreams & nightmares of what the future holds. Some see the 108 year-old black woman who calls herself Mother Abigail and believes her final mission is to carry out God’s plan. She calls people to start a commune in Boulder Colorado and live peacefully.
.
In their nightmares, the one they call “The Dark Man” visits & asks them to come worship him in the new Las Vegas where sin and lust and greed can flourish. The Dark Man embodies evil and thrives on violence and death & wants to see the world burn. Anyone who does not join him will perish. In the end, only the survivors can decide the ultimate fate of humanity. 
.
Okay, this books was INCREDIBLE & like, real-life scary. But how does one even begin to summarize a 1,153 page book?! It’s very hard. The things I enjoyed most about this book were the character development, the detail & the ultimate battle between good and evil. This book makes you THINK and feel paranoid about how the world really would play out if 99% of us were wiped out.
.
To summarize my thoughts? Basically - read this book. It’s often called King’s best work for a reason. It will make you laugh, cry, gasp and cringe. It shows you the very worst and the very best of humanity & to conquer evil, sometimes good must be sacrificed. One of the scariest thoughts I had is what side would most people choose if this happened today? I’d like to think good would win out, but, that’s also not guaranteed. 
.
ALL THE STARS for this door-stopper of a book ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

THE HOME STRETCH ☕️ #coffeeandcurrentlyreading 
.
I hit page 931 in The Stand by Stephen King today & that means I am on the final part of this 1,153 page beast of a book. I don’t believe King has ever had a thought that is less than 500 pages 😂
.
This is the first time I’ve tackled a novel over 1,000 pages & I was very intimidated at the start. But, I should’ve known I’d fall head first [down the rabbit hole, if you may] into this story. I’ve loved all my past experiences reading King & I’ve heard from many that this is his best work. I have definitely been blown away.
.
I have mixed feelings about being so close to the ending! I really don’t want this story to end, yet I am very anxious to find out what happens. Looking forward to reviewing this book soon!
.
Also, to all my book friends out there that have been wanting to tackle a 1000+ page book, GO FOR IT! You may be pleasantly surprised how quick it reads & it will definitely give you a sense of accomplishment [& an arm workout!] 💪🏼📚

A Series of Unfortunate Events 👁 Lemony Snicket
.
Oh how I thoroughly enjoyed my reread of the Vastly Frightful Despicable story of the Baudelaire orphans, a story I haven’t revisited since my elementary school days (thank heavens my school experience was nothing like the Baudelaire’s at Prufrock Prep.)
.
For those who know nothing of this Very Foul Disturbing narrative, It begins with the terrible fire that destroys the mansion & parents of Violet, Klaus & Sunny Baudelaire. Mr. Poe, a banker who always has a persistent cough, is in charge of their affairs and places them in the care of their [extremely] distant relative Count Olaf. The Count is a Villanous, Foul, Dishonest man (who believes himself to be a handsome/talented actor which is just not the case) whose main motive is scheming to get his hands on the Baudelaire fortune.
.
Throughout the books, the orphans travel from relative to relative only to find that misfortune and despair follow them everywhere & Count Olaf is always a step behind them making their lives more & more dangerous & miserable with each scheme. Only with Violet’s keen inventing mind, Klaus’s wonderful research talents & Sunny’s dental/cooking abilities are the children able to [barely] escape Olaf’s clutches each time. 
.
As the list of unfortunate events, murdered guardians, mysteries surrounding V.F.D. - a secret organization that the Baudelaire parents were part of - & sinister tattoos of eyes on ankles, which may stand for something noble or treacherous, the Baudelaire orphans wonder if their lives will ever be cheerful again. 
.
This series will take you, the reader, into the stormy waters of Lake Lachrymose with man-eating leeches, into a horrible school where the vice principle does not know how to play the violin but insists on doing so anyways, down a pitch black elevator shaft to rescue triplets, into a run-down carnival with starved lions, through the tallest mountains & the deepest caves of the sea - & if you decide to continue reading, which the author will advise you against - good luck, my Valued Fortunate Distingushed friend.

Hey reading buds 👋🏼 do what my fancy new pin from @outofprint says & READ BANNED BOOKS!!! Celebrate your intellectual freedom!!!
.

At the beginning of 2020, I promised myself I would read more classics/modern classics & reread ones that I didn’t appreciate in school. This reading challenge was made much easier by my “100 Epic Reads of a Lifetime” scratch off novelogue by @bnthr_dntht! I made it to 30/100 this year! 
.
I am a very type-A person & being able to scratch-off after reading a book was both motivating & extremely satisfying for me! Plus, I love the simple yet classic design of the poster - looks great hanging next to any bookshelf! 📚🥰

People Like Her 📱 Ellery Lloyd (#3 in my water trilogy)
.
Emmy never intended to become an Instagram influencer, but after finding out she was pregnant & her dream of being in charge of a fashion magazine becoming a thing of the past, Emmy searched for a way to build a career around being a mom. Thus, Mamabare was born.
.
Fast-forward a few years & add 1 million + followers & adoring fans, Mamabare is the platform Emmy connects to the millions of mums seeking solace in someone who gets what they’re going through. It is also Emmy and her washed-up novelist husband, Dan’s large source of income. But, Dan has always been hesitant about Emmy being so open about their family life and sharing many pictures of Coco and Bear online - fearful of what trolls and obsessed fans could do.
.
As Emmy and her Instagram success grow, the more superficial and insensitive she becomes & the fragile facade of her marriage and family life threatens to crack. It also becomes clear that one of her many followers wishes her harm & lurks ever nearer, threatening to ruin all Emmy is.
.
This book was a different kind of creepy and I enjoyed it for that reason. It explored the darker side of social media and the dangers of the information we post online. It brought to light how superficial social media life is: often staged, overly-filtered, over-exaggerated, with fake smiles. After reading this, I definitely realize how I myself live life through my camera lens at times & understand the need to be more present. It also reinforced the chilling fact that in making our lives public, we invite not only our friends & family to see, but also strangers who do not always have the best intentions.
.
ALSO big shoutout to @nicklausaltomare who captured his creepy shadow in the pool reflection without even meaning to 😂 (SWIPE to see up close) It worked perfectly for this book! #toothfulreviews

Jaws 🦈 Peter Benchley (#2 in my water picture trilogy)
.
“There’s nothing in the sea this fish would fear. Other fish run from bigger things. That’s their instinct. But this fish doesn’t run from anything. He doesn’t fear.”
.
DA DUM...DA DUM... The town of Amity is under attack by a man-eating shark. Bodies (well parts of bodies) wash up on shore, people go missing, some even witness the attacks. Chief of Police, Brody wants the beaches closed until they can be sure the shark is gone but many others, especially the mayor, push for the beaches to remain open. Here’s why: if Amity closes its beaches this summer, the town may as well be dead - for the locals of Amity survive the rest of the year off the profits they make from the rich-folk spending their summers there.
.
As more victims are claimed by the shark, the town doesn’t have a choice. The shark must be killed. Hooper, a young ichthyologist comes to help & him and Brody employ Quint (a hardcore fisherman) and his boat to catch the water devil. However, this Great White is unlike any other shark - smart & cunning - and promises to not die without a fight & claiming more victims.
.
After watching and loving the movie growing up, I was nervous reading the book, worried it wouldn’t live up to Spielberg’s film masterpiece. Now, I still like the movie more than the book but, I did enjoy reading this horror story. The book had more dark subplots to it that the movie eliminated including an affair (which I could’ve done without) & the mafia. I wish Quint’s character would’ve been developed better in the book, i liked his role in the movie more. Also, there were larger boring chunks where no one was getting eaten and I was upset lol but when action was happening...It was gory and exciting. 
.
Overall, I’m very happy I decided to read the book that goes along with a favorite movie of mine! (INNER TUBES WERE HARMED IN THE MAKING OF THIS PHOTO)
.
& always remember, “you’re gonna need a bigger boat”🪝🦈 #toothfulreviews

The House in the Cerulean Sea 🌊 TJ Klune (#1 in my water picture trilogy) 
.
“Sometimes, you were able to choose the life you wanted. And if you were of the lucky sort, sometimes that life chose you back.”
.
THIS BOOK WARMED MY HEART 💙 easily one of my favorites of this whole year & quite possibly of my new all-time favorites.
.
Linus Baker is a caseworker for The Department in Charge of Magical Youth & is good at what he does. Every magical child must be registered and accounted for, living in orphanages until they can get their power under control. Linus’s job is to make sure the orphanages are safe and the children are being well cared for, otherwise he recommends they get shut down.
.
At the age of 40, Linus is content, I guess. He has his old Victoria records, his sunflowers, his devious cat, Calliope & his picture of the sea (which he’s never actually seen before) with words underneath the picture reminding him everyday: “don’t you wish you were here?” But he doesn’t know what he’s missing - until one day his whole life changes.
.
Linus is summoned by Extremely Upper Management and given a vague, extremely classified new assignment that takes him to a far-away island with, perhaps, the most secret orphanage, in which resides 6 of the most dangerous magical children. His job is simple, observe and report for 1 month & determine if the orphanage should remain open.
.
Linus is greeted by the most unique & enigmatic individuals, being most intrigued by the master of the orphanage - Arthur Parnassus - whom [it’s clear from the beginning] will do everything in his power to keep the children safe, no matter the cost to himself. Linus finds the more time he spends on the island, the closer he becomes to its inhabitants & the the less objective he is able to be in his reports, which was a MUST according to Extremely Upper Management. 
.
Linus learns many things throughout his time on the island & you as a reader will too - finding parallels between this magical world and ours. I promise you will fall in love with all of the children & feel protective of them yourself. This book evokes powerful emotion because Klune makes the reader feel like part of the family. ❤️

THAT FEELING WHEN you finish your final exams and you are one semester closer to your DDS 🦷 PLUS you get to read for a month straight without studying interfering 😍#wootwoot
.
If you can’t tell, I am a very happy [and sleepy] girl. Cheers to finishing my first semester of clinic & actually treating patients! 2.5 years down & 1.5 to go! 🙌🏻
.
Dear dentistry & teeth, I LOVE you...but I don’t want to think about you for awhile! Catch you on the flippity-flip!
.
.
.

The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue ✨ V. E. Schwab
.
“Because time is cruel to all, and crueler still to artists. Because vision weakens, and voices wither, and talent fades. Because happiness is brief and history is lasting, and in the end ... everyone wants to be remembered.” 
.
Growing up, Adeline LaRue was told not to pray to the gods who answer after dark unless she be willing to trade more than simple trinkets. But desperate situations arise & Addie ends up selling her soul to the devil in exchange for immortality & freedom. He may have her soul when she is done with it, but there is a catch: she cannot be remembered by anyone she meets. She cannot make relationships, cannot write or draw or be captured in photos. She cannot do anything that would allow her to make a mark on the world or another person. 
.
Each year on the anniversary of her deal, the darkness returns to ask if she is ready to give up her soul - a way to leave the pain of constantly being forgotten by everything and everyone. But Addie is stubborn and determined to find excitement and happiness despite the limits of her curse. This book is a beautiful account of her life spanning across centuries & countries.
.
I know there has been a lot of hype surrounding this book & some have been let down. I am not one of those. I was completely enchanted by this book. Not only was the prose in and of itself, beautiful, but the entire essence of this story as well. The richness of the history, the excitement of travels across Europe, the amazing character development & the sweet, steady romance between star-crossed lovers are only a few of my favorite things I can name about this book.
.
The book did lag at times, but this didn’t diminish the impact for me. The fact that the chapters are short made it easier to push through the slower ones & I absolutely loved that the story bounced from present day and Addie’s past encounters with the darkness.
.
Again, this book might not be everyone’s favorite. But, I know for a fact it has become one of mine. It’s the first book in quite some time that I’ve felt sad to finish & had the urge to start again immediately. I will be talking about Addie for a long time.

The Giver 🛷 Lois Lowry
.
I had such a wonderful time rereading this classic from my childhood, I think I actually enjoyed it more as an adult because the meaning hit a little deeper for me this time. 
.
Our main character, Jonas, lives in a seemingly utopian society run by The Elders, in which human beings have finally learned how to live in harmony. They do this by the concept of “Sameness.” The society functions by homogenizing its citizens daily activities, family unit, job assignments, experiences, etc. There are no colors or emotions. Spouses are assigned, as well as jobs (when you turn 12), and each family can apply for 2 kids. What Jonas comes to realize is that all emotion, passion, pain and love have been cut out in order to achieve a peaceful society.
.
Everything changes when Jonas turns 12 & is selected as being the next “Receiver of Memory” - the highest and most special honor, but not a coveted position for it is also one of isolation and pain & Jonas is forbidden to discuss his training with anyone. After being taught by the previous Receiver, who is now considered “The Giver,” Jonas begins to question the society he lives in, and feels the veil has finally been torn off his eyes. Is the sacrifice really worth what has been gained? 
.
This book is eye-opening & depressing but it shows how valuable individuality & raw emotion is. Yes, it causes war, suffering, loss and poverty, but it is also the reason we are able to love and enjoy our life. If one never experiences sadness or pain then one can never truly be happy. Without these things, life really does become meaningless. #toothfulreviews

Jurassic Park 🦖 Michael Crichton
.
Yet another sci-fi classic I have fallen in love with! I absolutely love the film but I have to admit, the book was incredible. I {quite literally} could not put this book down - it was THAT good.
.
In case you don’t know the plot for this story: a very wealthy man named John Hammond has devoted millions of dollars to open his new “theme park” on an island in Costa Rica in which visitors can come experience dinosaurs - a true interaction with the past.
.
Hammond has hired the most ambitious scientist, engineer & staff to make his dream come to life. Extracting dinosaur DNA from insects, preserved in amber, who drank Dino blood & then cloning them to make the real deal, adding in bits of other DNA when needed. What could possibly go wrong with creating animals that we have absolutely no idea about?
.
The book takes place a few months before the park is to be open to the public. Funny things have been going on & some of the investors are questioning the secrecy surrounding the mysterious project they’ve paid lots of cash into - they want to know what truly goes on inside Jurassic Park & they have sent a lawyer to investigate.
.
Hammond, in an effort to save his own a$$ & show that nothing sketchy could possibly be happening - invites a paleontologist, paleobotanist, mathematician (specializing in chaos theory) and his two grandkids to the island to show off his greatest achievement. Everything looks well organized from the outside - until an internal conspiracy, main control power outage, de-electrified safety fences & a severe underestimation of dinosaur behavior wreck havoc on the visitors and staff. Can they ever get off the island alive? 
.
Again, LOVED this book so much. Perfect combo of science fiction & thriller plus a little gore for fun. Crichton did amazing at making facts and scientific terms enjoyable to read. This book is a fun read but also makes the reader question how far science can and SHOULD go - pushing boundaries anywhere will always have consequences. #toothfulreviews

The Handmaid’s Tale 🧺 Margaret Atwood
.
“Nolite te bastardes carborundum - don’t let the bastards grind you down.” 
.
A fundamentalist Christian theocracy called “The Republic of Gilead” has taken power over much of the United States after falling birthrates and terrorist attacks led to massive panic across the country. Under this religious totalitarian system each person has their place.
.
Under Gilead’s rule, Handmaids are fertile women considered to be morally “impure” in some way. They take the name of their commander thereby giving up their own. Handmaids are given to high ranking leaders in Gilead so that children may be born to the family. 
.
Under this totalitarian patriarchy, women are forbidden to read and write. We experience Gilead through our Handmaid narrator, Offred, as she navigates the horror that is her new reality. Once a month she must lie on her back and pray the Commander makes her pregnant. She only has value if her ovaries are viable. If she fails to get pregnant after a certain time, it’s off to the radiation poisoned colonies - which is certain death. The Republic of Gilead is harsh and unforgiving. 
.
This is such an iconic dystopian novel & I enjoyed devouring every page of it. I had watched the Hulu series before reading so I knew the plot, but I still really enjoyed reading the book! 
.
Some people have mentioned that this book is frustrating because Atwood doesn’t give a lot of answers to explain how Gilead came about, what’s really going on in the world, etc. However, I think this was deliberate. Offred didn’t have much information, she couldn’t risk discussing such topics, so the limits of our knowledge aligned with those of Offred’s and overall helped add to the mysterious & disturbing tone of this book.
.
PRAISE BE! I cannot wait to read The Testaments now! So glad I didn’t have to wait years for a sequel!
.
Under His Eye 👁 #toothfulreviews

The Trial ⚖️ Franz Kafka
.
The Trial is the psychologically terrifying tale of Josef K, a highly respected bank official, who is inexplicably arrested on the morning of his 30th birthday by two guards who burst into his apartment. For the rest of the story, Josef must find ways to defend himself against this mysterious charge of which he can get absolutely no information about. He has no idea why he’s under arrest & being tried - he just knows it’s not a joke & his life depends on the outcome.
.
This novel is first and foremost a warning against totalitarian government and the excess of bureaucracy. I think what made this book so chilling is how closely the story adhered to reality. There was no twisting or blown-out-of-proportion concepts or ideas. Everything was very believable & the ideas surrounding the government and the legal system hit close to home. 
.
Court proceedings obscured by other court proceedings. Responsibility of explanation deferred to some unidentified “higher-up” judge or court officials. Innocent until proven guilty? More like guilty until proven less guilty & becoming less guilty relies more on “who you know” rather than hard evidence.
.
This book was slow at times throughout, but when it picked up it held my attention unwaveringly. The best way I can describe reading this book is that it feels like someone is sitting on your chest and your breath is slowly leaking out of your lungs leaving you gasping at the air but cannot get new air in. Its a slow realization that innocence & logic don’t always prevail over a powerful, corrupt system.
.
Kafka’s vision of the future is the nightmare of our existence - trying to apply logic and fact to the absurd. When justice is compromised and those who are sworn to uphold it are corrupt - in what can the people put their faith in to rebalance the scales? #toothfulreviews

Hamlet 💀 William Shakespeare
.
{I sincerely apologize for bringing a tragedy to your Saturday morning feed, but I had never read Hamlet before & I surprisingly really enjoyed it!}
.
In a nutshell, this tragedy is this: The ghost of the Denmark king [Hamlet Sr.] reappears to his son [Hamlet Jr.] urging him to avenge his murder by killing his murderer, Claudius - Hamlet Sr. brother & also [conveniently] the new King of Denmark. To make matters even worse for Hamlet Jr. -  Claudius married his mother (that’s right - married his own brother’s wife)
.
Hamlet fakes madness while growing increasingly more eager to expose his uncle’s murderous conspiracy. He contemplates life & death, all the while seeking revenge...coming to find all too late that revenge itself is deadly. His own obsession may be his own downfall.
.
I’ll begin by saying reading anything by Shakespeare has always intimidated me. I’ve never read anything by him without the help of an English professor to legitimately walk me through each line 😂 so starting Hamlet by myself made me nervous! Now, I’m very happy I took on the challenge!
.
I give all the praises to the Barnes & Noble editions of Shakespeare’s work - they give you explanations & differing word choices for each page as you’re reading, making it so much easier to understand and enjoy!
.
Ultimately, I think every once-in-a-while we should pick up books that challenge us. I don’t necessarily mean that everyone needs to pick up Shakespeare or read a book that is of NO interest to them. What I mean is, don’t keep yourself from reading a book just because you are intimidated & feel you won’t understand.
.
Books will always mean different things to different people. If you’re interested in a book that intimidates you, I encourage you to pick it up and try! You may be pleasantly surprised as I was with Hamlet. I look forward to reading more of Shakespeare’s work especially since Barnes & Noble Shakespeare is here to help me! #toothfulreviews

Ready Player One 🕹 Ernest Cline
.
“Being human totally sucks most of the time. Video games are the only thing that make life bearable.”
.
An energy crisis, wide-spread poverty & death. The entire planet on the brink of chaos and collapse - that’s what the year 2044 holds for the human race. Most people don’t spend their time in “reality” though. Rather, they find their escape salvation in the OASIS: an expansive virtual reality universe created by the eccentric genius, James Halliday.
.
The book begins with the death of Halliday & the announcement of his [will-be-famous] contest to find a digital Easter egg hidden somewhere in the OASIS. The first person to complete the quest will inherit Halliday’s multi-billion-dollar fortune.
.
5 years have gone by with no avatar user making an progress towards finding the Easter egg. People begin to forget - brush it off as impossible, until a young Wade Watts [known as Parzival in the OASIS] puts together the meaning of the first clue. With his name instantly put on top of the scoreboard for the whole world to see, he realizes his fame also means danger to others who are seeking the fortune. If he wants to survive, he need to win & the race to the finish is on. He needs his vast knowledge of the 1980’s pop culture, near- perfect video gaming skills & help from some unlikely friends to win the ultimate prize.
.
Wow. I mean WOW. I absolutely LOVED this book so much, so much more than I expected to! This whole book felt like playing in a video game universe & it was beyond fun to experience. I cannot wait to watch the movie & for the second book [Ready Player Two] that comes out this month!
.
If you want a book that’s easy to follow, is consistently fast-paced and action packed then you will love this book! Also, if you enjoy the 80’s at all you will appreciate the hundreds of references to that era scattered throughout this wonderful book. 🎮
.
QOTD: do you enjoy playing video games, or did you when you were younger? #toothfulreviews

My main haunt @thebookloft 👻📚
.

Magic Lessons 🔮 Alice Hoffman
.
“Drink chamomile tea to calm the spirit. Feed a cold and starve a fever. Read as many books as you can. Always choose courage. Never watch another woman burn. Know that love is the only answer.”
.
17th century England -  Hannah Owens finds an abandoned baby in the snow protected by a black crow. She instantly knows this baby is special by her half moon-shaped birthmark - the mark of a naturally born witch. Hannah names the baby Maria & raises her as her own & teaches Maria all she can about the “Natural Art.” The most important lesson she gives Maria, is about love - “Always love someone who will love you back.”
.
As the story progresses, we follow Maria as she grows up & moves to the American colonies during the dangerous time of the Salem Witch Trials, where no woman or girl is safe in Massachusetts. We are with Maria as a young girl who naively falls in love & is betrayed by a deceitful man, thereby swearing off love forever. We are there as she foolishly invokes a curse that will affect the Owen women’s’ bloodline for generations to come. She may find out too late that true love is the only thing that matters.
.
GUYS!!! I’m going to be talking about this book for a LONG time & I would not be surprised if this is my favorite book this year. Also NEW FAVORITE AUTHOR ALERT 🚨 
.
This is the unforgettable prequel to Practical Magic & The Rules of Magic, but if you’re like me & have not read the other books in the series - DON’T LET THAT DETER YOU! You don’t need prior knowledge to read & fall in love with this story! I can’t wait to read the other two 😍 I cannot say this enough - READ THIS BOOK!!! #toothfulreviews

Am I the only one who gets creeped out by things hanging from trees? 🍂💀
.
I know I just posted a reel of these 5 books, but I loved the creepy look of them hanging, that I had to take a picture as well! I’ll give a little mini review of each down below! Any of these would be perfect to read these autumn months as the weather gets cooler and the light fades early. 👻
.
ANATOMY OF EVIL: analyses from a psychology, psychiatry, and neuroscience perspective looking into the minds of those whose actions are described as evil.
.
PET SEMATARY: a family moves into a new house in a rural part of Maine. Everything is perfect except for the makeshift pet cemetery in the woods behind their house. Warnings and nightmares try and repel the family from venturing onto the sacred land, let alone bury anything there. The family soon learns that sometimes, dead, is better.
.
COMA: A young medical student, Susan Wheeler, attempts to get to the bottom of what she believes to be a horrible conspiracy at Memorial Hospital. Patients are going in for routine, minor surgery and coming out in an inexplicable, irreversible brain death. Devoting herself to finding answers may just be the last thing Wheeler ever does.
.
AND THEN THERE WERE NONE: 10 strangers arrive at a remote island off the Devon coast invited by a mysterious host none of them have actually seen. Their host is nowhere to be found, but he/she knows more than enough about each guest’s wicked past. Each guest has been accused of murder and before the weekend is out secrets will be revealed and one by one they begin to die. Only the dead are above suspicion.
.
CUJO: a big, loving St. Bernard dog chases an animal into an underground hole only to be bitten by a rabid bat. Mans best friend turns into his worst enemy as Cujo becomes aggressive & sick with madness. A stay at home mom & her child run a fateful errand, but find her car is dead when she tries to return home. Stuck in their tiny car in the summer’s heat with no food or water - the mother and child have a frightening showdown with the rabid dog.

Piranesi 🏛 Susanna Clarke
.
This post is titled : STATUE OF A GIRL WHO FOUND A NEW FAVORITE BOOK located in the EIGHTY-EIGHTH WESTERN HALL near the 5TH VESTIBULE.
.
The House is all Piranesi has ever known. The House that is a labyrinth of infinite halls & corridors. The House where thousands of intricate statues line the walls & floors of every room. The House with the Ocean imprisoned in it & where 15 people reside - 13 dead & 2 living - Piranesi and The Other. 
.
Piranesi has weekly meetings with The Other, who is searching for A Great and Secret Knowledge which will grant him ancient powers. Piranesi, who has a grand understanding of The House, it’s ocean tides & endless statues, helps with The Other’s research & lives to explore the endless rooms. Until one day, evidence of a 16th person in The House appears & everything Piranesi has ever known is threatened.
.
This book was so good!😭 It was written beautifully through Piranesi’s journal entries and the fantasy concept was so intriguing. If you are going to read this book, I suggest you dive in as I did - without any prior knowledge of what this book is about. Stick with the story through the first 15 pages of confusion and complexity - the House will reveal all you need to know as you go along ✨ so go in blinded & see what Piranesi’s world has to offer!
.
PS - I apologize my fingers are literally covering the title 🙄
#mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

Leave the World Behind 🦩 Rumaan Alam
.
Family vacation. Large, beautiful house on Long Island made possible to rent through Airbnb. A moment to take a break from NYC. A breath of fresh air in the country. A chance to enjoy themselves. This is what Amanda & Clay believe the week holds for themselves & their kids Archie & Rose.
.
What they don’t expect? A late night knock at the front door revealed to be a husband & wife who claim to be the owners of the house. They bring with them news that a blackout has swept through NYC & the East coast. They drove all night in a panic to have shelter here. They need to be let inside. They need to stay until they know more information. Is it a fluke or is it the end of the world? The 2 families are left to wait this question out together with no phone service, no news. Just increasing paranoia & distrust of each other and the world as they know it.
.
Let me start by saying, if you like your book endings all tied-up in a perfect bow - this book is NOT for you. Personally? I appreciate an unsatisfying, “think-for-yourself” ending. It’s uncomfortable. It’s realistic.
.
This book slowly creeped me out but nothing outright scary happened. My growing sense of unease grew with the characters - increasing to down right panic at times, nervously glancing over my shoulders and wondering what the f*ck was going on. I felt the author did a great job of making me feel like I was trapped in that house right along with the characters.
.
Throughout, I felt the prose & sentence structure were overwritten and frustrating to understand at times - the detail, mostly in the beginning, felt distracting from the story. But, overall I think the author did an amazing job at transporting me as a reader into the story and not just an outsider looking in.
.
🦷⚠️: PS, if you don’t like teeth or things happening to teeth - don’t read. As a [future] dentist though, I personally loved it & felt it added perfectly to the “what the f*ck-ness” (probs not a word) of this story.
#mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

Slaughterhouse Five ☠️ Kurt Vonnegut {aka: The Children’s Crusade: A Duty-Dance with Death}
.
What do you get when you put WWII, time-travel & aliens together? Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse Five. One of America’s classic anti-war novels that, once again, appears more simple on the surface yet tackles many important subjects including PTSD, soldiers reintegrating into society after war & the horrors of war.
.
This book is crazy. Throughout, we follow Billy Pilgrim, a WWII veteran, as he time-jumps from moment to moment throughout his life. The central story is Billy’s experience as an American prisoner of war & ultimately ends with the devastating bombing of Dresden, Germany.
.
Now, I know I mentioned aliens - but this is by no means a science fiction novel! The way Tralfamadorians [4D alien species - green & plunger-shaped, resembling a hand with an eye at the center] fit in is this: They kidnap Billy & put him in a zoo on their planet to study him. To the Tralfamadorians, time is not linear. All moments are forever occurring, at all times and you can jump from moment to moment. This is how the story is set up as we follow Billy’s time-jumping through his life moments.
.
What I appreciated most about this book is it’s dark humor, satire & Vonnegut’s ability to write about such heavy concepts in light, straightforward way. War is a subject humans don’t like to think incredibly deeply about - it’s a subject that offers disturbing and horrifying secrets. Yet, it’s so important to understand the reality of PTSD & how the ones who fight for their country are inevitably changed forever as a result.
.
These newspapers are ones my grandpa (who fought in WWII) saved. One is from 1945, when Japan surrendered & the other is 1989 when the Berlin Wall fell.
#mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

The Song of Achilles 🏹 Madeline Miller
.
Guys, I’m swooning ALL OVER AGAIN for my second read by Madeline Miller! I cannot stress enough how she makes a classic, well-known story feel captivating & new - rushing through the pages to figure out how it ends, even though I already know.
.
This story is a different take on Homer’s Iliad - the story of the Trojan War, the fight to win back Helen of Sparta and of course Aristos Achaion, the best of the Greeks, Achilles. However, the story’s point of view is from Patroclus, an exiled prince, with whom Achilles has an inseparable bond.
.
I think one of the reasons I enjoyed this story so much [aside from the beautiful prose] is because Miller made it easy for me to learn and enjoy this story without much prior Iliad knowledge. That takes skill. I seriously can’t recommend this book & Circe enough. Also bring your tissues for this one. Easily all the stars for me 😍
.
What could make this book even better? I buddy read it with my dear book friend @michelles.bookshelf!!! 🤍 I can’t wait for our discussion & more buddy reads with you!
.
.

The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy 👽 Douglas Adams
.
DON’T PANIC!!!
.
Planet Earth and all its inhabitants are about to be vaporized by some Vogon aliens in order to facilitate an intergalactic highway for the hyperspace express route through the galaxy! Luckily for Arthur Dent, he is plucked off the planet by his friend Ford Prefect - an alien who has been posing as an “out-of-work” actor for the last 15 years, but is really a researcher for the revised edition of The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy - the most useful survival manual an interstellar hitchhiker can have.
.
Hop on the Heart of Gold spaceship with these two & join in their adventures which include meeting Zaphod Beeblebrox, the president of the Galaxy and the inventor of the Pan Galactic Gargle Blaster drink [which feels like having your brain smashed with a slice of lemon wrapped around a gold brick], Trillian, Zaphod’s gf & the super intelligent but incredibly depressed robot, Marvin. 
.
On this journey you’ll enjoy searching for the meaning of human existence & WHY the answer to the ultimate question of life, the universe & everything is 42.
.
On the surface this novel is an incredibly light & funny science fiction classic but it also offers some deeper meaning about human happiness and how searching for the meaning of life may cause us to miss our own in the process. 
.
Come along for this interstellar journey where humans are the 3rd most intelligent life form on Earth [just after mice & dolphins] & just remember: DON’T PANIC & DON’T FORGET TO BRING A TOWEL!!! 👽🌌👍🏼🛸 #mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

The Old Man and the Sea 🎣 Ernest Hemingway
.
84 days have gone by since Santiago, an old, poor Cuban fisherman, has caught a fish. On the 85th day of his fishing dry-spell, the old man is pulled out to the open sea in the Gulf of Mexico after hooking a giant marlin. On the surface, this story is about the relentless, challenging battle between the old man & the fish. But it’s meaning also runs much deeper.
.
This was my first read of Hemingway & let me start off by saying the prose was absolutely beautiful. I also enjoyed the underlying themes of this short novel: the role of luck in one’s life vs skill and perseverance, the reality of growing old, respect and reverence for nature, tenacity in the face of inevitable defeat & what really defines success. I believe this simple story has some important lessons to offer the reader.
.
I like this book much more after thinking about its meaning for a few days than I did right after reading. I had to work a little bit to get some depth from this story so I tried to analyze it like I was reading a book for school. I think this is a story that the reader chooses how much he/she wants to read into it & certainly would mean different things to an individual at different milestones of life. #toothfulreviews

The Guest List 🥂 Lucy Foley
.
Jules Keegan and Will Slater are absolutely picture perfect. He, a rising TV star, effortlessly charming & she, a self-made, ambitious publisher of her own magazine - you couldn’t put two people together who are more perfect on paper. their much anticipated wedding must be no different.
.
The remote location of the wedding makes it even more exclusive - a small island off the coast of Ireland where the guests must travel over from the mainland by boat. Every single detail of the day is planned to a “T.” However, it quickly becomes clear that no matter how perfectly you plan, you can’t control the weather nor people with something to hide.
.
With the photographs taken, cake cut, and alcohol flowing a little too freely the guests & wedding party plan to wait out the storm underneath the marquee. Alongside the choppy waters & unreliable electricity - petty jealousies & old, dark secrets threaten to surface. 
.
The bride. The groom. The best man. The wedding planner. The plus-one. The bridesmaid. Each person has something to hide, each person has a motive to kill & one individual will not leave that island again, alive.
.
This book was so so good! I loved it! The different points of view from multiple people kept the story interesting & fresh. The twists were surprising & realistic. Overall, I feel like this thriller could easily have been a true story. It’s spooky season people, definitely add this thriller to your list! #mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

Transcendent Kingdom 🧠 Yaa Gyasi
.
Wow. My head is swarming with thoughts about this book and it’s been difficult to find the right words to talk about this powerful, powerful story.
.
Gifty, a Ph.D. candidate in neuroscience at Stanford School of Medicine, has devoted the last 5 years towards researching reward-seeking behavior in mice and the neural circuits involved in addiction. Having lost a brother to a heroin overdose years earlier when a sports injury left him hooked on pain pills and looking after her depressed mother who is wasting her life away in bed, Gifty is determined that hard science can provide the answers to all of her unanswered questions. Throughout her research, Gifty struggles with reconciling her devoted, religious childhood self, preserved in journal entries, with the secular, scientific self she is today. This story is one of loss, addiction, grief and struggles with faith.
.
This story hit extra special for me. I related very closely with Gifty’s research into addiction, reward seeking behavior and the brain because I completed my undergraduate honors thesis researching a very similar issue. The opioid epidemic and heroine overdoses are very real issues that the United States has been battling for a long time. For me, as a future dentist, I wanted to know how my future profession fit into the problem. A large amount of people have their first experience with narcotics from a dentist (for wisdom teeth extractions & tooth pain).
.
In my research, I wanted to know if the amount of lecture hours a dentist had while in school on addiction & safe prescribing influenced their opioid prescribing habits, relationships with patients and adherence to ethical practices. I sent out a survey to hundreds of Ohio dentists & was amazed by the results. 
.
I won’t go into everything I found, BUT if you ever want to talk about this topic anytime, please feel free to reach out to me! #toothfulreviews

Fahrenheit 451 🚒 Ray Bradbury
.
“It was a pleasure to burn.”
.
Imagine living in a world where reading & possessing books is illegal. A world where books are banned as a means for the government to control the thoughts of the public and keep them complacent. Imagine a world where firemen START fires, their hoses filled not with water, but kerosene.
A fireman’s job is to burn all books, the houses that hide them & anyone who tries to protect them.
.
Guy Montag is a fireman in this dystopian world. He has become utterly aware of how empty and meaningless his life is so he turns to the books he’s ordered to burn in search of something deeper. Once a proud fireman, but now a “fireman turned sour” Montag struggles more and more each day to function in this escapist society. He longs for happiness, fulfillment & to understand whats wrong with society - so he turns to books. But no one who hides books is safe & no one can be trusted to keep the secret.
.
I love dystopian stories so much & this short classic by Bradbury is thought provoking, heart-breaking & quite honestly makes you appreciate your freedom to read books & have your own thoughts 💭🔥🚒 #mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

Final Girls 🔪 Riley Sager
.
Final girl (n.) - the last girl or woman alive to confront the killer, ostensibly the one left to tell the story
.
Dark woods. Screaming. A brandished knife. Searing pain. A white dress turned red. Blood. So much blood. And Coop, the cop who saved her life, her saving grace. These jumbled flashbacks are the only memories Quincy has of the horror she endured at Pine Cottage 10 years ago. Everything else is black.
.
Now Quincy has a thriving, instagram-worthy baking business & a stable, caring lawyer boyfriend. Samantha Boyd and Lisa Milner are other final girls who survived massacres of their own & Lisa attempts to bond with Quincy. But Quincy wants nothing to do with the fame and publicity that comes with the final girl lifestyle. But one day Lisa Milner turns up dead & Quincy soon realizes you can’t run from your past forever...🔪
.
I am finally caught up with all of Riley Sager’s books & this one was definitely one of my favorites! I loved the realism of a “slasher movie” this story portrayed & how the ending twists completely caught me off-guard (per usual). My experience was extra enjoyable though because I got to buddy-read it with one of my favorite people, @onceuponanattorney!!! ❤️ I can’t wait for many more with her in the future! Also, special thanks to @nicklausaltomare for putting up with me & being my model 🤩
.
This book was a perfect read for the start of spooky season 👻🎃 #mybookfeatures #toothfulreviews

The Catcher in the Rye 🚬 J.D. Salinger
.
“𝙒𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙘𝙠𝙨 𝙢𝙚 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙞𝙨 𝙖 𝙗𝙤𝙤𝙠 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩, 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙮𝙤𝙪’𝙧𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙩, 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙬𝙞𝙨𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙖𝙪𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙬𝙧𝙤𝙩𝙚 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙧𝙞𝙛𝙞𝙘 𝙛𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙣𝙙 𝙤𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙨 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙘𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙝𝙞𝙢 𝙪𝙥 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙛𝙚𝙡𝙩 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙞𝙩. 𝙏𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙙𝙤𝙚𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙣 𝙢𝙪𝙘𝙝, 𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝.”
.
In this once banned novel & acclaimed classic of American literature we follow Holden Caulfield, a 16-year-old rebellious teen who has been kicked out of multiple boarding schools, disappoints professors & believes everyone to be a “phony.” Upon being kicked out of his most recent boarding school, Pencey Prep, Holden opts to take to the streets of New York City for a few days before returning home to face his reality & consequences. As the reader, we follow his NYC adventures. 🍎
.
For the first 2/3 of the book, Holden drove me insane - he was indecisive, shallow & hypocritical. Although, there were times where I chuckled out loud, too, at Holden’s commentary - “I’m quite illiterate, but I read a lot.” After I finished the book, I went back through and read some different parts again & I began to understand the depth, emotion & struggle underlying [what I originally thought to be] superficialities of this story. A child trying to make it in an adult world that is very much disappointing, robbed of his childhood innocence earlier than is fair and trying to grow-up & move on in a world where he’s lost a brother who represented all that was genuine & true to him
.
Once I stopped reading this book in one-dimension, I connected and empathized with Holden & his frustrations/resentments against “phony” people & things. I also feel that way a lot of the time, which is why I’ve learned to appreciate and hold-on to genuine people & things in my life 🧡
.
PS - I’m not in NYC right now 😔 this is a canvas I had printed of a picture I took on top of Rockefeller Center when I was last there! #toothfulreviews

.

.

.
.

The Death of Vivek Oji 🌸 Akwaeke Emezi
.
“What does it mean for a family to lose a child they never really knew?” 
.
I will be thinking about this book for a long time & I never expected to love this book as much as I did. When I started, I actually thought there was a good chance I wouldn’t finish, but I am so glad I did & let me tell you...if you plan on reading this book, bring the whole dang tissue box for the last 2 chapters.
.
From the very beginning (really just from the title!) we know Vivek is dead. Grief pours from each of the characters — especially Vivek’s mother & father, who find him dead, left on their veranda, stripped of his clothes, and are in complete confusion how he died and who brought him back. Vivek’s mother suspects his closest friends, especially her nephew, Osita, are keeping secrets about Vivek’s mysterious death & vows to not rest until she learns the truth.
.
I don’t want to give too much of Vivek’s story away, but I want to convey the power this story radiates. I am having trouble finding the right words for this story. It is heartbreaking, yet freeing at the same time. This book is written non-chronologically & the point of view switches between third person narration & first person views from multiple characters. I found It to work perfectly with the telling of this story. 
.
Overall, I was stunned & heart-broken. Right now, those are the only words I have for my first Emezi novel. I would absolutely read more by her. 
.
⚠️: descriptive sexual scenes, incest, domestic violence, LGBTQ discriminating themes #toothfulreviews

Mexican Gothic 🍄 Silvia Moreno-Garcia
.
.
Okay, let me start off by saying that I REALLY liked this story, I just didn’t love it.
.
It’s the 1950’s and Noemí Taboada is a carefree, young socialite who spends her days & nights dazzling many suitors in Mexico City. One night, her partying is interrupted by her father who calls her home with concerns about her cousin, Catalina, stemming from a disturbing letter she sent regarding her husband:
.
“He is trying to poison me. You must come for me Noemí. You have to save me.” 
.
Noemí packs her bags & heads for an isolated mansion in the Mexican country to hopefully address these crazy allegations and get back to the city as soon as possible. But the rotting house & some of its inhabitants have other plans and are not keen upon letting either girl return.
.
Like I said, I did thoroughly enjoy this horror story, it just took ~200 pages to “build up” to the turning point where I had my “oh, sh*t” moment. I also couldn’t totally get behind some of the main plot points. Regardless, I think this book does tackle some interesting topics including Eugenics, Philosophy & Darwin’s evolution which I thoroughly enjoyed thinking about alongside this story. Also, 12 year-old Kristine, who wanted to be a mycologist (after reading Series of Unfortunate Events — The Grim Grotto & seeing it as a second best to Herbology) enjoyed all the information on fungi! 🍄
.
If this book has been on your radar, read it. I binge read this on the car ride home from vacation & am still in a bit of a book-hangover from Circe. So, under different circumstances, I may have loved this book, because like I said, it’s interesting! And Moreno-Garcia writes a captivating story with vivid descriptions & chapter cliffhangers. I would love to hear other people’s thoughts on this book! 🌸 #toothfulreviews

Circe 🔱 Madeline Miller
.
.
CALLING ALL LOVERS OF GREEK MYTHOLOGY TO READ THIS BOOK IMMEDIATELY
.
Man oh man did I LOVE this book — I found myself wishing for more as I finished the last page & turned back to the beginning because I didn’t want to be done with her story yet. This also happened to be my first buddy read EVER with my very sweet friend @maryhadalittlenook ❤️ I loved being able to share my thoughts & feelings about this story with her while reading!!! 
.
In this story we follow Circe, the least favorite child of Helios, god of the Sun, as she pushes through hundreds of years being unappreciated & bullied by other gods & nymphs in her father’s halls, as she is exiled to the island of Aiaia for performing witchcraft, as she encounters familiar mythological monsters & individuals such as the Minotaur, Scylla & Charybdis, Medea & Jason, Hermes & of course, Odysseus. Circe has long felt that she doesn’t belong among the gods & titans, yet her immortality & divinity also keep her separated from mortals she loves. Through years of honing her witchcraft on her island of exile, Circe searches for where she truly belongs.
.
Madeline Miller makes a well-known story exciting and novel, while at the same time easily smoothing the way for a reader who has no knowledge of The Odyssey to enjoy ✨being able to read this story while on the beach only made It better! I absolutely cannot wait to read Song of Achilles and any other work she writes. 🧡
.
.

The Vanishing Half ✨ Brit Bennett
.
.
Stella & Desiree Vignes are identical twins living in a small Black town in Louisiana. Mallard is a town so small it’s not recognized on any map. But, just like any small town, it has its rules — spoken & unspoken. A town that prides itself on making each generation of Negro lighter than the one before. At 16, however, the twins escape to New Orleans in search of a better more exciting life, wanting more to live for than Mallard can offer. Two twin sisters, 2 parts of 1 whole —  they could take on the world as long as they had each other. But things change. Stella unexpectedly leaves in the night & the two Vignes twins begin their separate lives. Desiree marries a darker man, one Mallard would never approve of & has a daughter that bears no resemblance to her. Stella secretly passes for a white woman and builds her entire life around this lie. She has a daughter as well, who grows up not knowing her true racial identity. What the twins could never imagine is that their daughters may be the key to weaving back together their separated lives. The only question is — is this what both twins want?
.
.
I had high expectations going into this novel & I ended up reading it in a little over 24 hours. I was not disappointed in the slightest. This novel is powerful & courageous, raw & emotional. It tackles important topics including race, gender & class. The character development is impeccable. The effort Bennett put into each and every character’s story is impressive and clear. Overall, this multigenerational story will make you think and feel all the things.
.
.
This book is hyped up, and for good reason. It’s not every day you come across a deep meaningful story like this. I would recommend that every person read this book.
.
.

The Turn of the Key 🗝 Ruth Ware
.
.
A child is dead & Rowan Caine is awaiting trial for murder. This book is her desperate letter to a lawyer — a written anecdote of what really happened in that horrible house near the Scottish moors with all of its invasive and malfunctioning technology, terrifying past and poisonous garden. She admits things don’t look good for her case. After all, she did lie to obtain the nanny post & the ever-watching cameras in every room would show footage of her losing her temper with the children. She’s not saying she’s innocent of any mistakes...she’s just not the one guilty of the murder. She begs the lawyer to read her entire story because he truly is her one & final hope...
.
.
This was my first experience reading anything by Ruth Ware & I was not disappointed! This book did however, take me about 100 pages to get really into the story. Also, it left me begging there would be some kind of second book! The twists at the end of the book left me audibly gasping — Overall, I LOVED this book! 
.
.
I finished this book during our car ride to SC & when I got to our condo, I noticed the “technology improvements” included an electronic front door key pad — It reminded me of the crazy technology that the Elincourts’ installed throughout their entire house — it honestly creeped me out a little & I knew I had to include it in the picture! 😂
.
.

Lock Every Door 🔑 Riley Sager
.
.
Recently jobless, single and broke - Jules, an orphan, fails to see how she will be able to continue living in Manhattan. An ad in the newspaper seeking an apartment sitter brings Jules to the doorstep of one of Manhattans most historic and secretive buildings - The Bartholomew. 
.
After an interview, Jules realizes she’s looking at $12,000 simply to live inside one of the recently vacant apartments until someone buys it. Not to mention it’s the exact same building that is the setting of her all time favorite book “Heart of a Dreamer”. Her best friend tries to tell her anything that seems too good to be true, probably is. But Jules needs the money...bad. Besides, there were only a few strict rules she had to follow & It was only temporary - she’d have enough money to hit the reset button in no time.
.
No nights away from the apartment. No visitors & No bothering the guests who are rich or famous or both. This seems easy enough to Jules who desperately wants to start over. However, the Bartholomew’s shady history & the sudden disappearance of another apartment sitter, Ingrid, leave Jules wondering if she should investigate further or just keep her mouth shut and take the money.
.
All the other residents of the Bartholomew are rich or famous. Why would they agree to allow poor, undignified “nobodies” without much family or friends take up residence there? Even if It is temporary. Unless, that’s the exact profile of a person they are looking for - someone that won’t be missed.
.
Sager did not disappoint again & I really liked the twist this story took! 🚪👻
.

A Burning 🔥 Megha Majumdar 
.
.
“If the police didn’t help ordinary people like you and me, if the police watched them die, doesn’t that mean, that the government is also a terrorist?”
.
.
A train catches fire & hundreds of people perish - it is the act of a terrorist group and the public wants justice. This story follows 3 characters:
.
-JIVAN: a young Muslim girl from the slums of India, just trying to make money to support her parents, is accused of being a terrorist after an unthinking, careless post on Facebook
.
PT SIR: a gym teacher who longs for the power, wealth & recognition that comes with being part of the upper-middle class. After putting his aspirations in a right-wing political party, he realizes he has something to gain if Jivan falls.
.
LOVELY: a wonderful hijra (transgender woman) who’s biggest aspiration is to be an actress on the silver screen but needs money and to learn English, has the alibi to set Jivan free but may lose everything if she speaks.
.
.
This book is POWERFUL, thrilling and heart-breaking. One that makes you rethink your opinions of humanity, ambition, political power and of “doing the right thing.”
