The Last Time I Lied 🤫 Riley Sager
.
.
Let’s play two truths & a lie:
.
ONE: Fifteen years ago Emma awoke in the middle of the night just in time to see 3 of her friends sneaking out of their cabin at Camp Nightingale. This is the last time she or anyone will ever again see Vivian, Natalie & Allison & is the reason the camp closes down.
.
TWO: In the present day, Emma is an on-the-rise artist in Manhattan, famous for her enormous, dark and twisted “forest” paintings. Yet, only she knows that the 3 missing girls are hidden underneath the layers of paint in every piece she’s painted, covered up, unseen, just as the 3 girls vanished so suddenly 15 years ago. She can’t paint anything else. 
.
THREE: Unexpectedly, the owner of Camp Nightingale, Franny, seeks out Emma to invite her back to the grand re-opening of the camp as the painting instructor. Against her better judgement, Emma agrees to return...but only because she wants answers - to uncover the real reason the 3 girls disappeared and get some closure for all the guilt she’s been repressing all these years. To try and shake the feeling that she’s to blame for the whole thing.
.
Wow, I read this book FAST. This is my second experience reading Sager, and I will back up my original feelings - he 👏🏼 knows 👏🏼 his 👏🏼 way 👏🏼 around 👏🏼 plot 👏🏼 twists 👏🏼
.
Thought I had the ending figured out multiple times - nope, my theories were rejected over and over again. But I enjoy that! I love not knowing what’s coming! 😵
.
Sager makes it easy to share in Emma’s increasing paranoia, guilt, mistrust, and desperation as she uncovers dark secrets that were meant to stay buried & a history that may repeat itself...
.
.

To Kill A Mockingbird 🦜 Harper Lee
.
.
The certain passage below hit a little closer to home while re-reading this book. I realize, sometimes, how much I miss the innocence of childhood.
.
.
“Naw, Jem, I think there’s just one kind of folks. Folks.” ... “That’s what I thought, too” he said at last, “ when I was your age. If there’s just one kind of folks, why can’t they get along with each other? If they’re all alike, why do they go out of their way to despise each other? Scout, I think I’m beginning to understand something. I think I understand why Boo Radley’s stayed shut up in the house all this time... it’s because he wants to stay inside”
.
.
Shoot all the blue jays you want, if you can hit ‘me. But remember it’s a sin to kill a mockingbird. 5⭐️
.
.

BALANCING ACT STACK (literally & figuratively!) - inspired by @carly.simone 📚 & a sort of #MeetTheBookstagrammer 
.
.
For many years my life has been a lot about balancing. Studying hard to get good grades so I could get into & then do well in dental school, spending time with family & friends, trying to stay active & get enough sleep ... & for a long time reading for fun just didn’t make the cut
.
.
My profession is a lot about balance too, which is why I love it. Dentistry is a perfect balance between science, engineering & artistry - Letting me learn & diagnose like a medical doctor, but express my creativity and work with my hands in the treatment I provide 🦷
.
.
This year, I made the resolution to bring reading back into my life again. I grew up with my nose always in a book & I just felt like a part of me was missing for a long time. I joined bookstagram not too long ago & feel so lucky to have been so warmly welcomed by this community & for the wonderful new friends I have made! Thank you for being a platform through which I can express my love of books & share it with others who love them just as much! 💛
.
.

Home Before Dark 👻 Riley Sager
.
.
25 years ago Maggie & her parents fled Baneberry Hall after only having moved into the beautiful Victorian mansion 20 days previously. The reason why they left is well-known to the world since Maggie’s father wrote a detailed book describing their terrible and haunting experiences...but is this the true story? 
.
Growing up in “The Book’s” shadow, Maggie thinks her parents are full of sh*t & believes there is a different truth to be uncovered as to why her family fled all those years ago. Having inherited Baneberry Hall after her father’s death, Maggie vows to return and prepare the house to be put on the market (despite a final warning from her father that it’s not safe for her to return). With no memory of her experiences in the house as a child & with a deep-seated desire to know the REAL truth, Maggie returns to Baneberry Hall & soon realizes that her father’s book may be the truth after all. Is there something paranormal associated with this house or is she about to uncover something even more sinister about the past?
.
.
Just when I thought I had the twists and turns figured out, Sager left me completely shocked and impressed. With many audible gasps and open-mouthed revelations, I don’t think I’ve ever read the last 100 pages of a book so fast. 👻
.
4⭐️

The Phantom of the Opera 🥀 Gaston Leroux
.
.
🎶 “Let the dream begin, let your darker side give in, to the power of the music that I write ... the power of the music of the night” 🎶
.
.
Phantom of the Opera 🎭 — I feel something extra special for this story because my parents named me after it! Also, I have been in love with the score from the musical since I can remember. However, I never read the book before this year! Although it was in some ways different than the movie/musical, I still thoroughly enjoyed the story!
.
One thing I really enjoyed about the book was the fact that you learn a lot more about the Phantom, himself. He even has a name! Erik! Never would’ve known unless I read the book 😂
.
While the book started a little slow, I found myself turning through the pages at the end wanting to figure out what was going to happen! This book was a little over-dramatic though lol I found myself rolling my eyes whenever Christine was being just super extra, Raoul sometimes too 😂
.
I enjoy the musical more than the book, but regardless, the Phantom will always hold a special place in my heart & I do not regret reading this French classic! ❤️ 3.5/5 ⭐️
.
P.S.- SWIPE to enjoy a phantom Halloween pic of me from circa 2005 😂🤦🏻‍♀️
.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest 💊 Ken Kesey
.
.
“He knows that you have to laugh at the things that hurt you just to keep yourself in balance, just to keep the world from running you plumb crazy” 💊
.
.
Wow, 5/5 ⭐️ for me - this book was hilarious, disturbing, shocking, heart-breaking — overall, just very powerful. The unforgettable characters, the raw reality of what insane asylums used to be like, and the point of view of the narrator are just a few reasons I loved this book (despite it being banned & highly controversial)
.
.
Yes, this book is old and I mean that in the way it depicts women & people of color. For me, although I don’t enjoy reading degrading and offensive language/themes - I try not to let them ruin a classic story for me, but rather, learn from it. The therapeutic power of laughter, friendships and having someone to believe in really connected me to this book.
.
.
“What do you think you are for Christsake, crazy or somethin? Well you’re not! You’re not! You’re no crazier than the average asshole out walkin around on the streets and that’s it!”
.
.

DYSTOPIAN STACK 👊🏼
.
“𝘼 𝙥𝙤𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙛𝙪𝙡 𝙡𝙚𝙣𝙨, 𝙧𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙬𝙚 𝙣𝙚𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙨𝙚𝙣𝙩, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝙩𝙤 𝙨𝙪𝙧𝙫𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙛𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙬𝙖𝙧𝙙 𝙞𝙛 𝙬𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩”
.
Dystopian fiction is quite possibly my favorite thing to read. The stories don’t leave me feeling happy or satisfied—but that’s why I love them so much, I can’t stop thinking about them! (I know my boyfriend gets annoyed with me because I always  want to discuss them, but I just can’t help it, they fascinate me!) It’s so crazy how their plots can seem so outrageous & impossible, yet I can also rationalize how the world could come to be that way & how some parts of the world are already that way. (Can anyone spot Big Brother watching my stack of books? 😂)
.
Today, where change is essential for the world, books are a perfect source to turn to and educate yourself. There are so many resources at our disposal to continue  to try and understand & learn. I think the quote from Fran Lebowitz applies to the current racial injustice movement perfectly: “𝙏𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙗𝙚𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙨𝙥𝙚𝙖𝙠. 𝙍𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙗𝙚𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠.”
.
.

𝙂𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙚𝙘𝙩𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙨  by Charles Dickens “𝙏𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙡𝙤𝙣𝙜 𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙙 𝙩𝙞𝙢𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙄 𝙠𝙚𝙥𝙩 𝙛𝙖𝙧 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙢𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙧𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙢𝙗𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙘𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙄 𝙝𝙖𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙧𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙖𝙬𝙖𝙮 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙄 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙦𝙪𝙞𝙩𝙚 𝙞𝙜𝙣𝙤𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙞𝙩𝙨 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙩𝙝”
————————————————————
There is a reason why classics are classics & their writers so well known. Dickens & Great Expectations is no exception. The characters in this story are timeless & original, the plot is full of complexity and unexpected turns and the story left me with a lot of different feelings, mostly a hollow sadness as I wished the book had ended differently but at the same time loving the realism of it. 
_____________________________________________
At its core, this book is about someone who is given the chance to have all their dreams come true: to be elevated higher than they ever thought possible, to be taken seriously by those who never gave a second glance before, to be loved by someone of a higher status, and to have the money to spend on anything they desire. To have dreamed about all of these things coming true for so long & once having it, realizing how good he had it before. The lessons to be learned in this book are numerous. ————————————————————
Being so much more than a love story, Great Expectations is about loyalty and forgiveness, it shows the dangers of money and misperceptions & it is a story of self-discovery & letting go. This narrative will have me thinking for a very long time 👏🏼 4.5/5 ⭐️
.
.

BOOK REVIEW: 𝙁𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙠𝙚𝙣𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙞𝙣 by Mary Shelley ⚡️
————————————————————
This book called into question many thoughts and concepts that I find to be very uncomfortable to think about and typically try not to dwell deeply upon. Frankenstein, however, forced me to acknowledge the fine line between scientific discovery and the dangers of “playing God.” It brought into the question the reality of human mortality and the basic human need for companionship & love which is, in a very real sense, like the necessities of hunger, thirst and shelter.
.
I found it particularly interesting to be reading this book at a time where the culture of the world is “accept and love everyone no matter their looks, sexual orientation, skin color, etc.” so my QOTD is this:

𝙄𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙮 𝙤𝙛 𝙁𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙠𝙚𝙣𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙞𝙣 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡 𝙩𝙤𝙙𝙖𝙮, 𝙙𝙤 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙤𝙣𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙧 𝙬𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙢𝙚𝙩 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙖𝙗𝙝𝙤𝙧𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙘𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙖𝙩𝙧𝙚𝙙? 𝙊𝙧 𝙙𝙤 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙’𝙫𝙚 𝙚𝙭𝙥𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙣𝙘𝙚𝙙 𝙖 𝙢𝙪𝙘𝙝 𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧 𝙨𝙞𝙙𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙝𝙪𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙞𝙩𝙮?
————————————————————
Overall, this is a wonderful classic and is nothing like the 1930s monster movie illusion I’ve had all these years. 
4.5/5 ⭐️
.
.

BOOK REVIEW:  𝘼 𝘾𝙡𝙤𝙘𝙠𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙠 𝙊𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚  by Anthony Burgess 4/5 ⭐️ “𝘈𝘯𝘥 𝘺𝘦𝘵, 𝘪𝘯 𝘢 𝘴𝘦𝘯𝘴𝘦, 𝘪𝘯 𝘤𝘩𝘰𝘰𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘦 𝘥𝘦𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘥 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘢𝘣𝘪𝘭𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘵𝘰 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦 𝘢𝘯 𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘭 𝘤𝘩𝘰𝘪𝘤𝘦, 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘢 𝘴𝘦𝘯𝘴𝘦 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘤𝘩𝘰𝘴𝘦𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘨𝘰𝘰𝘥.”
————————————————————
Synopsis: 
In a nightmarish, futuristic England where criminals take over after dark we follow the story of our narrator, Alex and his droogs (friends) while they spend their nights getting high before robbing & beating men and raping women. Nothing seems to be able to touch them, until a home-raid goes terribly wrong & Alex gets caught and sent to prison. In an effort to shorten his sentence, Alex opts for a new experimental treatment that claims to “cure” criminals. However, the controversy over this treatment is that it strips the receiver of choice between the good and the bad. For Alex, returning to society a “cured” man may actually mean becoming a helpless victim himself. ————————————————————
At first, I almost didn’t continue reading this book because it utilizes ’nadsat language’ a kind of Russian slang—I spent the first few chapters frustratingly looking up the meanings to words. But after awhile you start to learn what the words mean, and even come to like it.
————————————————————
I thought this book was going to be another dystopian novel all about violence, and while there is horrifying violence depicted, the book does not glorify violence nor do I think that is what the book is meant to be about. Rather, it explores the question of good & evil and what it means to be human. Is it better to choose to do bad than to be scientifically conditioned to be good, being stripped of having the ability to choose for yourself? ————————————————————
I recommend you find the edition that includes the final chapter. But read the story first as if it didn’t include the final chapter. It is amazing how the outlook of the story changes when you experience both of these different “endings.” Overall, if you’re going to read A Clockwork Orange, pour yourself a glass of wine in advance, O my brothers.
.

BOOK REVIEW: 𝙋𝙧𝙞𝙙𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙋𝙧𝙚𝙟𝙪𝙙𝙞𝙘𝙚  by Jane Austen 🌸⠀
⠀
“𝘝𝘢𝘯𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘥𝘦 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘥𝘪𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴, 𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘥𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘰𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘯 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘥 𝘴𝘺𝘯𝘰𝘯𝘺𝘮𝘰𝘶𝘴𝘭𝘺. 𝘈 𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘴𝘰𝘯 𝘮𝘢𝘺 𝘣𝘦 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘶𝘥 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘣𝘦𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘷𝘢𝘪𝘯. 𝘗𝘳𝘪𝘥𝘦 𝘳𝘦𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘰𝘱𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘰𝘧 𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘴𝘦𝘭𝘷𝘦𝘴, 𝘷𝘢𝘯𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘵𝘰 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘸𝘦 𝘸𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘬 𝘰𝘧 𝘶𝘴.”⠀
————————————————
𝚂𝚢𝚗𝚘𝚙𝚜𝚒𝚜:⠀
⠀
Nothing would make Mrs. Bennett happier than seeing all of her daughters married to wealthy men. At the arrival of Mr. Bingley, a rich bachelor who has just arrived in the neighborhood, the eldest daughter, Jane, makes a fast connection. The second eldest daughter, Elizabeth, has quite the opposite connection with Mr. Bingley’s [even wealthier] friend, Mr. Darcy whom she believes to be vain, haughty and conceited. As the story unfolds, Elizabeth finds that oftentimes, first impressions aren’t what they seem. ⠀
————————————————
This was my first experience reading anything by Jane Austen and I am absolutely enchanted by her. This book highlights how different the prospect of marriage was for women in the late 1700s-early 1800s and the importance of a woman having some wealth to be gained upon being married. Austen depicts well the entitlement of the wealthy and the “right” they felt they had to control the actions of lesser class individuals. There were many times my mouth hung open reading paragraphs of insults written in such elegant prose — Elizabeth always holds her own though, staying fiercely loyal to who she is, yet, humble enough to admit when she has made mistakes. ⠀
————————————————
Overall, this is a 5/5 stars for me! It took me a bit to get into it, but I was flying through the pages by the end. I cannot wait to read more by Austen! ⠀
.⠀
.⠀

✨NEW ANIMAL✨

by Ella Baxter

The June @theshamelessbookclub pick.

Amelia is meeting a lot of men.
 
But once she gets the sex, she wants from them, that’s it for her.
 
A terrible thing happened to that is stuck in her head, and it’s making her stuck too.
 
Being a cosmetician at her family’s mortuary business isn’t the best job for a young woman after all?  It doesn’t help her social life.
 
Amelia isn’t great at emotion either but when something happens to her mum, suddenly she is full of feelings.
 
Intertwined with a BDSM club, two fathers and some other broken people!
 
A short but sassy novel that gives a very unique (and amazingly uncomfortable) look at how grief can possess and affect a human, and society.  I say amazingly uncomfortable as a good thing.  Because grief is uncomfortable.

Amelia was a brutally honest and confident character and I liked how 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹 portrayed a non-typical family, from being in the business of death, to the throuple.  Very fun to read.

I met @mouthcake at the official launch of 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹 and I’ve been waiting for the right time to dive into this novel.  Hearing Ella speak really added another layer to the story and I felt I appreciated everything that little bit more? I think if I had read this without listening to the author, I wouldn’t feel the same about the subject, the characters and the entire storyline.

Not something I would usually pick up but so glad that I did!

✨SHELTER✨

by Catherine Jinks

There is a reason Meg lives alone, in a little place outside of town. 

There is a reason she offers shelter to Nerine and her daughters, on the run from a violent husband.

But things start happening, objects are disturbed and there’s strange noises in the night.

Has Nerine’s ex tracked her down?

Or has Meg’s husband come back to torment her some more?
 
This one comes with a shed load of trigger warnings from domestic abuse, child abuse, and animal abuse.

𝗦𝗵𝗲𝗹𝘁𝗲𝗿 is a hard novel to review without giving away too much information but let’s see how we go!

What I liked: 𝗦𝗵𝗲𝗹𝘁𝗲𝗿 not only focusses on physical domestic abuse but highlight emotional and mental abuse as well.  Meg’s abuse was never physical and the contrast between what she suffered/still suffers through was evident.

I also really enjoyed the middle of nowhere setting and the goosebumps while reading about the strange noises and ongoings.

What I didn’t like: I’m sorry but Nerine annoyed the f*ck out of me. I understand that as a victim she was neurotic/paranoid/altogether jumpy but there was NO development from that characteristic at all?

The twist seemed a little unrealistic also.

Overall, I’m glad that I read this book. It was what I needed during a lockdown and a week of crappy Melbourne weather! If you’re looking for a quick thriller read that has a great setting, check this one out!

Thank you to @text_publishing for my review copy.

It’s been a hot minute since I’ve shared a #lastnownext and that’s mostly because I tend to have a last, now, now, now, next, next, next situ going on 🤦🏻‍♀️

𝙇𝘼𝙎𝙏 - book I read was 𝗦𝗵𝗲𝗹𝘁𝗲𝗿, an Aussie outback thriller that highlights the differing an ongoing forms of domestic abuse faced to victims.

𝙉𝙊𝙒 - I am reading 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝗿𝘀𝗮𝘄 𝗢𝗿𝗽𝗵𝗮𝗻 which is an incredible emotional and compelling WW2 story that focusses on the children of war.

𝙉𝙀𝙓𝙏 - I am going to read 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹, which I’m really looking forward to because I don’t think it’ll be like anything I’ve read before. 

I’ve tagged some friends to join in! I love seeing what everyone is reading 💕

✨THE BEAUTIFUL FALL✨

by Hugh Breakey

Every 179 days Robbie forgets everything.

To survive the forgetting, and the overwhelming fear and disorientation, Robbie lives a lonely and regimented life.

Twelve days before his next forgetting, Julie invades his life – the only women he can remember meeting.

Robbie is forced to confront the face that his past is very different from how he imagined it, and how to come to terms with it.
 
There are elements of this book that are very repetitive – but this is about book about someone with memory loss, so I guess that’s to be expected.

Robert is quite an intense character, and in all honesty, I’m not 100% sure that I found him all that likeable..? There’s the obvious “oh I really feel for this guy because I can’t even imagine what this must feel like” but also he’s annoying?  

I can appreciate his annoying qualities though, because he does have to reset his life every six months. And it’s refreshing to read a main character that I don’t like.

I found Julie one dimensional and shady. Which is a shame because you want a love story that you wanna root for right?

Absolutely loved the premise of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗲𝗮𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗙𝗮𝗹𝗹, its’ different from anything I’ve read in a long time and I encourage you to check it out.
 
Thank you to @text_publishing for my #gifted copy

✨SORROW AND BLISS✨

by Meg Mason

Martha knows that there is something wrong with her, but she just doesn’t know what it is. 

Martha told her husband Patrick, before they got married, that she didn’t want to have children.

Patrick told Martha that he didn’t care because he’d do anything to make her happy.

Though nothing seems to work.

By the time Martha finds out what is wrong, it doesn’t really matter anymore. It is too late to get the only thing she has ever wanted. 

Or maybe it will turn out that you can stop loving someone and start again from nothing if you can find something else to want.

This book is incredible.

I put off reading it for so long because of the hype surrounding it and you know what? For once, the hype was legit.

𝗦𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗕𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘀 is both complex and simple.

It is about being sad. It is about relationships. Sisterhood, parenthood, friendships and everything that comes between.

This novel covers (very accurately IMO) mental illness and the stigma that surrounds it.  How mental illness can seep into our lives with no explanation and how it affects everyone around us.

It is also about happiness and finding those moments within ourselves and our surroundings. Our people and our places.

I’ve struggled to describe the writing of this book but the best I can come up is: disjointed but lyrical.  Kind of like Martha is just having a conversation with you.

And while Martha makes for a fabulous protagonist, the supporting characters (I’m looking at you Ingrid) are just as wonderful.

I’ve had some amazing discussions about this novel and I have a feeling this one will stay with me x

New releases are very exciting right? Those beautiful new editions gracing our shelves! But there’s also the pressure.

The pressure to jump on bandwagons and own the book as well. To read it before the masses and to share your review.

I’m guilty of this. And neglecting my back list titles. For passing up something that was released years ago, for something that was released last month.

I was looking at my shelves over the weekend and I really do have A LOT of titles that have been sitting there for WAY. TOO. LONG.

So I’m giving myself a little challenge. I’m affectionately calling it #fernsbookshelfbinge

All of these have been selected at random and I’m challenging myself to read every single one before my birthday (October).

A challenge like this is exciting because it’s such a wide range of genres and I do love exploring back list titles 🤩 

If you have any of these books and would like to #buddyread them with me, please let me know 👇🏻

✨EVIDENCE OF THE AFFAIR✨

by Taylor Jenkins Reid

The correspondence between Carrie Allsop and David Mayer reveals, piece by piece, the painful details of a devastating affair between their spouses. With each commiserating scratch of the pen, they confess their fears and bare their souls. They share the bewilderment over how things went so wrong and come to wonder where to go from here.

Written entirely in letter format between Carrie and David, as well as their spouses, the details of the affair are brought to light and the bond between the two heartbroken characters grows.

“𝙄𝙩 𝙞𝙨 𝙛𝙪𝙣𝙣𝙮 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙧𝙖𝙯𝙮 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙗𝙧𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙨 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝙪𝙥 𝙩𝙤 𝙨𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙪𝙨 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙩𝙝.“

At less than 100 pages, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝘃𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗳𝗳𝗮𝗶𝗿 explores what happens when our hearts break, and how freeing it can be. 

I’m not the biggest fan of TJR’s 𝗗𝗮𝗶𝘀𝘆 𝗝𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘀 or 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗹𝘆𝗻 𝗛𝘂𝗴𝗼 but this was a beautiful short story and I’m keen to scout out more of her earlier work!

✨THE SILENT PATIENT✨

by Alex Michaelides

Alicia Berenson writes in her diary as a release, an outlet – and to prove to her beloved husband that everything is fine.  She can’t bear the thought of worrying Gabriel or causing him pain.

Until, late one evening, Alicia shoots Gabriel five times and then never speaks another word.

Theo Faber is a forensic psychotherapist, and he is convinced he can successfully treat Alicia.  Theo becomes obsessed with investigating her crime but if she speaks, would he want to hear the truth?
 
The novel starts with this quote from Sigmund Freud.

“𝙃𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙨 𝙚𝙮𝙚𝙨 𝙩𝙤 𝙨𝙚𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙨 𝙩𝙤 𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙧 𝙢𝙖𝙮 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙚 𝙝𝙞𝙢𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙣𝙤 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙩𝙖𝙡 𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙠𝙚𝙚𝙥 𝙖 𝙨𝙚𝙘𝙧𝙚𝙩. 𝙄𝙛 𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙥𝙨 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙨𝙞𝙡𝙚𝙣𝙩, 𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙨 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙛𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙧𝙩𝙞𝙥𝙨; 𝙗𝙚𝙩𝙧𝙖𝙮𝙖𝙡 𝙤𝙤𝙯𝙚𝙨 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙝𝙞𝙢 𝙖𝙩 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙚.”
 
As we continue, there are many references to Freud and his theories as well as to Ancient Greek notables.
 
I think 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗶𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁 was just what I needed for a lockdown read and the short chapters held my attention enough to keep my engaged.

Was this novel fast paced? Yes.  
Was it also too rushed and untidy? I think so.

I didn’t like a single character; they were all one dimensional and honestly a bit bland.  Background of some characters could have been explored further to make for more compelling suspects and I would’ve liked more urgency and thrill from Alicia’s diary entries in the lead up to the crime and I think the entries themselves were written poorly.

I will admit, the twist got me good BUT the ending was soooo disappointing!!

I appreciate that Michaelides is a screen writer and that impacts his writing style, so can easily see this as an adaptation.

Two very much enjoyed novels that in typical fashion, I’m late to the party on.

I attended the book launch of 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹 back in March and I’ve been meaning to get to since then, it’s this month’s @theshamelessbookclub pick so what better excuse? 

𝗦𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗕𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘀 is one that I’ve put off because of the hype but I’m diving into it today in the hopes of those expectations being met!

Let me know 👇🏻 if you’ve read either of these - I’d love to chat!

✨THE NOTEBOOK✨

by Nicholas Sparks

There are few in this corner of the internet that have not read or watched 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸.

I was offered the opportunity to participate in the @tandemcollectiveglobal 25th Anniversary Celebration of this much-loved love story (there was a bit of mailing disaster and my copy arrived a lot later than everyone else’s) and it’s really made me think about film adaptations and why stories like this are so admired.

I remember the first time I watched 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸.  There were tears, a lot of tears.  In fact, in all honesty, I cry every time I watch the film.

I read the novel at high school, as well as numerous other Sparks novels and I’ve also watched nearly every film that has been adapted from his novels.

I think people cling to these novels because they give you a ride on an emotional roller coaster – they really make you feel all the feelings!

I’ll be honest, there are novels that are written much better, but Spark’s novels have become “modern” romance classics and I think will continue to be loved and enjoyed by many.

#whatfernreads presents 𝗔 𝗠𝗜𝗡𝗜 𝗥𝗘𝗩𝗜𝗘𝗪
 
✨A MAN CALLED OVE✨
 
by Fredrik Backman
 
Ove is the grumpiest man you will ever meet.

He thinks himself surrounded by idiots.

Is this rare? To find someone with such an old-fashioned clarity of belief and deed?  A lifelong dedication to making the world just so?
 
Ove reminds me of grandparents.  Not that my grandparents are or were particularly grumpy.  But they always seem to know…everything don’t they?

Ove made me laugh.

Ove made me cry.

I wasn’t really sure what to expect going into this one but 𝗔 𝗠𝗮𝗻 𝗖𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗱 𝗢𝘃𝗲 made for a surprising read and while slow paced, was full of hidden gems!
 
I will be checking out @backmansk backlist now!

𝗠𝗔𝗬 𝗪𝗥𝗔𝗣 𝗨𝗣 |

In May, I lost my reading mojo 🤷🏻‍♀️ and that’s totally okay. Some months are better than others and I was coming home from work mentally drained and exhausted and just couldn’t concentrate on more than 5 pages at a time. 

Things picked up a little towards the end of May and I’m grateful for my #audiobook reads!

Here’s what I read in the month of May:

•𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗼𝗰𝗸𝘄𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗼𝗿 📖

•𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝘂𝗹𝗶𝗽 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗲 📖

•𝗩𝗼𝘆𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗿 🎧

•𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗬𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗮𝗵 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗼𝗻 📖

•𝗔 𝗠𝗮𝗻 𝗖𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗱 𝗢𝘃𝗲 📖

•𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 📖

•𝗨𝗻𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗵𝗼𝗱𝗼𝘅 🎧 

Thank you to the tagged publishers and authors for the generously #gifted copies that made this month’s wrap up! I can’t wait for what June has installed ✨

✨THE DRESSMAKERS OF YARRANDARRAH PRISON✨

by Meredith Jaffé

Five years into a seven year prison sentence, Derek finds out that his daughter Debbie is getting married. Thanks to his ex-wife, Derek hasn’t spoken to Debbie since he was sent down.

He wants to make a grand gesture to show his daughter how much he cares and inspiration strikes during his weekly sewing circle. 🧵 

He’s going to make Debbie a wedding dress!

But as time runs out to make the dress with his motley gang of crims, the dress begins to take on greater significance, and Derek’s chance to reconcile with Debbie is getting slimmer and slimmer.

What a wholesome and enjoyable read! As an avid embroider and someone who grew up watching my seamstress grandmothers, I loved reading about the sewing techniques and found myself rooting for the men to finish their special project!

As the blurb suggests 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗬𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗮𝗵 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗼𝗻 ends up being about more than just Derek, Debbie and a wedding dress. It’s also about the fight for reading, education and highlights prison rehabilitation.

If you strip away a layer and look deeper, this novel showcases some incredible themes and I think this novel would make an excellent bookclub pick!

A huge thank you to @meredithjaffeauthor and @harpercollinsaustralia for this #gifted copy!

✨VOYAGER✨

by Diana Gabaldon 

The third instalment of the hugely popular 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 series picks right where the last novel left us.

There are significant differences in 𝗩𝗼𝘆𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗿 compared to the previous two novels however, and that is we get to see more of Jamie’s perspective and not just that of Claire.  

But it’s not just Jamie’s narrative we are introduced to, but Roger, Briana and Lord John Grey as well. Now I know that it seems like a lot of character’s points of views to keep track of but Gabaldon does a good job of making sure that they are not individual and in fact all line up together.  This really enriched the story and broke up the story (as it is a chunky one) and I liked hearing from Jamie and what he went through during and after the war.

𝗩𝗼𝘆𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗿 also takes us to a number of new locations including Boston and the West Indies but our Scottish hero is still at the heart of these stories.

I know a lot of people (I’m looking 👀 at you @the.nook.of.books stopped with the series after this book but I’m soldiering on with the next.

I should also share a disclaimer that I have watched the TV series, more than once 😏 (and if Josh asks it’s 100% for the story….) so nothing in the novels has come as a great shock or twist to me.  I felt the need to point this out as I have been asked how I have found the books compared to the show.

✨OUR WOMEN ON THE GROUND✨

This is the first collection of essays I have read and reviewed (and now I want all the recs for more please and thank you) but when I saw that it was the May pick for @booketybookbooks I knew it would be something special.

International media coverage of the Arab world is dominated by the work of Western correspondents however, in this collection 19 women share what it is really like to report on these issues.
𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 starts with a powerful introduction that carries the tone throughout this collection.

Entwining humour, sorrow and harsh reality this collection of essays from female Arab journalists evoked many thoughts and feelings for me.  Having studied journalism, I was naturally intrigued by their careers and how they came to be “on the ground”, but more so it was the blunt and heartbreaking realisation of taking a sit back and a deep breath after each essay to reflect on what I had just read.

These women and their families show immense bravery and humility in what they do.

I would suggest that this collection be essential reading for all.

✨THE TULIP TREE✨

by Suzanne McCourt

Blurb from the publisher:
 
Brothers Henryk and Adam Radecki’s relationship is one of fraught love and jealously. 

Henryk, unhappily married, becomes a rich and successful industrialist, while Adi, a devoted vet, finds and loses love. 

Their bond is tested throughout their lives, from the 1920s, against the background of Poland’s tragic and tumultuous relationship with Russia, through war, revolution and invasion, until 1954 in the Snowy Mountains of  Australia.

Adi’s wife and son are at the heart of this riveting tale, in which family secrets threaten to tear lives apart. Caught up in momentous events, each character reminds us of our power to survive extraordinary times, of the moral choices we make and the dramatic turns our lives can take.
 
When this novel arrived in the post, I was so excited.  It looked like everything I love in a historical fiction story, a multi-generational family saga that was set in a time I’ve not read a lot about that has a strong focus on the female characters and their lives.

While there were some elements that I enjoyed, such as the female aspect of this story and the focus on Adi’s wife and son, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝘂𝗹𝗶𝗽 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗲 fell short for me.

This is a time in history that I do not know a lot about, and having studied some of The Russian Revolution and the affect it had on surrounding countries, I was looking forward to learning more.  Unfortunately it felt disjointed and I didn’t know if something was happening in the past or the present as it chopped and changed quite regularly throughout.

I think if you’re looking for a unique look at a time in history, then this one is well worth exploring though! It’s not your typical war time historical fiction and has elements of a great story!
 
Thank you to @text_publishing for the #gifted advanced copy and to @eazyreads for putting up with my atrocious #buddyread habits.

✨DRAGONFLY IN AMBER✨

by Diana Gabaldon

The second novel in the 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 series tells the story of Claire and Jamie Fraser as they try to stop history from happening.

Having escaped from sadistic Black Jack Randal, Claire and Jamie are now living a life of luxury in Pairs - for the purpose of stopping Charles Stuart’s fatal rebellion, will they succeed or will the Battle of Culloden ruin Highland life once and for all?

𝗗𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗼𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘆 𝗶𝗻 𝗔𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿 introduces us to a cast of new characters (there’s always a lot to remember in series like this) who will become apart of Claire and Jamie’s lives forever. 

One thing I have to highlight in listening to the #audiobooks is that Davina Porter does an incredible job of portraying the different accents of our Scottish and English characters. As I’ve said before though, the narrative would be richer if there were different voices for each character.

There’s a LOT of built up in this novel, I mean it’s nearly 39 hours and over 700 pages of content. There’s flashbacks and flash forwards, new characters and places to be described. It’s probably one of my favourite things about this series, the intense and engrossing descriptions.

I felt that the last third of the novel really picked up the pace and moved too fast for me, considering all the lead up to the events. 

Stay tuned for book 3, where we discover the fates of our hero and heroine!

I’ve been in such a weird reading mood lately, and by the time I get home after a big day at work I just have no motivation to pick up my books! 

With the cooler days this weekend though I’m planning on staying in and catching up on some pages and thought I’d share what I’m #currentlyreading 👇🏻

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝘂𝗹𝗶𝗽 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗲 is a #gifted advanced copy ( thanks to @text_publishing ) of a new historical fiction hitting shelves this year and I’m #buddyreading with @eazyreads so far I’m finding it really interesting and am liking the unique perspective of this novel.

𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 is @booketybookbooks May #bookclub pick. Because it’s a collection of essays, I’ve been able to dip in and out of this one easily and can already tell that it’s going to be a favourite this year.

𝗩𝗼𝘆𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗿 is the third book in the 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 series - I’m making my way through these on #audiobook and I’m really starting to feel the need to escape to the Scottish Highlands!

Hoping with three great reads on the go I will get my reading mojo back 🤞🏻 

Also wanted to shout out @twogirlsonebookshelf and their stunning new bookmark range! These make great gifts and I just had to have my handle on mine 💕

#meetmeinmemes

I just HAD to jump on board this fun wee game, I’ve been in fits of giggles while going through so many 😂

I got Josh to pick the majority of these out - a task he took great delight in and I’m now here to share my memes with you all.

Enjoy 💕

✨UNORTHODOX: THE SCANDALOUS REJECTION OF MY HASIDIC ROOTS✨
 
by Deborah Feldman
 
Synopsis from @goodreads 

As a member of the strictly religious Satmar sect of Hasidic Judaism, Deborah Feldman grew up under of code of relentlessly enforced customs governing everything from what she could wear and to whom she could speak, to what she was allowed to read.  It was stolen moments spent with the empowered literary characters of Jane Austen and Louisa May Alcott that helped her to imagine an alternative way of life.

Trapped as a teenager in a sexually and emotionally arranged marriage, the tension between Deborah’s desires and her responsibilities as a good Satmar girl grew more explosive until she gave birth at nineteen and realised that, for the sake of herself and her son, she had to escape.

Having binge watched Unorthodox during lockdown last year, I was very eager to read Feldman’s memoir and listening via #audiobook added something else to the experience.

I was fascinated listening to Feldman’s childhood spent controlled and governed by strict religious rules.  What really stood out to me what the obvious difference between what females and males in the Satmar community were allowed to do.

That Feldman began her secret blog as a Hasidic feminist speaks volumes for itself.

I am always interested in memoirs such as these, that the contents only occurred ten years ago will surprise readers (apart from the occasional mention of Hillary Duff and the Backstreet Boys) because it could have been happening 40 or 50 years ago as well.

✨THE ANIMALS OF LOCKWOOD MANOR✨

by Jane Healy

The April #hfbookclub hosted by @r4ch4elreads I have been waiting for my copy to arrive in my container of good from New Zealand, so this review is well overdue!

Hetty Cartwright arrives at Lockwood Manor in charge of a special collection of museum artefacts that have been transported from London for their safety during the war.

Determined to prove her position at the museum is more than just a fluke due to the male staff being called up, Hetty takes great pride in looking after the animals in their new home.

Befriending the daughter of Lord Lockwood, unusual but kind Lucy Lockwood, Hetty starts to feel something isn’t quite right at Lockwood Manor and items start to go missing and things seem to come alive, she wonders if the gossip of ghosts is real.

I wanted so much to love 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗼𝗰𝗸𝘄𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗼𝗿 but I just wasn’t gripped by it. 

There are definitely elements that I enjoyed, the manor is its own character and really added that ghostly feel to the novel. I was interested in the animals and the museum processes.

And that cover 😍 just stunning!

This was a decent read and while this isn’t the must gushy review you’ll see from me, I would still pick it up if you’re interested in a book with gothic and ghostly elements.

✨GIRL, 11✨

Happy ANZ Pub Day @asuiterclarke 🥳

Elle Castillo is a former social worker turned true-crime podcaster who, after four seasons of successful investigations, decides to tackle a decades-old serial killer cold case.

The Countdown Killer established a pattern of taking and ritualistically murdering girls, each a year younger than the last. 

Elle receives a tip from a listener, she discovers his dead body and a child is abducted days later, and Elle is convinced TCK is back.

Will she be able to get law enforcement on her side before it’s too late?

Firstly, I LOVED the podcast narrative - such a unique aspect in this crime thriller!!

𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹, 𝟭𝟭 often felt like I was reading nonfiction, it was that gripping and it really felt like TCK and the crimes were real - is it awful to say I loved the detail the author gave?!

I also really liked how little nuggets of information were slowly drip feed into the story, so you aren’t overloaded all and once.

This novel really focuses on our natural obsession with true crime podcasts and shows (guilty 🙋🏻‍♀️) and how obsession can lead to dangerous paths.

I was genuinely gripped, it was full of psychological tension and I would recommend this brand new (debut!) thriller!

Big thanks to @text_publishing for an advanced copy!

𝗔𝗣𝗥𝗜𝗟 𝗪𝗥𝗔𝗣 𝗨𝗣 |

Overall v happy with my reading for this month and v excited for what May has in store!

✨THINGS IN JARS✨

by Jess Kidd

@thebookcovetersbookclub pick for April.

Bridie Devine is the finest female detective of her age. In order to save a stolen child, Bridie must enter the dark world of medical curiosities. The public love a spectacle and this child may well prove the most remarkable spectacle London has ever seen.

What a weird book.

That’s genuinely what I repeated to myself over and over again while I was reading it. In all honestly, this was nearly a DNF for me purely because I didn’t feel smart enough to understand what the heck was going on.

Neither the less, I persisted!

𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗝𝗮𝗿𝘀 gave me slight Rebecca vibes in some chapters, creeping in and settling as I went.

I don’t have much else to say in all honesty other than I would describe it as a real piece of gothic and ghostly fiction (which I usually enough) but I think it wasn’t was I was expecting.

I have become a BIG fan of retellings.

Classical retellings.

Well known stories told from the female perspective.

Hearing the stories of the losers of war.

I’m all for it!

I loved @nataliehaynesauthor 𝗔 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗦𝗵𝗶𝗽𝘀 so was very excited to find a copy of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗿𝗲𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝗝𝗼𝗰𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗮 which tells the stories of Oedipus and Antigone from the perspective of two women often overlooked.

I’ve also seen a lot of reviews popping up since the small paperback release of last year’s 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 by @suemonkkidd  which tells us the story of Ana, wife of Jesus and is set in the first century.

I’m genuinely looking forward to reading both of these! Have you read either?

✨THE LOST MAN✨

by Jane Harper 

TW: Domestic violence | sexual assault

Set in the brutal outback of Queensland, a man is found dead. Something had been troubling him, did he walk to his death? His two brothers are left to deal with the aftermath and are confronted with a lifetime of secrets.

While I thought the first 100 or so pages were slow, I would describe this as a medium paced crime novel.

Harper provides you with a bounty of characters and just enough background information on each to leave you questioning who the suspects are. 

One of the aspects that I really appreciated was the emphasis and spotlight on men’s (especially rural men’s) mental health, which is something that’s very prominent in New Zealand rural communities and I’m sure it’s just as important of a topic in Australia.

The setting in this novel is a character in itself and I think adds an interesting element to the story.

I was disappointed that it just...ended (?) as I would’ve liked a little bit more of an ending if that makes sense?

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗠𝗮𝗻 is not as strong (IMO) as her previous novels that I’ve read but that didn’t make it any less enjoyable for me and it was a great novel to finish off during a rainy weekend.

✨LAST NIGHT✨

by Mhairi McFarlane

OUT NOW ⭐️

Eve and Ed are best friends. 
Eve is in love with Ed.
Ed is in love with...someone else.
And no one knows Eve’s secret.

Until, one night, their lives are blown apart and all the secrets start to tumble out...

Okay, I’ll be the first to admit that I generally steer clear of this genre and in the first handful of chapters I did feel that it was disjointed and there was a lot going on...but, and without giving too much away, the blow that brings this book to life happens.

I really appreciated Eve’s inner-monologue, the mismatched and rambles sentences remind of how my mind thinks sometimes!!

This book is not a typical romance and I personally think it really hammers home the importance of friendships.

It’s hard to review without spoiling so I’ll leave you with this: you will be rushing to give your nearest and dearest a huge hug afterwards.

Thank you to @harpercollinsaustralia for my #gifted advance reading copy.

𝗕𝗢𝗢𝗞𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗟

I am slowly and steadily building up my library in our new home and am loving sorting my shelves!! 🥰

It’s all made so much better with #bookmail deliveries and I’m super excited to each and every book in this stack.

A solid collection of #historicalfiction (my fav) as well as exciting new and recent releases - thanks to all the tagged publishers and authors for the #gifted books!

I’ve also ordered a couple of these just because I’ve had them on my Wishlist for so long or for bookclub reads, looking at you @thebookcovetersbookclub 

Let me know if you’ve read any of these, have them on you #tbr or a keen for a #buddyread 💕

✨OUTLANDER✨

by Diana Gabaldon

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

🎧 Audiobook read and genuine question...how on earth do you make pictures of audiobooks look good?! Pls send help.

Anyway, on with my #review!

I will start with a disclaimer that I am already very much in love with James Alexander Malcolm Mackenzie Fraser and the way he says the word sassenach so this could very well be the biased review we’ve all seen coming...

The first in the now world famous series, thanks to @outlander_starz 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 follows our badass, swearing protagonist Claire Randall, a WW11 combat nurse as she finds herself transported to the 18th Century Scottish Highlands whilst on her second honeymoon with historian husband Frank.

Relying on her brains, medical experience and knowledge of the future, Claire navigates her way a handful of near miss murder and sexual assault attempts and the realisation that she won’t be returning to 1947 any time soon.

Accompanying her throughout is the aforementioned Jamie Fraser/McTavish/Red Jamie, who has his own fair share of near miss dramas following him as he tried to stay out of the hand of sadistic red coat, Black Jack Randall. Who just so happens to be Frank’s (yes, Claire’s Frank) six times great grandfather.

I have ummed and ahhed about diving into reading this series since the show was first released and I’m very glad I decided on the audiobooks. They are very easy to dip in and out of, plus as is always the case, there’s a lot of details that are missed out in the show which I’ve personally found great to now know. 

My only wish would be that it was narrated using both male and female voices to really get that Scottish accent through but asking @samheughan to narrate the books might be asking too much, ya ken?

Also, listening while at work when..ahem..thooooose scenes come on? 😳

✨A WOMAN IS NO MAN✨

by Etaf Rum

3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️

TW: Domestic Abuse | Assault

#litchatsbookclub read along with @bookish_nish 

In the winter of 2008, eighteen-year-old Deya is forced to meet with potential husbands at her grandmother, Fareeda’s, insistence. Deya’s only desire is to go to college and live a life different to that of her mother, Isra. 

Forced into a marriage at the same age, Isra leaves her family in Palestine for her new life in America. Full of fresh hope that the land of the free will provide, Isra struggles with her oppressive mother-in-law and strange husband, Adam.

Deya soon discovers the shocking truth of her family and struggles with the looming decisions she has to make.

“𝙇𝙚𝙩 𝙢𝙚 𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙡 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜. 𝘼 𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙤𝙣𝙡𝙮 𝙬𝙖𝙮 𝙪𝙥 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙, 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙝𝙚’𝙡𝙡 𝙘𝙡𝙞𝙢𝙗 𝙖 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣’𝙨 𝙗𝙖𝙘𝙠 𝙩𝙤 𝙜𝙚𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚.“

𝗔 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗡𝗼 𝗠𝗮𝗻 explores how the ‘prison’ of domesticity is nearly impossible to escape for Arab women and focuses on what a woman’s life is worth. Daughter. Wife. Mother.

It’s very sad to read and honestly made me incredibly angry, the grandmother did my head in for a number of reasons - mostly because she was treating her daughter-in-laws AND daughter in the same horrible way that she had been treated. No attempt to do better than what she had was ever made. If she had to suffer, then so did they.

I would recommend reading @caglareads review of this novel, it’s stuck with me ever since I read it and gave me a whole other view of this story. 

I obviously can’t comment on how close to the truth this novel takes, or bends in order to build the narrative but I’m intrigued to read more about the life of Arab women and there lives, and for me the best thing a book can do is make me think and want to know more.

Yesterday, after being heartbroken by believing that it had closed for the season, I discovered the @melbournebookmarket at @vicmarket 

Day made. 

Day not so made when I promised myself (and Josh 😒) that I would only get two books.

Decided on these two, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗿𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗛𝗼𝗿𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗹𝘂𝗲 𝗙𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆 and 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝘀 𝗔𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻.

If you haven’t already, check this market out - there is an incredible selection of books, some new releases and hard to find classics!

Let me know if you’ve read either of these 👇🏻 

I also found myself some slippers, which I was in desperate need of. We Southlanders decided we are quite at home in Melbourne when a cold front blasts through ❄️

✨IT’S BEEN A PLEASURE, NONI BLAKE✨

by Claire Christian

5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Struggling to move on from the end of her long-term relationship, 36 year old Noni Blake starts a list. A pleasure list. A zero-fucks-given list. Her search for pleasure takes her to the other side of the world, where she does find pleasure - in everything.

Okay, please excuse me while gush about this book! It’s been dominating my feed currently and it’s no wonder why 😍 This was a made me laugh, made cry, feel it in my soul kinda story. I’d heard SO many good things about 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗕𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗮 𝗣𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲, 𝗡𝗼𝗻𝗶 𝗕𝗹𝗮𝗸𝗲 that the hype was almost off-putting but I am so so glad that @ashleighslibrary picked this for #booksquad pick of the month.

Such a joyful, honest, endearing read! It’s fun, it’s sad, it’s real. It was like reading about every post break up cycle I’ve even been through... I’ll never think about school principals or Vikings the same 🙊

Genuinely one of my all time favourite reads. I am not all surprised by the love this book has received. It was an absolute pleasure!

𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗥𝗘𝗡𝗧 𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗𝗦

I’m back at it with multiple books on the go and you know what? I love it!

Love that I can dip in and out and it holds me accountable during buddy reads so I don’t fly ahead and ruin it for everyone else 🙊

So what am I #currentlyreading 📚

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗠𝗮𝗻 @janeharperauthor is a auto-buy author for me now and while less than 100 pages in, I’m already very interested in what’s going on in the outback!

𝗔 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗡𝗼 𝗠𝗮𝗻 is a #buddyread with @bookish_nish (are you joining us?!) and I’m a sucker for interwoven generational stories, this has a huge focus on race and religion so I’m looking forward to seeing where it goes.

And you will have seen from my stories that I’m participating in the @tandemcollectiveglobal read along of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗥𝗲𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗼𝗻 and how excited I am!! This is one that it hard to put down and only read to the set pages!

Three reads I’m all genuinely excited to pick up and read, dip in and out of and see what happens!

𝗢𝗡𝗘 𝗬𝗘𝗔𝗥 𝗢𝗙 𝗕𝗢𝗢𝗞𝗦𝗧𝗔𝗚𝗥𝗔𝗠

A year ago, I was in lockdown in New Zealand with Josh and his mum. We’d been away for the weekend and ended up getting “stuck” in Central Otago.

We were suppose to be moving to Melbourne the following week and I’d finished up at my job. I was unemployed, heartbroken and had one book with me. 

I made my way through Josh’s mum’s bookcase and had been thinking of creating a #bookstagram for a while.

Fast forward through a very rough year, of uncertainty and what-ifs and here we are. We’re been living our dream in our new home across the ditch. I’ve made the most amazing connections through this little corner of the internet, read some absolutely incredible books, picked up genres I would’ve never tried without your recommendations and am so so glad for taking a risk and creating this page.

Thank you to each and everyone of you who follow me, message me and read my reviews. It means the world ❤️

𝗟𝗢𝗡𝗚 𝗪𝗘𝗘𝗞𝗘𝗡𝗗 𝗣𝗟𝗔𝗡𝗦

This long weekend snuck up on us (literally didn’t realise it was Easter this weekend until Monday...) and so we haven’t made a lot of plans.

What we are doing though is making the most of the sunshine ☀️ and heading to a couple of @melbcomedyfestival gigs in the city! 

Of course reading is high on my list over the weekend and I’ve started both of these (and loving!) great reads. 

Stay safe and have a great weekend friends x

𝗠𝗔𝗥𝗖𝗛 𝗪𝗥𝗔𝗣 𝗨𝗣

Did we share any of the same reads this month? Let me know 👇🏻

A good wee few of my March reads were #gifted so thank you to the tagged publishers 💕

✨LITERARY LION TAMERS✨

by Craig Munro

An insightful #nonfiction from Craig Munro about his own career in publishing but also renowned Australian publishers.  There’s a mix of history, biography and literary detective work in this book that spans from the 1890’s to the 1990’s.
 
This was so interesting and I loved learning more about this industry and its history.  I would recommend to anyone interested in the world of editing and publishing to take a look at this one!
 
Thank you to @scribepub for my #gifted copy.

✨BLACKBERRY AND WILD ROSE✨

by Sonia Velton

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Part of the March #hfbookclub

You know when you just need a book that is sooo immersive and intriguing that you forget where you are for a moment?

𝗕𝗹𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗯𝗲𝗿𝗿𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗪𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝗥𝗼𝘀𝗲 was that book for me.

I picked it up just at the right time and it was one I genuinely couldn’t wait to get home and read!

I love this genre, I love learning about history. I loved learning about the silk weavers and this era - as someone who embroiders, it’s a very interesting topic for me

This novel (based on true events) is well paced, changing between Sara and Esther’s points of view which adds a very completing element, as the reader gets to see how both women are experiencing or reactions to their situation.

Just the kind of historical fiction that I love and I honestly can’t say much else more other than I really enjoyed it! #ipreview via @preview.app

✨THE FOUNDLING✨

by Stacey Halls

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

March @thebookcovetersbookclub pick

Georgian London. Six years after leaving her illegitimate daughter, Clara, at London’s Foundling Hospital, Bess Bright returns to reclaim the child she has never known.

Dreading the worst, that Clara has died in care, she is astonished when she is told she has already claimed her.

Her life is turned upside down as she tried to find out who has taken her little girl - and why...

Stacey Hall’s writing style is sooo good and very easy to read, despite the period she sets her stories in. I love how mesmerising and easy to get lost they are.

I would say 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 is essentially about motherhood and what lengths mothers go to for their children, to love them, keep them and protect them. It explores whether money or love is most crucial when raising a child.

Really enjoyable read with a touch of suspense and guess work!

𝗕𝗨𝗗𝗗𝗬 𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗 𝗔𝗡𝗡𝗢𝗨𝗡𝗖𝗘𝗠𝗘𝗡𝗧

@bookish_nish and I are thrilled to announce that we will be buddy reading 𝗔 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗡𝗼 𝗠𝗮𝗻 in April - and we’d love for you to join us!

Spanning decades this New York Times bestseller is a story about family and religion, dreams and expectations. 

If you’d like to join us, use the hashtag #litchatsbookclub or DM either of us for more information.

✨THE GAPS✨

by Leanne Hall

When sixteen-year-old Yin Mitchell is abducted, the news reverberates through the whole Year Ten class at Balmoral Ladies College. As the hours tick by, the girls know the chance of Yin being found alive is becoming smaller and smaller.

Everyone is affected by Yin’s disappearance—even scholarship student Chloe, who usually stays out of Balmoral dramas, is drawn into the maelstrom. And when she begins to form an uneasy alliance with Natalia, the queen of Year Ten, things get even more complicated.

This is a really hard one for me to rate and it’s not a genre I usually read so I’m just going to share my reading experience.

At the beginning of month, being in Melbourne for less than five days, I took myself to the offical book launch of @lilymandarin new YA novel 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗮𝗽𝘀.

I met Leanne after hearing her speak about the personal journey that writing this story was for her. She was so lovely and welcoming and listening to the story behind the story made my reading experience quite unique I think.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗮𝗽𝘀 is more than a YA novel. It’s more than it’s genre. It’s about women. Young women. It’s about race and power and privilege.

Honestly, having moved to a large city (the population of Melbourne is the same as the entire population of New Zealand...) has made me question my safety, especially at night time and using public transport. Obviously what’s been in the media lately has highlight the issue of women’s safety again. I thought Leanne did an incredible job of bringing these thoughts and emotions to life, after all - she’s been there.

If you’ve passed on reading this one because of the YA label, I wholeheartedly urge you to try it. You might be completely surprised just like me.

How do you decide what book to pick up next? 🤔

With a never ending Wishlist, and a forever growing #tbrpile it can be a tough decision picking what to read next.

I try and prioritise #bookclub picks and #ARCs but sometimes it’s completely a mood choice!

I think I’m going to read 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗕𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗮 𝗣𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝗻𝗶 𝗕𝗹𝗮𝗸𝗲 next, followed by a couple of the review copies I’ve recently been sent.

Let me know how you pick what to read! 👇🏻

✨THE IMITATOR✨

by Rebecca Starford

4.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💫

Evelyn Varley wins a scholarship to a prestigious boarding school where it is very clear she does not fit in. In order to remedy this, Evelyn hides her true self and her opinions and by the time she graduates from Oxford in 1939, has perfected her performance.

As war looms, Evelyn finds herself recruited to MI5 and she is assigned to the dangerous task of infiltrating an underground group of Nazi sympathisers working to form an alliance with Germany.

When a close friend is caught up in her mission, Evelyn’s loyalty is pushed to breaking point, forcing her to make an impossible decision.

I was instantly intrigued by this novel. I would describe it as a solid genre blend of historical fiction and suspense. 

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗜𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗼𝗿 takes on espionage in a way I’ve never read before and is compelling and hard to put down.

Evelyn’s character was strong and independent, thrown completely into the deep end when she joins the War Office. I personally loved how descriptive the author was about the places in this story - it felt like I had been transported!

There’s a real element of this being a psychological novel as well as a WW2 piece. It is a character study that explores how well you know someone, how well you know yourself. If you love historical fiction with just that riiiiight amount of twist - then this one is for you.

𝗕𝗢𝗢𝗞 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗟

The last couple of weeks I’ve been delighted to have these books show up and be added to my library!

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗲𝗮𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗙𝗮𝗹𝗹 explores the philosophical concepts between memory and identity. Out May 4 ✨

𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹, 𝟭𝟭 tells us the story of a social worker turned true-crime podcaster investigating a decades-old cold case. Out May 4 ✨

𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹 was officially launched on Wednesday and I went with @paulineisreading to the event and got to meet @mouthcake and listen to her talk about her debut novel ✨

𝗞𝗹𝗮𝗿𝗮 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝘂𝗻 is highly anticipated and was a wonderful gift from @paulineisreading (thank you 💕) and it asks what does it mean to love? ✨

𝗦𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗼𝗺 is a historical fiction novel about women in Australia fighting for freedom. And the vote. ✨

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗰𝗵𝘄𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗿 takes us on a journey of power and downfall, written from experience and is apparently hilarious in all the right ways ✨

𝗟𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗡𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 sounds like it’ll be a heartwarming story about friendship and love and all the ways it goes wrong ✨

As always, thank you to the tagged publishers for the #gifted copies ✨ I’m looking forward to each and every one!

✨THE FOUR WINDS✨

by Kristin Hannah

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Texas, 1934. Elsa Martinelli has found the life she’s always wanted. A home and a family on the Great Plains.

Drought and winds begins to threaten her community and Elsa must make a decision to put her family first.

I buddy read this with my gorgeous pal @calturnspages 💕

One of the first thing we spoke about was how different 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀 seemed to Hannah’s other novels. Usually within 100 pages I can tell if my heart is going to be ripped out - but with this one I couldn’t tell what direction it would go.

Elsa and her daughter Loreda are both strong and unique characters, determined to live their own lives - their way.

The Great Depression and Dust Bowl era is not something I’ve read or know much about so it was great to read about something different. 

While it wasn’t as emotional as other KH novels, I found that it’s educational aspects were of much more value to me! This is a slow being tale about life, parenthood, and female friendships.

In fact I was so inspired by this novel, I went and sourced a copy of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝗰𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 - one of Elsa’s favourite novels!

I would also take a moment to read the author’s note, it adds remarkable value to the novel.

✨THE PERFORMANCE✨

by Claire Thomas

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

As bushfires rage outside the city, three women watch a performance of a Beckett play.

Margot is a successful professor, preoccupied by her fraught relationship with her ailing husband. Ivy is a philanthropist with a troubled past, distracted by the snoring man beside her. Summer is a young theatre usher, anxious about the safety of her girlfriend in the fire zone.

This is not something I would have usually picked up, but thanks to @tandemcollectiveglobal and @hachetteaus I got to!

I normally find this style of writing and the lack of quotation makes really difficult to get my head around but in 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲, everything just...flowed.

The internal monologue of these three women was perhaps my favourite thing about this novel. At times, I was so emerged in their minds and thoughts, you’d forgive me for forgetting that there was a play in act at all. But then Winnie and Willie bound their way back in.  I’m also very glad that I didn’t feel overwhelmed or required to know Beckett while reading.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 is one of those novels that could be seen as pretentious (it’s very character driven) but I found it warm and engaging. Not one character stood out more than the other, to me their stories were all equal in importance.

The bush fire in the background of this novel added another dimension but I would have liked a bit more?

Thank you again @tandemcollectiveglobal for including me in #theperformancereadalong and for the #gifted book!

⭐️𝗛𝗔𝗣𝗣𝗬 𝗜𝗡𝗧𝗘𝗥𝗡𝗔𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡𝗔𝗟 𝗪𝗢𝗠𝗘𝗡’𝗦 𝗗𝗔𝗬⭐️

Today is International Women’s Day, and this year’s them is #ChoosetoChallenge - how will you celebrate women’s achievements and raise awareness against bias?

I’m sharing a stack of women authors, with books full of incredible women characters. 

Loving seeing all the #IWD2021 posts on my feed 💕

✨NIGHT ROAD✨

by Kristin Hannah

3.75/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️✨

I read this in a feeble attempt to make a dent in my #tbr pile and KH knows how to stomp on someone’s heart, that’s for sure! I don’t think I’ve left a book of her’s without a tear in my eye.

𝗡𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗥𝗼𝗮𝗱 was a good read, and just what I felt like but unfortunately something fell a little flat for me and I think it was because I found it...predictable? I’d figured out a few of the heartbreaking aspects that were coming pretty quickly and while knowing didn’t take away from the reading experience, I personally could’ve done with a few less hints at what was going to happen.

I enjoyed Lexi and Eva as characters but omfg Jude 🤬 did my bloody head in. Every time the novel focused on her, I just wanted to scream and shake her. What a woman. If I was a teenager again and had that kind of mother 😖 I think this is the point though, to show us what length parents do go to? I mean, ultimately this is a novel about parents and the love they have for their children.

Overall a good read, and KH definitely remains one of my favourite authors!

✨BORN A CRIME✨

by Trevor Noah

Trevor Noah was born a crime - not because he could answer back in five languages; not because his mother threw him out of the window of a moving car; not because he accidentally burnt down someone’s house with a magnifying glass; not even because he took Hitler to a bar mitzvah - but because this was South Africa and his mother was black and his father was white...

Josh and I both read/listened to this memoir so I present to you:

𝘼 𝙅𝙊𝙄𝙉𝙏 𝙍𝙀𝙑𝙄𝙀𝙒

𝙁𝙚𝙧𝙣: I’ve always enjoyed watching Trevor Noah and had read incredible reviews of his memoir, so knew I had to read it. I actually listened to the audio book while reading which added a fantastic element! 𝗕𝗼𝗿𝗻 𝗔 𝗖𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲 is revealing, funny and inspirational - and it is truely an eye opener on life in South Africa during apartheid. Trevor’s comedic nature makes this very readable (and for easy listening) considering the information and facts that are given. I really enjoyed learning about his life as someone with a black mother and a white father - a crime. I can definitely see why this is considered essential reading and would highly recommend it!

𝙅𝙤𝙨𝙝: This was really funny and interesting and I honestly laughed out lot often. I enjoyed all the facts about the different tribes and life during apartheid. Listening to the audio book with Trevor as the narrator was good and his mother seems like a bad-ass!

𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗥𝗘𝗡𝗧𝗟𝗬 𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗𝗜𝗡𝗚

I’ve got three 🤭 books on the go at the moment, and I’m loving it! Being able to dip in and out of each when I’m in the mood is great - though I know this isn’t for everyone!

✨𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 as part of #theperformancereadalong with @tandemcollectiveglobal and @hachetteaus - really enjoying this one! The writing style is so unique and I’ve had to stop myself rushing ahead!

✨𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗜𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗼𝗿 sounded right up my alley and when I saw that @nellreadsbooks was reading it, I knew I had to get my hands on it. It’s exactly the kind of story I enjoy!

✨𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀 is the latest from one of my auto-buy authors and I love a good KH! @calturnspages and I are buddy reading this one together, such a unique topic that is rarely written about!

What are you currently reading?

✨LEAVE THE WORLD BEHIND✨

by Rumaan Alam 

3.75/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️✨

Amanda and Clay take their teenage children on holiday to a remote house in Long Island. One night there is a knock at the door. It’s G.H and Ruth, who claim they own the house Amanda and Clay are renting for the summer. Amanda doesn’t think this is the kind of house black people would own.

Are these people safe from each other?

“𝙏𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙡𝙚𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙨𝙚 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙗𝙚𝙘𝙖𝙪𝙨𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙗𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙠,“ 𝘼𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙖 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠𝙨. “𝙄𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙬𝙖𝙮 𝙤𝙛 𝙖𝙘𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬𝙡𝙚𝙙𝙜𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙙𝙞𝙙𝙣’𝙩 𝙗𝙚𝙡𝙞𝙚𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙗𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙠 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙖𝙡𝙨. 𝘼 𝙘𝙖𝙣𝙣𝙮 𝙗𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙠 𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙖𝙡 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙩𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝙖𝙙𝙫𝙖𝙣𝙩𝙖𝙜𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩!“

Written before the global pandemic that we are currently living through, 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗕𝗲𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗱 taps into the general panic most of us will be use to when it feels like the world is ending. Like the characters in this novel, in our modern lives we reply heavily on communication networks but when these get shut down, they are thrown into chaos.

It took me a good while to get into this novel. But in saying that it was quite an easy read and I had it finished in a day. It looks at complex issues like race, parenthood, wealth and more. I like the bluntness. I like that it looked at both Amanda and Clay, and G.H and Ruth. I like that this felt like a real story, that it was definitely believable.

This is a very complex look at real life, it’s issues and how we live our lives.

For a month with only 28 days, February seemed to never end. I’ve had a crazier than usual month with an international move thrown in. 

I can’t believe that I actually succeeded in reading all of these, it was a really solid rating month for me as well. Only a couple of my reads fell short of the mark.

Here’s the wrap!

My #nonfiction pick for the month was:

✨DEATH ON THE NILE✨

by Agatha Christie 

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

A cruise down the Nile on a river steamer sounds like the perfect way to get away from it all.

But the tranquil darkness of an Egyptian evening can change fast when the air is thick with hot passions and cold malice. Temperatures rise when the first passenger is shot, and Hercule Poirot must abandon the mysteries of ancient Egypt and focus on altogether deadlier matters...

“𝙄’𝙙 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙥𝙪𝙩 𝙢𝙮 𝙙𝙚𝙖𝙧 𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙡𝙚 𝙥𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙡 𝙖𝙜𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙩 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙥𝙪𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙜𝙜𝙚𝙧.“

This was my first ever Christie novel and it’s easily one of her most famous works. I’ve always put off reading anything by this author as I’ve found them quite daunting and up until late last year, didn’t even enjoy crime novels.

There are a lot of characters to be introduced to at the beginning and at first I struggled with remembering how everyone was connected. But once the premise was set, I found 𝗗𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗵 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗶𝗹𝗲 to be most intriguing. 

I think it’s important to remember that this novel was first published in 1937, so the language and writing techniques used are very different to what we are used to in modern novels. In saying that, it didn’t feel like I was reading and old book! It felt fresh and interesting and I couldn’t wait to get to reading.

The plot is very neat and descriptive but still leaves the reader questioning whodunnit in subtle ways.

I’m so glad I picked this one up and will definitely be reading more Christie! Also cannot wait to see the new film adaptation and watch these characters come to life!

𝗖𝗢𝗙𝗙𝗘𝗘 & 𝗙𝗟𝗜𝗚𝗛𝗧 𝗘𝗦𝗦𝗘𝗡𝗧𝗜𝗔𝗟𝗦 |

It’s our last morning in New Zealand. WHAT?! 🤯 what an absolute shit show this last week has been, if you saw my stories you’ll know what nightmare we’ve had to go through just to get to this point!

After a lockdown both here and in Victoria, and an ongoing global pandemic - it was feeling like a whole lot of heartbreak and not a lot of anything else.  New requirements were announced 13 hours before we were due to fly which resulted in a rushed effort to prove negative Covid tests ($500 later thank you very much) and an extended stay in Auckland which we were not planning on.

But we have managed to make the most of the 2020 that was (or wasn’t).
We got use to living with each other full time, thanks lockdown 😉 we made plans for our future and continued to look forward to the day when we could finally go on our Trans-Tasman adventure.

I’m honestly not going to believe it’s happening until that plane touches down in Tullamarine 🛬 but I’ve got the essentials packed as you can see.

I started reading 𝗕𝗼𝗿𝗻 𝗮 𝗖𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲 last week but then I thought listening to the audio book along side it would be a bloody brilliant idea. And then Josh got jealous...and wanted to listen too. So now we’re listening to it on the flight. 

And if we’ve learnt anything this past year it’s that 𝙩𝙚𝙖𝙢 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙠 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙚𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙙𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙢 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙠 💕 we’ve also got the most AMAZING family and friends who have listened to every single drama and setback with warm hearts.

I also want to thank that amazing, supportive community that is #bookstagram for always sending positive messages when there was a block in the road. You know who you are 💝 and to the lovelies in Melbs who have offered to get coffees/drinks/show me around/take me book shopping - thank you a million times. I will 100% be taking you up on those offers.

But that’s enough rambling, ya girls gotta plane to catch! See you on the other side x o x o

✨THIS HAS BEEN ABSOLUTELY LOVELY✨

by Jessica Dettmann

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Molly is a millennial who has grand ideas of her mum Annie helping with the childcare of her new baby. Because everyone else’s parents are doing that.

But Annie has been buried under the responsibility of being a mother, wife, caregiver for thirty-five years and she can finally taste freedom.

Over one summer, Molly and her siblings join Annie in the family home and shocking revelations come to light. Everyone is forced to confront the question of what it means to be a family.

Okay what a hoot of a story, I love a bit of family drama and the way that this was all entwined throughout this story is actually so delightful.

I loved that the characters kind of just went off an random thought rambles (because hey I do that myself 😂) and it felt so genuine and not at all clinical? 

I’m loving novels that show readers what it’s like “in this day and age” to be a family, to have career dreams and dramas, as to feel like you’re constantly failing at everything.

This was absolutely lovely. Thank you to the team at @harpercollinsnz for my copy!

✨ONCE UPON A RIVER✨

by Diane Setterfield

3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫

February pick for @thebookcovetersbookclub 

In an ancient inn on the Thames, stories are exchanged. An injured stranger walks through the door with the drowned corpse of a girl in his arms.

Hours later, the dead girl stirs, takes a breath and returns to life. Is it a miracle or is it magic?

Who does the little girl belong to?

This is a story about a story. And I’m not 100% sure how to say what I feel about this story...

𝗢𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗨𝗽𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝗥𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿 is incredibly slow paced and it took me a long time to feel invested. It wasn’t until around page 200 that I thought, hey this is getting somewhere.

There’s and immensely large cast of characters to get your head around, all with their own rich backstories. The river also is a bold character in itself.

This story is beautiful, it’s bold. There is so much to love - it wobbles on the edge of historical fiction and magical realism. The cover is stunning. 

I would perhaps suggest reading this one if you’ve the time to really immerse yourself in the story, and I think that’s where I found my fault. 

Overall, a beautiful story.

✨THE GOOD SISTER✨

by Sally Hepworth

4/5 stars⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ 

#whatfernreads

TW: Sexual abuse, drug use, drug overdose.

Fern Castle works at her local library. She has dinner with her twin sister, Rose, three nights a week. And she avoids crowds, bright lights and loud noises as much as possible. Fern has a carefully structured life and disrupting her routine can be...dangerous.

When Rose discovers that she cannot fall pregnant, Fern sees her chance to pay her sister back for everything Rose has done for her. 

Fern’s mission to find a father for said baby will shake the foundations of the life she has carefully built for herself and stir up dark secrets from the past.

“𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙡𝙞𝙗𝙧𝙖𝙧𝙮...𝙞𝙨 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙤𝙣𝙡𝙮 𝙖 𝙛𝙚𝙬 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚𝙨 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙚𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙣𝙚𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚𝙡𝙞𝙚𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙧 𝙗𝙪𝙮 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙚 𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙞𝙙𝙚...“

Okay I’m just gonna start by saying (and this is no way related to the quality of this novel) that it is damn strange reading a story where one of the main characters has your name. How do you all do it?! I’ve only ever come across this one, and that’s in Charlotte’s Web.

Moving on....

This is the first of @sallyhepworth books that I’ve read, though I have her other titles on my shelves and I’ll get to them, I swear, because I love her writing!

Firstly, I have read and watched a lot of Sally’s interviews re this novel and the research and/or experiences that went into the writing. This story explores autism and neuro a typicality as well as fertility issues.

Fern and Rose’s individual chapters work together really well and Rose’s in particular add to the suspense of this domestic thriller (I don’t know 100% if that’s the genre it falls under, but that’s what it felt like to me 🤷🏻‍♀️). Rose’s insight to their upbringing definitely creates mystery.

I really enjoyed that this was character driven and I loved that the library was such a huge setting for this book, I thought Wally was all the heart eyes 😍 and from one Fern to another, was reminded to believe in myself.

Have you read this one?!

✨THE ONE HUNDRED YEARS OF LENNI AND MARGOT✨

by Marianne Cronin

4/5 stars ⭐️ ⭐️⭐️⭐️

OUT FEB 2021

Lenni Pettersson is seventeen-years-old and lives on the terminal ward. Lenni has questions she needs answers to, and stories she wants to uncover.

When she meets eighth-three-year-old Margot Macrae, a fellow patient offering new friendship, Lenin’s life begins to soar in ways she’d never imagined.

As their bond depends, a world of stories opens up: of wartime love and loss, of misunderstanding and reconciliation, of courage, kindness and joy.

Stories that have led them to the end of their days.

“𝙎𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚, 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙, 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙩𝙤𝙪𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙙 𝙪𝙨, 𝙤𝙧 𝙡𝙤𝙫𝙚𝙙 𝙪𝙨, 𝙤𝙧 𝙧𝙖𝙣 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙪𝙨. 𝙄𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙮 𝙬𝙚 𝙬𝙞𝙡𝙡 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝙤𝙣. 𝙄𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙜𝙤 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚𝙨 𝙬𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙚𝙣, 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙢𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙢𝙚𝙚𝙩 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙥𝙖𝙨𝙨𝙚𝙙 𝙪𝙨 𝙤𝙣𝙘𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙘𝙤𝙧𝙧𝙞𝙙𝙤𝙧 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙜𝙤𝙩 𝙪𝙨 𝙗𝙚𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙬𝙚 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙣 𝙜𝙤𝙣𝙚. 𝙒𝙚 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙗𝙖𝙘𝙠 𝙤𝙛 𝙝𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙧𝙚𝙙𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚𝙨’ 𝙥𝙝𝙤𝙩𝙤𝙜𝙧𝙖𝙥𝙝𝙨 - 𝙢𝙤𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙜, 𝙩𝙖𝙡𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙜, 𝙗𝙡𝙪𝙧𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙗𝙖𝙘𝙠𝙜𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙 𝙤𝙛 𝙖 𝙥𝙞𝙘𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙬𝙤 𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙧𝙨 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙛𝙧𝙖𝙢𝙚𝙙 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙞𝙧 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙜-𝙧𝙤𝙤𝙢 𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙩𝙡𝙚𝙥𝙞𝙚𝙘𝙚.“

I knew when I read the first page of this story, it had the potential to break my heart.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗢𝗻𝗲 𝗛𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗬𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗲𝗻𝗻𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗼𝘁 is so tender, so wise, so kind. I loved hearing about Margot’s life, loved Lenni’s honesty and strength in the face of her terminal, sorry “life-limiting”, illness. 

These are two spectacular and wonderful women who defy convention, who make an unlikely friendship and who made me laugh and made me cry. 

This was a very easy read despite the subject of death being at the forefront, Lenni and Margot are beautiful characters and this is genuinely an unforgettable debut novel about the lives we live and the stories we leave behind.

Thank you so much to @penguinbooksnz for this #gifted #advancedreadingcopy
