✨HOW DO YOU LIKE ME NOW?✨

by Holly Bourne

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Everyone wants to be Tori Bailey.

A straight-talking, bestselling author, she’s inspired millions of women around the world with her self-help memoir and uplifting posts online. What’s more, her perfect relationship with her long-term boyfriend is the envy of all their friends.

But Tori isn’t being honest.

While everyone around her is getting engaged and having babies, Tori’s boyfriend will barley look at her, let alone talk about marriage. And when her best friend Dee unexpectedly falls in love, Tori’s in danger of being left behind. 

Tori’s built a career of living her best life, but is she brave enough to admit it’s not what she wants?

“𝙏𝙪𝙧𝙣𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙧𝙩𝙮 𝙞𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙮𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙡 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙞𝙧𝙨. 𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙘 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙥𝙨, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙢𝙖𝙧𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 𝙬𝙝𝙤𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙨𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙣.“

𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗗𝗼 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗠𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝘄 is a slap in the face, honest and hilarious novel about life. About being in your late twenties/early thirties, about your friends moving on while you’re left behind. 

I loved it because it felt so real.

I also hated it because it felt so real.

There was so much to enjoy. References to the Moulin Rouge soundtrack, multiple attempts to get that perfect coffee snap for social media, that little pouch on your stomach affectionately called Herman.

I expected to hate Tori, and maybe a teeny bit of me did, but I also felt really sorry for her? Like, we’ve all mostly been there right? Who hasn’t been jealous of a friend, had a partner we wished we’d broken up with sooner than we did? If anything I was reminded, we are not perfect, we don’t need to be.

A fab novel. I’m so glad that I picked this one up! But be warned, this could home hard, so don’t go in expecting joy and rainbows all the way through.

𝗥𝗘𝗖𝗘𝗡𝗧 𝗔𝗗𝗗𝗜𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡𝗦 

I know what you’re going to say. I’m suppose to be clearing my shelves for the big move, not adding to them. 

But in my defence, I’ve had some vouchers to get through and I’ve made the most of that over the last couple of weeks.😍

I’m pretty thrilled with this wee collection, there were some real bargains/clearance/second-hand finds in here. 

It’s also looking very likely that we will have to do the 14 day quarantine when we arrive in Melbourne, so I’m making sure my carry on and checked in has for some decent reads and a mix of genres.

Have you read any in this pile and are there any I need to push to the top of my TBR? ✨

𝗚𝗘𝗡𝗥𝗘 𝗟𝗢𝗩𝗘 

I’ve been looking into books that were recommended based on my love of mystery and crime novels. @goodreads actually have a list of “similar reads” once you’ve finished a book and it was after reading 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗿𝘆 by Jane Harper, that Dervla McTiernan’s novels popped up. 

They sound right up my alley, and I’d seen a handle of fab reviews recommending this series based on Cormac Rilley - so I thought, what the heck! I’ll get them. Completely unlike me to commit to a series, as I’m usually a standalone girl through and through. 

Maybe it’s because they’re set in Ireland (one of my favourite countries to read about), maybe it’s the glowing reviews, or maybe I’m growing in my reading habits?

Either way, I’m glad to have pick both of these up and I’m sure I won’t regret it!

✨HITLER’S BROTHEL✨

by Steve Matthews

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Two sisters are brutally separated by war in tragic circumstances. Ania is imprisoned and forced to endure the atrocities of a Nazi concentration camp. Danuta’s search for her sister leads her into the dangers of the Polish Underground.

Each will do what they just to survive long enough to find each other. Their dream of being reunited is crushed in shocking circumstances.

In an astonishing twist of fate, the opportunity for revenge presents itself 60 years later. But faced with the ultimate decision what will be the outcome...seek justice or revenge.

Wow. What an emotional and brutal read. I don’t think I’ve come across a novel so incredibly well researched before. You’d be forgiven for forgetting that 𝗛𝗶𝘁𝗹𝗲𝗿’𝘀 𝗕𝗿𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗹 is indeed fiction. Despite the harrowing and heartbreaking scenes, I could not put it down.

As a massive history buff, I personally found the intricate details compelling and necessary to achieve what makes this novel so great. Without them, it would be just another story of the Nazi occupation. 

I’ve not read much on the Polish Underground and I found that fascinating.  I think a lot of people tend to forget that it wasn’t just Germany that was affected, but Poland and the majority of Eastern Europe also.

I think what I liked most about this story, is the multiple narratives. You get a look inside the characters, from prisoner, Nazi, resistance.

I highly recommend this novel if you’re wanting something intense and richly paced. And please, do read the author notes at the end for an insight into why he wrote this book and the research he undertook - including visits to the concentration camps.

A huge thank you to the author @stevematthewsauthor for the opportunity to read and review.

I’ve never participated in the #readpinkwednesdays tag because well...I don’t own a lot of pink books. And those I do own, I’ve either lent out or donated.

✨BONE CHINA✨

by Laura Purcell

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

January’s pick for @thebookcovetersbookclub 

Consumption has ravaged Louise Pinecroft's family, leaving her and her father alone and heartbroken. But Dr Pinecroft has plans for a revolutionary experiment- convinced that sea air will prove to be the cure his wife and children needed, he arranges to house a group of prisoners suffering from the same disease in the cliffs beneath his new Cornish home. 

Forty years later, Hester Why arrives at Morvoren House to take up a position as nurse to the now partially paralysed and almost entirely mute Miss Pinecroft. Hester has fled to Cornwall to try and escape her past, but surrounded by superstitious staff enacting bizarre rituals, she soon discovers that her new home may be just as dangerous as her last.

“𝘾𝙖𝙣 𝙖 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙩𝙧𝙤𝙡 𝙖 𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙨𝙚, 𝙖 𝙛𝙖𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙮, 𝙩𝙝𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖𝙨 𝙗𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙡𝙚 𝙖𝙨 𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙘𝙚𝙡𝙖𝙞𝙣?“

𝗕𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗮 is very atmospheric, absorbing and all consuming. Various characters within the novel seem to be haunted by the past and driven by duty, guilt and fear.

I found interesting parallels between Hester and Louise, strengthened by the alternative narrative of past and present. Their attempts to determine what is “real” and if fairies do really exist being the main one.

There’s a strong sense of old-time beliefs throughout that add the gothic, creepy nature to this novel - it was truely menacing.

I am definitely adding Laura Purcell’s backlist to my pile.

I spent some time over the weekend prioritising what books I want to read over the coming weeks, and one that I’m quite keen to get to is 𝗛𝗶𝘁𝗹𝗲𝗿’𝘀 𝗕𝗿𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗹.

Author Steve Matthews has produced a throughly researched novel about two sisters who are brutally separated by war. 

I was honoured when he reached out and asked if I would review his novel - having seen it on the shelves and wondered what it was about. I also greatly appreciated the personal note, thank you Steve!

This is going to be my next read I think, so keep an eye out for my review!

✨GIRL A✨

by Abigail Deans

4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

OUT NOW! 

Lex Gracie doesn’t want to think about her family, about growing up in her parent’s house of horrors or as her identity as Girl A: the girl who escaped.

But when her mother dies in prison, Lex and her siblings are left with the family home. She intends to turn it into something good but she must come to terms with her six siblings - and with the childhood they shared. 

I was so excited to be offered a chance to review 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹 𝗔! A huge thanks to @harpercollinsnz #gifted #proof #ad 

This is described as the biggest physiological thriller to hit shelves this year.

There’s a lot of characters to get your head around and the timeline jumps randomly but once you get use to it - the story is totally captivating. Lex and her siblings each have their own horrors to confront in the aftermath of their Mother’s death, and having a part of the novel focussed on each sibling really added to the book.

This is a slow paced novel, but that doesn’t make it any less compulsive. I couldn’t put it down and was completely gripped. Early days yet but I can totally see 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹 𝗔 being adapted into a mini-series. 

It amazes me that this is @abigailsdean debut, it is amazingly written and honestly made me feel uncomfortable. I wouldn’t be surprised if this is topping lists this year. What a strong start to 2021 new releases!

✨THE GOOD MOTHER✨
⁣
by Kim Lock
⁣
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
TW: suicide, depression, toxic/abusive relationships.
⁣
One ordinary afternoon, Fairlie Winter receives a devastating phone call - her best friend is dead.
⁣
The circumstances surrounding Jenna Rudolph’s death seem clear cut, however Fairlie can’t shake the feeling that Jenna, a devoted mother and wife, was hiding something.
⁣
And then Fairlie receives a letter from Jenna. Posted before she died.
⁣
Fairlie is forced on a journey to discover the truth - that she may not be ready for. 
⁣
I went into this one not expecting a lot. And I honestly couldn’t tell you why 🤷🏻‍♀️ goes to show though because I ended up really liking it.
⁣
I’ll admit, I did guess a few of the twists quite early on but that didn’t take away from the reading experience. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗠𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 addresses heavy topics and doesn’t hide Aqua from them. I think they’re so in your face, because in real life, they’re not always that way? 
⁣
What I liked it that these women weren’t characters who were perfect, with unrealistic lives and stories. They were written like real women, that we all know and love. 
⁣
Definitely pick it up and see what you think.

✨RANSOM✨
⁣
by David Malouf
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
From the walls of Troy, King Priam watched the body of his son, Hector, being dragged behind Achilles’ chariot in the Greek camp.
⁣
Maddened by grief at the death of his friend Patroclus, Achilles refuses to give up Hector’s body, but King Priam is convinced there must be a way of reclaiming the body - of putting compromise against heroics, new ways against the old, and of forcing the hand of fate.
⁣
Dressed simply and in a cart pulled by a mule, he sets of to speak to Achilles man to man and as a father.....
⁣
This is such a challenging book to read, so straight out the bat I need to say: I completely understand why this is studied as a text at schools.
⁣
Parts one and two are incredibly slow paced, to the point where I almost gave up. The writing is so full on, it felt like words that were just jumbled on a page.
⁣
But the remaining parts saved it! It’s a story about humanity, what it means to be a family and to be mortal.
⁣
I’m definitely enjoying retelling sun Greek Mythology and this is another one to tick off! I would recommend this to anyone studying Classics, or even teaching it. Also great if you’re wanting a different perspective.

✨THIS IS GOING TO HURT✨
⁣
by Adam Kay
⁣
Everyone one who told me to read this book was 100% right when they said I’d love it.

I don’t think I’ve ever laughed (or cried) so much while reading.
⁣
Kay’s secret diaries of his time as a junior doctor in the NHS are brilliant! They’re insightful and witty while being brutally honest and profound. I think a huge part of me enjoying this was that Kiwis quite often get their humour from our British counterparts and it felt so relatable even though I’ve never worked in the medical field or even stepped foot in Britain.
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗜𝘀 𝗚𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗧𝗼 𝗛𝘂𝗿𝘁 is a perfect read for any time of the year, albeit during summer made it even more of the perfect read for me. Even Josh has said he’d love to read it after I shared a few anecdotes with him. That’s a winner in my book. 🩺

✨PEOPLE OF ABANDONED CHARACTER✨
⁣
by Clare Whitfield
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️ ⭐️
⁣
OUT NOW (NZ)
⁣
London, 1888: young nurse Susannah rushes into marriage with a wealthy surgeon. She returns home from honeymoon with her new husband wrapped around her little finger.
⁣
But then everything changes. Thomas’s behaviour becomes volatile and violent. He stays out all night, returning home bloodied and full of secrets.
⁣
When the first woman is murdered in Whitechapel, Susannah’s interest of piqued. But as she follows the reports of the ongoing hunt for the killer, her mind takes her down the darkest path imaginable....is it coincidence? Or is her husband the man they call Jack the Ripper?
⁣
𝗣𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝗯𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗲𝗿 is a dark, tense and atmospheric novel with extremely flawed characters - I don’t think there was a single one that I remotely liked. While Susannah is someone I found irritating, I also strongly admired her inquisitive nature and that she was determined to make a life for herself.
⁣
There’s a very large focus on what it means to be a woman with little future, other than marrying for convenience, and suffering through endless abuse as a result. But it’s not only the married women who suffer, of course there are the whores and maids of London who fall victim to the murderous man. 
⁣
While the first part was very slow (for me) it picked up in the second half and I genuinely wasn’t bored by any small detail, it is very descriptive.
⁣
This is an excellent debut, that I really enjoyed and think if you enjoy tense mysteries, especially if they’re historical or gothic, you’ll really like this one! My only “warning” is that some might find it too graphic.
⁣
A huge thank you to @harpercollinsnz and @headofzeus for my advanced reading proof ✨

✨TRANSCENDENT KINGDOM✨
⁣
by Yaa Gyasi
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
My final #whatfernreads review for 2020 and what a book to end on!
⁣
Gifty is the younger child in a family of four who have emigrated from Ghana to the American South. While her gorgeous brother is a sports hero, her father longs to return home and her mother is desperate to hold this family of four together. When Gifty's brother's glorious success on the basketball court falters, addiction strikes and the mother turns inward, and to religion, to find a cure. Each one of the characters tries to find a way to heal the heartbreak- for the mother it is God, for Gifty's father it is escape and for Gifty, our narrator - it is science. 
⁣
What I want to say first is this: I’ve seen a LOT of reviews on this book comparing it to Gyasi’s debut 𝗛𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 (which I myself gave 5 stars ✨) but it’s important to remember that this is a completely different novel, with different characters and themes. Obviously the focus on race is prominent - but my advice is go into 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝘀𝗰𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗞𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗱𝗼𝗺 with an open mind or even blind. 
⁣
This book is sad and heartbreaking and frustrating. But it’s SO readable despite the heavy topics of addiction and depression. It binds together religion and science but in a way that just makes sense. 
⁣
“𝙒𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙖𝙡𝙠? 𝙒𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙢𝙨 𝙙𝙤 𝙬𝙚 𝙨𝙤𝙡𝙫𝙚 𝙗𝙮 𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙞𝙛𝙮𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙢𝙨, 𝙘𝙞𝙧𝙘𝙡𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢...𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩’𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙞𝙨 𝙖 𝙦𝙪𝙚𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙨𝙚𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙚𝙨 𝙝𝙪𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙨 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙣𝙞𝙢𝙖𝙡𝙨.“
⁣
Gifty is a character that annoyed me in some aspects yet I was completely empathetic for her when watching her mother drown in her darkness. The points made in this novel are profound and moving and it’s becoming increasingly clear that Yaa Gyasi is a voice for our generation.

Things I’m currently making the use of:
⁣
✨Boxing Day Sales
✨Gifted Christmas vouchers
✨The lighting and textures in this house
⁣
Stumbled across these two today while browsing the local bookstore and having never come across either of them before, thought hey these sound like a bit of me.
⁣
Oprah described 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗗𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗿 as the best thing since 𝗕𝗲𝗹𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗱.
⁣
𝗥𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗼𝗺 was sitting on the shelf, unassuming. It took my eye and has it turns out is a modern retelling of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗜𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗱 which many of you will know I’m all about! 
⁣
From memory, I can’t summon any reviews on either of these but if you’d read them, let me know!

✨THE PEARL THIEF✨
⁣
by Fiona McIntosh
⁣
3.75/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️✨
⁣
Severine Kassel is asked by the Louvre in 1963 to aid the British Museum with curating its antique jewellery, her specialty. Her London colleagues find her distant and mysterious, her cool beauty the topic of conversations around its quiet halls. No one could imagine that she is a desperately damaged woman, hiding her trauma behind her chic, French image.
⁣
It is only when some dramatic Byzantine pearls are loaned to the Museum that Severine's poise is dashed and the tightly controlled life she's built around herself is shattered. Her shocking revelation of their provenance sets off a frenzied hunt for Nazi Ruda Mayek.
⁣
Every time I read a novel set during/following the Nazi occupation, I find something else heartbreaking and incredibly courageous. I’ve said before, that having read so many, they would all start to sound the same or blend into each other but 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗲𝗳 had an unique element because of these mysteries jewels and Josh’s mum (who gave me the book to read) wasn’t wrong when she said it was a fantastic book!
⁣
I don’t want to give too much away because the characters all have secrets that I loved watching unveil themselves and don’t want to ruin that intrigue for anyone else
⁣
This was my first novel by McIntosh but oh it won’t be my last! A brilliant piece of historical fiction.

Mini Christmas Haul 🎄
⁣
So lucky to have received both of these lovely books for Christmas! And both gifted by special people too 💕

𝗦𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗞𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗻 is full of delicious and wholesome recipes and it was lovingly gifted by Josh’s Grandma! I’ve already been through and highlighted some of the meals I’ll be whipping up.
⁣
𝗧𝗿𝗼𝘆 was a present from Josh and boy does he know me well! Admittedly I did give him quite the bookish Wishlist to pick from, but he knows how much I love Greek Mythology and I couldn’t be happier with this one!
⁣
I hope you all had a lovely Christmas and stay safe x

Hello #bookstagram ✨
⁣
I wanna talk #genres because honestly I’ve got my good ol’ go to’s but lately I’ve been wandering further away and diving into the world of #crime #thriller #mystery and I honestly don’t know who this person is! 
⁣
I NEVER read these genres before joining this community, but funnily enough - it’s my Mum’s favourite! Maybe that’s why? Because I grew up with all these intense novels on the bookshelves? 
⁣
Fast forward and here I am devouring this new found (for me!) genre and I think it’s definitely because of our corner of the world. From reviews and recommendations, to being pushed to discover new reads. 
⁣
Out the books pictured, I’ve read four and I’ve purchased so many more. 📚
⁣
Tell me, what’s a genre you’ve discovered and enjoyed since joining bookstagram and please drop any recommendations below 👇🏻

✨THE NOWHERE CHILD✨
⁣
by Christian White
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Kim Leamy is approached by a stranger who believes she is Sammy Went, a two-year-old girl who went missing nearly thirty years previously.
 
Kim begins to explore her family history and finds that some questions don’t have answers and ends up travelling to Manson, a small town in Kentucky – into a dark past.
 
As the town, and the Went family histories begin to unravel will we find the answers that Kim is looking for?
 
A #bookstagram fav and I can see why! I read this one so quickly, even bringing to work to sneakily read during the quiet periods and telling poor J to shhh 🤫 more than once when he tried to talk to me (sorry boo).
⁣
This is a compelling novel that explores family relationships, extreme religious beliefs and truth.  𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗹𝗱 chapters alternate between ‘then’ (when Sammy disappeared) and ‘now’ (as Kim investigated the disappearance) and I think this adds an interesting element to the novel.  These chapters are fast paced and as the reader builds to climax, found it quite hard to put it down!
 
I personally found the language used was intriguingly informal for a thriller, and while being in this genre thought it was actually a very easy read.
 
I honestly think this a great novel and found it to be an excellent debut!

✨THESE VIOLENT DELIGHTS✨
⁣
by Chloe Gong
⁣
Readalong organised by @tandemcollectiveglobal @tandemcollectiveuk and @hachettenz 
⁣
A delightful debut that reimagines Romeo and Juliet, set in 1920’s Shanghai with a mysterious illness and even more mysterious monster. 
⁣
One of my favourite things about this community is the opportunity to read books I wouldn’t usually pick up, and this was the case with 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝗩𝗶𝗼𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀. I’m so grateful to have been included in the readalong for this novel! 
⁣
Though I think I’m the wrong audience for this particular book, don’t let that put you off because there are incredible themes and it makes for an interesting read. I personally didn’t connect with any of the characters buuuut my favourite part would have to have been the setting. 1920’s Shanghai sounds fascinating and for me, it really added to the pace and body of the text. 
⁣
“𝙏𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙨𝙖𝙮 𝙎𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙝𝙖𝙞 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙨 𝙩𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙖𝙣 𝙚𝙢𝙥𝙚𝙧𝙤𝙧’𝙨 𝙪𝙜𝙡𝙮 𝙙𝙖𝙪𝙜𝙝𝙩𝙚𝙧, 𝙞𝙩𝙨 𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙚𝙚𝙩𝙨 𝙨𝙥𝙧𝙖𝙬𝙡𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙣𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙤𝙣𝙡𝙮 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙡𝙞𝙢𝙗𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙖 𝙨𝙣𝙖𝙧𝙡𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙚𝙨𝙨 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙜𝙚....𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙨𝙖𝙞𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙎𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙝𝙖𝙞 𝙞𝙨 𝙖𝙣 𝙪𝙜𝙡𝙮 𝙙𝙖𝙪𝙜𝙝𝙩𝙚𝙧, 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙖𝙨 𝙮𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙨 𝙜𝙧𝙤𝙬 𝙤𝙣, 𝙞𝙩 𝙞𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙚𝙣𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙖𝙘𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙯𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙘𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙖𝙨 𝙢𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙡𝙮 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙚𝙣𝙞𝙩𝙮. 𝙏𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚 𝙧𝙪𝙢𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙨 𝙤𝙣 𝙒𝙚𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙣 𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙨𝙢 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙀𝙖𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙣 𝙡𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙧.“
⁣
If you like fantasy, romance (though nothing steamy 😉) and mystery then definitely check this out, I think it’s going to be very popular!

What books have you brought in the hopes that they’ll live up to the hype?
⁣
𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗰𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗞𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗱𝗼𝗺 is one I’m so hoping will be that book! I absolutely loved Yaa Gyasi’s debut 𝗛𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴, so I beyond excited to get my hands on this novel. 
⁣
It’s also the December pick for @shamelesspodcast ✨
⁣
Have you read it?!

✨TIDELANDS✨
⁣
by Philippa Gregory
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
England, 1648 -  is in the grip of civil war between renegade King and rebellious Parliament. The struggle reaches every corner of the kingdom, even to the remote Tidelands - the marshy landscape of the south coast.
 
Alinor, a descendant of wise women, crushed by poverty and superstition, waits in the graveyard under the full moon for a ghost who will declare her free from her abusive husband. Instead she meets James, a young man on the run, and shows him the secret ways across the treacherous marsh, not knowing that she is leading disaster into the heart of her life.
 
Suspected of possessing dark secrets in superstitious times, Alinor's ambition and determination mark her out from her neighbours. This is the time of witch-mania, and Alinor, a woman without a husband, skilled with herbs, suddenly enriched, arouses envy in her rivals and fear among the villagers, who are ready to take lethal action into their own hands.
⁣
“𝙏𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙨. 𝙉𝙚𝙞𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙨𝙚𝙖 𝙣𝙤𝙧 𝙨𝙝𝙤𝙧𝙚. 𝙉𝙚𝙞𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙬𝙚𝙩 𝙤𝙧 𝙙𝙧𝙮, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙣𝙤-𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙫𝙚𝙨.“
⁣
I’ll be honest, it took me quite a while into get into this novel, but once I was past the first 100 pages, I was fully invested in the story.
⁣
It’s quite plot beach which adds a very rich element to an excellent piece of historical fiction, based on a time I’m growing more and more interested in.
⁣
𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀 focuses intently on religion and the “old” and “new” ways of faith during civil war England. There’s also a focus on witchcraft and suspicion within a small and isolated community.
⁣
“𝙉𝙤 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙞𝙨 𝙞𝙣𝙣𝙤𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩. 𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝘽𝙞𝙗𝙡𝙚 𝙣𝙖𝙢𝙚𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙡𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙗𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙞𝙣 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙. 𝙀𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙨 𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙛𝙖𝙪𝙡𝙩: 𝙨𝙞𝙣 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙝 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙩 𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙙𝙤𝙤𝙧, 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙩𝙞𝙡𝙡 𝙅𝙪𝙙𝙜𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝘿𝙖𝙮.“
⁣
I throughly enjoyed reading about James, Alinor and her family and look forward to following their journey is the next instalment of the series!

The other day I rambled on about #noobligationsdecember so today I thought I’d share a wee mismatched stack of books I’d like to read over the Christmas and New Year break. 
⁣
Some of these have been on my #tbr for waaaaay too long, one was a present and a couple are #gifted ⭐️
⁣
Any you see here that I need to get to straight away?!

✨EXPECTATION✨
⁣
by Anna Hope
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
The December pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub 
 
Set in and around London, three college friends, now in their thirties, must come to terms with the gap between the lives they imagined for themselves and reality in the face of marriage, fertility struggles, and loss. 
As each woman longs for what the others seemingly possess, will their bonds of friendship sustain them in this liminal phase of their lives—or will their envy and desire tear them apart? 
⁣
I usually avoid novels about female friendships as I find them cliche and they just...annoy me.
⁣
𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 was the exact opposite and exactly what I needed it to be. Incredibly relatable characters and situations, issues I could understand and feel sympathy for.
⁣
While tackling heavy subjects like miscarriage, fertility, sex and depression - the exploration and breakdown of adult (and female) friendships is remarkably readable and I devoured it in less that two days.
⁣
It does leave you emotionally exhausted but for me, it was in a way that made sit back and think about life in all it’s rawness.
⁣
A highly recommended read!

𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗𝗔𝗟𝗢𝗡𝗚 🥀
⁣
I am SO excited to be included in @hachettenz @tandemcollectiveglobal  first ever New Zealand based #readalong for the new novel by @thechloegong 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝗩𝗶𝗼𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀!
⁣
The year is 1926, and Shanghai hums to the tune of debauchery.
⁣
A blood feud between gangs runs the streets red, leaving the city in chaos. At the heart of this is eighteen year old Juliette Cai, former flapper who has returned to assume her role as the proud heir of the Scarlet Gang - a network of criminals far above the law. Their only rivals in power are the White Flowers, who have fought the Scarlets for generations. And behind every move is their heir, Roma Montagov, Juliette’s first love....and first betrayal.
⁣
A unique and imaginative retelling of Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliette 🥀

𝗜 𝗪𝗢𝗨𝗟𝗗 𝗟𝗘𝗔𝗩𝗘 𝗠𝗘 𝗜𝗙 𝗜 𝗖𝗢𝗨𝗟𝗗

Let’s talk Poetry.
⁣
Love it? 😍
⁣
Hate it? 😒
⁣
Don’t know how to review it? 😩
⁣
I personally love poetry, I love that their are people in this world brave enough to share their most intimate thoughts with us. 
⁣
I think it’s inspiring, heartbreaking, and makes me feel all the feels when I’m reading it.
⁣
As for reviewing it? That’s a little more difficult, because like all art forms and all reading genres - it’s totally subjective. 
⁣
I’ve been lucky enough to have been #gifted some beautiful and harrowing poetry collections from @harpercollinsnz including this new collection from @iamhalsey ⭐️
⁣
The cover reminds of vintage collections, of course mixed that that eclectic artwork!

After sharing my #novemberwrapup I had a lot of people commenting and messaging me asking how I manage to read so many books 📚 
⁣
Everyone is different and so are our reading habits, some months I read ten books and sometimes all I manage is three or four. I find it totally depends on my mood, what else I’ve got going on in my life and ultimately the quality of the story that I’m reading.
⁣
I’ve learnt on #bookstagram that DNF’ing a book it totally okay so if a book isn’t holding my attention or feeling like it’s going to be that great, I let it go and move on to the next. 
⁣
I’ve also starting doing sections, normally 50 pages at a time and it’s a real motivation for finishing.
⁣
Overall though, enjoyment is the biggest factor and not putting pressure on ourselves or others to read a certain number of books. In fact in December, thanks to inspiration from @chooksandbooksnz I’m doing #noobligationsdecember including books that have been on my #tbrshelf for too long! And I can tell you know it’s not going to be a successful reading month!
⁣
I’ve also LOVED seeing everyone getting festive, and have slight FOMO over the all winter Christmas posts. For me and mine we have a real Kiwi Christmas 🎄 beaches, BBQ’s and backyard cricket are summer staples and I’m definitely going to be making the most of these loooong summer ☀️ nights!

#gifted #partner @harpercollinsnz 
⁣
Philippa Gregory has got to be one of my most owned authors. Her novels are where my love of #historicalfiction started and every time she publishes, I jump on that. 🤩
⁣
Her newly released novel 𝗗𝗮𝗿𝗸 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝘀 is the second in the Fairmile series, following 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀. 
⁣
I was beyond excited when this showed up on my doorstep and it’s timing couldn’t be more perfect as I’m starting 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀 this weekend! 
⁣
𝗗𝗮𝗿𝗸 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝘀 is out now ✨

✨THE SILENCE OF THE GIRLS✨
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
by Pat Baker
⁣
Queen Briseis has been stolen from her conquered homeland and given as a concubine to Achilles: famed hero, loathed enemy, ruthless butcher, darkly troubled spirit.
 
No one knows it yet, but there are just ten weeks to go until the Fall of Troy, the end of this long and bitter war. This is the start of The Iliad: the most famous war story ever told. The next ten weeks will be a story of male power, male ego, male violence.
 
But what of the women? The thousands of female slaves in the soldiers' camp - in the laundry, at the loom, laying out the dead?
 
Briseis is one of their number - and she will be our witness to history.
 
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗶𝗹𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹𝘀 focuses on the quiet and unassuming presence of women, giving us a unique perspective of one of the world’s oldest and well known war stories.
⁣
Briseis is a compelling narrator who speaks for herself, as well as sharing the stories of the women with whom she shares her new and terrifying existence.  We do see the development of Achilles as more than just an oppressor, and I have seen reviews questioning why some chapters are more heavily focussed on him but I personally feel it adds to the narrative and ultimately gives way to the relationship Briseis and Achilles have.
 
Another retelling that has cemented my love for Greek mythology!

It’s the first day of Summer in the Southern Hemisphere and well, well, well. Look what we have here. ☀️
⁣
Easily one of the most talked about novels in the last few weeks 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗟𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝗱𝗱𝗶𝗲 𝗟𝗮𝗥𝘂𝗲 🌟
⁣
Hotly anticipated, highly reviewed - this one wasn’t all that easy to source (@bookish_nish will know what I mean 😉) but it’s here and I’m very excited to jump in - what a way to start December!

| 𝗡𝗢𝗩𝗘𝗠𝗕𝗘𝗥 𝗪𝗥𝗔𝗣 𝗨𝗣 
⁣
Wow what a month! Was it just me or did it feel like November draaaaaaaagged?! 
⁣
One positive is that I read a heck of books (completely unintentional btw) and only one was disappointing. Thank you to the tagged publishers for my #gifted copies.
⁣
Two #nonfictionnovember picks:

✨THE ACCIDENTAL EMPRESS✨
⁣
by Allison Pataki
⁣
2.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
Having binge watched the latest season of The Crown, I was in desperate need of a historical fiction fix, that ideally featured royalty.  Welcome 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗰𝗰𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗘𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀.
 
The royal houses of Europe have always fascinated me, but Sisi is a lesser known character to me.  This portrayal introduces us to her as a teenager before her unlikely (and unplanned) marriage to Emperor Franz Joseph.  Having grown up in a very unconventional household, with little etiquette and rules, Sisi’s early life at court is less than a smooth transition – made even more unbearable by her over-involved mother-in-law.
 
I’m not going to lie.  There were parts of this novel that made me cringe.  It was more of a historical romance than I thought it would be, but I still learnt about the people included.
 
Sisi’s legacy is that she was vain and obsessed with her appearance, wasn’t allowed to raise her children and that she was bored with her husband.
 
This novel was just what I needed at the time and as I’ve said time and time again, #historicalfiction holds a very special place in my heart.

✨THE DRY✨
⁣
by Jane Harper
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
It hasn't rained in Kiewarra for two years. 
⁣
Tensions in the farming community become unbearable when three members of the Hadler family are discovered shot to death on their property. Everyone assumes Luke Hadler committed suicide after slaughtering his wife and six-year-old son. Federal Police investigator Aaron Falk returns to his hometown for the funerals and is unwillingly drawn into the investigation. 
⁣
As suspicion spreads through the town, Falk is forced to confront the community that rejected him twenty years earlier. Because Falk and his childhood friend Luke Hadler shared a secret, one which Luke's death threatens to unearth ... 
⁣
I was hooked from the get-go with 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗿𝘆!
The storyline includes flash backs to a past crime that adds to the crime we are introduced to at the beginning.
 
Growing up in a region that can suffer droughts, I could relate and feel empathy for this town of characters, I think that is what makes this novel so good.  The setting is real.
 
The character development and descriptions are very realistic and I didn’t grow bored of this well paced story.  Cleverly revealed clues add to the mystery.
 
It’s so hard to fathom that this was Harper’s debut novel!!

| 𝗦𝗧𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗜𝗡𝗚 𝗧𝗢𝗗𝗔𝗬

Today I’m starting 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗶𝗹𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹𝘀, which has been sitting on my #tbrshelf for quite some time!
⁣
I’m fascinated by retelling of classics or events from a female perspective and I’ve heard nothing but good things about this one! It was also shortlisted for @womensprize - how good?! 
⁣
Have you read it? ⭐️

✨THE END OF LONELINESS✨
⁣
by Benedict Wells
Translated by Charlotte Collins
⁣
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Jules Moreau’s childhood is shattered after the sudden death of his parents. Enrolled in boarding school where he and his siblings, Marty and Liz, are forced to live apart, the once vivacious and fearless Jules retreats inward, preferring to live within his memories – until he meets Alva, a kindred soul caught in her own grief. 
⁣
I am beyond grateful to @calturnspages for sending me this book.  It has made it all the more special.
 
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 is full of emotion and follows an ever-evolving story of family, love and of course – loneliness.
 
At only 230 pages, I expected to read it in a short amount of time, but ended up pausing often to reflect on the contents.  It definitely packs of punch.  To the heart.
 
This novel explores life and death, grief, yearning and loss.  Very character driven and I felt I was growing with Jules, Marty and Liz, dealing with their heartbreaks, depression and surreal adulthoods.
⁣
“𝘼𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙞𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙖 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙙. 𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙘𝙝𝙤𝙤𝙡, 𝙗𝙤𝙖𝙧𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜, 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙢𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙨. 𝘼𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙝𝙖𝙨 𝙗𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙨𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙞𝙣 𝙢𝙚, 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙄 𝙘𝙖𝙣’𝙩 𝙨𝙚𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙞𝙩’𝙨 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙛 𝙢𝙚. 𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙫𝙚𝙨𝙩 𝙤𝙣𝙡𝙮 𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙨 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙄’𝙢 𝙜𝙧𝙤𝙬𝙣-𝙪𝙥, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙞𝙩’𝙨 𝙩𝙤𝙤 𝙡𝙖𝙩𝙚.
 
A true reflection of human loneliness and how sadness can affect your whole life.
⁣
“𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙘𝙚𝙥𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙡𝙞𝙛𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙝 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙫𝙤𝙞𝙙 - 𝙬𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙞𝙩 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙗𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙧 𝙞𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙 𝙙𝙞𝙙𝙣’𝙩 𝙚𝙭𝙞𝙨𝙩 𝙖𝙩 𝙖𝙡𝙡? 𝙄𝙣𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙬𝙚 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙚, 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝙖𝙧𝙩, 𝙡𝙤𝙫𝙚, 𝙤𝙗𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙚, 𝙨𝙪𝙛𝙛𝙚𝙧, 𝙡𝙖𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙮. 𝙒𝙚 𝙚𝙭𝙞𝙨𝙩 𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙡𝙞𝙤𝙣 𝙙𝙞𝙛𝙛𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙨𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤 𝙫𝙤𝙞𝙙, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙚 𝙬𝙚 𝙥𝙖𝙮 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙞𝙨 𝙙𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙝.“

✨THE OTHER AMERICANS✨
⁣
by Laila Lalami 
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Late one spring night, Driss Guerraoui, a Moroccan immigrant in California, is walking across a darkened intersection when he is killed by a speeding car. 
⁣
The repercussions of his death bring together a diverse cast of characters: 
⁣
Guerraoui's daughter Nora, a jazz composer who returns to the small town in the Mojave she thought she'd left for good; his widow Maryam, who still pines after her life in the old country; Efrain, an undocumented witness whose fear of deportation prevents him from coming forward; Jeremy, a former classmate of Nora's and now a veteran of the Iraq war; Coleman, a detective who is slowly discovering her son's secrets; Anderson, a neighbor trying to reconnect with his family; and Driss himself.
⁣
“𝙁𝙤𝙧 𝙢𝙚, 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙙𝙚𝙨𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙣 𝘼𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙖, 𝙗𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤 𝙛𝙖𝙧 𝙖𝙬𝙖𝙮, 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙧𝙥𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙚𝙙.“
⁣
I would like to start this review by making it clear that I’m obviously in no way an authority on what it is like to be an immigrate in any country, so I don’t feel like I can comment on whether or not this novel is a true representation of this - or the cultures that it depicts.
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗢𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗔𝗺𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗻𝘀 has short, sharp character “chapters” with alternating views. This can be hit or miss due to feeling like you can’t fully connect with the characters but I felt this style was important for the premise of this story.
⁣
There are strong themes of race and religion - focusing on what it means to live in America and be American. I felt that Nora and Coleman were the standout characters, but would have liked to read more from Salma’s point of view. 
⁣
Slow in some parts, it did pick up in the second half. The character backgrounds are somewhat predictable and stereotypical but over all, a timely and well written novel that I’m very glad to have found.

✨ALL YOU CAN EVER KNOW✨
⁣
by Nicole Chung
⁣
Out Now 💫
⁣
What does it mean to lose your roots - within your culture, within your family - and what happens when you find them?
⁣
Nicole Ching was born severely premature, placed for adoption by her Korean-American parents, and raised by a white family in a shelters Oregon town.
⁣
From childhood, she was told that her biological parents had made the ultimate sacrifice in the hope of giving her a better life, but as Nicole grew up she faced prejudice that her adoptive family couldn’t see.
⁣
This is Nicole’s story of searching for the truth of her beginnings, it’s beautifully written, warm and moving.  My partner is adopted so I’m always interested in stories of adoption!
⁣
Review copy #gifted from @allenandunwinnz

✨THE TEN THOUSAND DOORS OF JANUARY✨
⁣
by Alix E. Harrow
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
In a sprawling mansion filled with peculiar treasures, January Scaller is a curiosity herself. As the ward of the wealthy Mr Locke, she feels little different from the artefacts that decorate the halls: carefully maintained, largely ignored and utterly out of place.
⁣
But her quiet existence is shattered when she stumbles across a strange book. A book that carries the scent of other worlds and tells a tale of secret doors, of love, adventure and danger. Each page reveals more impossible truths about the world, and January discovers a story increasingly entwined with her own.
⁣
“𝙄𝙛 𝙬𝙚 𝙖𝙙𝙙𝙧𝙚𝙨𝙨 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙨 𝙖𝙨 𝙖𝙧𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙚𝙡𝙤𝙜𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙡 𝙨𝙞𝙩𝙚𝙨, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙞𝙧 𝙡𝙖𝙮𝙚𝙧𝙨 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙞𝙘𝙪𝙡𝙤𝙪𝙨 𝙘𝙖𝙧𝙚, 𝙬𝙚 𝙛𝙞𝙣𝙙 𝙖𝙩 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚 𝙡𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙡, 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙖 𝙙𝙤𝙤𝙧𝙬𝙖𝙮. 𝘼 𝙙𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙩 𝙗𝙚𝙩𝙬𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚, 𝙪𝙨 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢, 𝙢𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙖𝙣𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙢𝙖𝙜𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙡. 𝙄𝙩 𝙞𝙨 𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙨 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙤𝙧𝙨 𝙤𝙥𝙚𝙣, 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙛𝙡𝙤𝙬 𝙗𝙚𝙩𝙬𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙𝙨, 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙣.“
⁣
I honestly didn’t know what to expect going into 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝗲𝗻 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀 𝗗𝗼𝗼𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗝𝗮𝗻𝘂𝗮𝗿𝘆 ✨ with this wonderful mix of history and fantasy, it’s totally understandable why this novel is so popular!
⁣
Harrow is obviously very passionate about literature, and that passion shines bright throughout this book. 
⁣
I found it to be magical, an education and an escape all at once. Everything one can ask for in stories such as these.

✨LETTERS FROM BERLIN✨
⁣
by Tania Blanchard
⁣
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
Susanna Göttmann’s adopted family’s safety is increasingly at risk during the Third Reich and desperate to protect the people she loves, Susie accepts the help of an influential Nazi officer - but it comes at the risk of abandoning any hope of a life with her beloved Leo, and joining the frightening world of the Nazi elite.
⁣
But her position offers critical intelligence and Susie seizes a dangerous opportunity to help the Resistance.
⁣
I don’t want to use the word ‘predictable’ because it sounds harsh, but I find with stories set during World War 2, and when you’ve read so much of this time period - you just seem to know what’s going to happen. Of course this isn’t a bad thing and within the first few chapters of this novel I knew something terrible and heartbreaking was going to happen.
⁣
Susanna’s unique perspective provides strength and compassion to the story. She’s one of the many women trying to aid her country and her people.
⁣
I read the Author’s Notes, which I always do as it adds an element of knowledge and appreciation to books. Susanna and her family are based on Blanchard’s family, and no matter how many stories I read on Nazi Germany and the Third Reich, it amazes me that people suffered so.
⁣
Thank you to @harpercollinsnz for providing me with a review copy of this story! #gifted #partner

| 𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗥𝗘𝗡𝗧𝗟𝗬 𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗𝗜𝗡𝗚 
⁣
As you may have seen on my stories, I’m making my way through two unique but equally beautiful stories at the moment.
⁣
𝗟𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗕𝗲𝗿𝗹𝗶𝗻 by Tania Blanchard brings to life a heartbreaking story of Nazi Berlin with ties of family and loss. One of my favourite time periods to read about, thank you to @harpercollinsnz for my #gifted copy. 
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝗲𝗻 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗗𝗼𝗼𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗝𝗮𝗻𝘂𝗮𝗿𝘆 by @alix.e.harrow is like books within books within books, a magical story!
⁣
I’m looking forward to sharing my reviews on both of these soon ⭐️

✨THE CONFESSIONS OF FRANNIE LANGTON✨
⁣
by Sara Collin
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
1826, and all of London is in a frenzy. Crowds gather at the gates of the Old Bailey to watch as Frannie Langton, maid to Mr and Mrs Benham, goes on trial for their murder. The testimonies against her are damning - slave, whore, seductress. And they may be the truth. But they are not the whole truth.
 
For the first time Frannie must tell her story. It begins with a girl learning to read on a plantation in Jamaica, and it ends in a grand house in London, where a beautiful woman waits to be freed.
 
“𝘼𝙣𝙮 𝙜𝙤𝙖𝙡-𝙗𝙞𝙧𝙙 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙡 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙢𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙬𝙤 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙖𝙣 𝙊𝙡𝙙 𝘽𝙖𝙞𝙡𝙚𝙮 𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙖𝙡 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙮 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙢𝙚, 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙮 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙧𝙞𝙨𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙧.“
⁣
I was hooked by this story from page one. Told in the first person, Frannie narrates her familiar yet unique plight and while you do start to suspect a few sinister plots, I was still totally gripped. 
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗙𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗲 𝗟𝗮𝗻𝗴𝘁𝗼𝗻 is dark and atmospheric, with an altering pace throughout. I think this was a wonderful piece of gothic fiction, with themes of race, sexuality and gender - what it means to be a women seeking education and to be more than one’s fate.
⁣
“𝙏𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙄 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙛𝙚𝙚𝙡 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙖 𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙, 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙡𝙚𝙨𝙨. 𝙏𝙤 𝙩𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙞𝙩. 𝙊𝙣 𝙥𝙖𝙥𝙚𝙧, 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙗𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙢𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙙 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙤 𝙨𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙚, 𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙 𝙞𝙨 𝙨𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙚𝙡𝙚𝙨𝙨.“

✨KNOW MY NAME✨
⁣
by Chanel Miller @chanel_miller 

This was the November pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub 
⁣
Known to the world as Emily Doe when she stunned millions with a letter.
 
Brock Turner had been sentenced to just six months in county jail after he was found sexually assaulting her on Stanford's campus. Her victim impact statement was posted on BuzzFeed, where it instantly went viral--viewed by eleven million people within four days, it was translated globally and read on the floor of Congress; it inspired changes in California law and the recall of the judge in the case. Thousands wrote to say that she had given them the courage to share their own experiences of assault for the first time.
 
Chanel Miller reclaims her identity to tell her story.
 
𝗞𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝗠𝘆 𝗡𝗮𝗺𝗲 will transform the way we think about sexual assault, challenging our beliefs about what is acceptable and speaking truth to the tumultuous reality of healing.
 
Entwining pain, resilience, and humour, 𝗞𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝗠𝘆 𝗡𝗮𝗺𝗲 was beyond anything I’ve read before.  It took me quite a while to read it, as I processed every single word written. Personally, I found the trial transcripts incredibly interesting.
⁣
Chanel’s story was told all over the world, I remember watching and reading every news story that was presented.  I remember feeling anger and disgust at the sentence, at the privledge. 
 
I’m so grateful to Chanel for writing this for the world, and for herself.

✨ALL OUR SHIMMERING SKIES✨
⁣
by Trent Dalton
⁣
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Darwin, 1942, and as Japanese bombs rain down, motherless Molly Hook, the gravedigger's daughter, is looking to the skies and running for her life. Inside a duffel bag, she carries a stone heart, alongside a map to lead her to Longcoat Bob, the deep-country sorcerer who she believes put a curse on her family. By her side are the most unlikely travelling companions: Greta, a razor-tongued actress and Yukio, a fallen Japanese fighter pilot. The treasure lies before them, but close behind them trails the dark. And above them, always, are the shimmering skies.
⁣
“𝘽𝙚𝙘𝙖𝙪𝙨𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙙𝙙𝙣𝙚𝙨𝙨 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙚𝙨𝙩 𝙚𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣. 𝙃𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙨𝙨 𝙞𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙙. 𝙄𝙩’𝙨 𝙖 𝙗𝙖𝙡𝙙-𝙛𝙖𝙘𝙚𝙙 𝙡𝙞𝙖𝙧. 𝘽𝙪𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙩𝙝 𝙤𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙨𝙖𝙙𝙙𝙣𝙚𝙨𝙨 𝙚𝙣𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙨 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙞𝙙𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪, 𝙚𝙨𝙥𝙚𝙘𝙞𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙟𝙤𝙮.“
⁣
Boy oh boy does he know how to rip out and shatter your heart then put it back together! His very unique writing style and use of dreamy language created a beautiful story of the land.
⁣
This novel focuses on a part of Australian geography that I’m not at all familiar with and it was magical to read about. Molly, Greta and Yukio make for an army of genuine and curious characters. Our band of heroes. And bless Molly for her positivity throughout what is honestly a crap life and for trying to change her fate. With her array of “sky gifts” she sets out on her own path.
⁣
“ ’𝙄 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙠𝙮 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙜𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙢𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙛𝙞𝙧𝙨𝙩 𝙜𝙞𝙛𝙩’, 𝙨𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙮𝙨. ... ’𝙄𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙢𝙮 𝙢𝙪𝙢 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙜𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙞𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙢𝙚....𝙄 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩. 𝙄’𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩. 𝙄 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙖 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙠𝙮 𝙢𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙜𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝙢𝙚 𝙜𝙞𝙛𝙩𝙨. 𝙉𝙤 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙚𝙡𝙨𝙚 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙜𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙢𝙚 𝙜𝙞𝙛𝙩𝙨. 𝙄 𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙠𝙮 𝙢𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙨𝙚𝙚 𝙢𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙞𝙩 𝙢𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙣𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝙢𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙮 𝙤𝙧 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣’.’“
⁣
A classic piece of Australian fiction, I must thank @harpercollinsnz for my gift.

#partnersofbookstagram 💕
⁣
Josh has supported my #bookstagram from day one, and proudly tells everyone that I have a “book blog” and “Fern gets sent books to review!” I think he was a little less enthusiastic when I had to help move all my books a couple of weeks ago 😬
⁣
But. Josh doesn’t read for pleasure. In his own words “I read enough at work” - engineering reports. But if a book provides a learning experience for him, then he’s more than happy to pick it up. 
⁣
His interest was peaked one day as I was browsing a bookstore and he spotted 𝗕𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗳 𝗔𝗻𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗶𝗴 𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 by none other than Stephen Hawking. He left without buying it and I said I’d get it for him as a Christmas present. Fast forward a week, and he asked if we could go back to the bookstore! 🤩
⁣
Josh loves learning about the world around him, which is evident in his field of work. This piece of non-fiction is the perfect book for him!

✨THE WITCHFINDER’S SISTER✨
⁣
by Beth Underdown
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
The November @thebookcovetersbookclub pick!
⁣
1645.
 
When Alice Hopkins' husband dies in a tragic accident, she returns to the small Essex town of Manningtree, where her brother Matthew still lives.
But home is no longer a place of safety.
 
Matthew has changed, and there are rumours spreading through the town- whispers of witchcraft, and of a great book, in which he is gathering women's names.
 
To what lengths will Matthew's obsession drive him? And what choice will Alice make, when she finds herself at the very heart of his plan?
⁣
The debut novel from Beth Underdown, a depressing depiction based on the real life Essex witch trials and witch hunter Matthew Hopkins.
⁣
Though a little slow in some pages, overall 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿’𝘀 𝗦𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 is a vivid and easily read, beautifully described novel.  I was drawn to Alice, Bridget, Grace and Rebecca - the secrets they hide and they ways in which they were connected. Alice especially is our protagonist and is a widow in a man’s world, relying heavily on her brother’s goodwill and fortune.
⁣
“𝙄 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙤𝙛 𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙙 𝙄 𝙝𝙖𝙙 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙬𝙖𝙣𝙩𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙗𝙤𝙤𝙠𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙁𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙨𝙖𝙞𝙙 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙤𝙤 𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙙 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙢𝙚, 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙯𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙮𝙚𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖 𝙗𝙤𝙤𝙠 𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙖𝙨 𝙗𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖𝙗𝙡𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙨𝙥𝙚𝙡𝙡 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙙𝙨.“
⁣
I really enjoy it when fiction is based on real people and events (his fic is my fav!) and I always find myself researching them further, that was no different with Matthew Hopkins.
⁣
An excellent introduction to this time in history that I know little about.

✨VIOLET BEND BACKWARDS OVER THE GRASS✨
⁣
by Lana Del Ray @lanadelrey 
⁣
A debut book of poetry from singer, songwriter, artist and poet Lana Del Ray.
⁣
The cover isn’t the only beautiful thing about this collection of poetry! It showcases typewritten manuscript pages and original photographs from Lana. 
⁣
I’ve absolutely loved making my way through this edition and it’s words, images and art. 
⁣
From Lana: 𝙏𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙚𝙘𝙡𝙚𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙘 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙨𝙩 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙩𝙧𝙮𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙨𝙤𝙣 𝙄’𝙢 𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙙 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢, 𝙚𝙨𝙥𝙚𝙘𝙞𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙗𝙚𝙘𝙖𝙪𝙨𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙥𝙞𝙧𝙞𝙩 𝙞𝙣 𝙬𝙝𝙞𝙘𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙬𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙣 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙖𝙪𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙞𝙘.
⁣
As I’ve said before, I find it very hard to “review” poetry, because it’s the deepest and most intimate thoughts of others. But I’m so grateful to the team at @harpercollinsnz for sending me this beautiful book. 🌻

✨WHILE YOU WERE READING✨
⁣
by Ali and Michelle 
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
The October pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub 
⁣
Meet Beatrix Babbage – 29-year-old dog-earer of books and accidental destroyer of weddings.
⁣
After ruining her best friend's nuptials, Bea relocates to the other side of the country in search of a fresh start, but after a few months, life is more stagnant than ever. Bea’s job is dead-end. Her romantic life? Non-existent. And her only friends are her books, her barista and her cleaning lady.
⁣
Then Bea stumbles across a second-hand novel, inscribed with notes. Besotted with the poetic inscriptions, Bea is determined to find the author ... and along the way, she finds herself entangled in one hell of a love quadrangle.
⁣
I want to start off by saying that 3/5 might now look like many stars, but I really did love this book, 𝗪𝗵𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗪𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 was just what I needed after a month of heavy and spooky reads. That isn’t to say that this novel isn’t full of important themes! 
⁣
It’s a book full of books, a book about a book lover, for book lovers!
⁣
I personally loved reading about Melbourne, which was suppose to become my new home (fingers crossed🤞🏻 this happens next year, we’ve been so excited watching the city open up) and all that the city has to offer. It genuinely feels like a love letter to Melbourne. The amount of times I told my other half “ooooh there’s a bit in this book about Brunswick! Oooh remind me to write down the name of this shop!” 😂
⁣
Bea is a hot mess, and I’m sure most of us can relate to that. 
⁣
Relatable, funny and heart warming, this was a fab read! 💕

| 𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗥𝗘𝗡𝗧𝗟𝗬 𝗥𝗘𝗔𝗗𝗜𝗡𝗚 
⁣
Yup, that’s right! I’m currently reading THREE books at the moment! 
⁣
I’m finding the “sections” method is really working for me and I like being able to jump in and out of books as I please.
⁣
𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗦𝗵𝗶𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝗸𝗶𝗲𝘀 as a buddy read with @bookswith_madz 🌟 this is my first book by Dalton, and it’s taking me a few chapters to get use to the writing style - but I can tell it’s going to break my heart.
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿’𝘀 𝗦𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 with @thebookcovetersbookclub 🌟 based on the real life witch hunter Matthew Hopkins, I did a little bit of research into him and wowee I cannot wait to see where this novel goes. 
⁣
𝗞𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝗠𝘆 𝗡𝗮𝗺𝗲 for @ontheshelf_bookclub and #nonfictionnovember 🌟 I followed this case through and I’m really excited to have the end of month discussion on this one.
⁣
Are you reading any of these at the moment?! What are you currently reading?

✨PRACTICAL MAGIC✨
⁣
by Alice Hoffman
⁣
3.5/5 ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
As children, sisters Gillian and Sally were forever outsiders in their small New England town, teased, taunted and shunned for the air of magic that seems to sparkle in the air around them. All Gillian and Sally ever wanted was to get away.
 
And eventually they do - one marries, the other runs as far from home as she can manage.
 
Years later, however, tragedy will bring the sisters back together. And they'll find that no matter what else may happen, they'll always have each other.
⁣
I was recently #gifted the much anticipated new release 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗟𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗼𝗻𝘀 and didn’t realise it was the prequel to both 𝗣𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 and 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗥𝘂𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰.
⁣
I felt I needed to read both the first two before diving in, so spent Halloween night with this beloved classic!
⁣
“𝙉𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝘿𝙖𝙮...𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙤𝙤𝙣 𝙞𝙨 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙟𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙤𝙪𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙙𝙖𝙮, 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙖𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙪𝙣 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙡𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙙𝙖𝙧𝙠 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙙𝙚𝙚𝙥.“
⁣
Sally and Gillian are as different as characters can be. But their bond is strong and they are bound for life. What I loved about this story, was that despite the synopsis, it’s not just about Sally and Gillian. It’s about Antonia and Kylie, and all the people that surround them. 
⁣
There is just enough information given about the Owens women that have come before them and it’s made me so keen to read the next two novels!

✨THE GIRL WITH THE LOUDING VOICE✨
⁣
by Abi Daré
⁣
4.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
As the only daughter of a broke father, Adunni is fourteen and a valuable commodity. Removed from school and sold as a third wife, the unspeakable happened when she is secretly sold as a domestic segment to a household in the wealthy enclaves of Lagos.
⁣
Adunni is repeatedly told that she is nothing. But Adunni won’t be silenced. She is determined to find her voice - in a whisper, in song, in broken English - until she can speak for herself, for the girls who came before, and did all the girls who will follow.
⁣
Oh Adunni.  How my heart broke for her over and over again while reading.  At times, it was hard to remember that we start this novel with a fourteen-year-old and follow through her hardships.  Fourteen.  I cannot imagine ever having to live a life like this, let alone being married off as a third wife at that age and then into a life of slavery.
 
“𝙒𝙝𝙮 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙣 𝙞𝙣 𝙉𝙞𝙜𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙖 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙢 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙨𝙪𝙛𝙛𝙚𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙚𝙣?“
 
All the while, through each event after the next, Adunni refuses to give up on learning and having a louding voice.
 
The broken English in which this novel is written adds a layer of authenticity and I really felt as if I was listening to Adunni’s “voice” while reading.  𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹 𝗪𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗼𝘂𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗩𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲 combines an unforgettable protagonist with a plight so familiar in literature – but in a way that is unique to itself and its geography.
 
In some ways it reminded me of a Cinderella story but instead of trying to find her Prince Charming, Adunni is searching for her voice and her education.
⁣
A moving novel that celebrates girls and their dreams.
⁣
@abidare_author I must know that Adunni got her happy ending!

| 𝗢𝗖𝗧𝗢𝗕𝗘𝗥 𝗪𝗥𝗔𝗣 𝗨𝗣

#backlistswithfern presents 

✨PACHINKO✨
⁣
Wow it’s been a while since I highlighted a backlist, but the other day I was telling @thegypsylibrary that I read 𝗣𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸𝗼 back in 2017 - and I still think about it! 
⁣
I’ve loved seeing this one making the rounds on #bookstagram and whenever I see it in a stack or if someone asks “what should I read next” this is the one I suggest! 
⁣
It’s a multi-generational, layered novel about family, loss and suffering. It delves into the Asian culture in a beautiful and understanding way.
⁣
If you haven’t read it yet, get to it 🌟

✨THE ESSEX SERPENT✨
⁣
by Sarah Perry
⁣
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
London 1893. 
⁣
When Cora Seaborne's husband dies, she steps into her new life as a widow with as much relief as sadness: her marriage was not a happy one, and she never suited the role of society wife. She moves her young son to Essex where rumours reach them from further up the estuary that the mythical Essex Serpent, once said to roam the marshes claiming human lives, has returned to the coastal parish of Aldwinter. 
⁣
Cora, a keen amateur naturalist with no patience for religion or superstition, is immediately enthralled, convinced that what the local people think is a magical beast may be a previously undiscovered species. 
⁣
Personally, while I love the idea of the plot and Cora as a character, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘅 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘁 felt never ending. The first parts dragged and I had to re-read sections to remember what was going on.
⁣
However! I ended up enjoying the pace of the second half and appreciate the language and technique used throughout. It honestly feels like it could’ve been written in the time period it’s set. A perfect read for October. 
⁣
Thank you @bristolianbooks for organising this one!

✨THE SURVIVORS✨
⁣
by Jane Harper
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Jane Harper is a firm favourite among Kiwi and Aussie #bookstagramers so I was really excited when this one was picked for the @wattleandfernbookclub October pick! It’s my first by this author but I’ll definitely be reading more!
⁣
Kieran Elliott's life changed forever on the day a reckless mistake led to devastating consequences.
⁣
The guilt that still haunts him resurfaces during a visit with his young family to the small coastal community he once called home.
⁣
Kieran's parents are struggling in a town where fortunes are forged by the sea. Between them all is his absent brother, Finn.
⁣
When a body is discovered on the beach, long-held secrets threaten to emerge. A sunken wreck, a missing girl, and questions that have never washed away...
⁣
For me, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘃𝗼𝗿𝘀 was a slow burn that turned into a gripping read that I could not put down. I love crime/thriller/mystery stories where non of the characters are 100% trustworthy and anyone could be the suspect. I only liked one or two characters throughout the entire story but nonetheless zoomed through the second half in a matter of hours because I just had to know what happened!
⁣
Highly recommend 🌟

✨BELOW DECK✨
⁣
by Sophie Hardcastle
⁣
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
TW: Assault, rape, sexual violence, mental illness, mentions of suicide.
 
The debut novel from author Sophie Hardcastle. A heartbreakingly poetic and haunting story about consent, about who has the space to speak and who is believed.
⁣
Twenty-one-year-old Olivia has synaesthesia, which means that she hears sounds and feels emotions in colour - but her life is mottled grey. Estranged from her parents and living with her grandfather who is drowning in sadness, Oli faces the reality of life beyond university alone.
⁣
When she wakes on a boat with no recollection of how she got there, she accepts the help of two strangers who change the course of her future forever. With Mac and Maggie, Oli learns to navigate a life upon open ocean and the world flowers into colours she's never seen before.
⁣
Four years later, Oli is the only woman among men on a yacht delivery from Noumea to Auckland. In the darkness below deck, she learns that at sea, no one can hear you scream.
⁣
What can I say about this novel that will do it justice?  I am in awe of 𝗕𝗲𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗸.
⁣
There are time jumps between parts that work so effortlessly and need little explanation, everything in this story moulds perfectly together.
⁣
𝗕𝗲𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗸 is so lyrical and profound.  I read this with @gretasbookclub and @naomisbookstagram as a buddy read, and we all agreed we found it nearly impossible to stop at the end of the set day’s pages.  At the same time, I found myself taking breaks, folding the book on my lap and whispering wow… the words in this novel are moving and heart breaking and left me breathless.

✨SWIMMING LESSONS✨
⁣
by Lili Reinhart 
⁣
I love reading poetry. I think the forward @lilireinhart gives at the beginning of her collection explains my thoughts on this craft perfectly:
⁣
“𝙬𝙚 𝙨𝙚𝙚 𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙚𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙙𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙖 𝙥𝙤𝙚𝙩 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙬𝙚 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙖𝙥𝙖𝙗𝙡𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙚𝙭𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙨𝙨𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙫𝙚𝙨.“
⁣
This is a debut collection of poetry that explores the euphoric beginnings of young love, battling with anxiety and depression (given the author’s experience in the face of fame) and while no means refined, 𝗦𝘄𝗶𝗺𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗟𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗼𝗻𝘀 is deeply intimate and relatable.
⁣
I think to put your deepest thoughts and feelings into ink and paper is incredibly brave and empowering and whoever does this deserves respect. For this, and many reason, I feel it’s unfair to give a star rating.
⁣
Thank you to @harpercollinsnz for sending me a copy to review. #gifted #partner #ad 

It has reinforced my love of passionate, bite sized poetry 🌸

✨WAKENHYRST✨
⁣
by Michelle Paver
⁣
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣

In Edwardian Suffolk, a manor house stands alone in a lost corner of the Fens: a glinting wilderness of water whose whispering reeds guard ancient secrets. Maud is a lonely child growing up without a mother, ruled by her repressive father. When he finds a painted medieval devil in a graveyard, unhallowed forces are awakened. Maud's battle has begun. She must survive a world haunted by witchcraft, the age-old legends of her beloved fen - and the even more nightmarish demons of her father's past. 
⁣
Spanning five centuries, Wakenhyrst is a darkly gothic thriller about murderous obsession and one girl's longing to fly free..
⁣
From the start I found this book really intriguing.  The Suffolk Fens provide a brooding backdrop to the story, with hints of the supernatural.
 
While much of the novel is set in the Edwardian era, the tale of female oppression is timely, and I thought it could’ve easily been set 200 year prior.
 
I found Maud to be an unlikely feminist heroine who, while she had her own dark secrets, I was rooting for her the entire story. 
⁣
Her father’s behaviour and attitude towards women was appalling, he was suppressive and controlling and I wanting to scream when reading his journal entries.  
 
Paver has wonderfully researched this era and setting to create a magnificent piece of fiction.
 
I only have one bone to pick, and without giving too much away – I just want to know more about THAT twist.  Otherwise, I highly recommend this gothic novel!

Thanks to @thebookcovetersbookclub for picking this one! 💫

✨DAISY JONES & THE SIX✨
⁣
by Taylor Jenkins Reid

3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
The one needs no introduction, 𝗗𝗮𝗶𝘀𝘆 𝗝𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘀 & 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗶𝘅 is a firm #bookstagram favourite. 

This post is also serving as my #onwednesdayswewearpink post!
⁣
I went into this one with low expectations but TJR did the trick with this interview style book based on a fictional band.
⁣
“𝘽𝙪𝙩 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙘 𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙘. 𝙄𝙛 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨, 𝙬𝙚’𝙙 𝙗𝙚 𝙬𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙜𝙪𝙞𝙩𝙖𝙧𝙨. 𝘽𝙪𝙩 𝙬𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩. 𝙒𝙚 𝙬𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙚 𝙨𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣.“
⁣
I was transported to 70’s with sex, drugs and rock and roll 🎸 🤟🏻
⁣
“𝙈𝙚𝙣 𝙤𝙛𝙩𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙮 𝙙𝙚𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙚 𝙖 𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙘𝙠𝙚𝙧 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙣 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚.“
⁣
Daisy is a force within the music scene, not content with being anyone but herself, for herself.
⁣
“𝙄 𝙝𝙖𝙙 𝙖𝙗𝙨𝙤𝙡𝙪𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙮 𝙣𝙤 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙨𝙩 𝙞𝙣 𝙗𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙗𝙤𝙙𝙮 𝙚𝙡𝙨𝙚’𝙨 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙚. 𝙄 𝙖𝙢 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙖 𝙢𝙪𝙨𝙚. 𝙄 𝙖𝙢 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙗𝙤𝙙𝙮. 𝙀𝙣𝙙 𝙤𝙛 𝙛𝙪𝙘𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙮.“
⁣
I enjoyed reading this, it reminded me of Almost Famous or A Star is Born and I found myself blasting a 70’s playlist while reading it! 
⁣
It’s almost hard to believe that these characters weren’t real. 
⁣
Unfortunately for me, I found that the story sort of just ... ended. With no real conclusion. And I would’ve loved a whole story just on Daisy or Billy.
⁣
“𝙒𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙬𝙞𝙡𝙡 𝙘𝙧𝙪𝙨𝙝 𝙮𝙤𝙪, 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬? 𝙄 𝙨𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙨𝙚 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙗𝙤𝙙𝙮 𝙝𝙪𝙧𝙩𝙨 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙗𝙤𝙙𝙮, 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙢 𝙩𝙤 𝙜𝙚𝙩 𝙗𝙖𝙘𝙠 𝙪𝙥, 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙣𝙤𝙩𝙞𝙘𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩? 𝙒𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙡𝙡 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜.“
⁣
Thank you @chapter_chat33 for asking me to buddy read this one with you!

✨THE GREAT ALONE✨
⁣
by Kristin Hannah
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
The September pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub 
⁣
Alaska, 1974.
Unpredictable. Unforgiving. Untamed.
For a family in crisis, the ultimate test of survival.
 
“𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙂𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝘼𝙡𝙤𝙣𝙚,“ 𝙇𝙚𝙣𝙞 𝙨𝙖𝙞𝙙. “𝙏𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙍𝙤𝙗𝙚𝙧𝙩 𝙎𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙞𝙘𝙚 𝙘𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙚𝙙 𝘼𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙠𝙖.“
 
Leni is thirteen years old, growing up in a time of change.  Her father is a former POW and he and her mother have a passionate, stormy relationship.
 
The family moves to the unknown and daunting landscape of Alaska, but find a generous community willing to help them settle.
 
But as winter approaches and Leni’s father’s mental health declines, she and her mother must learn to survive on their own.
 
Kristin Hannah owns emotionally compelling fiction, and I went in with very high hopes for 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗔𝗹𝗼𝗻𝗲 based off my feelings for 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗹𝗲 and other high rating reviews I’d read, and I was not disappointed.  I finished this novel during a snow storm, which seemed like an oddly fitting way to end.
⁣
I did find it somewhat predictable and the last few chapters felt particularly rushed but those would be the only flaws (for me) about this novel. 
⁣
It touches on really hard hitting topics, like physical and emotional abuse and the characters are all heavily flawed but I think that is what makes this story what it is.
 
KH has done it again and I’m off to add her entire backlist to my TBR.

Happy Pub Day to @jodipicoult for 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗼𝗳 𝗧𝘄𝗼 𝗪𝗮𝘆𝘀 ⭐️
⁣
“𝙒𝙝𝙤 𝙬𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙗𝙚, 𝙞𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙝𝙖𝙙𝙣’𝙩 𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙤𝙣 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙣𝙤𝙬?“
⁣
Dawn is a death doula, and spends her life helping people make the final transition peacefully. 
⁣
But when the plane she's on plummets, she finds herself thinking not of the perfect life she has, but the life she was forced to abandon fifteen years ago - when she left behind a career in Egyptology, and a man she loved. 
⁣
Personally, I took my time to relish this wonderful story. It embodies Picoult’s unique and emotive storytelling. It made me think about the complicity’s of life and love, this book will come in punches for some readers.
⁣
A massive thank you to @allenandunwinnz for sending me an advance review copy.
⁣
Get your hands on a copy today!

Spot any favourites?

✨THE PULL OF THE STARS✨
⁣
by Emma Donaghue
⁣
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
“𝘼𝙨 𝙛𝙖𝙧 𝙖𝙨 𝙄 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙡, 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙤𝙡𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙢𝙖𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙚 𝙜𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙖 𝙝𝙖𝙡𝙩. 𝘼𝙘𝙧𝙤𝙨𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙜𝙡𝙤𝙗𝙚, 𝙞𝙣 𝙝𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙧𝙚𝙙𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙪𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨, 𝙨𝙞𝙜𝙣𝙨 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙜𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙪𝙥 𝙪𝙧𝙜𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙤𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙞𝙧 𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝𝙨. 𝙒𝙚 𝙝𝙖𝙙 𝙞𝙩 𝙣𝙤 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙨𝙚 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙚𝙡𝙨𝙚; 𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛-𝙥𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙪𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙨𝙨 𝙖𝙨 𝙥𝙖𝙣𝙞𝙘.“
⁣
In an Ireland doubly ravaged by war and disease, Nurse Julia Power works at an understaffed hospital in the city centre, where expectant mothers who have come down with an unfamiliar Flu are quarantined together. Into Julia's regimented world step two outsiders: Doctor Kathleen Lynn, on the run from the police, and a young volunteer helper, Bridie Sweeney.
⁣
In the darkness and intensity of this tiny ward, over three days, these women change each other's lives in unexpected ways. They lose patients to this baffling pandemic, but they also shepherd new life into a fearful world. With tireless tenderness and humanity, carers and mothers alike somehow do their impossible work.
⁣
How completely strange to read a novel set in 1918 that has parallels to your life in 2020.
⁣
Yup 5 stars. I don’t have much to say about 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝘂𝗹𝗹 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘀 other than I thought it was amazing. I can’t explain what it was that made me love this book so much. I cried while reading it and I encourage you all to read it.
⁣
*small note, there are no speak marks for dialogue and this did throw me a little at the beginning.

✨BEFORE THE CROWN✨
⁣
by Flora Harding
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
As war rages across the world, Princess Elizabeth comes face to face with the dashing naval officer she first met in London nine years before.
⁣
One of the youngest first lieutenants in the Royal Navy, Philip represents everything she has always been taught to avoid. Instability. Audacity. Adventure.
⁣
But when the king learns of their relationship, the suitability of the foreign prince is questioned by all at court.
⁣
He is the risk she has never been allowed to take. The risk not even the shadow of the crown will stop her from taking…
⁣
Step through the palace gates and discover a captivating historical novel of royal secrets and forbidden love exploring the tempestuous courtship between Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip in the wake of WWII.
⁣
Okay, I LOVE @thecrownnetflix so when I saw this ARC pop up on @netgalley I knew I needed to read it. I am fascinated by the Royal Family and this novel is a sweet (fictional) telling of one of the most famous and long running marriages in history. Personally it was great reading more about the Duke of Edinburgh’s life before marrying into the Windsor family! 
⁣
Recommended for those looking into historical fiction but wanting to ease their way in, and for fans of Her Majesty 👑

| 𝗔 𝗚𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗹𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 
⁣
This post is two-fold.
⁣
Firstly things don’t always go to plan, in the simplest and sometimes most frustrating ways! There are 1000’s of us in this little corner of the Internet that have had their plans (big or small) disrupted or changed. I’ve seen and spoken to so many who dealt with each blip in their own way, and am reminded that it’s totally okay to talk about what’s going on. As I start a new job in the place that was only suppose to be a temporary home, I’m aware that I too need to be kind to myself. Remember, my inbox is always open. 💕
⁣
Secondly, hands up if you’ve become a Kindle convert? 🙋🏼‍♀️
⁣
I was 100% the girl who only ever brought/read physical books but during lockdown, I only had a couple with me and the Kindle saved me. See, there are good changes going on too!! 😅
⁣
It was actually given to me by Josh’s mum as she brought a new one and it honestly the best for taking away at weekends or to the hairdresser and other long appointments! I’ve just gotten myself a Kindle Unlimited subscription too! And it’s perfect for reading @netgalley ARC’s.
⁣
This wee gem is the perfect size for popping in a handbag as well. Thank goodness for small mercies. 🤩

✨THE GIVER OF STARS✨
⁣
by Jojo Moyes
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Set in Depression-era America, the story of the Kentucky Pack Horse Librarians.
⁣
When Alice Wright marries handsome American Bennett Van Cleve, she thinks she is escaping her stifling life in England. But life in small-town Kentucky with her over-bearing father-in-law isn’t what she imagined. So when a call goes out for a team of women to deliver books as part of Eleanor Roosevelt’s travelling library, Alice signs on enthusiastically.
⁣
With the leader Margery, Alice and the other librarians learn to become self-sufficient and independent, not something heard of in their backwards community. 
⁣
“𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙗𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙩𝙝 𝙤𝙛 𝙞𝙩, 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚. 𝘿𝙤𝙚𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙢𝙖𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙧 𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝙨𝙢𝙖𝙧𝙩 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙖𝙧𝙚, 𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝙘𝙡𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧, 𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛-𝙧𝙚𝙡𝙞𝙖𝙣𝙩 -- 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙡𝙬𝙖𝙮𝙨 𝙗𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙙 𝙗𝙮 𝙖 𝙨𝙩𝙪𝙥𝙞𝙙 𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙖 𝙜𝙪𝙣.“
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘀 is based on a true story rooted in America’s past, and I loved that it shows loyalty, humanity and passion. I loved that these women fought for themselves and what they believed in - bringing books to people who have never had any, arming them with facts that will change their lives.
⁣
“𝙉𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙙𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙖 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙖𝙧𝙢𝙚𝙙 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙖 𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙡𝙚 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬𝙡𝙚𝙙𝙜𝙚. 𝙀𝙫𝙚𝙣 𝙞𝙛 𝙨𝙝𝙚’𝙨 𝙩𝙬𝙚𝙡𝙫𝙚 𝙮𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙨 𝙤𝙡𝙙.“ 

Thanks to the team #litchatsbookclub for hosting another fab buddy read! Excellent pick! And to @calturnspages for gifting me this beautiful hard copy of the book 💕

✨THE FAMILIARS ✨
⁣
by Stacey Hall
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

To have a child she will trust a stranger.
To protect a secret she must risk her life.
⁣
In a time of suspicion and accusation, to be a woman is the greatest risk of all....
⁣
The stunning debut from @staceyhallsauthor 
⁣
Synopsis 👇🏻
⁣
Lancashire, 1612.
Fleetwood Shuttleworth is 17 years old, married and pregnant for the fourth time. But as mistress at Gawthorpe Hall, she still has no living child, and her husband Richard is anxious for an heir. Then she crosses paths by chance with Alice Gray, a young midwife, who promises to help her give birth to a healthy baby.
⁣
When Alice is drawn into the witchcraft accusations that are sweeping the north-west, Fleetwood risks everything by trying to help her. As the legendary Pendle witch trials approach and Fleetwood’s stomach continues to grow, time is running out and both their lives are at risk....
⁣
🌟

Wow, wow, wow. I was totally and utterly engrossed by 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗿𝘀 from the first page. It had everything I love about historical fiction. 
⁣
This story is based on real people, places and events and you can be guaranteed that I’ve been researching more about the Pendle witch trials since I started reading!
⁣
I loved that Fleetwood was a fiercely, independent character and that her husband Richard wasn’t a typical hero or villain either, given that most husbands written in historical fiction are either one or the other.
⁣
Absolutely enjoyed reading this novel and am so excited to read 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 now as well. 
⁣
Thank you @thebookcovetersbookclub for hosting this buddy read! Bring me more #historicalfiction any day 😍

✨SUCH A FUN AGE✨
⁣
DNF.
⁣
Ugh, I hate it when I pick up book that is sooooo highly praised and feels like it will be an incredible read...but just falls flat.
⁣
I’ve had some amazing conversations with other #bookstagramers about 𝗦𝘂𝗰𝗵 𝗔 𝗙𝘂𝗻 𝗔𝗴𝗲 and I’m beyond relived that I’m not the only one who feels this way. I was honestly panicking about sharing that this is a DNF for me because I thought I’d get harpooned. 
⁣
While this novel starts off with an absolute bang and has the potential to deal with really important and poignant issues in society, to me, it felt like it was going nowhere and dealt with those issues in a really soft way? 
⁣
I’m not bashing the author or the premise of this story in any way and I’ll definitely revisit this book but for now, I’m putting it away. 
⁣
Also just want to say a massive thank you to everyone who reminded me that DNF-ing books is totally okay and that I DON’T need to over justify my decisions. 💕

✨THE HUNTING PARTY✨ 
⁣
by Lucy Foley
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
During the languid days of the Christmas break, a group of thirtysomething friends from Oxford meet to welcome in the New Year together, a tradition they began as students ten years ago. For this vacation, they've chosen an idyllic and isolated estate in the Scottish Highlands--the perfect place to get away and unwind by themselves. They arrive on December 30th, just before a historic blizzard seals the lodge off from the outside world. But after a decade, the weight of secret resentments has grown too heavy for the group's tenuous nostalgia to bear. Amid the boisterous revelry of New Year's Eve, the cord holding them together snaps. On New Year's Day, one of them is dead, and another of them did it.
⁣
“𝙏𝙝𝙖𝙩’𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙤𝙡𝙙 𝙛𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙣𝙙𝙨. 𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙨𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢. 𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙡𝙤𝙫𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢. 𝙏𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙜𝙡𝙪𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙗𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙨 𝙪𝙨 𝙩𝙤𝙜𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧. 𝙄𝙩𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙛𝙖𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙮, 𝙄 𝙨𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙨𝙚. 𝘼𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙝𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙧𝙮. 𝙒𝙚 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙚 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙤 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧.“
⁣
August’s pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub was 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗣𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘆 🦌
⁣
I’ve read both of Foley’s whodunnit murder mystery’s now and while I’d been told 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗣𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘆 was more engaging than 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁, it just didn’t hold my attention that much 🤷🏻‍♀️ there wasn’t a single character that I liked, but I suppose it’s meant that way. 
⁣
To be fair, I’m absolutely useless at guessing twists so I was kept on my toes. But I had a fair idea about who was murdered and why. Who the culprit was however, that was a real twist for me!
⁣
I think these novels are a great way to ease into mystery/thriller genres and I will definitely read more of Foley’s work!!

Rebecca Wood arrives in Shipwreck Bay, ready for a quiet life as the new post mistress of this sleepy seaside town. Fleeing a scandal and haunted by her past, Rebecca is determined to make different choices.
⁣
“𝙈𝙮𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙦𝙪𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙪𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙢𝙚𝙣 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙧𝙤𝙬𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙙𝙤𝙜𝙨 𝙞𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙙 𝙞𝙩 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙣. 𝘼 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙖𝙣 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙙𝙞𝙙 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙨𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙙𝙚𝙚𝙥𝙚𝙨𝙩, 𝙢𝙤𝙨𝙩 𝙥𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙛𝙪𝙡 𝙨𝙚𝙘𝙧𝙚𝙩𝙨 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙬𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙣 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙞𝙢𝙢𝙚𝙙𝙞𝙖𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙮 𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧 𝙨𝙪𝙨𝙥𝙞𝙘𝙞𝙤𝙣.“

✨OLIVE✨ by Emma Gannon 

@emmagannonuk 
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Out now 🌼
⁣
Olive is many things, and it’s ok that she’s still figuring it all out, navigating her world without a compass. But life comes with expectations, there are choices to be made, boxes to tick and sometimes - stereotypes to fulfil. And when her best friends’ lives start to branch away towards marriage and motherhood, leaving the path they’ve always followed together, Olive starts to question her choices - because life according to Olive looks a little bit different. 
⁣
I think this is going to be a book that you either love or hate because the topics are really confronting.
⁣
Personally, I loved it. I think there are some really important themes discussed in OLIVE, in a relatable way.
⁣
“𝘽𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙨 𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙧𝙞𝙗𝙡𝙮 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙛𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙣𝙜. 𝙌𝙪𝙞𝙩𝙚 𝙖𝙬𝙛𝙪𝙡 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮.“
⁣
“𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙯𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 ’𝙨𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙’ 𝙜𝙤 𝙚𝙖𝙨𝙞𝙚𝙧 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙚𝙨𝙚 𝙗𝙤𝙖𝙧𝙙𝙨, 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙬𝙤𝙣’𝙩 𝙗𝙚𝙘𝙖𝙪𝙨𝙚 𝙗𝙧𝙞𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜.“
⁣
Olive dives into the world of mummy-blogging while researching for an article of child-free lifestyles and the hidden shame related to motherhood. She starts to deal with expectations and reactions when she begins telling those close to her of her choice NOT to have children...
⁣
“𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙖 𝙤𝙛 𝙗𝙚𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖 𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙨𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙖𝙨𝙨𝙚𝙙 𝙙𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙩𝙤 𝙢𝙚 - 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙢𝙮 𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧’𝙨 𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧, 𝙤𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙨𝙤𝙘𝙞𝙖𝙡 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙞𝙣𝙜. 𝙄𝙩 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙙 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙖 𝙣𝙤-𝙗𝙧𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙧. 𝙇𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙚𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙨 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙝𝙤𝙬-𝙩𝙤-𝙗𝙚-𝙖-𝙥𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙤𝙣 𝙢𝙖𝙣𝙪𝙖𝙡.“
⁣
I can’t tell you how many times I said “holy crap if that isn’t me?!” while I was reading it. Olive Stone’s (and that of her closest friends) daily #adultingstruggles could happen to any of us. 
⁣
OLIVE will give a voice to millions of women. It’s moving and witty, warm and loveable.
⁣
Thank you to the wonderful @harpercollinsnz for sending me an advance copy for review. #gifted #partner

I umm-ed and ahh-ed about whether or not to share this photo (or perhaps the meaning behind it) but decide it was important to let you know what I’m up to and why.
⁣
This bag of books is being donated to Hospice. Hospice provided palliative care for those with terminal illnesses and also provides care and support for family and friends during this time. 
⁣
In December of last year, J’s dad passed away and we spent a weekend in the care of Hospice Southland. I say we, because they really do care for all that visit, not just the patients. ❤️
⁣
There are lounge rooms that you can take over, with knitting and board games. Kitchen facilities so you don’t have to leave for meals and can stay with your loved ones. 

They also fit perfectly in my @cancer_society_nz daffodil reusable bag 🌼 
⁣
I’ve been thinking about donating some of my books to a charity for a while but had taken my time of selecting which one. I’m happy and proud that these will go to families who need them in one of the toughest situations.
