✨THE SEVEN HUSBANDS OF EVELYN HUGO✨
⁣
by Taylor Jenkins Reid
⁣
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
Telling the story of Old Hollywood star, Evelyn Hugo, who at the age of 79 decides to give a final interview to unknown journalist Monique Grant.
⁣
Summoned to Evelyn’s Upper East Side apartment, Monique listens as Evelyn unfurls her story: from making her way to LA in the 50’s to her decision to leave show business in the 80’s, and of course the seven husbands along the way.
⁣
Who was the love of Evelyn’s life?
That’s the big questions. That’s the hook of this book, seven husbands.
Which one did she love the best?
Which one was the real one?
⁣
“𝙄𝙨 𝙀𝙫𝙚𝙡𝙮𝙣 𝙃𝙪𝙜𝙤 𝙜𝙤𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙡 𝙢𝙚 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙚𝙣𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙩𝙤 𝙠𝙚𝙚𝙥 𝙢𝙚 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙚𝙙𝙜𝙚 𝙤𝙛 𝙢𝙮 𝙨𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙣𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧 𝙚𝙣𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙚𝙡𝙮 𝙧𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙖𝙡 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜.“
⁣
Okay #bookstagram I know how much this book is loved but it just didn’t do it for me 😬 I personally found it predictable and unfortunately it fell flat for me. This was my first TJR novel, and I went in expecting an epic historical fiction but this wasn’t it. While the book explored sexuality and how women in 50’s Hollywood felt they had to use their bodies to succeed, the last third of Evelyn’s life felt really rushed. I think my expectations were just too high for this one.
⁣
I gave it three stars though, it was an easy and quick read and because it explored topics that I wasn’t expecting!

✨EDUCATED✨ 
⁣
A memoir by Tara Westover
⁣
“𝙄 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩 𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙬𝙝𝙮 𝙄 𝙬𝙖𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙤𝙬𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙜𝙚𝙩 𝙖 𝙙𝙚𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙚𝙙𝙪𝙘𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙙.“
⁣
Tara Westover and her family grew up preparing for the End of Days.
⁣
According to the government, she didn’t exist. She hadn’t been registered for a birth certificate.
⁣
She had no school records, because she’d never set foot in a classroom.
⁣
No medical records because her father didn’t believe in hospitals.
⁣
As her father becomes for radical and her brother more violent, Tara knew she had to leave home. In doing she discovered both the transformative power of education, and the price she had to pay for it.
⁣
🌟
⁣
I can’t even begin to explain my thoughts and feelings as I was reading 𝗘𝗱𝘂𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱. Firstly, Tara is only a few older than me. And that she didn’t have a solid, modern education shocked me.
⁣
Her mother practiced as an untrained, unlicensed midwife “𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙞𝙧𝙚𝙡𝙮 𝙗𝙮 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙤𝙬𝙚𝙧 𝙤𝙛 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙤𝙬𝙣 𝙨𝙖𝙮-𝙨𝙤, 𝙬𝙝𝙞𝙘𝙝 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙚𝙣𝙤𝙪𝙜𝙝.“
⁣
Her father believed the government were brainwashing them. Learning in their family was entirely self-directed.
⁣
I found this memoir totally immersive and thought provoking. This rambling, shambles of a review doesn’t do it justice! It’s reminded me not to take my education or upbringing for granted!

✨THE BOOK OF HIDDEN WONDERS✨
by Polly Crosby
⁣
Happy Pub Day! 
⁣
“𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑏𝑒𝑔𝑖𝑛𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑎 𝑓𝑟𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑑𝑠ℎ𝑖𝑝 𝑎𝑟𝑒 𝑙𝑖𝑘𝑒 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑏𝑒𝑔𝑖𝑛𝑛𝑔𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑎 𝑏𝑜𝑜𝑘: 𝑦𝑜𝑢 𝑛𝑒𝑣𝑒𝑟 𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑤 ℎ𝑜𝑤 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑡𝑢𝑟𝑛 𝑜𝑢𝑡 𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑙 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑦 𝑒𝑛𝑑.“
⁣
A massive thank you to @harpercollinsnz for this #gifted book 🌟 #partner
⁣
First of all - this cover 😍 I don’t think any picture I take will ever do it justice, it’s an absolutely beautiful book. Inside and out. See below for the synopsis 👇🏻
⁣
𝙍𝙤𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙚𝙨 𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙧𝙖𝙢𝙨𝙝𝙖𝙘𝙠𝙡𝙚 𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙨𝙚 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙚𝙘𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙘 𝙖𝙧𝙩𝙞𝙨𝙩 𝙛𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙘𝙖𝙩, 𝙈𝙤𝙣𝙩𝙮. 𝙎𝙝𝙚 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙡𝙚 𝙖𝙗𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙥𝙖𝙨𝙩 - 𝙗𝙪𝙩 𝙨𝙝𝙚 𝙠𝙣𝙤𝙬𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙨𝙝𝙚 𝙞𝙨 𝙡𝙤𝙫𝙚𝙙.
⁣
𝙒𝙝𝙚𝙣 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙛𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙛𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙨 𝙛𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙖 𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 𝙤𝙛 𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙙𝙧𝙚𝙣’𝙨 𝙗𝙤𝙤𝙠𝙨 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙢𝙖𝙞𝙣 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙧𝙖𝙘𝙩𝙚𝙧, 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙨: 𝙚𝙭𝙤𝙩𝙞𝙘 𝙛𝙤𝙤𝙙𝙨 𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙖𝙧 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙖𝙗𝙡𝙚, 𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙛𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙨 𝙤𝙣 𝙏𝙑, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙧𝙨 𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙖𝙧 𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙞𝙧 𝙙𝙤𝙤𝙧, 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙗𝙤𝙤𝙠𝙨 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙩𝙖𝙞𝙣 𝙖 𝙩𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙨𝙪𝙧𝙚 𝙝𝙪𝙣𝙩 𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙩𝙤 𝙖 𝙜𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙥𝙧𝙞𝙯𝙚.
⁣

#bookchatswithroseandsoph

✨BURIAL RITES✨ by Hannah Kent
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
“𝙃𝙤𝙬 𝙤𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙥𝙚𝙤𝙥𝙡𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙤𝙛 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙙𝙚𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙨 𝙬𝙝𝙤 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙖𝙧𝙚.“
⁣
Agnes is sent to wait out her final days on the farm of District Officer Jón Jónsson, huge wife and their two daughters. Horrified to have a convicted murderess in their midst, the family avoids speaking with Agnes. Only Tóti, the young assistant reverend appointed as Agnes’s spiritual guardian, is compelled to try to understand, as he attempts to salvage her soul. As the execution draws closer, Agnes’s ill-fated tale of longing and betrayal begins to emerge. And with it the family’s terrible realisation that all is not as they assumed.
⁣
Based on a true story, 𝗕𝘂𝗿𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗥𝗶𝘁𝗲𝘀 is a deeply moving novel about personal freedom and the ways in which we will risk everything for love.
⁣
The perfect story to read during a cold and wild weekend, I devoured it! The Icelandic setting sounded ragged and magical. ❄️ The fact that Agnes was a real person and the last women executed in Iceland made it all the more moving.
⁣
I absolutely loved the prose in which this was written and cannot wait to read @hannahkentwrites 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗣𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲! 
⁣
“𝙄 𝙖𝙢 𝙙𝙚𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙡𝙤𝙨𝙚 𝙢𝙮𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙, 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩𝙚𝙣 𝙢𝙮 𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙩 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙤𝙡𝙙 𝙤𝙣 𝙩𝙤 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙮𝙚𝙩 𝙗𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙨𝙩𝙤𝙡𝙚𝙣 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙢𝙚. 𝙄 𝙘𝙖𝙣𝙣𝙤𝙩 𝙡𝙚𝙩 𝙢𝙮𝙨𝙚𝙡𝙛 𝙨𝙡𝙞𝙥 𝙖𝙬𝙖𝙮. 𝙄 𝙬𝙞𝙡𝙡 𝙝𝙤𝙡𝙙 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙄 𝙖𝙢 𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙞𝙙𝙚, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙠𝙚𝙚𝙥 𝙢𝙮 𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙙𝙨 𝙩𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩 𝙖𝙧𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙄 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙙, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙛𝙚𝙡𝙩.“

✨LITTLE FIRES EVERYWHERE✨ 
by Celeste Ng
⁣
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
A story of teenage romances.
A story of a custody battle.
A story of a town planned to perfection.
⁣
I’ll spare you the synopsis because this one has been making the rounds since it’s release, and as a result is a super popular one on #bookstagram. 
⁣
LFE was the July pick for @ontheshelf_bookclub and explores just how much one would do for their children.
⁣
𝗟𝗶𝘁𝘁𝗹𝗲 𝗙𝗶𝗿𝗲𝘀 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 is a slow burn (pun intended) novel. Most of the drama happens in the last third and I did find a lot of the background information unnecessary and felt that it college been about 100 pages shorter.
⁣
But in saying that, I really enjoyed the intensity of this story, the twists and turns and can totally understand why this has been hyped up and is loved by many! I’m really looking forward to watching the series now that I’ve read the novel!
⁣
“𝙏𝙤 𝙖 𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙩, 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙙 𝙬𝙖𝙨𝙣’𝙩 𝙟𝙪𝙨𝙩 𝙖 𝙥𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙤𝙣: 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙘𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙙 𝙬𝙖𝙨 𝙖 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚, 𝙖 𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙙 𝙤𝙛 𝙉𝙖𝙧𝙣𝙞𝙖, 𝙖 𝙫𝙖𝙨𝙩 𝙚𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙣𝙖𝙡 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙨𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙬𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙡𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙥𝙖𝙨𝙩 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙧𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙢𝙗𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙙 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙛𝙪𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙡𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙙 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙖𝙡𝙡 𝙚𝙭𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙙 𝙖𝙩 𝙤𝙣𝙘𝙚.“

✨THE VANISHING HALF✨
by Brit Bennett
⁣
3.5/5stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⁣
“𝑆𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑡𝑖𝑚𝑒𝑠 𝑤ℎ𝑜 𝑦𝑜𝑢 𝑤𝑒𝑟𝑒 𝑐𝑎𝑚𝑒 𝑑𝑜𝑤𝑛 𝑡𝑜 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑠𝑚𝑎𝑙𝑙 𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑠.“
⁣
While the Vignes twin sisters will always be identical, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the gates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happens to the next generation, when their own daughter’s storyline’s intersect?
⁣
“𝐷𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑟𝑒𝑒 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑆𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑙𝑎, 𝑀𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑑’𝑠 𝑔𝑖𝑟𝑙𝑠. 𝐴𝑠 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑔𝑟𝑒𝑤, 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑛𝑜 𝑙𝑜𝑛𝑔𝑒𝑟 𝑠𝑒𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑑 𝑙𝑖𝑘𝑒 𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑏𝑜𝑑𝑦 𝑠𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑡 𝑖𝑛 𝑡𝑤𝑜, 𝑏𝑢𝑡 𝑡𝑤𝑜 𝑏𝑜𝑑𝑖𝑒𝑠 𝑝𝑜𝑢𝑟𝑒𝑑 𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑜 𝑜𝑛𝑒, 𝑒𝑎𝑐ℎ 𝑝𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑖𝑡 ℎ𝑒𝑟 𝑜𝑤𝑛 𝑤𝑎𝑦.“ 
⁣
There are a collection of characters in this (now) well known novel. Not just Desiree and Stella, but the people who surround them and make their lives. 
⁣
I thought 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗩𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗛𝗮𝗹𝗳 felt like an authentic story due to the language and dialect used. The premise of this story is really fantastic and I love multi-generational stories where people’s lives and pasts intertwine with their futures! 
⁣
So glad that @_massivebooksquad picked this as our July read, and I loved seeing everyone’s reviews and what they thought!

Non-bookish post but I’ve the most AMAZING time on “holiday” 🥰
⁣
After a much needed break, where we headed back to one of our favourite spots for a few days, I’m nearly finished 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗩𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗛𝗮𝗹𝗳 and think I can potentially get one more book out before the end of July!

I LOVED the ideas behind the Random Acts of Kindness posts/exchanges but it was natural that bookstagramers here would be neglected. I personally had a few people message to say it was “too difficult or too much of a hassle” to send me a book. 🤷🏻‍♀️ 
⁣
So when these two wonderful surprises showed up on my doorstep I was beyond grateful and appreciative 💕 

@calturnspages @my.green.reads I am so thankful to you both for forgoing all the above mentioned reasons NOT to send me a book. They will both be treasured and cherished!

⁣
𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗡𝗔𝗧𝗨𝗥𝗔𝗟𝗜𝗦𝗧’𝗦 𝗗𝗔𝗨𝗚𝗛𝗧𝗘𝗥

And when I got home my @mybookmailnz trial box had arrived and I’m so intrigued by 𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗪𝗢𝗢𝗟𝗚𝗥𝗢𝗪𝗘𝗥’𝗦 𝗖𝗢𝗠𝗣𝗔𝗡𝗜𝗢𝗡.

𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗢𝗧𝗛𝗘𝗥 𝗔𝗠𝗘𝗥𝗜𝗖𝗔𝗡𝗦 was on a clearance table at my local @paperplusnz so I couldn’t pass it up! Book ban on? I think so 😬

✨THE YOUNG SURVIVORS✨
by Debra Barnes
⁣
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
A very quick review today, for a book I wasn’t expecting to finish so fast! 

What if everyone you loved was suddenly taken away? Five siblings struggle to stay together as the tides of war threaten to tear them apart.
⁣
When Germany invades and occupies France in the Second World War, the five Laskowski children lose everything: their home, their Jewish community and most devastatingly their parents who are abducted in the night. 
⁣
There is no safe place left for them to evade the Nazis, but they cling together, never certain when the authorities will come for what is left of them.
⁣
Inspired by the poignant, true story of the author’s mother, this moving historical novel conveys the hardship, the uncertainty and the impossible choices the Laskowski children were forced to make to survive the horrors of the Holocaust.
⁣
There isn’t much I could put down in words about this book. Written with lyrical prose and such pounding emotion 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘃𝗼𝗿𝘀 is a truely heartbreaking story. I read it in one sitting and would recommend to all historical fiction readers.
⁣
Thank you to @duck_books and @netgalley for the opportunity to read and review. 🌟
⁣
PS: I am LOVING being able to take my Kindle out on the go with me. I think if it helps make for quick reading and does the trick perfectly when I’m nannying!

✨THE LIGHT AT THE END OF THE DAY✨
by Eleanor Wasserberg 
⁣
Thank you so much to the wonderful team at @harpercollinsnz for sending me this beautiful and moving story! #partner #bloggerpartner
⁣
A family scattered.
Lovers torn apart.
A painting that unites them all.
⁣
When Jozef is commissioned to paint a portrait of the younger daughter of Kraków’s grand Oderfeldt family, it is only his desperate need for money that drives him to accept.
⁣
As Poland is engulfed by war, and Jozef’s painting is caught up in the tides of history, the Oderfeldts are forced to flee.
⁣
Spanning countries and decades, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗮𝘆 is a heartbreaking novel of exile, survival and how we remember what is lost.
⁣
“...𝐻𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑒𝑟 𝑑𝑖𝑑𝑛’𝑡 𝑠𝑒𝑒𝑚 𝑙𝑖𝑘𝑒 𝑎 𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙 𝑝𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑜𝑛 𝑎𝑡 𝑎𝑙𝑙, 𝑏𝑢𝑡 𝑎 𝑓𝑖𝑔𝑢𝑟𝑒 𝑖𝑛 𝑎 𝑓𝑎𝑖𝑟𝑦 𝑡𝑎𝑙𝑒, 𝑚𝑎𝑑𝑒 𝑜𝑓 𝑠𝑚𝑜𝑘𝑒 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑒𝑚𝑏𝑜𝑑𝑖𝑒𝑑, 𝑡𝑎𝑛𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑚𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑣𝑜𝑖𝑐𝑒.“
⁣
We first meet the Oderfeldts as they are fleeing their home before war catches up with them. They are so unprepared. They should have read more, listened more. To radios and their heart’s own terrors.
⁣
A cast of characters who’s stories are engulfed within each other’s, like puzzle pieces finding their way together. 💔

Out 22 July 🌟

✨THE NIGHTINGALE✨ 
by Kristin Hannah
⁣
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⁣
I don’t even know where to begin with this book. 😭 I apologise in advance if this is ineloquent 👇🏻
⁣
I’ll spare the synopsis, but this bold epic war story is heartbreaking and moving and gave me so many feelings. Spanning the period of the German occupation in France, two women fight for their country and their family. 
⁣
I’ll admit that I felt 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗹𝗲 was slow to start and I was worried this was just another over hyped #bookstagram novel BUT I was wrong and the hype is real. By the second half, I couldn’t put it down and found myself incredibly emotional with each twist and turn. 
⁣
A story of women forgotten during the perils of war.
⁣
“𝑀𝑒𝑛 𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑙 𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑟𝑖𝑒𝑠. 𝑊𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑛 𝑔𝑒𝑡 𝑜𝑛 𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ 𝑖𝑡. 𝐹𝑜𝑟 𝑢𝑠 𝑖𝑡 𝑤𝑎𝑠 𝑎 𝑠ℎ𝑎𝑑𝑜𝑤 𝑤𝑎𝑟. 𝑇ℎ𝑒𝑟𝑒 𝑤𝑒𝑟𝑒 𝑛𝑜 𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑎𝑑𝑒𝑠 𝑓𝑜𝑟 𝑢𝑠 𝑤ℎ𝑒𝑛 𝑖𝑡 𝑤𝑎𝑠 𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟, 𝑛𝑜 𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑎𝑙𝑠 𝑜𝑟 𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛𝑠 𝑖𝑛 ℎ𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑟𝑦 𝑏𝑜𝑜𝑘𝑠.
𝑊𝑒 𝑑𝑖𝑑 𝑤ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑤𝑒 ℎ𝑎𝑑 𝑡𝑜 𝑑𝑜 𝑑𝑢𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑤𝑎𝑟, 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑤ℎ𝑒𝑛 𝑖𝑡 𝑤𝑎𝑠 𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟, 𝑤𝑒 𝑝𝑖𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑 𝑢𝑝 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑝𝑖𝑒𝑐𝑒𝑠 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑡𝑒𝑑 𝑜𝑢𝑟 𝑙𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑠 𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟.“

While I’m trying to gather my thoughts on my latest read, I’m going to share another #backlistswithfern 🌟
⁣
A while back, I shared a review for 𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗟𝗜𝗟𝗔𝗖 𝗚𝗜𝗥𝗟𝗦 by Martha Hall Kelly, this is the prequel to that story:
⁣
✨𝗟𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗥𝗢𝗦𝗘𝗦✨
⁣
Inspired by true events, we’re introduced to Eliza Ferriday in 1914. Eliza is travelling to St. Petersburg with a cousin of the Romanov royals, but when Austria declares war on Serbia and Russia’s imperial dynasty begins to fall, Eliza returns to America while her friend Sofya and family flee to the countryside.
⁣
In America, Eliza does her best for the White Russians but when news from Sofya stops coming she fears the worst.
⁣
This story celebrates the unbreakable bonds of women’s friendship during the darkest days of history.
⁣
I love stories based on real people and events and need to read more from this period of Russian revolution - If you’ve got any good recommendations for me, drop them below 👇🏻

✨PLAYDATE✨ by Alex Dahl
⠀⠀
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⠀⠀
𝗔 𝗴𝗿𝗶𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝘀𝘆𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗹𝗼𝗴𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗿𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗮 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗴𝗶𝗿𝗹.
⠀⠀
Lucia Blix went home from a play date turned sleepover with her new friend Josie. The next day, when Lucia’s father arrived to pick her up, the house was empty. No furniture, no family, no Lucia.
⠀⠀
“𝐴𝑛 𝑎𝑐𝑡 𝑜𝑓 𝑗𝑢𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑐𝑒 𝑐𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑒𝑠 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑏𝑜𝑜𝑘 𝑜𝑛 𝑎 𝑚𝑖𝑠𝑑𝑒𝑒𝑑; 𝑎𝑛 𝑎𝑐𝑡 𝑜𝑓 𝑣𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑒𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑒 𝑤𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠 𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑜𝑓 𝑖𝑡𝑠 𝑜𝑤𝑛.“
⠀⠀
This new novel is set in Norway and my honest first thought was that it was VERY dialogue heavy. It’s a really good premise/storyline and one of the most interesting things I found was that it included chapters from the mother of Lucia, her kidnapped and from Lucia herself.
⠀⠀
The second half of the story saved this novel for me, by starting to see where it was going (first half dragged) and further important character development.
⠀⠀
I’m still recommending this book and as that, going to leave this review here. I don’t want to spoil anything 😉
⠀⠀
“𝑤𝑒 𝑏𝑒𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑣𝑒 𝑤ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑤𝑒 𝑎𝑟𝑒 𝑡𝑜𝑙𝑑, 𝑎𝑐𝑐𝑒𝑝𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑤ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑜𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟𝑠 𝑠𝑎𝑦 𝑎𝑠 𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑡ℎ, 𝑐𝑜𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑙𝑒𝑠𝑠 𝑡𝑖𝑚𝑒𝑠 𝑒𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑦 𝑑𝑎𝑦. 𝐵𝑢𝑡 𝑠ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑑 𝑤𝑒?“

Thank you to @netgalley for the ARC!

✨HOMEGOING✨ by Yaa Gyasi
⠀⠀
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
I don’t know if I’m going to be fully able to encompass all of my thoughts about 𝗛𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 in one caption, but I’ll do my best.
⠀⠀
Two sisters with two very different destinies. One sold into slavery; one a slave trader’s wife.
The consequences of their fate reverberate through the generations that follow.
⠀⠀
“𝐴𝑡 𝑛𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡, 𝐸𝑠𝑖 𝑑𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑚𝑒𝑑 𝑡ℎ𝑎𝑡, 𝑖𝑓 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑎𝑙𝑙 𝑐𝑟𝑖𝑒𝑑 𝑖𝑛 𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑠𝑜𝑛, 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑚𝑢𝑑 𝑤𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑑 𝑡𝑢𝑟𝑛 𝑡𝑜 𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑐𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑑 𝑏𝑒 𝑤𝑎𝑠ℎ𝑒𝑑 𝑎𝑤𝑎𝑦 𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑜 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝐴𝑡𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑐.“
⠀⠀
This is a story of black slavery that spans continents and generations.
⠀⠀
“𝑌𝑜𝑢 𝑤𝑎𝑛𝑡 𝑡𝑜 𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑤 𝑤ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑤𝑒𝑎𝑘𝑛𝑒𝑠𝑠 𝑖𝑠? 𝑊𝑒𝑎𝑘𝑛𝑒𝑠𝑠 𝑖𝑠 𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑠𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑎𝑠 𝑡ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑔ℎ 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑏𝑒𝑙𝑜𝑛𝑔 𝑡𝑜 𝑦𝑜𝑢. 𝑆𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ 𝑖𝑠 𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑤𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑡ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑒𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑦𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑏𝑒𝑙𝑜𝑛𝑔𝑠 𝑡𝑜 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑚𝑠𝑒𝑙𝑣𝑒𝑠.“
⠀⠀
𝗛𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 explores horrors but also humanity and hope.
⠀⠀
A wise, compassionate and illuminating novel. It broke my heart and could not be more relevant or needed.
⠀⠀
Please, read this book.

✨THE HENNA ARTIST ✨ 
by Alka Joshi
⠀⠀
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
I know you’ve probably seen this book everywhere atm but I NEED to share my thoughts on our June @_massivebooksquad pick.
⠀⠀
From the first chapter of 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗲𝗻𝗻𝗮 𝗔𝗿𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁 I was instantly transported to another place. 
Indian customs and culture are not something I’m familiar with and this book has made me so interested! ⠀⠀
I was absorbed in the fragrant and bustling streets of 1950’s Jaipur, India and it’s post-British rule.
⠀⠀
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗲𝗻𝗻𝗮 𝗔𝗿𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁 is vivid and compelling, a woman’s struggle for fulfilment in a society pivoting between the traditional and modern.

We see Lakshmi take on a (reluctant) role of both sister and mother to her unknown teenage sister Radma, as well as street child Malik who was my favourite character!
⠀⠀
Alka Joshi @thealkajoshi has created an incredible story that left me wanting more!

𝗗𝗡𝗙 | THE MISSING by Daisy Pearce
⠀⠀
A missing girl. A loving mother who never gave up. A betrayed wife who doesn’t know who to trust.
⠀⠀
I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review. ⠀⠀
Unfortunately 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 fell flat for me and I felt it was going nowhere. Having read other reviews it seems as there’s no resolution or result to the story and I DNF by 50% and am glad I didn’t continue.
⠀⠀
I didn’t like a single character, couldn’t relate to anything or anyone and while it was fast paced and gripping at the beginning few chapters it dragged for the remainder of what I did read. I really wanted to like this one and I’m always gutted when I don’t.

✨THE GUEST LIST✨ by Lucy Foley
⠀⠀
3.5/5 stars ⭐️ ⭐️⭐️💫
⠀⠀
A June pick for @ourbacklistbookclub and @saturdaybookstaclub as well as a @reesesbookclub pick, I’ve seen 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁 all over the gram and I’ll admit I was tempted but had read so many conflicting reviews. I went in with low expectations and ending up really enjoying it!
⠀⠀
A remote island off the coast of Ireland, a brewing storm, a wedding and a guest list full of secrets and lies.
⠀⠀
A classic whodunnit.
⠀⠀
This is a very character heavy story, and in saying that there was not a single character in this book that I liked. Initially I thought it was a little bit slow but by halfway I was genuinely shocked by twists and turns and found myself re-reading bits to make sure I wasn’t mistaken!
⠀⠀
It was such a quick and easy read, the only thing that let it down for me was the slow build up and incredibly annoying characters but I’m definitely going to get myself a copy of Foley’s 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗣𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘆 to read now!

⠀⠀
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
A modern-day ghost story that is woven through generations and is both a spellbinding and chilling read.
⠀⠀
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗶𝗹𝗸 𝗛𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲 by Kayte Nunn @kaytenunn2 is richly and beautifully descriptive. From the first few chapters I was desperate to know more about the House and the women who’s history from the 18th Century to now were entangled in. ⠀⠀

✨SILVER SPARROW✨ by Tayari Jones
⠀⠀
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
This was the June pick for @shaynes_shelf bookclub and I’m so glad!
⠀⠀
From the first line “𝑀𝑦 𝑓𝑎𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟, 𝐽𝑎𝑚𝑒𝑠 𝑊𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑝𝑜𝑜𝑛, 𝑖𝑠 𝑎 𝑏𝑖𝑔𝑎𝑚𝑖𝑠𝑡.“, 𝗦𝗶𝗹𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝗦𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 by @tayari had me hooked.
⠀⠀
Dana has always known that she and her mother were the secret family of James Witherspoon. While her first meeting with his other daughter Chaurisse is anticlimactic but necessary the two soon become fast friends, and the lives of six people are destined to implode.
⠀⠀
There is an incredible build up of background information on the lives of the adults in this story, interestingly from the daughter’s points of view - and explains how they all came to be where they are now.
⠀⠀
I think initially you’re suppose to feel for Dana and her mother Gwen, as they are the “forgotten” family but during part two of the novel, you really understand Chaurisse and Laverne’s lives as well.
⠀⠀
Jones’ notations say that she hopes readers will come away from the book with a sort of tolerance for people who find themselves in complicated and messy situations. Both women is this story love their daughters with a bottomless devotion.
⠀⠀
𝗦𝗶𝗹𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝗦𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 is a heartbreaking story about the complexity and fragility of families, there are no winners here.
⠀⠀
“𝐿𝑜𝑣𝑒 𝑖𝑠 𝑎 𝑚𝑎𝑧𝑒. 𝑂𝑛𝑐𝑒 𝑦𝑜𝑢 𝑔𝑒𝑡 𝑖𝑛 𝑖𝑡, 𝑦𝑜𝑢’𝑟𝑒 𝑝𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑡𝑦 𝑚𝑢𝑐ℎ 𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑒𝑑. 𝑀𝑎𝑦𝑏𝑒 𝑦𝑜𝑢 𝑚𝑎𝑛𝑎𝑔𝑒 𝑡𝑜 𝑐𝑙𝑎𝑤 𝑦𝑜𝑢𝑟 𝑤𝑎𝑦 𝑜𝑢𝑡, 𝑏𝑢𝑡 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑛 𝑤ℎ𝑎𝑡 ℎ𝑎𝑣𝑒 𝑦𝑜𝑢 𝑎𝑐𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑠ℎ𝑒𝑑?“

I’m Fern 👋🏻 and I live in Dunedin, New Zealand. My partner and I are patiently waiting for the borders to re-open so we can continue with our postponed move to Melbourne, Australia!
⠀⠀
I’ve always loved reading, 📚 and historical fiction is easily my favourite genre. My reading has become more diverse during lockdown/isolation and I’ve discovered a love for mythical fiction and crime fiction!
⠀⠀
In my spare time, I love cross stitching (I’ve been working on my current piece for just over a year and I’m nearly finished!) and exploring our amazing backyard that is New Zealand. We’re big fans of trying out different restaurants and coffee spots in the weekends. ☕️
⠀⠀
Bookstagram has been so welcoming and I have loved getting to know my new friends in this community! Always feel free to pop by and say hi!

Reading is such an essential part of my life and always has been. I am very aware that I’m privileged enough to have access to fiction, non-fiction and other forms of books easily within my reach.
⠀⠀
I was taught from a young age that reading is a way of teaching, of learning and of improving.
⠀⠀
Thanks to this community I’ve discovered more titles to educate myself and to show awareness for what is going on within our world.

✨STITCHING A LIFE✨
by Mary Helen Fein
3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
A young adult immigration story, based on the author’s own ancestors. Fein drew on her family history to write 𝗦𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗟𝗶𝗳𝗲, weaving stories passed down from previous generations. ⠀⠀
Showing why people wanted to escape to the New World, and what drove over two-and-a-half-million Jews to flee Eastern Europe, I would recommend this story for readers who are looking to ease into the historical fiction genre. An incredibly well researched novel. ⠀⠀
I’d also recommend reading the author’s notes for context.
⠀⠀
“𝑇ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑓𝑙𝑒𝑑 𝑝𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑡𝑦 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑎𝑛𝑡𝑖-𝑆𝑒𝑚𝑖𝑡𝑖𝑠𝑚. 𝑇ℎ𝑒𝑦 𝑠𝑜𝑢𝑔ℎ𝑡 𝑠𝑎𝑓𝑒𝑡𝑦 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑠𝑝𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦.“
⠀⠀
Thanks to @netgalley @shewritespress and @booksparks for the opportunity to review this ARC.

I shared this on my story on Tuesday night but I wanted to share it again because this quote from 𝗖𝗶𝗿𝗰𝗲 by Madeline Miller really stood out to me, amidst all that is going on in our world at the moment. Not even at the moment, all the time actually. It’s never stopped. ⠀⠀
I’ve always tried to be diverse in my reading, and I hope that everyone continues to do so - not just for now and not just because everyone else is telling you to.

✨CIRCE✨ by Madeline Miller
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⠀⠀
This was definitely a #bookstagrammademedoit purchase. I’d seen it everywhere and just had to read for myself to discover what all the hype was about. ⠀⠀
𝗖𝗶𝗿𝗰𝗲 is a retelling of The Odyssey from a  modern female perspective. The daughter of a god and a Titan, Circe is born rather ordinary in comparison to her parents and siblings. But she has a dark power of her own: witchcraft.
⠀⠀ “𝐴 𝑔𝑜𝑙𝑑𝑒𝑛 𝑐𝑎𝑔𝑒 𝑖𝑠 𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑎 𝑐𝑎𝑔𝑒.“
⠀⠀
Miller brings mythical characters to life and weaves together a number of well known myths and I honestly delighted in being reminded of them throughout the story.
⠀⠀
Circe is a women that history forgot, like so many, to the men of her life. But she is a daughter, mother, lover, witch. Her gift threatens those around her as well as the mighty gods and her epic tale of rivalry, love and loss burns hot and bright.
⠀⠀
“...𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑠 𝑤𝑜𝑟𝑙𝑑 𝑖𝑠 𝑎 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑑 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑟𝑖𝑏𝑙𝑒 𝑝𝑙𝑎𝑐𝑒, 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑤𝑜𝑟𝑡ℎ 𝑠ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑎𝑡.“

THE BLUEST EYE by Toni Morrison
⠀⠀
“𝐶ℎ𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑑 𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ 𝑝𝑎𝑖𝑛 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑤𝑜𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟 𝑡ℎ𝑎𝑡 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑛𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑙 𝑏𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑠 𝑝𝑜𝑒𝑡𝑟𝑦.“ - @nytimes ⠀⠀
Such an important story, that is still as relevant in 2020 as it was when published in 1979 and the time it was written about, the 1940’s.
⠀⠀
Educate yourself. Educate others.

⠀⠀
𝙰𝙾𝚃𝙳: I definitely source historical fiction when I’m looking for a new read! I know it’s not everyone’s cup of tea, but I absolutely love stories that tell tales of time’s gone by. I’ve read most of Philippa Gregory’s novels and I couldn’t go past her latest 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀.

If you’ve got a go to genre, let me know below! Even better if you’ve got some fab #historicalfiction recommendations for me! 👇🏻

Continuing with my love of #historicalfiction and #backlistswithfern is this inspiring novel based on true events.
⠀⠀
✨LILAC GIRLS✨ by Martha Hall Kelly
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
Caroline Ferriday is a New York socialite.
⠀⠀
Kasia Kuzmerick is a teenager in Poland.
⠀⠀
Herta Oberheuser is an ambitious young German doctor.
⠀⠀
The lives of these three women are set on a collision course when the unthinkable happens and Kasia is sent to Ravensbruck, the notorious Nazi concentration camp for women. Their stories cross continents – from New York to Paris, Germany, and Poland – as Caroline and Kasia strive to bring justice to those whom history has forgotten.
⠀⠀
Because this story is based on real people and events, it makes it even more harrowing. I found 𝗟𝗶𝗹𝗮𝗰 𝗚𝗶𝗿𝗹𝘀 well researched and wonderfully written, entwining three lives together in a haunting and beautiful way. I read this first a couple of years ago and I still think about it today. Lovers of historical fiction, give this one a go!
⠀⠀
I’ve also read the prequel 𝗟𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗥𝗼𝘀𝗲𝘀 and enjoyed it too!

Hey @primer_au I couldn’t pick just one favourite book so I’m gonna tell you why I love reading & reviewing!
⠀⠀
For me reading is an escape, to other worlds, to someone’s else live and journey. Reading is a way of teaching and exploring. Reading is powerful.
I love sharing the books I read with this incredible community and encouraging others to pick up a book they wouldn’t usually select. I love hearing “I read this book because of you.”
⠀⠀
I really hope that you #PickMePrimer so I can continue to share the wonderful world of books!

It’s a grey and dull day in Dunedin so I’m sharing another #backlistswithfern ✨CAGING SKIES✨ by Christine Leunens
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
The story that inspired the award winning film 𝗝𝗼𝗷𝗼 𝗥𝗮𝗯𝗯𝗶𝘁 directed by Kiwi legend @taikawaititi ⠀⠀
I was interested in reading this novel due to the hype of the film. 𝗖𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝗸𝗶𝗲𝘀 is beautifully tragic and immensely heartbreaking to read.
⠀⠀
The story follows Johannes, an avid member of the Hitler Youth. As the war rages on, he discovers his parents are hiding a Jewish girl called Elsa behind a false wall in their large house in Vienna. His initial horror turns to love and obsession.
⠀⠀
Both manipulating and manipulated, Johannes soon finds he is the only one aware of Elsa’s existence in the house the only one responsible for her survival.
⠀⠀
As a lover of historical fiction, and having read many novels from this time period, it was different for me to read from this character point of view. ⠀⠀
My heart truely ached while reading and the possessive and thrilling nature of the novel really surprised me!!

✨THE HEART’S INVISIBLE FURIES✨ 
by John Boyne
5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
This story follows Cryil Avery (who’s not a 𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙 Avery) and his funny and moving search to find his place in a world that seems to delight in gently tormenting him at every turn. Adopted as a baby after his sixteen year old mother is cast out from home, Cyril is more of a curiosity for his adoptive parents than a son. He meets Julian Woodbead and his whole world changes.
⠀⠀
Wow! I was instantly engrossed within this story. Outraged, moved and astounded. I fell for Cyril’s character, his innocence seemed so endearing and his emotions were constantly conflicted throughout.
⠀⠀
I don’t want to spoil this for anyone at all but it was laugh out loud funny, heartbreaking and John Boyne dealt with so many stereotypes within 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘁’𝘀 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗙𝘂𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀 from homosexuality, the AIDS/HIV pandemic of the 1980’s/90’s to the Catholic Church and the response to pre-martial childbearing.
⠀⠀
I highly recommend this novel. Thank you so much to @mysharedstacks @slreadsbooks and @bookishrhetor for organising a read along for this incredible novel!

𝗔 𝗚𝗜𝗥𝗟 𝗠𝗔𝗗𝗘 𝗢𝗙 𝗔𝗜𝗥 | 🌟
⠀⠀
Thank you so much to @quercusbooks for including me in the social media release of #AGirlMadeofAir by Nydia Hetherington!
⠀⠀
I haven’t been able to stop looking at this video clip and it’s got me SO EXCITED for September when this spectacular and marvellous novel will be released!!
⠀⠀
𝗦𝘆𝗻𝗼𝗽𝘀𝗶𝘀: Born into a post-war circus family, our nameless star was unwanted and forgotten, abandoned in the shadows of the big top. Until the bright light of Serendipity Wilson threw her into focus.
⠀⠀
Now an adult, haunted by an incident in which a child was lost from the circus, our narrator, a tightrope artiste, weaves together her spellbinding tales of circus legends, earthy magic and folklore, all in the hope of finding the child... But will her story be enough to bring the pair together again?
⠀⠀
I can’t wait to get my hands on a copy 😍

✨MY DARK VANESSA✨by Kate Elizabeth Russell
3.5/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⠀⠀
I read this as part of @littlebookbirdie May #birdiebookclub and it was really hard for me to go into this novel with an open mind, due to reading so many polarising reviews.
⠀⠀
As most of you know the plot involving 15 year old Vanessa being groomed into a relationship with her English teacher, I’ll spare you the synopsis.

50 pages into 𝗠𝘆 𝗗𝗮𝗿𝗸 𝗩𝗮𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗮, and I was instantly uncomfortable, creeped out and cringing. I was hooked and at the same time wanting to put it away and never open it again.
⠀⠀
Vanessa was beyond irritating as a character, but I have an inkling that’s intentional? I just wanted to shake her and scream for her to see sense! There is manipulation from Strane from the outset, by making Vanessa believe that it was all her idea, that she started the relationship.
⠀⠀
“...𝑏𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑘𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑚𝑒 𝑎𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑡, 𝑝𝑢𝑡𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑚𝑒 𝑏𝑎𝑐𝑘 𝑡𝑜𝑔𝑒𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟 𝑎𝑠 𝑠𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑛𝑒𝑤.“
⠀⠀
As a woman, I wanted and expected more from her character - but that’s a point of MDV right? She doesn’t think anything they did was wrong.
⠀⠀
In the end, I found it to be a lot of build up and background for a kinda predictable ending...? It fell flat for me.
⠀⠀
This is obviously a really tough subject matter to address and I think Russell has done a great job of bringing it to light. The fact that her writing made me physically feel while reading, is in itself wonderful.

✨THE CHOICE✨ by Dr. Edith Eger
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
What an incredible story, I finished this in two days. Edith’s telling of her life before, during and after The Holocaust was incredibly inspiring. From Auschwitz to Mauthausen, Hungary to Vienna and then Edith’s life in the United States. ⠀⠀
Training for the Olympic gymnastics team and a exceptional ballet dancer, Edith is sent to a concentration camp with her family as a teenager and forced to dance for The Angel of Death - Josef Mengele. Edith and her sister Magda survive unimaginable circumstances not only at Auschwitz, but in their post-liberation lives as well.
⠀⠀
I felt so moved reading this, and the choices she made to learn and astoundingly forgive what happened to her and her family. Using her experiences to help her future patients, Edith and her story left me thinking, wondering and with more appreciation for the choices we get everyday.

I had a few requests for this  #backlistswithfern review so here we go!
⠀⠀
✨BELGRAVIA✨ by Julian Fellowes
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
A secret unravels behind the porticoed doors of London's grandest postcode. Set in the 1840s when the upper echelons of society began to rub shoulders with the emerging industrial nouveau riche, Belgravia is people by a rich cast of characters. But the story begins on the eve of the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. At the Duchess of Richmond's new legendary ball, one family's life will change forever.
⠀⠀
I read this back in 2017 while suffering Downton Abbey withdrawals. I’ve honestly enjoyed everything that Fellowes has put out, whether book, film or series! 𝗕𝗲𝗹𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗮 is a standout period drama/historical novel with twists and turns and you as the reader are waiting with baited breath for the characters to discover the truth! ⠀⠀
There’s now a @itv @epix TV series for this novel and I am beyond excited to watch it and see these character come to live. Julian Fellowes is really a master of this genre and so if you loved Downton I highly recommend you read this!

As voted by you, the first of the #backlistswithfern reviews is:
⠀⠀
✨THE TATTOOIST OF AUSCHWITZ ✨ by Heather Morris
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
Based on a true story, 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗶𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝘂𝘀𝗰𝗵𝘄𝗶𝘁𝘇 brings to life Lale Sokolov’s time in the infamous concentration camp, Auschwitz-Birkenau. Lale was given the job of tattooing the prisoners marked for survival - scratching numbers into his fellow victim’s arms to create what would become one of the most potent symbols of the Holocaust.
⠀⠀
Lale was determined to survive but he was determined to save the girl he meets waiting in line to be tattooed as well. So begins the love story of the Tattooist of Auschwitz.
⠀⠀
I’m aware that many who’ve reviewed this have pointed out the number of historical inaccuracies within this story and found it too much like an academic retelling, but I want to stick to what made this book 4 stars for me.
⠀⠀
Morris did a lot of research while writing, meeting Lale and his family. For me, she created something extraordinary and incredibly touching out of Lale’s story and if a book can stay with me and still have me thinking about it two years later, I think that is magical in itself. It also made me want to research further which I think is a bonus!
⠀⠀
I should point out, I did study The Holocaust significantly so it is a topic that instantly appeals to me so I could be slightly bias within this review.

✨ WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING ✨ by Delia Owens 3.5 stars ⭐️ ⭐️⭐️💫 ⠀⠀
Part coming-of-age, part murder-mystery, I don’t need to give a synopsis to this one as it’s been a bestseller and since so many of you have read it! But a warning, this will be a #unpopularopinion - I did not love this novel.
⠀⠀
I want to start off by saying that I was so nervous to read WTCS because it was sooooo hyped up, a Reese’s Book Club pick and all over social media. ⠀⠀
I found it so hard to get into, and the language was such a trip for me. Though I do think it adds a unique aspect.  I persevered because I am not one to NOT finish a book, in saying that, it did take me way longer than usual to finish. And I’m still not 100% what I thought about it.
⠀⠀
I kept waiting for the “big” moment to happen, and feel really disappointed by it.
⠀⠀
𝗪𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗿𝗮𝘄𝗱𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗦𝗶𝗻𝗴 is beautifully written, full of gorgeous descriptions of the world beyond yonder and that for me was it’s saving grace.
⠀⠀
Big thanks to @yiotasbooks @readwithrozoid @living.thousands.of.lives lives @prettygoodreads and @celestialreads for hashing this one out with me while I struggled through and for not making me feel bad about my views!
⠀⠀
“I wadn’t aware that words could hold so much. I didn’t know a sentence could be so full.”

✨ UNDER THE COVERS ✨ by Jenny Lynch 🌟🌟🌟🌟 4 stars!
⠀⠀
I loved this memoir #gifted for review by @maryeganpublishing ⠀⠀
Former editor Jenny Lynch takes the wraps off the unreported side of life in print, explodes myths, unearths secrets and shows that even on seemingly conservative publications such as the New Zealand Woman's Weekly things were seldom exactly as they seemed.
⠀⠀
I found this to be incredibly honest and witty, relatable and real. It was like reading a piece of home, and Kiwi life all in one. 
I’m passing it on to my Nana to read next as she loves The Women’s Weekly and I’m sure she will love this read too!

Mine is 𝙋𝙧𝙞𝙙𝙚 𝘼𝙣𝙙 𝙋𝙧𝙚𝙟𝙪𝙙𝙞𝙘𝙚 by none other than Miss Austen herself. I don’t really know why, it’s just one of those stories I’ve always enjoyed and I have a wee collection of editions. 
Like many, we studied it at school and not even that could put me off!
⠀⠀
𝐴𝑓𝑡𝑒𝑟 𝑎𝑙𝑙 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟𝑒 𝑖𝑠 𝑛𝑜 𝑒𝑛𝑗𝑜𝑦𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡 𝑙𝑖𝑘𝑒 𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑑𝑖𝑛𝑔!🧡

✨ A THOUSAND SHIPS ✨ by Natalie Haynes 4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
⠀⠀
The retelling of the famous Trojan war from an all-female perspective.
⠀⠀
“𝑇ℎ𝑒𝑟𝑒 𝑎𝑟𝑒 𝑠𝑜 𝑚𝑎𝑛𝑦 𝑤𝑎𝑦𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑎 𝑤𝑎𝑟: 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑟𝑒 𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑙𝑖𝑐𝑡 𝑐𝑎𝑛 𝑏𝑒 𝑒𝑛𝑐𝑎𝑝𝑠𝑢𝑙𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑑 𝑖𝑛 𝑗𝑢𝑠𝑡 𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑛𝑡. 𝑂𝑛𝑒 𝑚𝑎𝑛’𝑠 𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒𝑟 𝑎𝑡 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑏𝑒ℎ𝑎𝑣𝑖𝑜𝑢𝑟 𝑜𝑓 𝑎𝑛𝑜𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟, 𝑠𝑎𝑦.“
⠀⠀
In the middle of the night, Troy is woken - in flames. Ten seemingly ending years of brutal conflict between the Greeks and the Trojans are over, and the Greeks are victorious.
⠀⠀
The devastating consequences of the fall of Troy stretch from Mount Ida to Mount Olympus, from the citadel of Troy to the distant Greek islands, and across oceans and sky between. ⠀⠀
“ - 𝑎𝑙𝑙 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑇𝑟𝑜𝑗𝑎𝑛 𝑤𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑛 - 𝑠ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑑 𝑏𝑒 𝑚𝑒𝑚𝑜𝑟𝑖𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑠𝑒𝑑 𝑎𝑠 𝑚𝑢𝑐ℎ 𝑎𝑠 𝑎𝑛𝑦 𝑜𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟 𝑝𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑜𝑛. 𝑇ℎ𝑒𝑖𝑟 𝐺𝑟𝑒𝑒𝑘 𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑡𝑠 𝑡𝑜𝑜.“
⠀⠀
What I loved about 𝘼 𝙏𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙨𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙎𝙝𝙞𝙥𝙨 was that it retold mythological classics that I learnt in school in such a compelling and unique way! Perhaps if you weren’t familiar with these fables and some of the characters, you would easily get confused. There is a character list at the beginning of the novel but as I read it on a kindle, I found it hard to flick back to.

I’ve always been drawn to these stories and I loved this one!
⠀⠀
This story is told from multiple perspectives, and tells of before, during and after the battle that raged for so long. The women who lost everything. The women that men and history neglected. And of course, the woman who started it all. ⠀⠀
“...𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑠 𝑖𝑠 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑤𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑛’𝑠 𝑤𝑎𝑟, 𝑗𝑢𝑠𝑡 𝑎𝑠 𝑚𝑢𝑐ℎ 𝑎𝑠 𝑖𝑡 𝑖𝑠 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑚𝑒𝑛’𝑠...𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑝𝑎𝑖𝑛 𝑜𝑓 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑤𝑜𝑚𝑒𝑛 𝑤ℎ𝑜 ℎ𝑎𝑣𝑒 𝑎𝑙𝑤𝑎𝑦𝑠 𝑏𝑒𝑒𝑛 𝑟𝑒𝑙𝑒𝑔𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑑 𝑡𝑜 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑒𝑑𝑔𝑒𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑟𝑦, 𝑣𝑖𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑚𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑚𝑒𝑛, 𝑠𝑢𝑟𝑣𝑖𝑣𝑜𝑟𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑚𝑒𝑛, 𝑠𝑙𝑎𝑣𝑒𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝑚𝑒𝑛...𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑦 ℎ𝑎𝑣𝑒 𝑤𝑎𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑑 𝑙𝑜𝑛𝑔 𝑒𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑔ℎ 𝑓𝑜𝑟 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑖𝑟 𝑡𝑢𝑟𝑛.“

✨THE OTHER PEOPLE ✨ by CJ Tudor 3 1/2 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️💫
⠀⠀ “You’re suppose to do anything for your child. Anything.”
⠀⠀
𝚀: 𝚆𝚑𝚢 𝚊𝚛𝚎 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚌𝚊𝚕𝚕𝚎𝚍 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝙾𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚛 𝙿𝚎𝚘𝚙𝚕𝚎?
𝙰: 𝚆𝚎 𝚊𝚛𝚎 𝚙𝚎𝚘𝚙𝚕𝚎 𝚓𝚞𝚜𝚝 𝚕𝚒𝚔𝚎 𝚢𝚘𝚞. 𝙿𝚎𝚘𝚙𝚕𝚎 𝚝𝚘 𝚠𝚑𝚘𝚖 𝚝𝚎𝚛𝚛𝚒𝚋𝚕𝚎 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚗𝚐𝚜 𝚑𝚊𝚟𝚎 𝚑𝚊𝚙𝚙𝚎𝚗𝚎𝚍. 𝚆𝚎’𝚟𝚎 𝚏𝚘𝚞𝚗𝚍 𝚜𝚘𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎 𝚗𝚘𝚝 𝚒𝚗 𝚏𝚘𝚛𝚐𝚒𝚟𝚎𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚜 𝚘𝚛 𝚏𝚘𝚛𝚐𝚎𝚝𝚝𝚒𝚗𝚐. 𝙱𝚞𝚝 𝚒𝚗 𝚑𝚎𝚕𝚙𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑 𝚘𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚛 𝚏𝚒𝚗𝚍 𝚓𝚞𝚜𝚝𝚒𝚌𝚎. 
Driving home one night, stuck behind a rusty old car, Gabe sees a little girl’s face appear in its rear window. She mouths one word: Daddy. It’s his five-year-old daughter, Izzy. He never sees her again. 
Three years later, Gabe spends his days and nights traveling up and down the highway, searching for the car that took his daughter, refusing to give up hope, even though most people believe she’s dead. “Throughout the year, it seemed, there were events designed to remind the lonely that they were indeed lonely.” Fran and her daughter, Alice, also put in a lot of miles on the road. Not searching. Running. Because Fran knows what really happened to Gabe’s daughter. She knows who is responsible. And she knows what they will do if they ever catch up to her and Alice.

Thriller and horror/supernatural novels are NOT my cup of tea. I find myself thinking “WTF?!” throughout the first quarter of The Other People. Initially confused by how all the characters were intertwined with each other (though I think this is perhaps intentional?), the connecting elements started to come together.
I think I guessed one or two of the twists earlier on, again this could be intentional.

The Other People is really well written, I can definitely see why the author has been compared to Stephen King, and while I didn’t love this novel - I couldn’t put it down because I just had to know what happened!! I could see this being adapted into one of those British crime drama mini-series (which oddly enough, I really like watching..?).

So glad that we are able to buy and have books delivered in New Zealand again! 🎉Huge thanks to the booksellers of NZ for doing what you do and during such testing times! I’ve made purchases 🤫 from my locally owned @paperplusnz and @unitybooksauckland - @booksellersnz have a great list of stores to pick from as well.

✨ LETTERS TO THE EDITOR ✨ by Mo McDonald 2/5 stars ⭐️⭐️
•
•
•
During the 1980s, Jack Kelly was a celebrity broadcaster and successful novelist. His life in the public eye allowed him a privileged position which few experienced, with access to select places and an army of adoring fans. Several decades later, Jack receives a phone call from his secretary. The urgency in her voice stops him in his tracks. A story about Jack has emerged on social media and gone viral. It details his relationship with a young woman, Marian Davies, thirty years previously. The last thing Jack needs is scandal, especially when he's about to embark on an important new career move. As he looks back over the decades since he last saw Marian, to a time before social media when he controlled the narrative, one question remains: why has Marian reappeared?
•
•
•
I don’t have much to say about this book other than I REALLY wanted to enjoy it but I found Letters to the Editor quite dull and old fashioned. It was slow, and extremely character driven throughout. I kinda just wanted it to be over 🤷🏻‍♀️ which is absolutely not what I look for in a book. •
•
•

✨ ATTRACTION ✨ by Ruby Porter 3/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️
•
•
•
The present reckons with the past in Attraction. Porter’s unnamed narrator is on a road trip across New Zealand with her friends Ashi and Ilana, haunted by the specter of her emotionally abusive ex-boyfriend, her complicated family background and New Zealand’s colonial history. Jealousies intensify as the young women work out who they are and who they might become.
•
•
•
I was drawn to this novel because it was written by a New Zealand author and because of that aspect, it felt like I was reading about what I knew. Places. Language.
•
•
•
The unnamed narrator is an unusual aspect but makes this story unique. It was bitsy, hard to read but short and sweet. I could see this being a text studied in high school, it’s something my teachers would’ve had us read. ⠀⠀
A solid three stars for me, thank you to @netgalley and @textpublishing

✨ NAOMI ROSE ✨ by Kirsten Esden
4/5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
•
•
An avid reader, ten year-old Naomi Rose already knows the power of a good story. When her mother dies, Naomi’s emotional struggle is exacerbated by her attempts to appease her father’s demands for self-restraint and composure.
•
•
•
With her father increasing turning to the bottle for solace, Naomi seeks attention elsewhere, devising highly embellished tales to shock her classmates and delight in their reaction. But one tale goes too far and Naomi’s life begins to unravel...
•
•
•
Naomi Rose navigates the life of a troubled teenager well. Losing her mum at a young age, sets the scene for her ongoing actions and behaviour.
•
•
•
The novel jumps from present day, adult Naomi, to ten year-old, to teenager. Adult Naomi questioning if “there is a cut-off point when grief becomes an excuse rather than a justification.” I enjoyed this real, it reminded me of teenage life - the ups and the downs of navigating our way through. It was a short novel (I finished it in a day) and I honestly didn’t know who the ‘Gardner’ was until the last page! An outstanding debut from @kirstenesden “Life does not happen to us. We are not passive bystanders in our own destinies. We choose how to behave, we make decisions, but everything has consequences.”
•
•

✨ PEOPLE LIKE US ✨ by Louise Fein 4/5 Stars ⭐️ ⭐️⭐️⭐️
•
•
Hetty Henrich is a perfect German child. Her father is an SS officer, her brother in the Hitler Youth, training to become a fighter pilot, herself a member of the BDM. She believes resolutely in her country, and the man who runs it.
•
•
•
Until Walter changes everything. Blonde-haired, blue-eyed Walter. The boy who saved her life. A Jew.
As Hetty falls deeply in love with a man who is everything she’s been taught to hate, she will have to risk everything to save him, even if it means sacrificing herself.
•
•
•
Wow. My heart ached after reading this. From the outset you understand that, probably like so many children of the Reich, Hetty doesn’t fully comprehend what is going on in the world around her - or why. There is a vague innocence about it all. That the physical traits between an Ayran child and a Jewish child are difficult to tell. But soon Hetty starts to discover that Walter “oozes otherness”, that looks are deceiving, blood and breeding never lie. 
She decides that Walter is worth the risk. •
•
•
There are themes are sexuality throughout, the different social expectations of genders. Why can a boy do this, but a girl can’t? •
•
•
The author has done an amazing job of describing that not all Germans agreed with the racial hatred regime forced upon them. Hetty begins to learn of the hardships and restrictions placed on Jewish people. Her mind alters and her love for Walter grows. She starts to stand up for her own beliefs, while hiding a number of secrets too.
•
•
•
Stories from this time are rarely written from the “Nazi” point of view, it was heartbreakingly refreshing.
•
•
•
“There are two sides, or more perhaps, to every thought. Every action. We only ever want to see one.”
•
•

✨ THE MURMUR OF BEES ✨ by @sofiasegoviaautora and translated by Simon Bruni @amazonpublishing is set against the backdrop of both the Mexican Revolution and the Spanish Influenza of 1918 (a little bit spooky reading about, given the current circumstances). From the day that old Nana Reja found a baby abandoned, in a blanket covering of bees, little Simonopio is for some locals the stuff of superstition, a child kissed by the devil. He becomes a cause of wonder for his adopted family. Followed by his protective swarm of bees and living to deliver his adopted family from threats, Simonopio’s purpose in time. Will be divined.
.
.
This story is well crafted, with gorgeous prose and a storyline that flows beautifully.  The Murmur of Bees 🐝 is easily one of the most outstanding stories I’ve ever read, you can almost feel and hear the hum of the bees as you read.  I encourage you - if you have not already - to read this masterpiece! .
.

.
.

✨THE MAIDENS✨ 
Happy Pub Day to the highly anticipated sophomore novel by @alex.michaelides !
.
.
#mythoughts :

 “It was written” is the expression in Greek. Meaning, quite simply, from that moment on, their destinies were sealed.”
 - The Maidens 

This is slow-burn goodness. I loved the examination on grief, the Greek references, the Tennyson poetry, and the nod to THE SILENT PATIENT. 
The opening pages introduce us to Mariana, a 36-year old therapist, who is still mourning the loss of her husband a year earlier. 
After a group session one evening, she receives a fevered call from her niece Zoe, at college in Cambridge. A young woman’s body has been found, and Zoe can’t locate her best friend Tara. 
To Cambridge Mariana goes. 
Zoe discloses something alarming about professor Edward Fosca and Mariana is determined to see her nieces fears investigated. When no one takes her seriously, she decides to investigate on her own.

I saw the twist coming but it was still delicious. I absolutely loved the descriptions of Cambridge, and of Greece. There were some tangents I struggled to find relevance in but that’s probably a me issue. Overall I really enjoyed this. 
,
.
Thank you so much to {partner} @celadonbooks for my copy! 
.
.

☕️ WITH TEETH 🦷

It’s Monday so you know what day it is, #coffeeandcurrentlyreading . After finishing THE MAIDENS, I wanted a good family drama. So I picked up WITH TEETH by @kristen__arnett . I’m about a third of the way in and I’m feeling for Sammie. It’s one thing to not be able to bond with your child (I feel like we need to normalize that and encourage seeking help rather than the proverbial “stoning”), but to have a child that won’t bond with you is probably tough. Thus far she really tries. Her wife Monika seems to be losing patience with the situation, but is absent enough to really not see the whole picture and be able to empathize with her wife. And that’s my other beef, women /men who are the full-time caretakers of the family children should be listened to, not brushed off or vilified. 
All of that being said, this book is so good! I am really looking forward to where it goes. Samson is definitely …. unlikable, I know, he’s a kid, I shouldn’t say that, but he’s a bit diabolical. I keep thinking about that movie “The Bad Seed” while I’m reading 👀. 
.
.
Also, let’s hear it for #lbgt representation in fiction 🌈🙌🏼. 
.
.
.
Give me your #lbgtq book recommendations! 🌈🌈
.
.
.

✨NICE GIRLS✨
By: Catherine Dang 
Pub date: 9/7/21
Thank you @williammorrowbooks for my #gifted copy.
✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨

#mythoughts :

This was so good for a debut. I couldn’t put it down, and I loved the author’s writing style. 

Mary was frumpy and not in the least bit cool back in high school. But she works hard in school and gets accepted into Cornell, prompting the local paper in her small town to write an article about her entitled, “Ivy League Mary”. Only then do get classmates take notice of her. And then she’s off, out of her small town, to bigger things. 

Her junior year, everything changes for her in the blink of an eye when she’s expelled from Cornell. She goes home, humiliated, gets a job at a local grocer, a failure. 

When a local girl goes missing, it’s a big deal. This isn’t just any girl, Olivia Willard is a rising influencer and a former friend of Mary’s. Mary can’t help but connect the dots to another missing girl from their town, DeMaria Jackson. 
No one believes her or even gives credence to her ideas. It’s made clear that these are two very different types of girls. Or are they…..?

I found highlighting the way people from different backgrounds and socioeconomic strata are treated by the public and the police to be important and ambitious. 
*(In my own town there are two cases that display this. See: Heidi Seeman and Erica Botello, San Antonio Tx.)*

Also interesting was the notion that when you get down to it, sometimes you’re friends with someone due to proximity and convenience. 

This thriller kept me guessing and I loved the well described atmosphere. 
✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨

Is this one on your radar? If not, I hope I put it there!
Happy Saturday, folks. 
.
.

✨THE CHECKLIST✨
By: Addie Woolridge 
Thank you @booksparks & @montlakeromance_france for my gifted copy.  #SRC2021 
✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨

Dylan Delacroix is successful, has an amazing (if not predictable) boyfriend, and makes lists for EVERYTHING. 
When her boss relocates her to Seattle from Houston, she knows it’s a power move on his part. He didn’t take well to being upstaged on a recent project. 
Dylan is dreading the temporary assignment for so many reasons, namely that Seattle is home. Growing up her family life wasn’t completely stable or secure, hence her need for lists, some sense of order. 
Though this is labeled romance, I found it to be a multi-layered story with some profound moments. This makes a fabulous beach/weekend read, grab it! It’s out now! 
.
.
Do you make lists?? I’m a huge list maker. Though my husband calls me stuck in the last century because I use pads of paper or notebooks and a pen. Old school!
.
.
.

✨THE QUEER PRINCIPLES OF KIT WEBB✨
Happy pub day to this beautiful book! 

Thank you to #partner @avonbooks & @tlcbooktours for my copy of this absolutely delightful #lbgtq romance! 
___________________________________
 “Kit Webb had principles. He was certain of it. Even at his worst, which had reliably been found at the bottom of a bottle, he hadn’t hurt anyone, at least not too badly. Well at least not on purpose. Better, perhaps, to say that he never threw the first punch”. 
___________________________________

Here is the synopsis:

Kit Webb has left his stand-and-deliver days behind him. But dreary days at his coffee shop have begun to make him pine for the heady rush of thievery. When a handsome yet arrogant aristocrat storms into his shop, Kit quickly realizes he may be unable to deny whatever this highborn man desires.

In order to save himself and a beloved friend, Percy, Lord Holland must go against every gentlemanly behavior he holds dear to gain what he needs most: a book that once belonged to his mother, a book his father never lets out of his sight and could be Percy’s savior. More comfortable in silk-filled ballrooms than coffee shops frequented by criminals, his attempts to hire the roughly hewn highwayman, formerly known as Gladhand Jack, proves equal parts frustrating and electrifying.

Kit refuses to participate in the robbery but agrees to teach Percy how to do the deed. Percy knows he has little choice but to submit and as the lessons in thievery begin, he discovers thievery isn’t the only crime he’s desperate to commit with Kit. 

But when their careful plan goes dangerously wrong and shocking revelations threaten to tear them apart, can these stolen hearts overcome the impediments in their path?
✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨

The absolute perfect book for #pridemonth , grab it, it’s adorable. 
.
.
.

✨MONA AT SEA✨
By Elizabeth Gonzalez James
@booksparks #src2021 
Pub date: 6/30/2021
✨
✨
What were you doing during the Recession of 2008? I was 28, and going through a divorce. To be honest I didn’t even notice a recession. My husband on the other hand was a 21 year old college student, who was let go from a retail job, only to find out that there weren’t many jobs. It hit him hard. It actually took him years to recover financially from that era. MONA AT SEA depicts an experience more like my husband’s. 
________________________________________
Synopsis:

Mona is a Millennial perfectionist who fails upwards in the midst of the 2008 economic crisis.

Despite her potential, and her top- of-her-class college degree, Mona finds herself unemployed, living with her parents, and adrift in life and love. Mona’s the sort who says exactly the right thing at absolutely the wrong moments, seeing the world through a cynic’s eyes. In the financial and social malaise of the early 2000s, Mona walks a knife’s edge as she faces down unemployment, underemployment, the complexities of adult relationships, and the downward spiral of her parents’ shattering marriage. The more Mona craves perfection and order, the more she is forced to see that it is never attainable. Mona’s journey asks the question: When we find what gives our life meaning, will we be ready for it? 
________________________________________

I’ve already started this one and it’s so witty and insightful. I am loving it. Thank you to @booksparks for putting in the Summer Bucket List lineup! 
.

✨AFTER FRANCESCO✨

Thank you to #partner @bibliolifestyle & @kensingtonbooks for having me on tour❤️
.
.
“Coinciding with the 40th anniversary of the first reported AIDS cases, a tribute to a generation lost and a powerful, universal exploration of heartbreak and recovery. 
Set in the late 1980’s at the peak of the AIDS crisis….”.
.
.
#mythoughts :

“You walk slowly, my darling boy, you keep your own pace. And those that tell you to move past your grief just don’t understand your journey”. -Aunt Nora

“Be curious first, judgmental a distant second.”- Francesco 

I loved this book so much. It’s a study in grief and loss. Immense loss. It’s 1988 and Kevin Doyle is a gay man living in NYC in the midst of the AIDS epidemic. He’s lost so many friends, but when he loses the love of his life, Francesco (Frankie) his life goes off the rails. Nothing matters anymore, he drinks himself into oblivion, gets fired from his job, and his friends are worried about him. After he nearly dies from alcohol poisoning, his friends know they need to help him make a change. So off he goes to Aunt Nora’s house in small town Minnesota where the memories of being in the closet surround him. 

I loved Aunt Nora. For 1988, and a Catholic, she loves and accepts her nephew in a way that would have been rare and made me cry a few times. I also love that his macho Minnesota best friend Tommy who supports and loves him. I feel like that would have been rare as well. 
This book is beautiful, heartbreaking, uplifting, it’s a little bit of everything. 
.
.
For more of Kevin Doyle’s story, read THE YEAR OF ICE, depicting his senior year of high school and his struggle to stay in the closet. 
.
.

☕️THE TRUTH AND OTHER HIDDEN THINGS - by Lea Geller
.
.
#mythoughts :

I actually laughed at much of this book and it was exactly what I needed. There’s such a great mix of humor and real issues though. Being the same age as the main character made me completely invested in her story.

Bells Walker is 42, finds out she’s pregnant after a failed IUD, and then that her family is moving to a small town called Pigkill. 
She really tries to make the best of things, she’s wanted a bigger place for her growing family, she wants her husband to feel important in the university arena after trying for tenure..... but when she sees the dilapidated home, the savage mom groups, kombucha everywhere (!!!), she’s had enough. 
She starts an anonymous blog about the people in her small town and calls herself the County Dutchess. It’s takes off like wildfire and Bells finally feels important for a change. She’s always sacrificing her wants and needs and boy it feels good to be writing. 
But if comes at a cost. Someone figures out the person behind the blog and all hell breaks loose. 
Personally I wanted her husband to be less self-centered and less selfish, but I think that’s part of the ultimate point. His mother obviously dotes on him, and his brothers success makes him a bit insecure. 

I find the observations Bells makes hilarious, I think overuse of the word millennial is intentional. The end is so sweet, and there is a moment with her teenage son that absolutely made me tear up. I really loved this book, highly recommend if you want a laugh with a side of substance. And maybe to find out what the hell a Bisnut is.
.
.
.
Thank you so much @suzyapprovedbooktours & @leagellerauthor for my spot on this tour. It was truly a delight. 
.
.
.
.

✨WHEN WE WERE ALL STILL ALIVE✨
By: Keith Mcwalter 
✨
@booksparks 
#summerpopup 
✨
This is a book with universal themes like loss, grief, regret, aging. And it tackles them in such a unique way, with dual timelines and a “live in the now” approach. 
✨
Synopsis:

For Conrad Burrell―husband, father, and successful attorney in the autumn of his life―the world has come apart. Having long ago lost his first wife, the mother of his grown daughter and a widow herself, to youth and pride, he’s now lost his second to a violent accident,. “You think you’re finished, that you have no more stories in you,” his ex-wife warns, and he fears she’s right. Within hailing distance of the end of his days, after a lifetime of meeting the expectations of others, none are left but Conrad’s own, and he must discover whether love survives death as well as divorce―whether family memory can redeem individual mortality.

What do we do, then, we widows and widowers for whom there’s nothing left but the world’s permission to stop what we’ve done all our lives? In the cities of his youth, in the deserts of New Mexico, but most of all in a small Pennsylvania town, Conrad finds he has one more lesson in love to learn from the women of his past, and the one woman he's certain he can't live without.
_____________________________________

This is out now for you to grab or order ❤️

MY REMARKABLE JOURNEY 
a memoir by Katherine Johnson 
.
.

The remarkable woman at heart of the smash New York Times bestseller and Oscar-winning film Hidden Figures tells the full story of her life, including what it took to work at NASA, help land the first man on the moon, and live through a century of turmoil and change.

In this memoir, Katherine shares her personal journey from child prodigy in the Allegheny Mountains of West Virginia to NASA human computer. In her life after retirement, she served  as a beacon of light for her family and community alike.  Her story is centered around the basic tenets of her life—no one is better than you, education is paramount, and asking questions can break barriers. The memoir captures the many facets of this unique woman: the curious “daddy’s girl,” pioneering professional, and sage elder. 

This multidimensional portrait is also the record of a century of racial history that reveals the influential role educators at segregated schools and Historically Black Colleges and Universities played in nurturing the dreams of trailblazers like Katherine. The author pays homage to her mentor—the African American professor who inspired her to become a research mathematician despite having his own dream crushed by racism. 
____________________________________
Thank you so much to @tlcbooktours , @tlcdiversity & @amistadbooks for having me on this tour. I am honored to read this incredible woman’s story. 
The book is available now so add it. Seriously ❤️.

.
.
Are you enamored with the moon and the stars and the night sky? I am. To think there are people who have been there is mind blowing.

🌴THE GUNCLE🌴
By: Steven Rowley 
Happy pub day to this beautiful book! 
Many thanks to @booksparks #SRC2021 & @putnambooks {partner} for my copy.
.
.
For my first favorite quote, head on over to @cozy.coffee.reads review, but here’s my second favorite quote from the book:

“Guncle rule number seven: In this house we wear what we want. It doesn’t matter if it’s for boys or girls..... We don’t worry about what others think. Deal?”
.
.
There are so many moments I could choose from, but as the momma of a six-year old boy who asked me for hot pink shorts and pink shirt to match, we are no strangers to being judged for stupid crap. 
I digress. 

Everyone needs a Guncle (gay uncle) Patrick. A TV star on hiatus who has methodically pushed everyone away after losing the love of his life, he’s not exactly in a good place.
When his brothers wife passes away and he goes home for the funeral, he’s confronted with the shock that the same brother is a pill addict. 
Along with that he’s, going into treatment straight away and wants Patrick to watch over his two children Maisie and Grant for ninety days. 
Patrick can’t think of a worse idea or a worse person for such a task but he relents. The slow transformation between these three grieving people is stunning and there’s so much levity to offset the sad. I laughed so many times. I also cried. 
I’m not sure if I could have loved this one more. I was so impressed with Patrick’s sense of duty, it took my breath away. 
Grab this. You need it. You’re welcome. 
.
.
.

Ok, it’s actually leftover French Toast from @maxandlouies because it’s so delicious I rationed it. If you’re in #SanAntonio , give this place a try because everything is good.

This book though! Thank you @henryholtbooks for my copy of RIDGELINE , it is post Civil War fiction at it’s finest. 
.
.
Synopsis: 

In 1866, with the country barely recovered from the Civil War, new war breaks out on the western frontier―a clash of cultures between the Native tribes who have lived on the land for centuries and a young, ambitious nation. Colonel Henry Carrington arrives in Wyoming’s Powder River Valley to lead the US Army in defending the opening of a new road for gold miners and settlers. Carrington intends to build a fort in the middle of critical hunting grounds, the home of the Lakota. Red Cloud, one of the Lakota’s most respected chiefs, and Crazy Horse, a young but visionary warrior, understand full well the implications of this invasion. For the Lakota, the stakes are their home, their culture, their lives.

As fall bleeds into winter, Crazy Horse leads a small war party that confronts Colonel Carrington’s soldiers with near constant attacks. Red Cloud, meanwhile, wants to build the tribal alliances that he knows will be necessary to defeat the soldiers. Colonel Carrington seeks to hold together a US Army beset with internal discord. Carrington’s officers are skeptical of their commander’s strategy, none more so than Lieutenant George Washington Grummond, who longs to fight a foe he dismisses as inferior in all ways. The rank-and-file soldiers, meanwhile, are still divided by the residue of civil war, and tempted to desertion by the nearby goldfields. 
____________________________________

Based on real people, this one releases on June 1. Also, it’s the same author as THE REVENANT. 
.
.
Whatcha got goin’ on today?
.
.
.
.

✨LITTLE PIECES OF ME✨
 
Thank you to @getredprbooks & @williammorrowbooks for my gifted copy. 
.
.
#mythoughts :
So those DNA tests.... so easy these days. And helpful, you can find cousins, even put away killers. 
In this book though, Paige Meyer finds out her beloved father, isn’t. A genealogy site tells her a certain Andy Abrams is her biological father. Her world is upended, and when she asks her mother Betsy, all is denied.
There is a switch between timelines throughout the book. College student Betsy Kaplan is dating sweet but boring Mark. Enter Andy who is popular, gregarious, a ladies man. Everything that her Betsy’s best friend Sissy wants for her. But Andy has secrets that he wants to keep hidden. One night he and Betsy decide to throw caution to the wind....
.
. 
.
I love Paige’s best friends, Maks and Margaux, they are so supportive. I somewhat understand Betsy, can’t judge too much, it’s an impossible situation I think. Overall I loved this book so much, Allison Hammer is definitely an auto-buy for me.
.
.
. 
Have you taken one of those genealogy tests? I plan on it. My sister did and found out some of her heritage is in Africa. We have different fathers so I’m curious to see what the differences will be.
.

.

✨CRYING IN H MART✨ 
By: Michelle Zauner 

I am not the hugest fan of memoirs, but this one is so unique. It combines family, food, grief, and love. 

Excerpt:

Every dish I cooked exhumed a memory. Every scent and taste brought me back for a moment to an unravaged home. Knife-cut noodles in chicken broth took me back to lunch at Myeongdong Gyoja after an afternoon of shopping, the line so long it filled a flight of stairs, extended out the door, and wrapped around the building. The kalguksu so dense from the rich beef stock and starchy noodles it was nearly gelatinous. My mother ordering more and more refills of their famously garlic- heavy kimchi. My aunt scolding her for blowing her nose in public. 
 
Crispy Korean fried chicken conjured bachelor nights with Eunmi. Licking oil from our fingers as we chewed on the crispy skin, cleansing our palates with draft beer and white radish cubes as she helped me with my Korean homework. Black- bean noodles summoned Halmoni slurping jjajangmyeon takeout, huddled around a low table in the living room with the rest of my Korean family. 
__________________________________________________
.
Thank you so much to @booksparks @aaknopf for my gifted book and for including it in the #SRC2021 lineup. It’s out now and I highly recommend you grab it. 
.
.
Is food part of how you access your memories? It is for me. Sometimes I close my eyes and see myself in the kitchen with my grandma, chopping celery for the Thanksgiving stuffing. 
.
.
.

THE MOTHERS
Out now! 
SYNOPSIS: 

Grace and Dan Arden are in their forties and have been on the IVF treadmill since the day they got married. Six attempts have yielded no results, and with each failure a little piece of their hope dies. 

Priya Laghari and her husband Nick Archer are being treated at the same fertility clinic, and while they don’t face the same time pressure as the Ardens, the younger couple have their own problems. 

On the same day that Priya is booked for her next IVF cycle, Grace goes in for her final, last-chance embryo transfer. Two weeks later, both women get their results. 

A year on, angry and heartbroken, one of the women learns her embryo was implanted in the other’s uterus and must make a devastating choice: live a childless life knowing her son is being raised by strangers or seek custody of a baby who has been nurtured and loved by another couple. 
_________________________________________
So the crazy part about this book is that it’s based on the true story of an IVF lab mixup. I cannot imagine. I’m only a quarter through this but I can say that this is compelling right off.

GIRL IN THE WALLS 
By A.J. Gnuse
Thank you to @bibliolifestyle & @eccobooks for my gifted copy!
.
.
No matter how unlikely the story is, this is such a unique premise. Plus, I pretty much love when I have to suspend disbelief, It’s one of my favorite devices. So here is another great coming-of-age novel to enjoy. 
.
.
Synopsis:
A mesmerizing and suspenseful coming-of-age novel about an orphan hiding within the walls of her former family home—and about what it means to be truly seen after becoming lost in life. 

Eventually, every hidden thing is found. 

Elise knows every inch of the house. She knows which boards will creak. She knows where the gaps are in the walls. She knows which parts can take her in, hide her away. It’s home, after all. The home her parents made for her, before they were taken from her in a car crash. And home is where you stay, no matter what. 

Eddie is a teenager trying to forget about the girl he sometimes sees out of the corner of his eye. But when his hotheaded older brother senses her, too, they are faced with the question of how to get rid of someone they aren’t sure even exists. And as they try to cast her out, they unwittingly bring an unexpected and far more real threat to their doorstep. 
_____________________________________
This published on May 11, so it’s out for you to grab!

THE ESSENCE OF NATHAN BIDDLE
By: J. William Lewis
Publishing on 6/1/2021
Thank you to @tlcbooktours & @greenleafbookgr for my gifted copy of this gorgeous book. 
.
.
Synopsis:

Protagonist Kit Biddle is a rising prep school senior who finds himself tangled in a web of spiritual quandaries and intellectual absurdities. Kit’s angst is compounded by a unique psychological burden he is forced to carry: his intelligent but unstable Uncle Nat has committed an unspeakable act on what, according to the Uncle’s deranged account, were direct orders from God.

The tragedy haunting his family follows Kit like a dark and foreboding cloud, exacerbating his already compulsive struggle with existential questions about the meaning of his life. When the brilliant, perhaps phantasmic, Anna dismisses him, Kit quickly spirals into despair and self-destruction. But when his irrational decision to steal a maintenance truck and speed aimlessly down the highway ends in a horrific accident and months of both physical and emotional convalescence, Kit is forced to examine his perceptions of his life and his version of reality.
_______________________________________
There’s something lovely about the coming-of-age sub genre, they always end up being my favorite books. I hope you grab this one❤️

☕️ I love you @nurse_bookie & @norma_gindi for including me in the tour for “I’m not a psychologist, but I do have a PhD in motherhood”
.
.
MOM GUILT IS REAL, PEOPLE!!! 
I’ll be blunt, I don’t feel guilty or second guess a damn thing I do. I don’t have regrets or lingering thoughts about much—— except parenting! Now, here’s the thing, I parent with mental illness piggybacking, so I am constantly reassessing my approach, my responses, my lack of interest in my son’s four hours of Beyblade tournaments....
.
.
With chapters like: 
Discipline, Respect, Social Connections, the book is extremely easy to navigate. The section on mom guilt made me feel so much better. 
There is a section called “What Does Acceptance Look Like?”. 
Well people I cried a little bit. Because sometimes I lose sight of my beautiful son in all of his glory, this miracle I finally was able to have, just because he won’t listen to something I’ve asked him to do several times😑. Yea, I’ve had a shit year, I’m sad, a lot. I fear that my son suffers from my own inadequacies and limitations. Depression is very limiting. 
But this little book was enough for me to feel like enough for that moment.
I really will recommend this to every parent I know. And maybe some of you all are really really confident, well rounded parents. Well I think I’d still recommend it because it has so many little gems that I think are universal. 
.
.
Thank you for coming to my Ted-talk lol. No seriously, thank you all for being my soundboard and for reading my ramblings and always being kind. I love this community ❤️
.
.
.

☕️RUNAWAY TRAIN☕️
By: Lee Matthew Goldberg 
Thanks to @tlcbooktours & @wisewolfbooks for my gifted book.
.
.
Full disclosure: I love anything set in the nineties. I graduated high school in 1997 so Nico is right around my age as this begins in 1993 and she’s 16. I absolutely loved every 90’s reference. Loved! The music especially because it completely consumed my existence back then. This book brought back vivid memories for me. However I was completely different from Nico in pretty much every way. I was pretty straight-laced I even called my mom to pick me up from parties when I felt like things weren’t safe or a good idea.
I also called her when we skipped school to give her the address of where we went because safety people! I know, I was an odd mix of safety first and school sucks.
Ok onto the book.
.
.
Synopsis:

They told me I was an out-of-control train about to crash…

Everything changed when the police officer knocked on the door to tell me – a 16-year-old – that my older sister Kristen had died of a brain aneurysm. Cue the start of my parents neglecting me and my whole life spiraling out of control.

I decided now was the perfect time to skip town. It’s the early 90’s, Kurt Cobain runs the grunge music scene and I just experienced some serious trauma. What’s a girl supposed to do? I didn’t want to end up like Kristen, so I grabbed my bucket list, turned up my mixtape of the greatest 90’s hits and fled L.A.. The goal was to end up at Kurt Cobain’s house in Seattle, but I never could have guessed what would happen along the way. 
_______________________________________________
Man, I miss my Docs. 
Alright, what year did y’all graduate high school? I feel like I’m an older #bookstagrammer . 
.
.
.

📖 LAST ONE AT THE PARTY 📖
“Once experienced, panic attacks and depression never truly leave you; even if they aren’t physically there, the memory is, like an imprint in concrete”. 
.
.
I could not put this book down! Thank you so much to @hodderstoughton & @beth_writes_stuff for my gifted copy.
.
.
Onto my thoughts.... I rarely read post-apocalyptic literature. At least the new stuff, but I need to change that. Because this was completely immersive. 
The year is 2024 and a plague called 6DM has eradicated the entire population as far as our unnamed narrator knows. She’s selfish, uncertain, flawed, more hotel than live off the land- she’s most of us. Which is what made this book a freakin’ page-turner. I don’t think I’d be remiss to say that this might not be the read for everyone, it’s pretty gruesome, there’s a certain rat incident that made my skin crawl, plus the sheer reality of what the body count would be and what that would mean is very well laid out. 
We get glimpses of the narrators previous life through her journaling. Her relationships with her parents, best friends, her husband. And I think a lot of people won’t like her. However she’s as real as it gets. A few times I thought, that’s daft, at some of her choices, both before and after the apocalypse. Then I reframed it in my own personal terms and let me tell you, as far as post-apocalyptic goes, she’d beat me in a second. 
I think the big thing to consider is who are you when there’s no one to impress, no social mores, nothing to tell you what to be anymore..... and maybe some of the things she does will shock the reader, but I find them pretty realistic. Plus she’s someone with mental health issues and I completely appreciate that facet of her story. 
.
.
I hope some of you grab this one, I found it to be the book I didn’t know I needed to read. 
What is a book that surprised you? 
.
.
.
.

✨Book Review✨
HER LAST HOLIDAY 
By C.L. Taylor
Thank you to {partner} @harpercollins , @tlcbooktours @cltaylorauthor 
☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️☕️

#mythoughts :
CL Taylor’s books have been on my Amazon wishlist for a long time, so when presented with a tour I jumped! And I wasn’t disappointed. 
.
.
When Fran’s sister Jenna disappeared two years ago on a retreat, it fractured her family. And her if she’s being honest. A large age difference and vast personality differences meant that Fran didn’t get as close to her as she would have liked. 
Her regret, complied with nagging questions propel Fran into uncharted territory, desperate to get answers about her sister. So she signs up for a retreat run by the same duo that lost three people, including Jenna two years ago, Tom Wade and and Kate. 

Tom served his time in prison for the disaster that happened, but before that he was the head of Soul Shrink, which had a massive social media following and many devout fans. Kate pushes him to restart the idea and so a new retreat is born. The very one that Fran is on.

I loved Fran’s can-do personality, and felt really sad for the space she put between herself and people in general.
Jenna just seemed like she needed direction. Both the women’s issues stemming from different parental expectations. 

Tom was a weakling, I didn’t like him. But I kinda liked not liking him. Kate reminded me of Marla from the “I Care A lot” Movie. 

Throughout the book I suspected pretty much everyone so I loved that it kept me guessing. I did not see the end coming!
Loved this one, can’t want to read more by Taylor. 
This one published on 4/27, so you can grab it now!
That cover😍
.
.
.

By: Camille Pagán
Thank you {partners: @uplitreads @camillepagan } for my #gifted book.

About the book:

It’s been thirteen years since doctors declared Libby Ross-Velasquez a goner. Yet here she is―cancer free. So why doesn’t she feel more alive?

Sure, Libby’s husband, Shiloh, has been distant. One of their daughters has a serious health condition. And her father’s death hovers over Libby like a rain cloud. Still, this eternal optimist knows she’s the winner of the existential lottery.

But when her forced cheer isn’t enough to keep her family from catching her blahs, she decides to fly them all to Vieques. The Puerto Rican island is where she and Shiloh fell in love―and where she decided to fight for her life after her cancer diagnosis. Where better to put their problems into perspective?

Then a tropical storm strikes. Libby pretends everything’s fine, even as she fears she’s doomed her family. What she can’t see is that the worst disaster they’ve faced may be the best thing that ever happened to them. But first, they have to get through it.
__________________________________________________

Ok, I so only started reading This Won’t End Well, as well as Don’t Make Me Turn This Life Around, but I love Camille pagán’s writing! It’s fun, witty, heartfelt, everything you need right now. 
Have you read any of her books?
Which is your favorite?

Daniel Abe, a young doctor in Chicago is finally coming back to Hawai'i. He has his own reason for returning to his childhood home, but it is not to revisit the past, unlike his Uncle Koji. Koji lives with the memories of Daniel’s mother, Mariko, the love of his life, and the scars of a life hard-lived. He can’t wait to see Daniel, who he’s always thought of as a son, but he knows the time has come to tell him the truth about his mother, and his father. But Daniel’s arrival coincides with the awakening of the Mauna Loa volcano, and its dangerous path toward their village stirs both new and long ago passions in their community.

Alternating between past and present—from the day of the volcano eruption in 1935 to decades prior—The Color of Airinterweaves the stories of Daniel, Koji, and Mariko to create a rich, vibrant, bittersweet chorus that celebrates their lifelong bond to one other and to their immigrant community. As Mauna Loa threatens their lives and livelihoods, it also unearths long held secrets simmering below the surface that meld past and present, revealing a path forward for them all.

_______________________________________________
The writing in this is so vivid and descriptive, the story so multi-layered, I’m enjoying lingering on each page. 
.
.
Happy Sunday everyone ❤️
.
.
.
.
