☕️📖 Happy Pub day to this deliciously twisted book and thank you to @williammorrowbooks for my gifted copy. 
.
.
Ive always loved anything that has to do with boarding school. Even though I was the kid who’d call my mom to pick me up from a slumber party, I romanticized the notion of boarding school. I’d imagine myself on some north eastern campus, fall foliage, staring out my dorm window, writing from an antique desk..... 
.
.
This book isn’t that at all 😏.
.
.
Book synopsis:

Can we ever really escape our past?

The girls of St John the Divine, an elite English boarding school, were notorious for flipping their hair, harassing teachers, chasing boys, and chain-smoking cigarettes. They were fiercely loyal, sharp-tongued, and cuttingly humorous in the way that only teenage girls can be. For Josephine, now in her thirties, the years at St John were a lifetime ago. She hasn’t spoken to another Divine in fifteen years, not since the day the school shuttered its doors in disgrace.

Yet now Josephine inexplicably finds herself returning to her old stomping grounds. The visit provokes blurry recollections of those doomed final weeks that rocked the community. Ruminating on the past, Josephine becomes obsessed with her teenage identity and the forgotten girls of her one-time orbit. With each memory that resurfaces, she circles closer to the violent secret at the heart of the school’s scandal. But the more Josephine recalls, the further her life unravels, derailing not just her marriage and career, but her entire sense of self. 
____________________________________
This book is compulsively readable and you just keep turning pages. I opened it and sat there for a good half of an hour, just lost in the story. So grab it today, put it on your #tbr !
I’ve never known anyone who’s gone to boarding school, have you?
.
.
.
.

@booksparks #WRC2021 Book Feature! 
.
.
Burnt Sugar 
By: @avnidoshi 
@overlookpress 
Publishing on 1/26/21

.
.
About the book:

NPR Best Book of 2020 

“I would be lying if I say my mother’s misery has never given me pleasure,” says Antara, Tara’s now-adult daughter. 
In her youth, Tara was wild. She abandoned her marriage to join an ashram, and while Tara is busy as a partner to the ashram’s spiritual leader, Baba, little Antara is cared for by an older devotee, Kali Mata, an American who came to the ashram after a devastating loss. Tara also embarks on a stint as a beggar (mostly to spite her affluent parents) and spends years chasing a disheveled, homeless artist, all with young Antara in tow. But now Tara is forgetting things, and Antara is an adult––an artist and married––and must search for a way to make peace with a past that haunts her as she confronts the task of caring for a woman who never cared for her. 

Sharp as a blade and laced with caustic wit, Burnt Sugar unpicks the slippery, choking cord of memory and myth that binds mother and daughter. Is Tara’s memory loss real? Are Antara’s memories fair? In vivid and visceral prose, Tibor Jones South Asia Prize–winning writer Avni Doshi tells a story, at once shocking and empathetic, about love and betrayal between a mother and a daughter. A journey into shifting memories, altering identities, and the subjective nature of truth, Burnt Sugar is a stunning and unforgettable debut.

.
.
.

Synopsis:

When Tara Peary’s twin sister Sophie goes missing, Tara dives into New York’s underbelly to find her. Sophie is the one person who’s ever truly understood her, and Tara knows her sister isn’t the only one who needs help.

Tara is also on the run emotionally from her complicated childhood. Her memories are threatening to overwhelm her emotions and derail the hunt for Sophie. A psychotherapist keeps her afloat, but when Tara begins dating her therapist’s young tech-millionaire neighbor, she risks losing the only lifelines she has left.

The more Tara uncovers about her sister’s disappearance and the dark side of the rich elite, the less certain of the truth she becomes. As Tara reaches the center of the mystery, spanning from her childhood home in Georgia to a Southern California beach, she has to decide whether the truth is a price she’s willing to pay.
———————————————————
This one publishes on 2/2/21. It’s an intense psychological thriller that I found a little hard to get through. Some triggers (rape, childhood trauma), but definitely worth a read if you want a dark, twisty thriller.

☕️📖👁 #coffeeandcurrentlyreading . Monday my friends. It’s a day for coffee by the gallon. 
So #TheMinders by @johnmarrs.author , thank you so much to @berkleypub & @netgalley for my copy to review. 
This is absolutely in my top ten anticipated books of 2021. 
.
I am a huge fan of John Marrs, his futuristic novels feel like episodes of Black Mirror. The perfect blend of a thrilling, nuanced plot, combined with a reckoning that technology has its limits. And as with anything, too much of it is definitely a bad thing. 
In The Minders, countries are in danger of being hacked by an organization that wants their deepest, darkest secrets. The UK develops an initiative to store its security secrets within the minds of five humans. Humans can’t be hacked, they can be trained to be soldiers for the government. What could go wrong? Well humans are fallible and .... human. Fellow Marrs fans will be happy to know that plot elements from both “The Passengers” and “The One” make it into this book, weaving it into a fantastic semi-extension. But make no mistake, this is a stand-alone with the twists, turns and ultimate horror that you’d expect. 
The Minders is available on 2/16/21 and I highly recommend adding it you your #tbr . 
.
.
.
.
.

☕️👁📖 #thrillerthursday .... Today is my stop on @suzyapprovedbooktours for #CoverYourTracks by @dacoauffenorde . Synopsis in comments. 
.

My thoughts: 
Woah this is a break-neck thriller! No pun intended. The author wastes absolutely no time getting into the story. The first few pages put you right into the middle of Margot and Nicks situation and doesn’t let up. The story alternates between Margot and Nick’s past starting from childhood. They each had fairly traumatic upbringings, in different ways, and it’s clear they have been shaped by their trauma. But they’ve also moved past it, surpassing their parents low expectations. The big twists I somewhat saw coming but that made it no less of a page turner. I really liked this book, I always appreciate a full backstory in any book. 4⭐️
.
.
Thank you to @suzyapprovedbooktours and @dacoauffenorde for my spot on this tour! 
.
.
.
.

January is #cervicalcancer awareness month. Teal is the color, so I’m stacking for my sister and for everyone living with this diagnosis. 
Get screened. I know if you don’t have health insurance that may be an obstacle. But there are many free resources for women’s health, your city probably has a program or two. 
.
It’s been over a year since my sister was diagnosed and everything has changed. 
For me, there’s life before her diagnosis, and after. There’s a very clear divide. I can’t look at photos from the before very easily. My sister isn’t a complainer, so it’s even worse when she smiles through pain and fear and everything else she deals with. 
.
.
Just get your pap, know your risks, prevention and early detection ✅✅.
.
.
Though nothing is ever certain for anyone, I’m choosing to believe my sister is on the road to remission. Any positive thoughts, prayers , we welcome them all! 
.
.
.

☕️📖 I loved “The Silent Treatment” by @abbiegreavesauthor so much that when I saw she had a new book coming out, I knew I had to read it. And it didn’t disappoint. It’s heartbreaking, tragic and lovely. 
.
. 
Mary waits at the train station every day, holding a sign, “Come Home Jim”. It’s a curious sight but no one pays her any mind until she causes a bit of a ruckus and a young journalist, Alice, knows there’s a story there. What’s more is she connects with Mary on a personal level. She knows the pain of losing someone in the blink of an eye. She resolves to find Jim, to give Mary closure. 
The story asks the questions, how much do we really know about anyone, how long can we hang on to love, how much do we choose to leave out when we look at our loved ones? 
I suppose this is a romance, it absolutely has that aspect. But more it’s a story of self-discovery and triumph over loss. It’s is an achingly beautiful book and I will read anything Abbie Greaves writes forevermore. 
#AnywhereForYou comes out on 4/6/21. Add it to your #wishlist ❤️
.
.
.
.

☕️🎆🎊📖 So here it is. My first book of #2021 , finished that 3 am. Good time, it’s a song. I digress.
I still don’t quite know how I feel about it. Most of the time I’d tell you that I love when a book is referenced in another book. If you’ve read this one, you’ll know of what I speak. However in this, I didn’t feel like I could love it. The characters felt a little one-dimensional to me, I didn’t like any of them. Albert Bitterman felt by far, the most fleshed out. I will say it’s a great thriller if you haven’t read one or are just getting into them. 
I know a lot of you loved it so I’m very much in the minority and that’s ok. It’s ok to just like (or even hate) a book that everyone loves. 
Happy 2021! To better times ahead. 
.
.
.
. 
.

☕️📚 Ok I really couldn’t pick just ten so here are my #top20of2020 ! Every one of these books made me feel something, think, research further, or just plain gave me enjoyment. I feel like we needed books more than ever this year. 
As for 2021, I hope to read a lot. But the only thing I want is my sisters’ health. I think for most people 2020 was the year of the Coronavirus, and indeed it was for our family as well. 
But more so it was a year where we watched my beautiful sister wage a war against a vicious cancer and we really thought it would be over, this war. Things didn’t turn out that way. So here’s to 2021 and the cancer warriors out there. But especially my sister, who I’m definitely overbearing with, but I just don’t know any other way to be😂❤️. 
.
.

@bookmarked 
Synopsis:

Raffy has a passion for bedazzling. Not just bedazzling, but sewing, stitching, draping, pattern making―for creation. He's always chosen his art over everything―and everyone―else and is determined to make his mark at this year's biggest cosplay competition. If he can wow there, it could lead to sponsorship, then art school, and finally earning real respect for his work. There's only one small problem... Raffy's ex-boyfriend, Luca, is his main competition.

Raffy tried to make it work with Luca. They almost made the perfect team last year after serendipitously meeting in the rhinestone aisle at the local craft store―or at least Raffy thought they did. But Luca's insecurities and Raffy's insistence on crafting perfection caused their relationship to crash and burn. Now, Raffy is after the perfect comeback, one that Luca can't ruin.

But when Raffy is forced to partner with Luca on his most ambitious build yet, he'll have to juggle unresolved feelings for the boy who broke his heart, and his own intense self-doubt, to get everything he's ever wanted: choosing his art, his way.
—————————————————————-

#FayeFaraway by #HelenFisher:

- Faye is a thirty-seven-year-old happily married mother of two young daughters. Every night, before she puts them to bed, she whispers to them: “You are good, you are kind, you are clever, you are funny.” She’s determined that they never doubt for a minute that their mother loves them unconditionally. After all, her own mother Jeanie had died when she was only seven years old and Faye has never gotten over that intense pain of losing her.

But one day, her life is turned upside down when she finds herself in 1977, the year before her mother died. Suddenly, she has the chance to reconnect with her long-lost mother, and even meets her own younger self, a little girl she can barely remember. Jeanie doesn’t recognize Faye as her daughter, of course, even though there is something eerily familiar about her...

As the two women become close friends, they share many secrets—but Faye is terrified of revealing the truth about her identity. Will it prevent her from returning to her own time and her beloved husband and daughters? What if she’s doomed to remain in the past forever? Faye knows that eventually she will have to choose between those she loves in the past and those she loves in the here and now, and that knowledge presents her with an impossible choice.
—————————————————-
This one comes out on 1/26/21 so add it to your lists! I’m obsessed with the premise. I don’t live with regret at all, but some of the people most dear to me are gone. What I wouldn’t give to go back, even for a day. 
.
.
If you could go back in time, for any reason, would you? 
.
.
.
.

🎁🎄☕️ Well I took a much needed break and I hope you are all fabulous. How was your Christmas??? I love Christmas. I relate to Buddy the Elf so closely, I scream “I know him!” when I even hear the word Santa.
.
.
But I’m a mom now. And it’s soooo amazing to pass that on to my son. And to watch his face on Christmas morning and just everything is magical.
.
.
Lemme tell you how my Christmas Eve went. 
My son was so anxious about not falling asleep for Santa to come that HE DIDN’T FALL ASLEEP........
.
.
Santa had to come in the fifteen minutes here and there when sleep finally came. Then he’d pop up and ask if it was daytime. I swear, if you want to torture a tired parent, I’ll rent my son out. Cause damn he’s good. 
It all ended up being a beautiful day, my sister was released from the hospital, my husband and I were delirious from fatigue Lolol.
.
.
This mug! I opened it and said YESSS! I’m using it year round. It’s applicable. Christmas is still so lovely and I can’t wait until next year. Hopefully my son falls asleep. On the real, being the parents of a high needs, autistic child has completely changed our notion of what to expect from parenthood. In a good way. It’s tough, but I’d never trade it. So, Merry day after Christmas everyone! Love to all❤️.
.
.
.
.
.

📚🎄☕️ I’m here for all the cozy Sunday vibes. In reality I’m eating Cheerios from the box and watching “Inside Out” with my son while my husband wraps Santa gifts. With a cuppa in my hand at all times. 
.
.
Ok so #TheMidnightLibrary is such a fan favorite, you can’t see it but I have little pink sticky tabs all over my copy. Such poignant gems, @mattzhaig is no stranger to mental health issues and I loved it. I love his writing. So I bought #HowToStopTime ! @cozy.coffee.reads recommended it so I had to. I defer to the great donut goddess. 
.
.
I haven’t read Addie La Rue but this books premise has that vibe. Tom Hazzard has a rare condition that ages him very slowly, as in he looks 41 but has been alive for centuries. He has one rule, never fall in love. But alas, he breaks his own rule and must decide whether to stay stuck in the past or finally begin living in the present. 
.
.
That’s all paraphrased but it sounds so good. I’m currently reading “Me Before You” and it’s the first thing that has really held all of my attention in a really long time. I don’t like romance all that much but I do like stories about the human condition. Love seems to be the common thread. The thing that saves us from being savage. 
.
.
Are you ready for Christmas?? FIVE MORE DAYS!!!!!!!!!!
.
.
.

📚☕️ “Different Seasons” , some of my absolute favorite movies have come from this book and I’ve never read it. Which I decided to remedy immediately. The movie (Stand By Me) gave me one of the most poignant quotes: 
“I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?”. 
.
.
For me it’s been true. My best friend Ryan is the best friend I’ll ever have. We were born four months apart, across the street from each other. He went a vastly different direction by the time we were teens and passed away when we were 24. But 12, 12 were our heydays. 
.
.
Shawshank Redemption and Apt Pupil also came from this book. But I’ll be starting with “The Body” which spawned Stand by me”. 
.
.
My sister got me a plant baby! @traderjoes had these little potted pretties outside and Phi bought us one each. I’m really going to try to keep this one not dead😁. 
.
.

☕️📖
#BookReview :
“The Dead Season” by Tessa Wegert 
@berkleypub 
.
.
My thoughts:
To say this book is atmospheric would be an understatement. The upstate New York  small town setting and Swanton Vermont are vivid. 
Shana Merchant is still on leave after a traumatic kidnapping and torture at the hands of serial killer Blake Bram. In a few short days, Shana finds out her long lost uncle was in fact murdered twenty years before, and a child goes missing from a tourist spot while on a class trip. She knows they are related, Bram taunts her and follows her. In order to save a child, she must play Bram’s game and win in time. The past that she’s tried so hard to forget is her only key to figuring everything out.
.
.
Wow I loved this book. The writing is phenomenal, I couldn’t put it down. 
5 big old ⭐️. 
Thank you so much to @suzyapprovedbooktours for my spot on this tour!
.
.
.
.

SYNOPSIS:

Emma loves her life. She’s the mother of a precocious kindergartener, married to her soulmate—a loyal and loving police detective—and has a rewarding career as a doctor at the local hospital. 

But everything comes crashing down when her son, Josh, is diagnosed with a rare form of cancer. 

Determined to save him, Emma makes the risky decision to sell opioids to fund the life-saving treatment he needs. But when somebody ends up dead, a lethal game of cat and mouse ensues, her own husband leading the chase. With her son’s life hanging in the balance, Emma is dragged into the dark world of drugs, lies, and murder. Will the truth catch up to her before she can save Josh?

SYNOPSIS: 
Have you ever been wrong about someone? 

Juno was wrong about Winnie Crouch. 

Before moving in with the Crouch family, Juno thought Winnie and her husband, Nigel, had the perfect marriage, the perfect son—the perfect life. Only now that she’s living in their beautiful house, she sees the cracks in the crumbling facade are too deep to ignore. 

Still, she isn’t one to judge. After her grim diagnosis, the retired therapist simply wants a place to live out the rest of her days in peace. But that peace is shattered the day Juno overhears a chilling conversation between Winnie and Nigel… 

She shouldn’t get involved. 

She really shouldn’t. 

But this could be her chance to make a few things right. 

Because if you thought Juno didn’t have a secret of her own, then you were wrong about her, too.

🎉Happy Pub- day to @rachelmansmckenny and her absolutely gorgeous book #TheButterflyEffect !! Today is also my @suzyapprovedbooktours review so here it goes. 
.
.
My thoughts:
Greta is a little bristly, perhaps even unlikeable? But she’s ok with that. She prefers bugs to humans any day. While in the rainforest doing her PhD research, she gets word that her twin brother, Danny has had an aneurysm. So home she goes. Home is Midwest America, the last place Greta wants to be. But she loves her brother, not so much Meg his fiancé but that’s family right? Some you like, some you tolerate. 
Greta seems to push everyone away, including her mother, we also find out that she and Danny had a difficult upbringing. Greta feels guilty that she wasnt there when her dad died, her mom wasn’t there for them.
Greta seems many things, one of them is redeemable. And this is just from my own personal experience, but from the start I wondered if she was on the Autism Spectrum. 
I absolutely loved the way this played out, loved how Greta became more than her eccentricities, there is such beauty in the writing. I love a unique protagonist. I loved Greta.
4⭐️.
.
.
.
Thank you so much to @suzyapprovedbooktours & @alcovepress for my spot on this tour! 
.
.
Do you love quirky protagonists??
.
.
.

❤️📖 #BookReview :
The Watcher by @jenniferpashley 
Publisher: @crookedlanebooks 
.
.
My thoughts:
I really liked this dark, atmospheric domestic thriller. 
Set in small-town upstate New York, everything played out like a movie while I read. Maybe that’s how good Pashley is at vivid description. 
We get two points of view, that of seasoned detective Kateri Fisher, and that of Shannon Jenkins, a drop out teen who had to grow up far too quickly.
Since this is the second in a series, we get a few references to Kateri’s past which I really enjoyed. I love seeing a well faceted, fleshed out character. 
Shannon’s parts are heartbreaking. He’s almost metaphorically cut off at the legs before he even has a chance in the world. An addicted mother, a secret sister, and bills to pay. He meets a handsome stranger in the diner he works for and things finally seem to be turning around for him financially. 
Until the day blood is found everywhere in the home he shares with his mother , and his secret sister is found hiding in a closet. The obvious culprit to everyone seems to be Shannon, but Kateri has a nose for depravity and she has a feeling they need to look further than the scared teenager in front of them.
I really love how this one wrapped up and I’m hoping it’s not the last we see of Kateri.
.
.
.
Thank you so much to @suzyapprovedbooktours for my spot on this tour!
.
.
.

.

SYNOPSIS:

High Fidelity meets The Magicians in this ‘90s punk rock fantasy by triple threat guitarist, author, and Hugo Award–winning editor Jason Heller.

Peter, a punk rock guitar player with OCD tendencies—It’s why everyone calls him rePeter—works at The Wax Rack, a record store in Denver. Pete has a talent he couldn’t understand until he attends a by-invitation-only concert at a secret warehouse location.

Pete can do things if he performs a ritual that dives into his OCD, you can call it magic if you want, and this band, Order of Organs, are all magicians, and they need Pete as much as he needs them, if they’re going to save Denver from what’s coming.

Filled with the anti-mainstream and DIY ethos of the movement, Repeater is the heartbreaking punk rock fantasy we need. 
______________________________

Very interesting! I can’t wait to read it❤️. 
.
.
.

📖☕️ Happy Pub Day @joyjordanlake_books on the gorgeous #UnderAGuildedMoon . Thank you to @getredpr for my spot on this tour. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

Biltmore House, a palatial mansion being built by the Vanderbilts, American “royalty,” is in its final stages of construction in North Carolina. The country’s grandest example of privilege, it symbolizes the aspirations of its owner and the dreams of a girl, just as driven, who lives in its shadow.

Kerry MacGregor’s future is derailed when, after two years in college in New York City, family obligations call her home to the beautiful Appalachians. She is determined to distance herself from the opulence she sees rising in the Blue Ridge Mountains, however close its reach. Her family’s land is among the last pieces required to complete the Biltmore Estate. But something more powerful than an ambitious Vanderbilt heir could change Kerry’s fate as, one by one, more outsiders descend on the changing landscape—a fugitive from Sicily, a reporter chasing a groundbreaking story, a debutante tainted by scandal, and a conservationist prepared to put anyone at risk to stoke the resentment of the locals.

As Kerry finds herself caught in a war between wealth and poverty, innocence and corruption, she must navigate not only her own pride and desperation to survive but also the temptations of fortune and the men who control it. 
————————————————————

How’s that for some amazing #historicalfiction ?! With this gorgeous cover, the perfect Christmas gift for the historical fiction lover;)
.
.
.

☕️📖 And herein lies the power of #bookstagram . @bookswithlulu asked for non-thriller book recommendations in her recent post. And this book is the one that most frequently comes to mind.
.
.
“Dear Edward” by @annnapolitano is a masterpiece. A testament to the resilience of the human spirit even in the face of the greatest tragedy. 
The story:
Twelve-year Edward Adler is the sole survivor of a plane crash that kills his parents and 183 other passengers. 
He is an absolute miracle, a media sensation. But Edwards heart died on that plane. He goes to live with his childless aunt and uncle, and befriends their neighbor, Shay. She’s about his age and for inexplicable reasons, the only human he feels safe around. He sleeps on her floor until it is deemed no longer proper. 
.
.
When Edward makes it to and surpasses the age his big brother was when he died, he has a bit of an existential crisis. 
So many questions are posed in this book. How do you carry on after unimaginable loss, who are you without the people who define your existence....
.
.
I cried so hard at this one. The epilogue is one of the best I’ve read. @pattyisbooked can tell you all the reasons this book is pure gold. I love how much she loves it. The passion she has for a book like this says so much about her spirit ❤️ .
,
.
.
Happy Saturday everyone! Feel free to post your thoughts about this book, or your favorite book this year! This is definitely my favorite of 2020.
.
.
.
.
.

☕️🎄📖 “Tis’ the season for some thrillers”. And a @suzyapprovedbooktours ! I’m really excited to read #TheDeadSeason by @tessawegert . It’s the second in her Shana Merchant series, but reads quite well as a stand-alone. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

After leaving the NYPD following her abduction by serial killer Blake Bram, Shana Merchant hoped for a fresh start in the Thousand Islands of Upstate New York. Her former tormentor has other plans. Shana and Bram share more than just a hometown, and he won't let her forget it. When the decades-old skeleton of Shana's estranged uncle is uncovered, Bram issues a challenge: Return home to Vermont and solve the cold case, or the blood he spills next will be on her hands.

As Shana interviews members of her family and the community, mining for secrets that could help her solve her uncle's murder, she begins to realize how little she remembers of her childhood. And when Bram grows impatient and kidnaps again, leaving a trail of clues Shana alone can understand, she knows his new victim will only survive if she wins the psychopath's twisted game. In order to solve one mystery, Shana must wade into her murky past to unravel another. 
.
.
.
And of course I added the first in the series “Death in the Family” to my list. 
.
.

I hope everyone has a magnificent or at least peaceful evening my #booksta friends❤️. 
.
.
.
.

.
.
My affinity for true crime isn’t strictly salacious. The forensics and psychological profiling is intrinsic to understanding not only the killers brain, but the human brain. John Douglas was an innovator and a pioneer at a time when people couldn’t see the need for his research. 
All of that being said, he and Mark Olshaker have a new book out! “The Killer’s Shadow” is one of my most anticipated reads this year. 
.
.
Partial synopsis:

The October 8, 1977 shooting was a forerunner to the tragedies and divisiveness that plague us today. John Douglas, the FBI’s pioneering, first full-time criminal profiler, hunted the shooter―a white supremacist named Joseph Paul Franklin, whose Nazi-inspired beliefs propelled a three-year reign of terror across the United States, targeting African Americans, Jews, and interracial couples. In addition, Franklin bombed the home of Jewish leader Morris Amitay, shot and paralyzed Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt, and seriously wounded civil rights leader Vernon Jordan. The fugitive supported his murderous spree robbing banks in five states, from Georgia to Ohio. 
.
.
I feel like this couldn’t be more relevant. What we are experiencing today has deep, old roots. Thank you so much to @deystreet for my gifted copy of #KillersShadowBook . It will be imminently devoured. 
.
.
.
I know this Thanksgiving looks a whole lot different from anything we’ve ever seen, but I urge everyone to be grateful for the good things. I’m extensively, fiercely grateful for my family of course. Particularly my sister who keeps teaching me what real grace and strength and love look like. Thank you my darling @turning.pages.with.phia . You are forever my inspiration and I may just become a good person yet❤️. 
.
.
.
.
.

I don’t know exactly why but I love books about Instagram perfect people who aren’t perfect. Maybe because what you see on Instagram is rarely the whole, or even true story. And this book has it all.

Synopsis:
Followed by Millions, Watched by One

To her adoring fans, Emmy Jackson, aka @the_mamabare, is the honest “Instamum” who always tells it like it is. 

To her skeptical husband, a washed-up novelist who knows just how creative Emmy can be with the truth, she is a breadwinning powerhouse chillingly brilliant at monetizing the intimate details of their family life.

To one of Emmy’s dangerously obsessive followers, she’s the woman that has everything—but deserves none of it. 

As Emmy’s marriage begins to crack under the strain of her growing success and her moral compass veers wildly off course, the more vulnerable she becomes to a very real danger circling ever closer to her family.

In this deeply addictive tale of psychological suspense, Ellery Lloyd raises important questions about technology, social media celebrity, and the way we live today. Probing the dark side of influencer culture and the perils of parenting online, People Like Her explores our desperate need to be seen and the lengths we’ll go to be liked by strangers. It asks what—and who—we sacrifice when make our private lives public, and ultimately lose control of who we let in. . . .
.
.

📚 “Often , what comes with age is not wisdom, but intolerance.”
- #TheChalkMan  by @cjtudorauthor my thoughts, loose review? 
I’ve wanted to read this for a while and didn’t look at reviews until a few weeks ago. So I went in apprehensive. Ready to not like it. I looked for reasons not to like it. But folks, I loved it. 
.
.
I loved the atmospheric, foreboding writing. There were some insightful gems, many quotes made it to my journal. 
Any book that starts in the 1980’s with a band of kids is my jam. As I started reading I thought a lot of “The Shadows”, down to the woods playing a pivotal role in the story. 
I’m also fond of a slow burn thriller. 
Someone asked me if I liked the characters and I didn’t think about it until then, but no, I didn’t. And truthfully I like a story that doesn’t have likable characters. What I don’t like are wooden, flat characters. This book wasn’t that at all. It was uncomfortable in is rawness and honesty in fact. 
I disagreed that all 12 year old boys want to find a dead body, until I remembered there is an entire movie dedicated to that notion (Stand by Me, a story by Stephen King before it was a movie). 
Maybe the only beef I had with this book is that I wanted more. I don’t know why but I could have kept reading about this group of ragtag kids turned awkward adults. Because I loved this one so much, i just ordered “The Other People”. 
.
.
.
What are you reading this weekend?? And what is your favorite holiday drink at @starbucks ? Mine is the #eggnoglatte 
.
.
.
.
.

☕️📚🌍🪐#friyay ! A few weeks ago @sand_between_pages tagged me in the 
#whereintheworldstack and you know I love a good stack challenge. Books can transport you anywhere, even other worlds. Which is my favorite thing to do. Go anywhere at the turn of a page. So here’s my stack:

The Martian- Might be lame, but I desperately want to go to space. Not necessarily be an astronaut or anything like that. Just the the solar system, feel something so big wrapping around you that you don’t have words that come close to what you feel. 
.
The Chronicles of Narnia- Narnia is and will always be my favorite place. I’ve been to Cair Paravel a thousand times, Aslan feels like a dear friend, the Dawn Treader is as vivid in my mind as the screen in front of me. Yes, Narnia is my favorite place. Fantasy lands count!
.
Freak- @jenniferhillierbooks always sets her books in the Pacific Northwest which is my favorite part of the USA. It’s speaks to my soul. I’m not at home in the sun, give me fog and tall trees any day. 
.
.
Me Before You- England, I love it. I love the culture, I love the history, I love the countryside. All of it. 
.
.
Anne Of Green Gables- Canada and PEI are stunning! My cousin spent a really long honeymoon in PEI and I’m still jealous 15 years later 🤣. 
.
.
The Hobbit- Middle Earth. I really don’t need to say more. I had a dog named Shire and a cat named Arwen..... 
.
.
.
So there you have it, some of my favorite places that books take me. 
What would your stack look like? Where are your favorite places in this world or any other?

.
.
.

✨Book Review✨
Thank you to @suzyapprovedbooktours & @joannafitzpatrick.author for my copy of #KatherineMansfield to review.
.
.
Prior to getting this book, I had only a cursory body of knowledge regarding Katherine. I knew she was a contemporary of Virginia Woolf and I had read I tiny bit of her writing. 
What the author did with this story is take what we know and give it life. She gave Katherine a voice, and a personality with extensive research. 
.
. 
I loved her spunk, and her bohemian lifestyle. I mostly resonated with her medical battle. She was determined to beat tuberculosis, going to several different doctors, and trying several experimental treatments, even slightly defying her husband’s opinions. 
It is the mark of a fighter, to never give up. It saddened me that she so desperately wanted to join her friends in simple things outdoors. My heart broke for her a lot. Knowing that she only lived to be 34 was gut wrenching as I read. 
I am definitely going to read more of her writing. She was so talented. 
4⭐️
.
.
.
.

☕️📖 Book Feature☕️📖
Thanks to @girlfridayproductions & @garydicksonauthor I bring you “An Oddity of Some Consequence”. 
.
.
Synopsis:

Robert Valmer moves from Rome to Beverly Hills in 2015, where against his better judgment, he falls for Alexis Roth, PhD, psychologist to the stars. But Alexis wants to know everything. Start from the beginning, she says. The beginning? Can he really tell her about how he fled France during the French Revolution in 1789 or about Italy during World War II? If he tells her even a little, will she think of him as a liar or a freak rather than a lover?

He tries to deflect her probes, pleading shyness, but she knows that reticence is often the veil behind which secrecy lurks. His practice of stonewalling only further ignites her burning curiosity.

As the pressure for honesty mounts, he does what he’s always done—flee. But Alexis is not a lover to be easily dismissed. She follows him to Europe, determined to track him down for an explanation. Where can she start when her quarry doesn’t want to be found? Each clue she uncovers leads her deeper into intrigue.
,
.
.
.
If you’re down for a good mystery, with some time travel, this is your book.
.
. 
Do you like books with time travel? I do, I find it a really interesting element that adds rich layering to the plot. 
.
.
.
.

☕️📖 .... you know guys, I thought we could use a cozy, calm picture today. After the past 24 hours I know I do. And this book! Thank you @htpbooks & @hanoversquarepress for my gifted copy of “Before the coffee gets cold” by Toshika Kawaguchi . I absolutely love the premise of this book, here’s a synopsis for you all:
.
.

If you could go back, who would you want to meet?

In a small back alley of Tokyo, there is a café that has been serving carefully brewed coffee for more than one hundred years. Local legend says that this shop offers something else besides coffee—the chance to travel back in time. 

Over the course of one summer, four customers visit the café in the hopes of making that journey. But time travel isn’t so simple, and there are rules that must be followed. Most important, the trip can last only as long as it takes for the coffee to get cold. 
.
.
——————————————————————————————
What ah introspective read. I cannot wait to delve in. 
So what would you go back in time for? Who would you want to see?
I would go back to any regular day at the breakfast table with my grandparents. The safest most wonderful place on earth.
.
.
.
.

In this enchanting and introspective journal, Coelho takes you down the path of reflection and imagination. With 45 thought-provoking questions, you will explore mind and soul as you consider the signs and omens along your journey, make peace with the unknown, and learn to listen to your heart's desires. Journey includes an introduction from Coelho, plenty of blank space to write, and beautifully designed quotes from his most popular books, speeches, interviews, and posts. Exquisitely produced, with a white and copper foil-stamped cover, Journey is a must-have for fans of this legendary writer-and anyone seeking a space for discovery and inspiration.

- Pearl Jenkins is a nobody. She was a woman who lived as a hermit in the woods. One day, she's nowhere to be found, and all that's left behind is a pool of blood and a child no one knew existed, raised completely off the grid and in the grip of Pearl's manic paranoia.

Book Synopsis: 
The Townhouse Bar, midtown, July 1992: The piano player seems to know every song ever written, the crowd belts out the lyrics to their favorites, and a man standing nearby is drinking a Scotch and water. The man strikes the piano player as forgettable.

He looks bland and inconspicuous. Not at all what you think a serial killer looks like. But that’s what he is, and tonight, he has his sights set on a gray haired man. He will not be his first victim.

Nor will he be his last.

The Last Call Killer preyed upon gay men in New York in the ‘80s and ‘90s and had all the hallmarks of the most notorious serial killers. Yet because of the sexuality of his victims, the skyhigh murder rates, and the AIDS epidemic, his murders have been almost entirely forgotten.
.
.
Pub date: March 9, 2021

☕️📚 #coffeeandcurrentlyreading , and omg this book🔥. Let me preface by saying that I am almost unable to read digitally, my eyes stay on a paragraph for so long, I have memory issues so flipping back to remember things is incredibly difficult....... and yet, my @amazonkindle ap tells me that I am 40% through this! It’s so engaging, thank you @stmartinspress @macmillanusa , @netgalley & @sallyhepworth for my gifted arc. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS: 

From the outside, everyone might think Fern and Rose are as close as twin sisters can be: Rose is the responsible one, with a home and a husband and a fierce desire to become a mother. Fern is the quirky one, the free spirit, the librarian who avoids social interaction and whom the world might just describe as truly odd. But the sisters are devoted to one another and Rose has always been Fern's protector from the time they were small. 

Fern needed protecting because their mother was a true sociopath who hid her true nature from the world, and only Rose could see it. Fern always saw the good in everyone. Years ago, Fern did something very, very bad. And Rose has never told a soul. When Fern decides to help her sister achieve her heart's desire of having a baby, Rose realizes with growing horror that Fern might make choices that can only have a terrible outcome. What Rose doesn't realize is that Fern is growing more and more aware of the secrets Rose, herself, is keeping. And that their mother might have the last word after all.
.
.
I love, love, love that Sensory Processing issues have been mentioned. It’s starting to be more recognized and that makes me so happy.  My son and I both have Sensory issues, and are both on the Spectrum. It is nice to feel represented in literature ❤️. 
Also, I now need a Cavoodle. 
.
.
This one is out on April 13, 2021. If you haven’t added it to your #tbr , you must. 
.
.
.
.

📚👀☕️#THRILLERTHURSDAY 👀📚😳
Have I got a thriller recommendation for y’all......
“I’m terrified of what will happen when I tell her. But I’m even more terrified that nothing will happen, that she’ll ignore me and carry on like normal”

This quote doesn’t encompass the essence of the book, but it’s a perfect example of how the author captures human nature. So many times the fear of telling someone a hard truth lies in the fear that they will not act on it.
Aside from that, the authors bio states that she “writes thrillers for angry women”. 
Carly is an awkward freshman in college with anger built up. 
Scarlett is a professor with an agenda: to make men pay for their misdeeds towards women — with their lives. 
The story alternates between the two women and themes emerge: men thinking they can take what they want, be it a glance or a touch. 

Reading through I felt rage. At all the memories I have of feeling objectified, unsafe, awkward because I was getting unwanted attention. We should be able to wear what we want without men looking at us like some fried chicken or some shit. My words, not from the book. I get the anger. This book is binge worthy. I could not put it down. A female serial killer who takes out pos men? 
Yea I’m there for that. 
5 freakin’ ⭐️ ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💪🏻
.
.
Thank you so much to @scoutpressbooks & @laynefargo for my gifted copy❤️
.
.
.
.

📚☕️ Ok I have a #bookrecommendation for you guys. #BlackBuck by @askmateo (Mateo Askaripour) is astoundingly unique and funny. I feel like it’s flown under the radar and it really should be front and center. It’s satire at its finest. 
Thank you so much to @hmhbooks & @bookishfirst for my gifted copy. It’s out on January 5, 2021 but you can already add it to your Amazon wishlist. 
.
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

There’s nothing like a black salesman on a mission.
An unambitious twenty-two-year-old, Darren lives in a Bed-Stuy brownstone with his mother, who wants nothing more than to see him live up to his potential as the valedictorian of Bronx Science. But Darren is content working at Starbucks in the lobby of a Midtown office building, hanging out with his girlfriend, Soraya, and eating his mother’s home-cooked meals. All that changes when a chance encounter with Rhett Daniels, the silver-tongued CEO of Sumwun, NYC’s hottest tech startup, results in an exclusive invitation for Darren to join an elite sales team on the thirty-sixth floor.

After enduring a “hell week” of training, Darren, the only black person in the company, reimagines himself as “Buck,” a ruthless salesman unrecognizable to his friends and family. But when things turn tragic at home and Buck feels he’s hit rock bottom, he begins to hatch a plan to help young people of color infiltrate America’s sales force, setting off a chain of events that forever changes the game.

Black Buck is a hilarious, razor-sharp skewering of America’s workforce; it is a propulsive, crackling debut that explores ambition and race, and makes way for a necessary new vision of the American dream.
.
.
.
.

📚☕️ This is a @suzyapprovedbooktours that is very close to my heart. @doesanyonewritelettersanymore wrote an account of her own mental health journey and it is beautiful. It’s beautiful to be raw and honest and write without fear. I believe in the power of writing, journaling. Pictured are my own journals.
Mental illness has so much stigma surrounding it still. I personally have heard “go keto and it’ll clear up, you don’t pray enough, you’re possessed by the devil, you’re weak.........” 
.
.
I’ve heard it all. I take medication, proudly and without a second thought. No, I don’t think keto will calm my psychosis, nor is my mental illness a product of weakness or anything I’m doing wrong. People who live with it know real strength. 
Thank you @suzyapprovedbooktours & @doesanyonewritelettersanymore for putting me on this book tour❤️
.
.
.

What a beautiful tour from @tlcbooktours & @harperviabooks Such gorgeous books from a formidable author, and non-fiction to boot. Yes please❤️
.
.
The Sum of Our Days:
In this powerful memoir, Isabel Allende reconstructs the painful reality of her life after the death of her daughter, Paula. 
.
.
My Invented Country:
This book orbits two life-changing moments: the 1973 assassination of her uncle Salvador Allende Gossens which sent her into exile and inspired her literary career; and the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, on her adopted homeland, the United States. 
.
.
Paula:
When her daughter, Paula, became gravely ill and fell into a coma, Isabel Allende began to write the story of her family for her unconscious child. Bizarre ancestors are introduced; delightful and bitter childhood memories are shared; amazing anecdotes of youthful years are relived, and the most intimate secrets are quietly passed along. 
.
.
.
All of these are Allende’s personal memoirs and history, beautiful and heartbreaking and funny.  Absolute must-reads. 
.
.
.

✨Book Feature✨
Happy Publishing Day!
“Absolution”
By: Regina Buttner @reginabuttnerbooks 
Publisher: @shewritespress 
Publishing date: 10/13/2020
.
.
.
Synopsis:

Jeanie thinks she was to blame for the sexual assault she suffered in college—and she’d do anything to keep her old-school Catholic family from finding out about the resulting pregnancy, as well as what she did to conceal it.

Years have passed since the assault, and Jeanie’s husband, Greg, still thinks she’s the seemingly innocent girl he married in a rush to spite his controlling mother. It’s the height of the Seattle dot-com boom, and he’s too busy cashing in his stock options to pay attention to his wife. He isn’t aware of Jeanie’s lingering shame and guilt, or that she married him in the desperate hope that devoting herself to marriage and motherhood would somehow absolve her from the sins in her past.

Their hidden agendas collide when Greg discovers evidence of Jeanie’s long-ago pregnancy. As she confesses the details of that drunken night with her married professor, Greg’s pristine image of her is blown. His shock deepens into violent fury, and Jeanie realizes she needs to leave him—but Greg won’t let her go. He’s up for a big promotion, and he’s not about to let her ruin his reputation by walking out on him. He’ll resort to blackmail if necessary. Or worse. 
.
.
.
WOW, this book. Powerful, though I haven’t finished it yet, it’s one that I keep picking back up. A beautiful debut from this author. Thank you to @getredpr for my copy and my tour spot❤️.
.
.
.
.

☕️📚 Wow to this #bookmail !! 
#TheFourWinds by Kristin Hannah @kristinhannahauthor is another piece of historical fiction gold. Thank you so much to @stmartinspress for my #gifted copy. 
The premise grabs me for a few personal reasons. It’s set in 1934 Texas, my grandma would have been 12. She grew up on a farm in South Texas. I don’t have much to go on but her stories of that time are etched in my mind. They grew everything they ate, life was modest but gratitude abundant. I love Kristin Hannah’s ability to transport you to times and places and I can’t wait to delve into this beautiful story! 
.
.
Here’s the synopsis: 

Texas, 1934. Millions are out of work and a drought has broken the Great Plains. Farmers are fighting to keep their land and their livelihoods as the crops are failing, the water is drying up, and dust threatens to bury them all. One of the darkest periods of the Great Depression, the Dust Bowl era, has arrived with a vengeance. 

In this uncertain and dangerous time, Elsa Martinelli—like so many of her neighbors—must make an agonizing choice: fight for the land she loves or go west, to California, in search of a better life. The Four Winds is an indelible portrait of America and the American Dream, as seen through the eyes of one indomitable woman whose courage and sacrifice will come to define a generation. 
Scheduled to release on 2/9/21. You won’t want to miss this one. Just add it to your list. 
.
.
.
.
.

I have a #bookrecommendation for you guys, “No Hesitation” is a fast paced, in depth thriller by Kirk Russell @kirkruss7 It’s the third in his Paul Grale series but can be read as a stand alone. Thank you to @girlfridayproductions for my copy! 
.
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

FBI bomb tech Paul Grale isn’t a computer expert, but he knows trouble when he sees it. Independence Base, a new top-secret military facility north of Las Vegas, houses a breakthrough artificial intelligence that has US enemies worried and on the move. Threat chatter is already way up when a known terrorist bomber—and Grale’s archnemesis—slips past border security. Then two of Independence Base’s star computer coders go missing. Were they kidnapped as part of a terror plot? Or did they quit in protest, taking their vast knowledge of the potentially dangerous AI code with them?

Special Agent Grale still grapples with the injuries sustained clearing IEDs in Iraq years ago. He’s managed the pain with exercise and over-the-counter drugs for years, but it’s getting worse. People at the office are beginning to talk. When he’s accused by a crooked pharmacist of illicit use of painkillers, he finds himself isolated and facing an uncertain future. Possibly, the end of his career. But first, Grale must push through the pain long enough to thwart an attack . . . as a terror team waits for the right moment to strike.
.
.
Out now, add it to your #tbr !
.
.

SYNOPSIS:
When Bianca appears late one night at her brother's house in Santa Ana, she is barely conscious, though not alone. Jubilee, wrapped in a fuzzy pink romper, is buckled into a car seat. Jubilee, who Bianca feeds and clothes and bathes and loves. Jubilee, who Bianca could not leave behind. Jubilee, a doll in her arms.
Told in alternating points of view, Jubilee reveals both the haunting power of our lived experiences and the surreal possibility of the present to heal the past.

The first thread, "Before Jubilee," follows Bianca in her girlhood home on the Mexicali border as she struggles with her high school sweetheart, Gabe, and a secret they've shared since she was fifteen.
The second thread, "With Jubilee," is told from the point of view of her new love, Joshua, who along with Bianca's family helps her cope with a mysterious trauma by accepting Jubilee as part of the family. As Joshua's love for Bianca grows, he fears that Jubilee has the power to tear his tiny family apart.
Alternating chapters give readers a unique perspective on Bianca's present and on her relationship with Jubilee as her past life with Gabe comes to a catastrophic end.

.
.

Thank you so much to @lizarodman , Jennifer Jordan & @atriabooks for one of my most anticipated reads of 2021. 
Everyone knows how much I love true crime and #TheBabysitter is the craziest kind of true I’ve heard of in a while. 
.
.
Synopsis:

Growing up on Cape Cod in the 1960s, Liza Rodman was a lonely little girl. During the summers, while her mother worked days in a local motel and danced most nights in the Provincetown bars, her babysitter—the kind, handsome handyman at the motel where her mother worked—took her and her sister on adventures in his truck. He bought them popsicles and together, they visited his “secret garden” in the Truro woods. To Liza, he was one of the few kind and understanding adults in her life. Everyone thought he was just a “great guy.” 

But there was one thing she didn’t know; their babysitter was a serial killer. 

Some of his victims were buried—in pieces—right there, in his garden in the woods. Though Tony Costa’s gruesome case made screaming headlines in 1969 and beyond, Liza never made the connection between her friendly babysitter and the infamous killer of numerous women, including four in Massachusetts, until decades later. 

Haunted by nightmares and horrified by what she learned, Liza became obsessed with the case. Now, she and cowriter Jennifer Jordan reveal the chilling and unforgettable true story of a charming but brutal psychopath through the eyes of a young girl who once called him her 
friend.
.
.
Woah was my reaction when I read the blurb. This one is out 3/2/2021 , add it to your #TBR 👍🏻👍🏻
.
.
.
.

📚Book Review📚
“A Borrowed Life” 
By: @kerry_anne_king 
@lakeunionauthors publisher 
Pub date 9/22/20
.
.
My thoughts:
I completely loved this book from beginning to end. Possibly because I identified with so much of it, but it touches on such relatable topics, I feel like anyone might. 
Liz loses her husband Thomas, a pastor, within the first few pages. I like that it jumps right into her journey. Right during the loathsome knitting circle that Liz leads and can’t stand. She’s a pastors wife, but we find out that her choices were never simple. And that she’s dying to break free.
When Thomas dies, it’s her chance. 
She joins a theater group through her friend (eventually bestie Val), meets her kinda crush Lance there, and starts to really live. 
She also realizes just how much under Thomas’s thumb she was. Which leads her to realize that their grown daughter, Abigail, was completely controlled by Thomas as well. 
Abigail tries to control Liz but Liz is never going back. 
And then gasp, a pregnancy out of wedlock.

Mmkay, I hated Thomas for the entire book, and didn’t like Abigail until the last few pages. I think I audibly uttered “back the fuck off” at least once.

But I have met women like Liz , especially in the church (certainly not trying to put down organized religion here) , so I recognized her self doubt and the realizations she had. 
There was such immense beauty in her journey, I cried. I was rooting for her and felt for her. I think it’s been a while since I connected to a character this much. 
I couldn’t put this down, and loved the entire story. 5⭐️
.
.
Thank you to @tlcbooktours & @lmunley for my #gifted copy of this book to review ❤️. 
.

☕️👁🔍 Ok where my #truecrime lovers??? I’m a fanatic and so are my sisters. I’m thrilled at my #gifted copy of Killer Triggers by #joekenda from @blackstonepublishing . ID is by far my most watched channel. 
This one is out on March 9, 2021 but you can add it to your list on Amazon. Cause I had it there when I opened my #bookmail 😂. 
.
.
Joe Kenda is such a badass. That’s why I used my Badass Bookworm bookmark from @sarcastic_reader_shop . It fits. 
So the book synopsis: 

The most common triggers for homicide are fear, rage, revenge, money, lust, and, more rarely, sheer madness. This isn’t an exact science, of course. Any given murder can have multiple triggers. Sex and revenge seem to be common partners in crime. Rage, money, and revenge make for a dangerous trifecta of triggers, as well.

This book offers my memories of homicide cases that I investigated or oversaw. In each case, I examine the trigger that led to death. I chose this theme for the book because even though the why of a murder case may not be critical in an investigation, it can sometimes lead us to the killer.

And even if we solve a case without knowing the trigger, the why still intrigues us, disrupting our dreams and lingering in our minds, perhaps because each of us fears the demons that lie within our own psyche—the triggers waiting to be pulled.
.
.
.
Definitely reading ASAP. How is everyone this gloomy Wednesday? It’s gloomy here and that’s my favorite kind of day for reading. 
.
.
.
.
.
.

🎊Happy Pub-day @wendywalkerauthor !🎊 This is a ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ all the way and definitely one of my favorite books this year. So many twists and turns.
.
.

My @goodreads review:

Wow this book. I loved every second of it. 
Molly Clarke is driving home from her sons school on a deserted country road during a storm. 
Her family has fallen apart since the death of her 9 year old daughter five years prior.
Molly thinks everyone’s life would be better off without her, so when she runs out of gas, her thoughts of deserting her life are strong in her mind.

When her family is finally notified that her abandoned car and a note are found, everyone is certain that she left and doesn’t want to be found.

Her daughter Nicole feels it in her bones that something is off. That her mother would never leave them. So she sets off to find answers in the small, tight lipped town of Hastings. Her brother Evan makes her swear to find their mother. Nicole promises.

What ensues is soooo twisted and deliciously meandering. I thought I had things figured out a few times, but like any good thriller, I was proven wrong. Brilliant writing and a wonderful story. Absolutely one of my favorite thrillers of 2020. Thank you so much to @stmartinspress and Wendy Walker for my copy to review. 
.
,
.
Go grab this!!! Just do it. 
.
.
.
.

Another @suzyapprovedbooktours ! I’m really excited for #AgathaArchIsAfraidOfEverything . I don’t like comparing books but within the first few pages I’m getting Eleanor Oliphant vibes and I love it! Not to mention, this cover art is everything.
Publisher: @alcovepress 
Author: @kbairokeeffe 
Publication Date: November 10, 2020

.
.
. 
SYNOPSIS:

Agatha Arch's life shatters when she discovers her husband in their backyard shed, in flagrante delicto, giving the local dog walker some heavy petting. Suddenly, Agatha finds herself face to face with everything that frightens her...and that's a loooooong list.

Agatha keeps those she loves close. Everyone else, she keeps as far away as possible. So she's a mystery to nearly everyone in her New England town. To her husband, she's a saucy, no-B.S. writer. To her Facebook Moms group, she's a provocateur. To her neighbor, she's a standoffish pain in the butt. To her sons, she's chocolate pudding with marshmallows. And to her shrink, she's a bundle of nerves on the brink of a cataclysmic implosion.

Defying her abundant assortment of anxieties, Agatha dons her "spy pants"--a pair of khakis whose many pockets she crams with binoculars, fishing line, scissors, flashlight, a Leatherman Super Tool 300 EOD, candy, and other espionage essentials--and sets out to spy on her husband and the dog walker. Along the way, she finds another intriguing target to follow: a mysterious young woman who's panhandling on the busiest street in town.

It's all a bit much for timorous Agatha. But with the help of her Bear Grylls bobblehead, a trio of goats, and a dog named Balderdash, Agatha may just find the courage to build a better life.
.
.
Add this quirky gem to your #tbr ❤️❤️❤️❤️

☕️
☕️
SYNOPSIS:

Allison James is a people pleaser and rule follower, but the day before her thirty-fifth birthday, that all backfires: she is unexpectedly fired from the public relations firm she’s worked at for twelve years, only to come home and find out that her fiancé has been sleeping with her maid of honor.

Feeling lost, Allison takes her friend Jordan’s advice and uses the time off for some self-reflection. Over the next few months, she devours countless self-help books (albeit skeptically), schedules a soul reading with an astrologer/psychic/magician, and goes on a meditation retreat in Costa Rica, where she finally starts to feel like she’s getting her groove back.

Back at home, her desire to escape the condo she once shared with her fiancé makes her a regular at the new coffeehouse in her neighborhood, where she finds some guidance from (and eye candy in) the attractive owner, Eric. Between Jordan’s support, the Barnes & Noble self-help aisle, and the Tao of Eric, Allison gradually discovers that her old life wasn’t as perfect as she thought—and that if she truly wants to find her happily-ever-after, she’s going to have to start writing her own rules. 
☕️
☕️
I’m only a few pages in and let me tell you, I’ve had a dark week personally. This is just the thing I need right now. It’s out, grab it! 
.
.

✨INDIE BOOK FEATURE✨
Thank you to @booksparks {partner} for my copy of #TheSergeantsDaughter by @teressajshelton . A powerful memoir about childhood abuse and resolving to not let it break you. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

As a little girl, Teressa’s father dotes on her and little sister, Karen, while mercilessly mocking her older sister, Debbie. Teressa thinks its Debbie’s fault―until she gets a little older and he begins tormenting her, too. Soon enough, his verbal abuse turns physical. Her sergeant father brings his military life home, meeting each of his daughters’ infractions with extreme punishment for them all. Meanwhile, their mother watches silently, never defending her daughters and never subjected to physical abuse herself. Terrified to be at home and terrified to tell anyone, Teressa seeks solace in books, music, and the family she can find outside of her home: a best friend, a kind neighbor, and a doting grandfather. At first cowed by her father’s abuse and desperate to believe that maybe, one day, things will change, Teressa ultimately grows into a young woman who understands that if she wants a better life, she’ll have to build it for herself―so she does. 
.
.
.
On a personal note, I have to say, being in an abusive household changes you in ways that aren’t predictable. But it can also empower you. Adversity teaches you to persevere and take pride in your successes big or small. 
This book is out, grab it❤️
.
.
Also, I had to show off my super friggin’ cute #pumpkinspicelatte booksleeve by @bookishblingsleeves ☕️☕️
.
.

SYNOPSIS: 

It’s been almost two years since investigative reporter, Jack Logan, and television producer, Taylor Parks brought down the Institute—the secret facility responsible for indoctrinating a generation of America’s political and media power players. Their lives are just getting back to normal, and Jack and Taylor have settled into married life with their young son, Evan. The man who’d threatened their lives—Damon Crosse, is dead, and his evil plan for society thwarted.

But soon a series of bizarre murder/suicides capture Jack’s attention. When he begins to piece together the seemingly unrelated incidents, a disturbing pattern emerges. Could someone be intentionally causing people to become homicidal? Meanwhile, Taylor is producing a story about a class action suit against a national insurance company that has reached the Supreme Court. As Jack and Taylor uncover layer after layer, they start to suspect that their stories are connected and that there is something darker and more insidious at play.

When they make the shocking discovery that Crosse actually faked his own death, and is very much alive, Jack and Taylor must race against the clock to try and find him before he executes his new plan to take back control and destroy not only their lives,  but the future of the country. 
.
.
I definitely am going to order the first one #TheNetwork .

About the book:

This is a poignant comedy about a crime that never took place, a would-be bank robber who disappears into thin air, and eight extremely anxious strangers who find they have more in common than they ever imagined.

Viewing an apartment normally doesn’t turn into a life-or-death situation, but this particular open house becomes just that when a failed bank robber bursts in and takes everyone in the apartment hostage. As the pressure mounts, the eight strangers slowly begin opening up to one another and reveal long-hidden truths.

As police surround the premises and television channels broadcast the hostage situation live, the tension mounts and even deeper secrets are slowly revealed. Before long, the robber must decide which is the more terrifying prospect: going out to face the police, or staying in the apartment with this group of impossible people.

Thank you to @bookclubbish , @parkrowbooks & @njooyounkim for my copy of #TheLastStoryofMinaLee . 
This one publishes on September 1st and I love a multi-generational drama. 
.
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

Margot Lee's mother, Mina, isn't returning her calls. It's a mystery to twenty-six-year-old Margot, until she visits her childhood apartment in Koreatown, LA, and finds that her mother has suspiciously died. The discovery sends Margot digging through the past, unraveling the tenuous invisible strings that held together her single mother's life as a Korean War orphan and an undocumented immigrant, only to realize how little she truly knew about her mother.

Interwoven with Margot's present-day search is Mina's story of her first year in Los Angeles as she navigates the promises and perils of the American myth of reinvention. While she's barely earning a living by stocking shelves at a Korean grocery store, the last thing Mina ever expects is to fall in love. But that love story sets in motion a series of events that have consequences for years to come, leading up to the truth of what happened the night of her death.

Told through the intimate lens of a mother and daughter who have struggled all their lives to understand each other, The Last Story of Mina Lee is a powerful and exquisitely woven debut novel that explores identity, family, secrets, and what it truly means to belong. 
.
.
.

#indiebooks ✨Feature✨
@booksparks {partner}
#HaveYouSeenTheseChildren by @veronicaslaughter 
#memoir 
—————————————————-
SYNOPSIS:
Four young children caught between love and hate—hostages to the cruelty of revenge. A deceitful American father and a naïve decision by a Filipino mother transformed their lives forever. 
Valorie, Veronica, Vance, and Vincent’s perfect world turned into a nightmare one hot afternoon in 1959 in Cebu, Philippines. What was to be a quick lunch with their father turned into a flight to America, where four dreadfully long years of running from state to state, hiding, and vanishing into the night followed. Kidnapped from the only world they knew, confusion quickly set in. At nine, Valorie, the eldest, liked seeing their father after his absence for over a year. Vance, a timid six-year-old, went along with whatever Valorie did. Vincent, the baby at three, cried for his mother while clinging to Veronica for comfort. Veronica, eight, was the only one who was truly panicked by what was happening around them—and she recognized instantly that she and her siblings would have to stick together in order to survive. In that moment, her childhood ended and the warrior within her emerged. 

Moving from state to state and school to school, avoiding the law, looking over their shoulders at every turn, the four Slaughter children found themselves fighting not only the heartbreak of separation from their loving mother but also poverty, discrimination, and abuse. Their only weapons were their deep love for one another and an unwavering determination to survive the trials they faced—and find their way back to their mother. 
——————————————————
I find most memoirs to be so powerful in that the author is basically bleeding on to the page. I’m always inspired and prodded to write my own but when I read memoirs like this one I feel like my story pales in comparison.
If you wrote your own memoir, what would it be called?
.
.

✨INDIE BOOK FEATURE✨
@booksparks {Partner} #TheAlohaSpirit by @lulleseit 
SYNOPSIS:

The spirit of aloha is found in Hawaii’s fresh ocean air, the flowers, the trade winds . . . the natural beauty that smooth the struggles of daily life. In 1922 Honolulu, unhappy in the adoptive family that’s raised her, Dolores begins to search for that spirit early on―and she begins by running away at sixteen to live with her newlywed friend Maria.

Trying to find her own love, Dolores marries a young Portuguese man named Manolo His large family embraces her, but when his drinking leads to physical abuse, only his relative Alberto comes to her rescue―and sparks a passion within Dolores that she hasn’t known before. Staunch Catholics can’t divorce, however; so, after the Pearl Harbor attack, Dolores flees with her two daughters to California, only to be followed by both Manolo and Alberto. In California, Manolo’s drinking problems continue―and Alberto’s begin. Outraged that yet another man in her life is turning to the bottle for answers, Dolores starts to doubt her feelings for Alberto. Is he only going to disappoint her, as Manolo has? Or is Alberto the embodiment of the aloha spirit she’s been seeking? 
.
.
Such a gorgeous cover and it sounds like suuuch a good read. I also want to thank @mellymel0304 for these insanely gorgeous cookies that so happened to match the book I’m featuring today. I love a pretty cookie, don’t y’all? 
Happy Saturday everyone ❤️

✨INDIE BOOK FEATURE✨
@booksparks {partner} #PoeticLicense by  @gretchcher . Alright, this is one memoir I want to delve into. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

At age forty, with two growing children and a new consulting company she’d recently founded, Gretchen Cherington, daughter of Pulitzer Prize–winning poet Richard Eberhart, faced a dilemma: Should she protect her parents’ well-crafted family myths while continuing to silence her own voice? Or was it time to challenge those myths and speak her truth—even the unbearable truth that her generous and kind father had sexually violated her?

In this powerful memoir, aided by her father’s extensive archives at Dartmouth College and interviews with some of her father’s best friends, Cherington candidly and courageously retraces her past to make sense of her father and herself. From the women’s movement of the ’60s and the back-to-the-land movement of the ’70s to Cherington’s consulting work through three decades with powerful executives to her eventual decision to speak publicly in the formative months of #MeToo, Poetic License is one woman’s story of speaking truth in a world where, too often, men still call the shots. 
.
.
.
Triggers: sexual abuse, psychological abuse.
What a powerful story. I applaud the author for telling her truth. 
What’s the last non-fiction you read?
.
.
.
.

✨INDIE BOOK FEATURE✨
I am thrilled to be a part of @booksparks #indie book box this summer. Here is #TheTakeawayMen by @meryl_ain . If you like WWII historical fiction, you need to grab this one. 
.
.
SYNOPSIS: 

With the cloud of the Holocaust still looming over them, twin sisters Bronka and Johanna Lubinski and their parents arrive in the US from a Displaced Persons Camp. In the years after World War II, they experience the difficulties of adjusting to American culture as well as the burgeoning fear of the Cold War. Years later, the discovery of a former Nazi hiding in their community brings the Holocaust out of the shadows. As the girls get older, they start to wonder about their parents’ pasts, and they begin to demand answers. But it soon becomes clear that those memories will be more difficult and painful to uncover than they could have anticipated. Poignant and haunting, The Takeaway Men explores the impact of immigration, identity, prejudice, secrets, and lies on parents and children in mid-twentieth-century America. 
.
.
.
Wowsa you guys. This one sounds so good. It’s out now!
.
.
.
.

🌵🌵📚📚🌵🌵
Well y’all know I have two sisters 😏. 
Meet Phi. Sophia. She loves Narnia, the classics, and Evelyn Hugo. 
.
.
Phi was born when I was 12. She was the sweetest thing from the moment she was born. Her cry sounded like a kitten my momma likes to say. I was so proud of her. I showed my baby sister off to anyone and everyone. 
It’s so hard to even know what to say about a human who made me into a sister and an Auntie. And who was in the room when we found out my son would survive to birth. Who painted my nails and braided my hair when I was in labor.
Who loves my son like her own.
And who is going through a rare cancer with such grace and beauty.
So yea, it’s hard to know what to say....
.
.
.
@smariee425 even I don’t have a big enough grasp over the English language to articulate everything I want to say.  Luckily I think you know me so well, you already know. 
.
.
.
.
.

I am so excited to have partnered up with @booksparks to showcase some amazing #indie books and authors. 
.
. 
#TheMillOfLostDreams by #LoriRhoda published on August 11th and I can’t wait to read it. It’s a wonderful piece of Historical Fiction spanning the 1870’s through the early 1900’s. Set in Fall River, Massachusetts, the largest textile manufacturer in the US at the time, the story follows three immigrant families and their dreams of America being a better life. 📚📚📚
I was so glad to grab @britrbennett “The Mothers” as one of my @bookofthemonth ad-ons. The Vanishing Half was beautiful and heartbreaking and everything in-between. I expect no less from The Mothers. Have you read it??
.
.
.
I wanted to talk about learning. And how we are all on different paths, and that’s ok. This years events have caused a much needed movement. It has at times caused me so much anger and despair, I’ve had to divorce myself from watching or reading things for a bit. It’s not as though I don’t have a background regarding Black History, I do. If you ask my momma, it has angered me since I was old enough to realize that there was a damn problem. 
But I’m an intense and emotional person, so I find that I with newfound eyes, I’ve had to digest things slowly or I become profoundly depressed. 
Whatever rate you have to go at, that’s fine, don’t let people make you feel like you’re not doing enough. Everyone is different and at different places in their journey. Just don’t stop. Keep those eyes open. Only then can we change the hideous trajectory we’ve been on. 
I realize this was probably poorly worded and I may get under a few peoples skin, but I don’t have any ill intentions. On the contrary, I’m so heartbroken and disillusioned that I’ve had to pace myself. 
All of that being said, love each other, be kind. And wear a damn mask lol. 
Happy weekend everyone ❤️
.
.
.

,
.
.
SYNOPSIS: 
When Alex arrives in Provincetown to patch things up with his new wife, he finds an empty wine glass in the sink, her wedding ring on the desk, and a string of questions in her wake. The police believe that Alex's wife simply left, his marriage crumbling before it truly began. But what Alex finds in their empty cottage points him toward a different reality:

His wife has always carried a secret. And now she's disappeared.

In his hunt for the truth, Alex comes across Layla, a young woman with information to share, who may hold the key to everything his wife has kept hidden. A girl without a clear recollection of her own past. A strange, quiet girl whose memories may break them all.

To find his wife, Alex must face what Layla has forgotten. And the consequences are anything but quiet. 
.
.

☕️📚☕️📚☕️
Happy Saturday everyone! I hope it’s treating you well🥰.
#bookmail is the best mail!
I have said so many times how much I love the book #TheGreatBelievers . However, I cannot read a piece of historical fiction without exploring the history behind it to the most thorough extent of my abilities. I guess that’s why I chose sociology and anthropology as my support work in college. 
I ordered #AndTheBandPlayedOn by the late #randyshilts . 
.
.
HIV and AIDS is still a crisis but we’ve come a long way, and have a long way to yet to go. Exploring the history, sociology, epidemiology of a global crisis seems to be the way I roll. I know that I’m disgusted by my own country’s treatment of HIV and AIDS, but I want to explore how other countries treated it. 
.
.
Obviously this isn’t a light topic, but I’m not warm and fuzzy. I’m a scholar, I have to know things. No matter how dark and ugly. 
However! I leave you with a pretty picture of a #latte brought to you by my baby sister who gave me a @zulay_kitchen milk frother for my birthday. I love you @mlouuuise !! 
And thank you all for all of your birthday wishes, I truly love this community ❤️
.
.
.
.
.

☕️📚☕️📚☕️
@cozy.coffee.reads tagged me in the #lastbook challenge. It took me a while to put a few together because so many books have it all. They make me laugh, cry, angry.... but here it goes:

😢The last book to make me cry: #DearEdward , I’ve cried at a few books this year, I’m an emotional person. But nothing so far has come close to evoking the feels that this book did. Even the happy, sweet moments made me tear up because it was all so poignant in the context of the story. I remember weeping after I closed this one, and picking up my sleeping son. 
.
.
😂 made me laugh: #OneToWatch had such funny, witty moments (Chris Evans), and I really did laugh audibly. Such a cute read.
.
.

😡made me angry: #TheVanishingHalf , racists piss me off. Nuff said. 
.
.
🤷‍♀️couldn’t finish: #GreenRiverRunningRed : I fully intend on finishing this one. And I read little bits every now and then. It’s good, but not fast paced by any means. 
.
.
👁changed my mind: #TheGreatBelievers was everything. But I grew up thinking the Reagan era was the bomb-dizzle. However, as an adult I realize that the gay/HIV crisis was treated egregiously. I started digging for every bit of information I could find about that time period, books and documentaries. Truly an eye-opening book.
.
.
.
So there it is. If you’re reading this, consider yourself tagged!
.
.
.

☕️BOOK REVIEW☕️

Ryn Brennan is a force in the world of venture capital. She’s on the verge of making partner in her company, forged a path in a male-dominated sector, and is about to close a major deal.
She also just found out that her adoring husband of ten years had been cheating on her. 
With Carly Santos. Who is co-founder of the startup company, aka Ryn’s major deal that she has to close. 
Can Ryn sit across from his mistress and seal the deal without clawing her face off? 
.
.
I loved this book. Women supporting women. Ryn and Carly both learn from each other. Everyone needs a friend like Carly. She’s ridiculously resilient, sweet and amazing. 
There is also a #MeToo aspect to this book and I friggin’ loved it. It’s a pipe dream but I hope every day things like it happen. 
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

🔪💍THRILLER THURSDAY💍🔪

I’m doin’ it, I’m taking the plunge! 
Into two twisty marital thrillers. Is that a thing? I’m making it a thing. I love thrillers that have wicked twisted marriages involved. Maybe because even though my own marriage isn’t perfect, the most twisted thing about it is me sending my husband pics of his socks everywhere he leaves them, and adding the knife emoji.

☕️THRILLER THURSDAY☕️

I want to thank @kaliwriting for sending me the pdf of her book #TheMonstersWeMake . I started reading but then stopped because there’s a reason I don’t read digitally. I have memory issues so I find myself flipping back and forth in a book frequently. I know, write things down. But there’s no way to know what I’ll forget so there’s no real point or advantage to that. 
All this to say, I stopped reading because within the first 20 pages, this book is just so good. 
.
.
It is based on the real Des Moines paperboy kidnappings in the early 1980’s. 
I’ll put the synopsis in comments.
This one is out on August 11. It’s a really good read so far and I can’t wait to get my hands on a physical copy. 
.
.
There is a documentary called “Who Took Johnny” about Johhny Gosch, I’ve watched it over and over. 
Kidnapping is something I’ve been obsessed with since I was 10, and a girl my own age, Heidi Seeman was abducted in my hometown. My own daddy, hard nosed as he was, wept the day her body was found. 
That case was when I knew that bad things can happen. It also forged my love for true crime. 
.
.
This book merges both, so naturally I fervently sought it. 
Thanks again Kali. 
.
.

.
.
