#coffeeandcurrentlyreading 
Well goodbye reading slump! Hello #dontlookforme by @wendywalkerauthor 😍. I was legitimately upset that I needed to put this one down last night to go to sleep. 
From the very first few pages you are sucked into Molly’s world of sadness, grief, introspective inner monologue. And that’s the first chapter! 
Molly disappears on a dark stormy night. There is a note found in a local motel is apologetic and tells her family not to look for her.
Her daughter Nicole knows this isn’t her moms style. Knows that she’d never leave them willingly. It’s up to her to prove what no one else believes. 
This is proving to be one of my favorite thrillers, it doesn’t let up in that genre, but it has heart, it’s a family drama too. 
This one is set to publish on September 15. Put on on your #tbr , thank me later. This is my first Wendy Walker book but by far not my last. 

.
.
Thank you to @stmartinspress & @wendywalkerauthor for this gifted copy ❤️
.
Also, thank you to anyone who watched our live video last night or since. My sisters are the best. I love how smart, beautiful and fun they are. I’m a very lucky woman. 
.

💊TUESDAY💊 

Book Review:
#booktour stop; 
“The First To Lie”by Hank Phillippi Ryan 
Publishes on 8/4/2020 by @forgereads 
.
.
.
Pay attention when you read this! There are many characters, multiple POV switching, extremely detail oriented. I can only imagine that comes from Hanks background in investigative reporting.
There are so many layered lies interwoven through each other, as the story unfolded my shoulders let go of their tension. Because I was on the edge of my seat reading this, trying to guess where it was headed. 
There’s also the present and the past to contend with in dissecting this story, and it all hinges on taking down Pharminex, a drug company complicit in death and sterility for women. 
Monifan is supposed to be a miracle drug for women suffering from fertility issues, the use of it for such is off label though. For many women it proves to be a nightmare, robbing them of the chance to ever have children. 
The Vanderwald family owns Pharminex and isn’t going to let their fortune go so easily. 

There’s a reporter, her assistant, a lawyer, a woman posing as a pharmacy rep.... but which one is the liar?
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
.
.
.
Looooved this one so much. Thank you so much to @suzyapprovedbooktours & @hankpryan for my review copy. 
.
.
.

📚New Books & Coffee☕️

Simple pleasures in life are often the most poignant. I love that you can vaguely see the steam coming off of my coffee cup. 
.
.
Last night I was so exhausted and just responding to my son on autopilot mode.
He asks, “what’s wrong momma?”
I say, “Momma’s just a little sad”.
.
. 
When he asked why, I perked up, aware that I need to tread lightly. I’m the mom, I need to be on my game.
.
.
“No reason baby, sometimes you just get sad.”
.
.
“Is it because of Aunt Margie?”
.
.
Wow guys, kids really do pay attention to everything. The previous night he had a memory of my aunts home. Which led to a conversation about death and cancer. And he picked up on the fact that his Auntie Phia has cancer. The fear in his eyes was palpable. I held my breath before speaking. 
.
.
These are such difficult conversations but I don’t believe in shielding my son from everything, nor can I. We are realizing that he picks up even on our unspoken moments. So I’m honest with him. Sensitive, but honest. 
Parenting is hard and it’s not a one-size fits all thing. 
Do your best and give yourself grace. That is my hope for you all my friends. 
.
.
.
ETA: I saw a challenge called #readingabovetheclouds and this stack counts! 
.
.
.
.
.

#book review 
Thank you @suzyapprovedbooktours & @maddiedaws for my copy of #ahappycatastrophe !
.
This is the sequel to #matchmakingforbeginners but I found that it can absolutely be read as a stand alone. Though the first book is delightful I hear. 
This story really is magical, quite literally! Marnie is a matchmaker and sees sparkles around her matches. If that sounds not believable, it’s written in the most sincere way, there isn’t anything campy about it. 
Marnie has a big question to ask her longtime boyfriend Patrick. 
She wants them to have a baby.
Patrick, for reasons of his own, isn’t on the same page. 
In comes Fritzie......
Fritzie is the product of a one night stand from Patrick’s past. Her mother basically leaves her at the doorstep. 
Marnie is sweetness and love incarnate because she takes this little girl as if she’s her own. 

Patrick isn’t so sure about any of it. I began to get really annoyed with him, I didn’t think he deserved Marnie. 
And at a point, she decides the same. 
I would rather not give too much away, because this is a completely charming story. But what I will say is that I had tears in my eyes and then went into the ugly cry at the end. 
On a personal note: I absolutely love the way @maddiedaws puts adoption in such a beautiful light. I have fertility issues and so do my sisters. Adoption is an amazing thing and I love when it’s handled so wonderfully in literature. 
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
.
.
.

Getting snowed in at a beautiful, rustic mountain chalet doesn’t sound like the worst problem in the world, especially when there’s a breathtaking vista, a cozy fire, and company to keep you warm. But what happens when that company is eight of your coworkers…and you can’t trust any of them?

Carly clawed her way back from being a teenage runaway to become an accomplished scientist, caring single mom, and co-founder of her startup. Once she marries her loving fiancé, she'll secure the complete family she craves. But she's blindsided to discover her not so perfect fiancé is already married—to Ryn, her company's biggest investor.

In an industry full of not-so-subtle sexism, can the two women rise above, and work together to overcome heartbreak, and ensure their success?

Hold on while I pinch myself. I cannot thank @atriabooks , @simonandschuster & @lisajewelluk enough for my #gifted copy of Invisible Girl.
This is by far my most anticipated and sought after book this year. I will be out of commission today lol. .

SYNOPSIS:

LONDON: On a fine avenue of grand houses, big cars and electronic gates, lies a neglected urban wasteland

It is nearly midnight, and very cold. Yet in this dark place of long grass and tall trees where cats hunt and foxes shriek, a girl is waiting... When Saffyre Maddox was ten something terrible happened and she's carried the pain of it around with her ever since. The man who she thought was going to heal her didn't, and now she hides from him, invisible in the shadows, learning his secrets; secrets she could use to blow his safe, cosy world apart.

Owen Pick is invisible too. He's thirty-three years old and he's never had a girlfriend, he's never even had a friend. Nobody sees him. Nobody cares about him.

But when Saffyre Maddox disappears from opposite his house on Valentine's night, suddenly the whole world is looking at him. Accusing him. Holding him responsible.

Because he's just the type, isn't he? A bit creepy?

INVISIBLE GIRL: A story of secrets and injustices, and of how we look in the wrong places for the bad people while the real predators walk among us in plain sight. ——————————————————
PUBLISHES OCTOBER 13, 2020
.
.
.
.

**A Plea if you will:
If you are in Texas or one of the many states that are seeing rises in Covid, please stay home if and when you can, wear a mask in public. Wash your hands. My sister just finished chemotherapy. This virus isn’t political, we have let it divide us which is something I have trouble fathoming. It’s not a hoax. Some people get mild symptoms, and some need hospitalization. And some die.
Even a cloth mask when worn by everyone gives a measurable level of protection. My baby sister just waged a war on a vicious fkin cancer, and I cannot stand the thought of her getting sick because people have the right not to wear a mask, a right to congregate.....
It’s not about rights at this point, it’s about the collective good. Let’s actually be the UNITED States of America. .
.
.

Synopsis:

When Ruby King’s mother is found murdered in their home in Chicago’s South Side, the police dismiss it as another act of violence in a black neighborhood. But for Ruby, it’s a devastating loss that leaves her on her own with her violent father. While she receives many condolences, her best friend, Layla, is the only one who understands how this puts Ruby in jeopardy.

Their closeness is tested when Layla’s father, the pastor of their church, demands that Layla stay away. But what is the price for turning a blind eye? In a relentless quest to save Ruby, Layla uncovers the murky loyalties and dangerous secrets that have bound their families together for generations. Only by facing this legacy of trauma head-on will Ruby be able to break free.

An unforgettable debut novel, Saving Ruby King is a powerful testament that history doesn’t determine the present and the bonds of friendship can forever shape the future. .
.
.
We are all trying to diversify our reading and this is perfect. My goodness the writing is stunning. Add this to your #tbr guys. I can’t believe it’s a debut novel, it’s just beautiful. .
.
.
.
.
.

Synopsis:

In 1992, a car accident kills a young man and forever changes the lives of three people… Now, twenty years later, they’ll all come to regret the choices they made that day, as the secrets and lies they’ve told to protect each other become the very things that tear their lives apart.

After a night of fun, Abby was responsible for the car crash that killed her beloved brother. It is a sin she can never forgive herself for, so she pushes away the man she loves most, knowing that he would eventually hate her for what she’s done, the same way she hates herself.

Twenty years later, Abby’s husband, Nate, is also living with a deep sense of guilt. He was the driver who first came upon the scene of Abby’s accident, the man who pulled her to safety before the car erupted in flames, the man who could not save her brother in time. It’s this guilt, this regret that binds them together. They understand each other. Or so Nate believes.

In a strange twist of fate, Liam (her old lover—possibly her true soulmate) moves in with his own family next door, releasing a flood of memories that Abby has been trying to keep buried all these years. Abby and Liam, in a complicit agreement, pretend never to have met, yet cannot resist the pull of the past—nor the repercussions of the dark secrets they’ve both been carrying… .

SYNOPSIS:

Amanda is a new mother, and she is breaking. After a fight with her partner, she puts the baby in the car and drives from Queens to her hometown in rural Ohio, where she shows up unannounced on the doorstep of her estranged childhood best friend. Amanda thought that she had left Carrie firmly in the past. After their friendship ended, their lives diverged radically: Carrie had a baby the summer after high school, became a successful tattoo artist, and never escaped Ohio s conservative grid of close-cut grass. But the trauma of childbirth and shock of motherhood compel Amanda to go back to the beginning and to trace the tangled roots of friendship and family in her own life.

Compelling and engaging, Everything Here Is under Control is a raw, honest, occasionally hilarious portrait of the complexity, conflicting emotions, and physical trauma of both modern motherhood and the intense, intimate friendships that women forge in their youth.
.
.
.
So much yes, you guys will want to read this.
It publishes on July 28, add it to your lists! Thank you again to @blackstonepublishing for my gorgeous finished copy. .

🥀SUNDAY🥀

Harlem
BY LANGSTON HUGHES
What happens to a dream deferred?  Does it dry up  like a raisin in the sun?  Or fester like a sore—  And then run?  Does it stink like rotten meat?  Or crust and sugar over—  like a syrupy sweet?  Maybe it just sags  like a heavy load.  Or does it explode? .
.
.
I was 10 when I discovered “Harlem” in a book of poetry. I knew nothing of the writer, only that he spoke my language. At that point it was the most profound thing I had read. .
.
To this day it remains powerful for me. A lot more has transgressed in 30 years in my life. 
But I also am privy to the dreams that have been deferred by so many BIPOC. Simple dreams like being able to walk out the front door without fear. And big dreams like getting their work published. .
.
I’m certainly not here to assert that I can even imagine or relate to that struggle, I just want to celebrate one of the greatest poets to ever live. 
Happy Sunday folks❤️
.
.
.
.

SYNOPSIS:

It all started with just one little lie. But we all know that it never ends there. Because, of course, one lie leads to another…

Growing up, Jane and Marnie shared everything. They knew the other’s deep-est secrets. They wouldn’t have had it any other way. But when Marnie falls in love, things begin to change.

Because Jane has a secret: she loathes Marnie’s wealthy, priggish husband. So when Marnie asks if she likes him, Jane tells her first lie. After all, even best friends keep some things to themselves. If she had been honest, then perhaps her best friend’s husband might still be alive today…

For, of course, it’s not the last lie. In fact, it’s only the beginning…

Seven Lies is Jane’s confession of the truth—her truth. Compelling, sophisticated, chilling, it’s a seductive, hypnotic page-turner about the tangled, toxic friendships between women, the dark underbelly of obsession and what we stand to lose in the name of love. .
.
.
Has this been on your radar? I hear great things! .
.
.
.
.

I couldn’t sleep. So I took inventory. 
I looked through my library for every black author, book with significant black main characters, or books about black issues.
I am ashamed. 
I have hundreds of books. 9 is the total in this picture dealing with BIPOC. 
I can’t feel good as a reader without doing better. Or as a human. 
I will do better. .
.
.
.
.
.
.
#thenickelboys #suchafunage #thecountofmontecristo #getalifechloebrown #raincitylights #administrationsoflunacy #uncletomscabin #roots #themanintheironmask #colsonwhitehead #alexandredumas #kileyreid #alexhaley #amplifymelanatedvoices #ownvoices #poc #educationmatters #bookphotography #dobetter #bookstagram #reader

I was 6 and it was 1985 when parts of this speech were given to me to read in first grade.
I found it the most powerful thing I’d ever read at that young age. This part in particular, because it encompassed everything I felt but could not articulate. From the moment I could make my own opinions and have thoughts, I knew a persons character was what I was drawn to or repelled by. 
Of course I noticed color. But only as a person notices the different colors of flowers or the changing colors of leaves.
I’m obviously naive to think, and have kept hoping this notion would come to pass, that King’s notions would still be a dream. 
But I vow to do better. I vow to listen. Learn. Support. Stand.

It is 2020 and we are still not there. It’s egregious. I’m angry, sad. But I will do better.  I’m listening and reading everyone’s recommendations and taking notes. If I refrain from speaking it is because I do not feel educated enough to offer words. But I’m working on it. #mutedandlistening .
.
.
.
.

I’m so happy to be a part of the #copyboy book tour with @suzyapprovedbooktours & @blantonstroud ! This book is so readable, I started and really couldn’t put it down. I compulsively read the first page of any new book and I really loved the first five pages of this. If you love historical fiction or bad ass women, this one’s for you 🙌🏻.
.
.
SYNOPSIS: "This is Raymond Chandler for feminists.” — Sharma Shields, author of The Cassandra 
Jane's a very brave boy. And a very difficult girl. She'll become a remarkable woman, an icon of her century, but that's a long way off.

Not my fault, she thinks, dropping a bloody crowbar in the irrigation ditch after Daddy. She steals Momma’s Ford and escapes to Depression-era San Francisco, where she fakes her way into work as a newspaper copy boy.

Everything’s looking up. She’s climbing the ladder at the paper, winning validation, skill, and connections with the artists and thinkers of her day. But then Daddy reappears on the paper’s front page, his arm around a girl who’s just been beaten into a coma one block from Jane’s newspaper―hit in the head with a crowbar.

Jane’s got to find Daddy before he finds her, and before everyone else finds her out. She’s got to protect her invented identity. This is what she thinks she wants. It’s definitely what her dead brother wants. .
.
PUB DATE: 6/23/2020
.
.
I know there is a lot going on in the country right now, I myself am heartbroken. A man’s near to last words calling for his momma, well that’s something I can’t bear. My heart is with his momma and his whole family right now. Please join me in thinking about a family who lost their loved one. Peace and love to you all❤️.
.
.
.
.
.

She really is an artist which is so cool for me, my own son is way more happy to kick a ball, or you know, anything. So that fits more with my sister Phi, who is so athletic. It takes a village my friends!
.

.

👁THURSDAY👁 
Happy #thrillerthursday 😏😏
Thank you so much to @atriabooks @simonandschuster & @svaughanauthor for my #gifted copy of #littledisasters .
.
.
.
Liz is an ER doctor who gets paged about an injured baby who needs to be looked at more closely. When she gets to the floor, she sees it’s none other than her close friend Jess, with her ten month old, Betsey. What’s more, the story that Jess is providing isn’t adding up.
Liz is faced with the difficult choice to be a Dr. first and report the injury to authorities, or give her friend the benefit of the doubt.
It takes a good deal of thought but she rightfully decides to report the incident which sets a process in motion that exposes Jess and her family as not quite as perfect as they seem.
.
.
.
My thoughts:
The story was really well written, though I found less thriller and more domestic drama. I got a feel for the characters and was absolutely able to connect with them. I’m a mother so I don’t know if that’s why, but I think I saw a little of myself in Liz and Jess. Jess is the “perfect” mom, we all know one. We also know that perfection doesn’t exist and there are obviously issues that brings up. 
This book dealt with mental illness so well, some might find it raw but there’s nothing tame about mental illness. Bravo for that, we need to have those conversations, we need to normalize mental illness and postpartum mental health. Add this one you guys, and make it a book club read. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
Available 8/18/20
.
PS.... I want to thank @pepperidgefarm for providing my family with delicious cookies because I’m no Jess.
..
.
.

Hi y’all! I am #stackingpink today for my dear, dear friend Barbara, who you guys might know as @the.tattooed.reader . .
.
This lady... as of last week is a breast cancer survivor!!! She’s a warrior. She fought this thing and killed it.
She’s also been there for me during my darkest moments, putting herself and her worries aside to give me kind words, advice, and love. There’s never been a time that she hasn’t made herself open and fully available for me. I tried hard to leave her be on my worst days because I felt like I had nothing good or worthwhile to give her. But she never fails to remind me that she loves me. Never. It sucks that she’s so far away because if not, she’d never get rid of me! One day though, we will have coffee and chat and hug.
For now though, I will be grateful for my friend who is a #breastcancersurvivor . .
.
Let’s all be grateful for love and people and the things that no amount of money can buy💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗
.
.
.

Happy Pub Day to this absolutely beautiful book, #ahappycatastrophe !
Thank you to @suzyapprovedbooktours @maddiedaws and @amazonpublishing for my copy. It’s the sequel to the extremely popular “Matchmaking for Beginners”.

SYNOPSIS:

Marnie MacGraw and Patrick Delaney have been in love for a few years now, enough to realize that they are imperfectly perfect together. Still, there are some things that maybe need a little attention. Marnie’s ebullient; he’s brooding. She thrives on change; he prefers stability. She sees marriage and parenthood in their future, but he can’t see beyond the shadow of an earlier tragedy.

Then an eight-year-old surprise from Patrick’s past shows up on their doorstep, cartwheeling into their lives and spinning things in all directions. While it’s not exactly the change she envisioned, it looks like instant family to Marnie. But Patrick, afraid of being hurt again, retreats further into himself. Suddenly, two very different pieces of a beautiful puzzle find it harder and harder to fit. How can Marnie trust in the magic of the universe when it seems to be doing its best to knock her off her feet?

But some love stories are worth waiting for. And what’s love without a little chaos anyway? .

Review: 
This is not my usual genre, but I’m so glad I read this book. 
Kate Bradley moves from California to NYC, hoping to tackle the big stories. However, being the daughter of a senator, she’s given politics to cover. 
She also kindly takes over the rent for a friend in what turns out to be a really shabby apartment, she could have had a fabulous place provided by the news station.

So things are looking bleak. When all of a sudden there is a massive power outage in the city, and everything changes.

A do gooder is suddenly paying people’s bills and buying people coffee , etc anonymously.
Kate and a co-worker are on the trail trying to find this mysterious stranger..... constantly derailed by someone’s menacing messages.

I really  liked this one, such a feel good book for times like these. Thank you to the publisher and author for my review copy.
4⭐️

BOOK SYNOPSIS:

Saint Petersburg, 1905. Behind the gates of the Karenin Palace, Sergei, son of Anna Karenina, meets Tolstoy in his dreams and finds reminders of his mother everywhere: the vivid portrait that the tsar intends to acquire and the opium-infused manuscripts Anna wrote just before her death, which open a trapdoor to a wild feminist fairy tale. Across the city, Clementine, an anarchist seamstress, and Father Gapon, the charismatic leader of the proletariat, plan protests that embroil the downstairs members of the Karenin household in their plots and tip the country ever closer to revolution. Boullosa tells a polyphonic and subversive tale of the Russian revolution through the lens of Tolstoy's most beloved work. .

💄MONDAY💄 *BOOK TOUR*

Thank you to @harperbooks , @livconstantine2 & @suzyapprovedbooktours for this book, what a fun tour! I love my thrillers.
.
.
.
Review:
This book reads like a lifetime movie, a bit of a guilty pleasure. 
It definitely sucks you right in, and with a little bit of campy drama, keeps you there.
The plot seems cliche enough, the “husband trades his wife in for a younger model” trope. 
The key here is “seems cliche”....., cause yea, I was thrown for a loop. It was perfectly twisted and suspenseful.
I kept screaming in my head “GET A LIFE JOANNA!” . Piper never seemed particularly anything to me except a little bit selfish. Not likable or unlikeable. 
At one point I did think she had to be involved in something sinister because she had a “sordid” past.
The twist though, was everything. Loved it!
4⭐️
PUB DATE: 5/19/2020
.

Thank you so much to @duttonbooks , @riley.sager &  @the_grateful_read for my #gifted copy of #homebeforedark . .
SYNOPSIS: 
A woman returns to the house made famous by her father’s bestselling horror memoir. Is the place really haunted by evil forces, as her father claimed?
What was it like? Living in that house.
Maggie Holt is used to such questions. Twenty-five years ago, she and her parents, Ewan and Jess, moved into Baneberry Hall, a rambling Victorian estate in the Vermont woods. They spent three weeks there before fleeing in the dead of night, an ordeal Ewan later recounted in a nonfiction book called House of Horrors. His tale of ghostly happenings and encounters with malevolent spirits became a worldwide phenomenon, rivaling The Amityville Horror in popularity—and skepticism.
Today, Maggie is a restorer of old homes and too young to remember any of the events mentioned in her father’s book. But she also doesn’t believe a word of it. Ghosts, after all, don’t exist. When Maggie inherits Baneberry Hall after her father’s death, she returns to renovate the place to prepare it for sale. But her homecoming is anything but warm. Even more unnerving is Baneberry Hall itself—a place filled with relics from another era that hint at a history of dark deeds. As Maggie experiences strange occurrences straight out of her father’s book, she starts to believe that what he wrote was more fact than fiction. ———————————————————-
PUB DATE: June 30, 2020
.
.
You have to put this on your list guys✔️✔️✔️✔️
.

Thank you so much to @minotaur_books & @anna_downes_writer for my gifted copy of #thesafeplace ! 
The cover alone... swoon. .
.
With the book came a letter from the author, describing how the book came to be. She talks about having a baby and a toddler and having this amazing life, but still wanting to find the time for creativity. So she writes in every spare moment, while the kids are sleeping, scribbling notes while they’re playing... and I related in such a huge way. Though I’ve never penned a book, I do the same thing. I write and scribble in every moment in between, I get up out of bed so I won’t forget an idea. Mommas are the ultimate multitaskers! 
I can’t wait to read this book, such a labor of love and sacrifice. .
.
BOOK SYNOPSIS: 
Emily is a mess.

Emily Proudman just lost her acting agent, her job, and her apartment in one miserable day.

Emily is desperate.

Scott Denny, a successful and charismatic CEO, has a problem that neither his business acumen nor vast wealth can fix. Until he meets Emily.
Emily is perfect.
Scott offers Emily a summer job as a housekeeper on his remote, beautiful French estate. Enchanted by his lovely wife Nina, and his eccentric young daughter, Aurelia, Emily falls headlong into this oasis of wine-soaked days by the pool. But soon Emily realizes that Scott and Nina are hiding dangerous secrets, and if she doesn't play along, the consequences could be deadly. .

👤SATURDAY👤 
The Shadows. Alex North’s sophomore novel. Not really because he’s written under a different name but that’s neither here nor there. .
.
4.5⭐️
We see detective Amanda Beck again so this book happens in the same universe as The Whisper Man. 
The prologue introduces a heinous crime against a child by his “friends” and that sets the stage for the book. 
Paul is being taken by the police, he is their primary suspect. We find out why and who were the actual perpetrators in the rest of the story.
In present day Paul comes back to visit his mother in hospice after not seeing her, or the town he grew up in, for 25 years.
.
.
There are now copycat crimes....
.
.
Guys I don’t want to say too much or too little. Just that I really enjoyed this one. In some ways even more than TWM. My sister also said the same. In some ways she liked it better. Either way it comes out July 7, is it on your wishlist? .
.
.
.

🥀TUESDAY🥀 
It’s #truecrimetuesday folks. Another book by #johnglatt . 
I ordered this book immediately after getting the arc of “The Perfect Father”. .
.
I think very few of us need any introduction to the Cleveland abductions and subsequent fall out, but also triumph of three brave women. But I’ll provide a blurb from @goodreads all the same. —————————————————— The Lost Girls tells the truly amazing story of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight, who were kidnapped, imprisoned, and repeatedly raped and beaten in a Cleveland house for over a decade by Ariel Castro, and their amazing escape in May 2013, which made headlines all over the world. The book has an exclusive interview and photographs of Ariel Castro's secret fiancé, who spent many romantic nights in his house of horror, without realizing he had bound and chained captives just a few feet away. There are also revealing interviews with several Castro family members, musician friends and several neighbors who witnessed the dramatic rescue. ———————————————————- I’ll never say that this is an easy genre to read. But I will say that the depths the human mind can go, the harm it can afflict is horrifying and at the same time, fascinating.
I find myself pondering, was this person born this way or were they created.... nature vs. nurture and such.
And there is ample evidence to support nurture (or lack thereof ), however, I do think some people are born missing whatever chip that makes us human.
.
.
I don’t want to bring y’all down though! So tell me something good that came from this quarantine state??
Love to all of you , may you all be well🌺🌺
.
.
.

👁THURSDAY👁

It’s #thrillerthursday , and I have a crazy awesome recommendation for y’all!
.
.
Thank you @parkrowbooks , @harpercollins & @launger for my gifted copy of #confessionsonthe745 .
.
Only a few pages in and I’m definitely hooked. This book comes out in October but add it to your #tbr now! I love the premise, domestic thrillers never get old for me, and I love anything that starts with secrets divulged to a stranger. 
I know I’ve told things to perfect strangers that I just had to get out. You’ll likely  never see them again, so it just feels safer... but is it? .
.
BOOK SYNOPSIS: 
Be careful to whom you tell your darkest secrets…
Selena Murphy is commuting home from her job in the city when the train stalls out on the tracks. She strikes up a conversation with a beautiful stranger in the next seat, and their connection is fast and easy. The woman introduces herself as Martha and confesses that she’s been stuck in an affair with her boss. Selena, in turn, confesses that she suspects her husband is sleeping with the nanny. When the train arrives at Selena’s station, the two women part ways, presumably never to meet again.

But days later, Selena’s nanny disappears.

Soon Selena finds her once-perfect life upended. As she is pulled into the mystery of the missing nanny, and as the fractures in her marriage grow deeper, Selena begins to wonder, who was Martha really? But she is hardly prepared for what she’ll discover.
.
.
.
PUB DATE: 10/6/2020
.
.
Get psyched for this one!!
.

🏡TUESDAY🏡 
#truecrimetuesday ? Can that be a thing? Well I just made it a thing.
.
.
Thanks so much to @stmartinspress & @netgalley this gifted copy of “The Perfect Father” by John Glatt. .
.
If you don’t know the story of Chris Watts and his heinous crimes, this book has it all and then some. I’ve watched a lot of documentaries and tv footage of the horrors, but John Glatt gives a ton of background into both Chris and Shannan. He fills in the story so that you get a more complete perspective of how everything played out and began.
.
. 
Notice that this is true crime, it is trigger city. Murder being the billboard of trigger warnings. I’m only half-way through and I’m really liking the way the author had put a really well known story together with some interesting background. 
I think I am drawn to the true crime genre because it is a reminder that there is a facet of humanity so dark and depraved that we really can’t let our guard down. That doesn’t mean living in fear, but it does mean to live and exist mindfully and cautiously.
.
.
This book has an expected Pub Date of July 21, 2020. .
.
Do you read any true crime?
.
.
.
.
.

📖SATURDAY📖

This cover ami right guys???!
.
.
I 100% credit my sister with getting me into thrillers. And now I’m hooked. My other sister loves the classics, but between all three of us, our taste in literature definitely overlaps. It’s one of the things we all love.
.
.
.
If you’ve been following me for a while you know that without my sisters, there is no me. That is not to say that I’m not an autonomous being with my own interests.... but I’d imagine if my heart were a patch work quilt, they are the thread that holds it together. .
.
. 
They’re smart, funny, kind... I like to joke that I taught them well. But in reality it was they who’ve taught me. They have taught  me to be more human from the day they were born. Until I held my sister I never knew how fierce love could feel. 
I was 12 when she was born and never looked back. I was in love with this precious, beautiful being in my arms. All of her dark hair, her toes were so tiny... when she cried she sounded like a kitten. .
.
That was 28 years ago today. 
28 years I’ve had this amazing person in my life. And there’s no way I’d be half the person that I am if there were no her. 
@sophiamarie425 Happy Birthday baby sister. Thank you for everything. I know 27 was shit. But let’s make 28 to the year of a thousand miracles and infinite beauty. I love you more than cake. .
.
.
.
.

SYNOPSIS:

Raised by a drug-addicted mother and criminal stepfather, she became her younger sisters' only hope-and the rock that held her family together. Now, high school senior Angel Ferente is nowhere to be found.

Last seen on public transit in the middle of the night, the talented competitive swimmer with an independent streak could have ended up just about anywhere. But on the rough streets of Philadelphia, in a community plagued by drugs and violent crime, her family and friends are finding plenty of cause for concern.

Narrated by Angel's troubled younger sister Jeannine and her swim teammate Alex, Watermark explores the challenges of growing up in the inner city in the midst of the crack epidemic and how one girl found refuge in the act of swimming and the steadfast support of her team. Alex and Jeannine form a bond as they find ways to cope with Angel's absence.

The swim team and members of a struggling community come together in search of the missing teen-will they manage to figure out where she has gone and track Angel down alive?
.
.
PUB DATE: 5/5/2020

☕️SUNDAY☕️ How is everyone??
My son has been sick for about a week (not Covid thank god), and I’m exhausted. .
.
Who loves Lisa Jewell @lisajewelluk ?I discovered her on #bookstagram and I’m so glad I did. 
I’ve been collecting her back work, because when I love an author I have to own everything they’ve ever written. .
.
I found “Ralph’s Party” on @halfpricebooks and it’s an excellent copy! 
This was the first book she ever penned, in 1999 and it was on a dare. 
It’s much different than her recent thrillers, but if you ever think she deviates in a way you’re not used to, her early work proves she doesn’t have a formula. She can write anything. 
Synopsis:

Meet the residents of the London brownstone on 31 Almanac Road who together weave a tangled web of romance. Ralph, a ne'er-do-well artist, suddenly realizes he's head over heels in love with his new flatmate Jem, the most fun and sensible girl he's ever encountered. Unfortunately, Ralph's best friend, Smith, has already won Jem's affections, although Smith has not entirely given up his passion for the femme fatale, Cheri, who lives upstairs. Across the hall, Karl and Siobhan have been happily unmarried for years, until Karl gets a smashing job as a London rush-hour DJ and momentarily gets tempted into Cheri's cozy lair. .
.
.
I can’t wait to grab the sequel, which admittedly is a bit difficult to find. .
.
Hope you are all ok, I know current events are a bit scary. I’m nervous because my state is reopening softly, but cases are rising. Just gonna keep yo what we’ve been doing as a family though. .
.
.
.
.

👨‍👩‍👧TUESDAY👨‍👩‍👧 BOOK REVIEW:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ The Silent Treatment is absolutely a five star read for me.
Aside from the fact that I couldn’t put it down, the writing is superb and it’s a beautiful love story. Notice I didn’t say romance, tough it has a bit of that, but it’s a love story. A story about marriage and relationships, the good, the bad and the ugly.
.
.
.
It’s divided into two parts “Her Silence”, and “His Silence”. In the first part we see that Maggie has overdosed on sleeping pills and Frank never leaves her side in the hospital. Maggie’s in a coma and a kind nurse tells Frank to talk to her.
So he does. Pensively at first but then it flows. And we hear their love story from his point of view starting from day one all the way to the present. They’ve been married 40 years.
Frank has stopped talking in the present after a traumatic event. Which in the very beginning I thought meant he was a distant husband, a cold man.
Through his story we see the opposite.
What a love story! If ever a man loved a woman the way Frank loves Maggie! #goals ...
.
.
.
In His Silence, we are told Maggie’s side through a series of letters Frank finds. 
On her end we learn that her infertility and overwhelming desire to have children gets in the way of her happiness and by extension, their marital happiness.
.
.
I’ll save the rest for you to read my friends. This is absolutely one of my favorite books this year. It’s a quiet, moving, powerful book. 
Thanks again to @tlcbooktours , @abbiegreavesauthor & @williammorrowbooks for the opportunity to review this one. .
.
.
.

BOOK SYNOPSIS:

A lifetime together. 
Six months of silence. 
One last chance. 
By all appearances, Frank and Maggie share a happy, loving marriage. But for the past six months, they have not spoken. Not a sentence, not a single word. Maggie isn’t sure what, exactly, provoked Frank’s silence, though she has a few ideas.

Day after day, they have eaten meals together and slept in the same bed in an increasingly uncomfortable silence that has become, for Maggie, deafening.

Then Frank finds Maggie collapsed in the kitchen, unconscious, an empty package of sleeping pills on the table. Rushed to the hospital, she is placed in a medically induced coma while the doctors assess the damage.

If she regains consciousness, Maggie may never be the same. Though he is overwhelmed at the thought of losing his wife, will Frank be able to find his voice once again—and explain his withdrawal—or is it too late? .
.
.

SYNOPSIS:
Breezing into the tony seaside paradise of Westport, Connecticut, gorgeous thirtysomething Piper Reynard sets down roots, opening a rehab and wellness space and joining a local yacht club. When she meets Leo Drakos, a handsome, successful lawyer, the wedding ring on his finger is the only thing she doesn’t like about him. Yet as Piper well knows, no marriage is permanent.

Meanwhile, Joanna has been waiting patiently for Leo, the charismatic man she fell in love with all those years ago, to re-emerge from the severe depression that has engulfed him. Though she’s thankful when Leo returns to his charming, energetic self, paying attention again to Evie and Stelli, the children they both love beyond measure, Joanna is shocked to discover that it’s not her loving support that’s sparked his renewed happiness—it’s something else.
Piper. Leo has fallen head over heels for the flaky, New Age-y newcomer, and unrepentant and resolute, he’s more than willing to leave Joanna behind, along with everything they’ve built. Of course, he assures her, she can still see the children.

Joanna is devastated—and determined to find something, anything, to use against this woman who has stolen her life and her true love. As she digs deeper into Piper’s past, Joanna begins to unearth disturbing secrets . . . but when she confides to her therapist that she fears for the lives of her ex-husband and children, her concerns are dismissed as paranoia. Can she find the proof she needs in time to save them? .
PUB DATE: 5/20/2020

You guys I invite you to take part in my #gratitudebookstack challenge ❤️ .
.
.
I’ll admit, I get jaded with this ol’ world we live in. 
Healthcare alone in this country is enough to get me on a soapbox. 
And now with this pandemic things seem dismal at best some days.
.
.
.
Yesterday though I had a short but so, so meaningful exchange with Emily Giffin. Yea the Emily Giffin, author of mass best sellers and gorgeous to boot.
I was low. Last week was a Fkin doozy in my personal life.
I shared that with her plus the fact that reading her books was about the only thing I was able to accomplish. 
She didn’t have to care, or take an interest, but she did. 
And with that, illuminated how amazing humanity really is. 
Thank you @emilygiffinauthor for being compassionate and all around phenomenal. You made a difference. .
.
.
So my G-R-A-T-I-T-U-D-E Stack challenge. It’s simple, spell out gratitude with your spines.
.
.
.
G- Get a life Chloe Brown @taliahibbert 
R- Regretting You @colleenhoover 
A- all we ever wanted @emilygiffinauthor 
T- the ties that bind @emilygiffinauthor (pub date 6/2/2020)
I- It Ends With Us @colleenhoover 
T- The Dilemma B.A Paris (pub date 6/30/2020
U- Until I find You @reafrey (pub date 8/11/2020
D- Darkly Dreaming Dexter , Jeff Lindsay
E- Eleanor Oliphant is completely fine @gailhoneyman 
__________________________________________

I’ve tagged a few people in this challenge but if you’re reading this consider yourself tagged! .
.
And tell me, what are you grateful for today?
.
.
.
.
.
.

☕️📚SATURDAY☕️📚 Having received an ARC for @emilygiffinauthor #theliesthatbind , I decided to go on an Emily Giffin binge.
Cause when #socialdistancing you need all the feels. .
.
.
I gave “The Lies That Bind” ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💫 and I’m aching to start “all we ever wanted”. .
.
.
How is everyone managing? I think my little family is bored but cozy. My son misses seeing people and going to Target lol. 
But my sister has a compromised immune system due to illness and so that’s why I stay home. For her. And in principle for thousands like her.
I could take things more lightly but I’m not one to take anything lightly.
For her, this virus could be dire.
I ask all of you to think before you mingle, even with family. This thing is tough to contain but if we use even basic science of virology and what it sticks to, as well as basic hygiene, the world will be a little safer.
.
.
Plus, Ozark is back on Netflix sooooo😏 .
.
.
.
.
.

🌙🌊FRIDAY 🌊 🌙 
Sigh. Another day of stayin’ home. But yay for #bookmail! 
Thank you so much to @harpercollins & @menna.vanpraag #gifting me a finished copy of this insanely gorgeous book. It’s just stunning. And its a genre a bit outside of my comfort zone so I’m thrilled to read it! I haven’t delved much until fantasy outside of LOTR so it’s high time I do!
.
.
.
. 
BOOK SYNOPSIS:

As children, Goldie, Liyana, Scarlet, and Bea dreamed of a strange otherworld: a nightscape of mists and fog, perpetually falling leaves and hungry ivy, lit by an unwavering moon. Here, in this shadowland of Everwhere, the four girls, half-sisters connected by blood and magic, began to nurture their elemental powers together. But at thirteen, the sisters were ripped from Everwhere and separated. Now, five years later, they search for one another and yearn to rediscover their unique and supernatural strengths. Goldie (earth) manipulates plants and gives life. Liyana (water) controls rivers and rain. Scarlet (fire) has electricity at her fingertips. Bea (air) can fly.

To realize their full potential, the blood sisters must return to the land of their childhood dreams. But Everwhere can only be accessed through certain gates at 3:33 A.M. on the night of a new moon. As Goldie, Liyana, Scarlet, and Bea are beset with the challenges of their earthly lives, they must prepare for a battle that lies ahead. On their eighteenth birthday, they will be subjected to a gladiatorial fight with their father’s soldiers. If they survive, they will face their father who will let them live only if they turn dark. Which would be fair, if only the sisters knew what was coming.

So, they have thirty-three days to discover who they truly are and what they can truly do, before they must fight to save themselves and those they love.

This one is out on March 31, 2020! .
.
.
.

👁MONDAY👁 
Holy cow this book! 
To be honest, I was rather bored with it until the last few pages.
I did figure out the twist for the most part but it was deliciously twisted to read.
.
.
David, Adele, Louise, Rob.... the four main characters.
Louise i found to be insufferable. One minute she is in awe of her little boy and relishing her luck at having him, and the next he’s an annoyance for some reason or another.
.
. 
The rest of the characters I really can’t say much about without ruining the story for those who haven’t read it.
.
.
.
Did you love this book? Most people hate the ending but I quite loved it. .
.
.
.
.
.

☺️FRIDAY☺️ You guys, I took the plunge. I’m reading my first e-book on @netgalley ! 
Thanks so much to @atriabooks & @simonandschuster for sending me this copy, I’ve desperately wanted to read this for a while.
.
.
BOOK SYNOPSIS:  When Fern Douglas sees the news about Astrid Sullivan, a thirty-four-year-old missing woman from Maine, she is positive that she knows her. Fern’s husband is sure it’s because of Astrid’s famous kidnapping—and equally famous return—twenty years ago, but Fern has no memory of that, even though it happened an hour outside her New Hampshire hometown. And when Astrid appears in Fern’s recurring nightmare, one in which a girl reaches out to her, pleading, Fern fears that it’s not a dream at all, but a memory.

Back home in New Hampshire, Fern purchases a copy of Astrid’s recently published memoir—which may have provoked her original kidnapper to abduct her again—and as she reads through its chapters and visits the people and places within it, she discovers more evidence that she has an unsettling connection to the missing woman. As Fern’s search becomes increasingly desperate, she hopes to remember her past so she can save Astrid in the present…before it’s too late.
.
.  PUB DATE: 8/20/2020
.
.
.
This is exactly the kind of book I needed right now. From the first sentence I knew I wouldn’t be able to stop reading. 
Though I will say it’s hard to get used to not turning pages, but for this book?
Totally worth it.  Add this to your list!!! .
.
.

She’s a freakin trooper, and she’s so smart and kind and her page is beautiful. .

🥀WEDNESDAY🥀

I was uninspired yesterday. All of this staying home has me a bit bored and apathetic. 
But I missed pub day for one of my top 5 anticipated reads of 2020!
Thanks to @berkleypub & @stephaniewrobel for my #gifted copy of “Darling Rose Gold”, which hit shelves yesterday 3/17/2020. .
.
. 
I followed the Dee Dee Blanchard case pretty closely and you will see a lot of that case echoed in these pages.
But this book is far more sinister. .
.
Neither of the two main characters are like able . Rose Gold Watts is bitter and manipulative and self-serving. There’s no silver lining to anything for her.
Her mother, Patty, in prison for keeping Rose in a state of perpetual illness (munchausen) has just gotten released. And who takes her in? 
Her daughter.
Patty is determined to gain her social status back in her small town but they’re having none of it.
Nonetheless, her inner monologue is conniving and wickedly unconscionable.
Mother and daughter are equally trying to play one another, but who will win?
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
.
.
.
I couldn’t put this one down! 
I’m in a slump. A bad reading slump. I made a vow to not reread anything this year, but hell, I just may go ahead and read this one over because it’s that good.
.
.
.
Stay safe my #booksta fam. Take only what you need and share if you have extra. Love to all❤️
.
.
.
.
. #darlingrosegold

☕️MONDAY☕️ Oh my word, how is everyone doing with this craziness?? Even my son knows what Coronavirus is by now and he’s 5. 
My hope is that you are all well and that even though this is a bit of a crisis, your mental health is holding strong. .
.
So with all of this social distancing I’m gettin’ to some of my arcs. I will say that this one draws you right in. At least it did me. .
.
SYNOPSIS:

Tabitha Girard had her heart broken years ago by Connor Ford. He was preppy and handsome. She was a pool girl at his country club. Their affair should have been a summer fling. But it meant everything to Tabitha.

Years later, Connor comes back into Tabitha's life—older, richer, and desperately unhappy. He married for money, a wealthy, neurotic, controlling woman whom he never loved. He has always loved Tabitha.

When Connor’s wife Nina takes her own life, he’s free. He can finally be with Tabitha. Nina’s home, Windswept, can be theirs. It seems to be a perfect ending to a fairy tale romance that began so many years ago. But then, Tabitha finds a diary. "I’m writing this to raise an alarm in the event of my untimely death," it begins. “If I die unexpectedly, it was foul play, and Connor was behind it. Connor—and her.” Who is Connor Ford? Why did he marry Nina? Is Tabitha his true love, or a convenient affair? As the police investigate Nina’s death, is she a convenient suspect?

As Tabitha is drawn deeper into the dark glamour of a life she is ill-prepared for, it becomes clear to her that what a wife knows can kill her. 
PUB DATE: 6/9/2020
.
.
Will you be adding this to your list?
.
.
.
.
.

Oh and shoutout to my beautiful husband @randallondrums , I didn’t mention his birthday on the 6th of March and I’d like to now. 
That man has been through the worst and the best with me.  He’s always steady. And good. That man is good.
I fell in love with him a loooong time ago when my grandma was in a nursing home. It was difficult, a cousin of mine found her disgusting. Wouldn’t touch her. 
My grandma had dementia. She’d stick her hands in the toilet and all  kinds of things.
.
.
One afternoon that man of mine and I went to see her. And he didn’t skip a beat. He heated up her cup of ensure and got her a straw. Put it to her mouth, wiped her mouth when it dribbled down.
He held her hand.
.
. 
You guys, in that moment I knew I never wanted to live a life without him in it.
That was ten years ago.
@randallondrums I love you baby. I will always love you. Happy BELATED birthday my darlin.

.
.

☕️TUESDAY☕️ Happy Pub Day to arguably my most anticipated read of 2020. I made sure that I finished a book last night so that when this arrived I could dive in.
.
.
.
This book is apparently a difficult read. I like difficult reads. I have very few triggers. There are very few things that I can’t read through. 
This is a trigger book for a lot of people though, from what I’ve seen, so keep that in mind. .
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

Exploring the psychological dynamics of the relationship between a precocious yet naïve teenage girl and her magnetic and manipulative teacher, a brilliant, all-consuming read that marks the explosive debut of an extraordinary new writer.

2000. Bright, ambitious, and yearning for adulthood, fifteen-year-old Vanessa Wye becomes entangled in an affair with Jacob Strane, her magnetic and guileful forty-two-year-old English teacher. 
2017. Amid the rising wave of allegations against powerful men, a reckoning is coming due. Strane has been accused of sexual abuse by a former student, who reaches out to Vanessa, and now Vanessa suddenly finds herself facing an impossible choice: remain silent, firm in the belief that her teenage self willingly engaged in this relationship, or redefine herself and the events of her past. But how can Vanessa reject her first love, the man who fundamentally transformed her and has been a persistent presence in her life? Is it possible that the man she loved as a teenager—and who professed to worship only her—may be far different from what she has always believed?
.
.
.

☕️SATURDAY☕️ Blue boxes make me happy 🥰
It’s @bookofthemonth time folks!
.
.
.
The blurbs of these are easy to look up, so I won’t post those. 
But I will say that I’m surprised by how excited I am to read about Lydia Bird considering how much I didn’t love “One Day In December” (I know, gasp!).
.
.
First of all I’ve been in love with the cover art since day 1. And second it deals with loss and grief in an important way. Those are two things that have shaped much of my personal philosophy. I value the people that love so much, so fiercely... and I’m broken when I lose them. So I fight with my propensity to let grief overrun me at times.
.
.
.
“A Good Neighborhood” sounds like a really compelling read! I see mixed reviews but I really think it’s one I’ll enjoy. “The Great Believers” seems extremely deep and emotional and I am looking forward to it. .
.
.
.
.
So what did you order this month????
.
.
.
.

📚WEDNESDAY📚 
I don’t know about you, but when I discover an author that I really love, I have to collect and devour their back work. 
@jenniferhillierbooks is that author for me. .
.
I couldn’t put down “Little Secrets” or “Jar of Hearts” and afterward I had major book hangovers. 
I then began looking for her other books. @thriftbooks has been a great resource for me (I’m not a rep), because I definitely prefer hardcovers and original book cover art.
.
.
“The Butcher” came in a few days ago and I was stoked! .
.
SYNOPSIS:

A rash of grisly serial murders plagued Seattle until the infamous "Beacon Hill Butcher" was finally hunted down and killed by police chief Edward Shank in 1985. Now, some thirty years later, Shank, retired and widowed, is giving up his large rambling Victorian house to his grandson Matt, whom he helped raise.

Settling back into his childhood home and doing some renovations in the backyard to make the house feel like his own, Matt, a young up-and-coming chef and restaurateur, stumbles upon a locked crate he’s never seen before. Curious, he picks the padlock and makes a discovery so gruesome it will forever haunt him… Faced with this deep dark family secret, Matt must decide whether to keep what he knows buried in the past, go to the police, or take matters into his own hands.

Meanwhile Matt’s girlfriend, Sam, has always suspected that her mother was murdered by the Beacon Hill Butcher—two years after the supposed Butcher was gunned down. As she pursues leads that will prove her right, Sam heads right into the path of Matt’s terrible secret. .
.
.
Jennifer Hillier seems to be able to artfully weave in emotion into a great thriller and I’m there for it. .
.
Happy hump day folks;)
.
.
.
.
.
.

🔎TUESDAY🔎

Happy Pub Day to one of my most anticipated reads of #2020 !!
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

Years ago, bookseller and mystery aficionado Malcolm Kershaw compiled a list of the genre’s most unsolvable murders, those that are almost impossible to crack—which he titled “Eight Perfect Murders”—chosen from among the best of the best including Agatha Christie’s A. B. C. Murders, Patricia Highsmith’s Strangers on a Train, Ira Levin’s Death Trap, A. A. Milne's Red House Mystery, Anthony Berkeley Cox's Malice Aforethought, James M. Cain's Double Indemnity, John D. Macdonald's The Drowner, and Donna Tartt's A Secret History.

But no one is more surprised than Mal, now the owner of the Old Devils Bookstore in Boston, when an FBI agent comes knocking on his door one snowy day in February. She’s looking for information about a series of unsolved murders that look eerily similar to the killings on Mal’s old list. And the FBI agent isn’t the only one interested in this bookseller who spends almost every night at home reading. There is killer is out there, watching his every move—a diabolical threat who knows way too much about Mal’s personal history, especially the secrets he’s never told anyone, even his recently deceased wife.

To protect himself, Mal begins looking into possible suspects . . . and sees a killer in everyone around him. But Mal doesn’t count on the investigation leaving a trail of death in its wake. Suddenly, a series of shocking twists leaves more victims dead—and the noose around Mal’s neck grows so tight he might never escape.
.
.
.
Peter Swanson has quickly become one of my go-to authors and even though I couldn’t manage to score an arc of this beauty, I preordered a week ago cause #need . .
.
Happy reading #booksta friends! Will you be checking this one out?
.

#bookmail ! Yesterday’s bookmail but it counts lol.
Thank you so much to @burnhousebooks & @missmeganallen for this copy of “The Meat Hunter”.
.
.
You guys, the premise of this book is WILD!! My sister is vegan so I’m completely intrigued.
.
.
.
SYNOPSIS:

Molly Bishop grew up on a farm and was horrified by her father’s indifference toward the animals they raised, viewed only as slabs of flesh to be consumed by a ravenous society. Now a seductive and cunning young woman, she seeks out the cruelest members of the meat industry and offers up her own brand of redemption. Molly’s mission is clear. Those who raise animals for meat should understand what it feels like to become meat. But the FBI is onto her— they’ve sent in Michael Lair, a whip-smart agent with his own set of demons. And as a deadly game of cat-and-mouse ensues in the nation’s heartland, they must rely on their instincts and intellect to determine who prevails. .
.
.
.
.
It’s definitely a really different concept and I can’t wait to read. 
PUB DATE: March 20, 2020, add it to your list!!
.
.
.
.
.

SYNOPSIS:

After surviving a car accident on an icy road in Hagen, North Dakota, Lily Baker regains consciousness with no idea where or who she is. Scattered Bible verses and the image of a man lying in a pool of blood haunt her memory.

The same night of the accident, a young woman is murdered and tossed in a dumpster. Kylie Milliard, Hagen’s only detective, doesn’t immediately recognize the victim, but Kylie soon discovers that Lily and the dead woman share a dark past…if only Lily could remember what it was.

Lily and Kylie both want answers. But Kylie has to play by the book. Lily has to play it safe. And the more Lily learns about her identity, the more she fears the truth. . .
.
This one is out 7/7/2020 , add it to your list!🙌🏻

.
Y’all know I love my thrillers and this author has a treasure trove of things I put on my Amazon list.

Thanks again Danielle, can’t wait to grab your other books❤️

🌱MONDAY🌿

So this book is definitely a case of #bookstagrammademedoit ... and it’s probably not something that would have caught my attention before I was a momma. But I do think it’s something everyone would find something to connect to.
.
.
.
I can’t imagine what the mother of a Columbine shooter would go through. As parents we feel and know that we will love our children through anything and everything. Even Ted Bundy’s mother loved him, though she was tormented by what he was.
And that I imagine is sheer torture. 
We hope to raise decent human beings. We know they won’t be perfect, but we expect that what at least some of what we instill will stick.
In the case of a parent who has a child with damaging, violent pathology, I’d assume there is so much guilt. 
I feel guilt on a daily basis. 
Am I doing enough, too much, making good memories more than bad. Will he grow up strong but empathetic, kind but wise.
The meanderings of the typical mom brain.
But if he were to do something devastating, something that affected many people.... what would that mean, how would I feel about this life that I put out into the world.... .
.
Sue Klebold wrote a powerful memoir, very well structured. The chapters are divided into parts one and two, with each individual chapter touching on a specific things, titles like “Boyhood” and “The End of Denial”.
.
.
.
I have already started reading and I feel like I’ll cry at least once. Anyone who knows me knows that the most important thing in my life has been the near impossible miracle of becoming a momma. I was told it wasn’t to be. So I might be a little more sentimental than some parents! .
.
.
.
.

.
.
About the book: 
A futuristic novel in which government appointed celebrities live every moment of the day on camera. One of these celebrities, Marlow, discovers a shattering secret about her past, she’s also desperate to shed her celeb status. 
35 years before, Orla a novelist meets Floss, a wannabe A-lister who has a plan to launch then from obscurity, no matter the cost. All that matters are their “followers”. All three ladies are soon thrown together in a cataclysmic twist that changes the tides in America.
.
. 
If you like dystopian/futurist fiction with some dark humor I think this ones for you.
Plus that cover!! Happy Sunday folks 💕💕💐
.
.
.
.

☕️SATURDAY☕️ Yay for another @goodreads win! “Almost Just Friends” by Jill Shalvis, can we just talk about this gorgeous cover???😍😍😍
.
.
SYNOPSIS:
Piper Manning’s about as tough as they come, she’s had to be. She raised her siblings and they’ve thankfully flown the coop. All she has to do is finish fixing up the lake house her grandparents left her, sell it, and then she’s free.

When a massive storm hits, she runs into a tall, dark and brooding stranger, Camden Reid. There’s a spark there, one that shocks her. Surprising her further, her sister and brother return, each of them holding their own secrets. The smart move would be for Piper to ignore them all but Cam unleashes emotions deep inside of her that she can’t deny, making her yearn for something she doesn’t understand. And her siblings…well, they need each other.

Only when the secrets come out, it changes everything Piper thinks she knows about her family, herself…and Cam. Can she find a way to outrun the demons? The answer is closer than she thinks—just as the new life she craves may have already begun.
.
.
This is part of a series but it can also be read as a stand-alone .
I love anything that involves a strong sibling bond because that’s one of the most important things in my life, so I will probably be reading more of the series.
.
.
.
#qotd : are you close with your siblings?
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

🔍MONDAY🔍

I took the weekend off from social media for the most part. Sometimes you just need that❤️
.
.
Thank you so much to @kensingtonbooks for sending me this book! I’ve wanted it since I glimpsed it on Goodreads. .
.
You guys know how much I love true crime and mystery, so of course when I saw a book about the Elisa Lam case, I feverishly pursued it.
.
.
Elisa Lam was a twenty-one year old student from Canada who decided she wanted to tour the western US.
.
.
She checked into the Cecil Hotel in Los Angeles and not long after, vanished. The last anyone heard of her was January 31, 2013.
.
.
On February 19, 2013 a maintenance worker who was investigating complaints about the hotels water quality, found Elisa in a water tank.
.
.
The most eery part of the case is an short surveillance video that captures Elisa on an elevator acting really strange. She walks out of the elevator and that’s the last known footage of her.
.
.
It’s an insanely frustrating case and the author does a lot of research, having to bypass Elisa’s family and LAPD who has refused to speak any further.
This is a great read for anyone interested in this case, or real life mysteries.
.
Goes on sale 2/25/2020 !!! .
.
.

🍰FRIDAY🍰

We made it!!!! I love weekends. 
How bout you?
.
.
.
Ok so I haven’t yet read this book, and the blurb is easy to look up. But it provokes conversation about marriage and “how far we’ve come”.
.
.
This is a topic I like and don’t like.
I am a stay at home momma. I intend on staying a stay at home momma. I want my son to come home to cookies and cocoa like I did. I want to be able to go on his field trips every now and then. 
I love the idea that I’ll tend to my home and all that old fashioned shit.
.
.
I don’t want it all. And a lot of people try to make me feel really bad, like I don’t have higher aspirations or I’ve given up on the struggle for women’s equality. 
I don’t think we’ve made it that far if we’re shaming women for choices. I love your choice to work and have children and be a tiger. But my choice doesn’t lack integrity in contrast.
.
.
And yes, I know that not everyone has this choice, and that I am blessed to be in a one income family. It’s far from easy though, we make sacrifices. We can’t go to Europe lol.
.
.
Alright, I’ll finish my ramblings to say, we are all warriors, I think we are important no matter what we’ve designated our place in society.
I just hope people understand that I am living my highest aspiration. 
Love to all! .
.
.
.

Thank you so much to @kensingtonbooks for this copy of “Some Choose Darkness”!! It’s been on my list for a while. 
#thrillerthursday .
.
SYNOPSIS:

The truth is easy to miss, even when it’s right in front of us. As a forensic reconstructionist, Rory Moore sheds light on cold-case homicides by piecing together crime scene details others fail to see. Cleaning out her late father’s law office a week after his burial, she receives a call that plunges her into a decades-old case come to life once more. 
In the summer of 1979, five Chicago women went missing. The predator, nicknamed The Thief, left no bodies and no clues behind—until police received a package from a mysterious woman named Angela Mitchell, whose unorthodox investigation skills appear to have led to his identity. But before police could question her, Angela disappeared. Forty years later, The Thief is about to be paroled for Angela’s murder—the only crime the DA could pin on him. As a former client of her father’s, Rory becomes reluctantly involved with the killer—though he continues to insist he didn’t murder Angela. Now he wants Rory to do what her father once promised: prove that Angela is, in fact, still alive.

As Rory begins reconstructing Angela’s last days, another killer emerges from the shadows, replicating those long-ago murders. With every startling discovery she makes, Rory becomes more deeply entangled in the enigma of Angela Mitchell—and in The Thief’s tormented mind. Drawing connections between past and present is the only way to stop the nightmare, but even Rory can’t be prepared for the full, terrifying truth that is emerging . .
Such a good book! .
.

Turns out her mom, Patty Watts, was just a really good liar.

After serving five years in prison, Patty gets out with nowhere to go and begs her daughter to take her in. The entire community is shocked when Rose Gold says yes.

Patty insists all she wants is to reconcile their differences. She says she's forgiven Rose Gold for turning her in and testifying against her. But Rose Gold knows her mother. Patty Watts always settles a score.

Unfortunately for Patty, Rose Gold is no longer her weak little darling... And she's waited such a long time for her mother to come home. .

☕️TUESDAY☕️ I won this book that’s been on my TBR for a long while! Thank you so much @readit.loveit.swapit , your puppy stationery has me seeing hearts 😍.
.
.
Holly Banks Full Of Angst:
Per @goodreads 
Holly Banks could not have made a worse first impression on the seemingly perfect moms in her new affluent community, the Village of Primm. Turns out wearing pink piggy pajama bottoms while dropping off her kindergartener late to the first day of school wasn’t her best look.

Not to mention Holly’s worried her husband may be having an affair, she can’t get her daughter to stop sucking her thumb, her hard-won film degree is collecting dust, and to top it all off, the power-hungry PTA president clearly has it in for her…

To make matters even worse, Holly’s natural eye for drama lands her smack-dab in the middle of a neighborhood mystery—right as her own crazy mother shows up in Primm “to help.” Through it all, Holly begins to realize her neighbors may be just as flawed as—and even wackier than—she is, leaving her to wonder: Is there such a thing as a perfect mom? .
.
This blurb! Ok as a mom I see how crazy it’s gotten. To be perfect, especially social media perfect.
.
.

I will never, ever forget the party we took my then two year old son to, and we’re told by another mom that we had been taken off the guest list for another party because my son didn’t fit “the image”. .
.
Tha fuq??? My sisters and my mom had a field day with this person because well, it’s insane. But I’m constantly reminded that’s what we are around. Parents who seem to care about the wrong things, and pay little attention to whether their children are kind, respectful, responsible humans.
.
.
Am I the perfect momma?
Nope. In that realm, perfection doesn’t exist.
But I do hope that I teach my son the important things in life and that they stick.
.
.
Thanks again for the win @readit.loveit.swapit !!! Can’t wait to read it!
.
.
.
.

💗THURSDAY💗

BOOK REVIEW: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ “I CAN’T STAND CONTEMPORARY ROMANCE!!” I scream in my head as I feverishly devour this book.
What I don’t like about romance as a genre is the fluff factor. I can read Jane Austen but the new stuff ... not for me. 
I digress.
.
.
.
Can I really give five stars to a contemporary romance? 
Why yes I can.
.
.
.
Alex is the son of Ellen, President of the United States (I know, cool right??? Finally a female president😂),
Henry is a prince of England. 
Both in their early twenties, both the face of their particular dynasty.
And they hate each other.
When something happens to force them together to save global face so to speak. .
.
They end up realizing they have more in common than they thought. They are both shackled by the constraints of their fame.
So cliche right?????
Wrong.
.
.
This book has some fluff, but it’s excusable somehow. 
It also broaches extremely important topics like quite obviously the rigors of fame. But also things like being true to self, figuring out who you are which I think your twenties are for.
And LBGTQ. 
I don’t care what side of religion or politics you fall on, I feel like it’s important to realize that people are harming themselves and worse, because they don’t feel like they can express who they are to the important people in their lives. .
.
.

Most important in this life is kindness. Understanding. You never, ever know what a person is going through. Celebrities may look like they have it all, but this book poignantly points out their lives come at a price.
.

I am glad I gave this book a chance because it was just the right balance of fun and substance.
It is the first pink spine I own!
.
.
.

🌊MONDAY🌊

BOOK REVIEW:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
Long Bright River was my first read of 2020 and deserves all the stars.
.
.
It centers on two sisters: the older one Mickey and the younger one Kacey.
They are both so different but love each other deeply. They balance each other out. 
Mickey is older but has a naivety that makes her seem younger. 
Kacey is rebellious, fearless and addicted to drugs by the time they are both in their teens.
.
.
As adults, Mickey becomes a Philadelphia police officer and Kacey a drug addicted prostitute.
.
.
Much past that I’d rather you read for yourself. This book is everything. 
Mystery, drama, suspense, thriller....
and it’s thoughtfully written, almost poetic in notion, especially Mickey who really takes center stage. Her thoughts and inner monologue are truly beautiful and raw.
.
.
Sigh.
Major book hangover right now. .
.
What are you reading??? Happy Monday everyone!
Read. This. Book.
.
.
.
.
.

💙SATURDAY💙

Such A Fun Age!
Has this been on your radar? Or better yet, have you read it yet? The premise is not what I thought when I initially spotted the cover on goodreads. .
.
SYNOPSIS:

Alix Chamberlain is a woman who gets what she wants and has made a living showing other women how to do the same. A mother to two small girls, she started out as a blogger and has quickly built herself into a confidence-driven brand. So she is shocked when her babysitter, Emira Tucker, is confronted while watching the Chamberlains’ toddler one night. Seeing a young black woman out late with a white child, a security guard at their local high-end supermarket accuses Emira of kidnapping two-year-old Briar. A small crowd gathers, a bystander films everything, and Emira is furious and humiliated. Alix resolves to make it right.

But Emira herself is aimless, broke, and wary of Alix’s desire to help. At twenty-five, she is about to lose her health insurance and has no idea what to do with her life. When the video of Emira unearths someone from Alix’s past, both women find themselves on a crash course that will upend everything they think they know about themselves, and each other.

With empathy and piercing social commentary, Such a Fun Age explores the stickiness of transactional relationships, what it means to make someone “family,” the complicated reality of being a grown up, and the consequences of doing the right thing for the wrong reason. .
.
I can’t wait to get to this one. 
And cocoa. Yummmm. It’s shaping up to be a brilliant Saturday. .
.
.
.

🏠SUNDAY🏠

#treatyoself ! So The Mother-in-Law went on sale and I picked it up. Meaning I clicked “place order”. I’ve wanted this one for a long while and I was glad for a fantastic price.
.
.
SYNOPSIS:
A twisty, compelling novel about one woman's complicated relationship with her mother-in-law that ends in murder... From the moment Lucy met her husband's mother, Diana, she was kept at arm's length. Diana was exquisitely polite, and properly friendly, but Lucy knew that she was not what Diana envisioned. But who could fault Diana? She was a pillar of the community, an advocate for social justice who helped female refugees assimilate to their new country. Diana was happily married to Tom, and lived in wedded bliss for decades. Lucy wanted so much to please her new mother-in-law. 
That was five years ago.

Now, Diana has been found dead, a suicide note near her body. Diana claims that she no longer wanted to live because of a battle with cancer.

But the autopsy finds no cancer.
The autopsy does find traces of poison and suffocation. 
Who could possibly want Diana dead? 
Why was her will changed at the eleventh hour to disinherit both of her adult children and their spouses? .
.
Have you read this one? 
How’s your relationship with your mil?
I love my mil but we have very little in common so I’ll never have a super close relationship with her. #cestlavie 🤷‍♀️
.
Happy Sunday everyone ❤️❤️
.
.
.

📚SUNDAY☕️ So my momma went to the thrift store a few weeks ago and got each one of her girls a book. We are all readers as I mentioned and the thought of her carefully selecting something for each of our personalities almost brings me to tears.
I love hard folks! Not often, and not many people, but when I love someone it’s mafia-esque.
.
.
.
Love has saved me every time I’ve hit rock bottom. 
Way back in 2008 when my ex-husband pretty much abandoned me for a chick he knocked up, I wasn’t doing so well. But my baby brother, who was 4 at the time may I add, went on walks with me every day. He’d intuitively talk or let me talk about things you’d chat with a child about. I remember holding his hand and feeling so much love in the moment.
.
. 
In 2012 after my grandma had passed and my mental health spiraled to the lowest it’s ever been, I sat in my kitchen with a knife to my wrist, desperately wanting to quiet the torment in my head and body. But my niece was 1 at the time and my gosh she was everything to me. 
Her little face popped into my head and I told myself I needed to be healthy for her. 
The next day I called everywhere I could for mental healthcare. I had no money, no insurance but finally Jewish family services came to my rescue with a grant that made my care free. .
.
Love is everything. 
May you have a beautiful Sunday ❤️
.
.
.
.

BOOK SYNOPSIS:
A sensational crime, a missing teen, and a mother and daughter with no one to trust but themselves come together in this shocking debut thriller by R. H. Herron. “Mama? Help me.” Laurie Ahmadi has worked as a 911 police dispatcher in her quiet Northern California town for nearly two decades. She considers the department her family; her husband, Omid, is its first Arab American chief, and their teenaged daughter, Jojo, has grown up with the force. So when Laurie catches a 911 call and, to her horror, it’s Jojo, the whole department springs into action.

Jojo, drugged, disoriented, and in pain, doesn’t remember how she ended up at the home of Kevin Leeds, a pro football player famous for his on-the-field activism and his work with the CapB—“Citizens Against Police Brutality”—movement. She doesn’t know what happened to Kevin’s friend and trainer, whose beaten corpse is also discovered in the house. And she has no idea where her best friend Harper, who was with her earlier in the evening, could be.

But when Jojo begins to dive into Harper’s social media to look for clues to her whereabouts, Jojo uncovers a shocking secret that turns everything she knew about Harper—and the police department—on its head. With everything they thought they could rely on in question, Laurie and Jojo begin to realize that they can’t trust anyone to find Harper except themselves . . . and time is running out. .
.
Have you read this? Mixed reviews but that doesn’t deter me too often. A book isn’t for everyone. .
.
.

💄SATURDAY💄 “It’s not his love I’m worried about” she says, “it’s theirs”. .
.
This book.... dayuummmm!
.
.
So the narrator is married to a man with two other wives. An arrangement she agreed to because she became smitten with a man who turned out to be a polygamist. .
.
She’s jealous, and insecure and ultimately goes snooping for information about Seth’s other wives. Part of the arrangement is that they aren’t supposed to know anything about each other.
.
.
I spent the beginning of the book disgusted by the narrators willingness to “roll over” both literally and figuratively, for a man. Who she chose to marry. Knowing everything.
That being said, I couldn’t put this book down! I’ve been waiting to read this for a while so perhaps my review is influenced by that. But this was ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ for me.
.
****TRIGGERS: miscarriage, infertility, domestic abuse .
.
.
.

.
Side note, let’s talk mental illness. 
I live with it. It’s there all the time, every day. Panic disorder/agoraphobia/PTSD... and more recently, depression.
For some people it’s manageable through some awesome breathing and therapy techniques.
For others it’s a matter of that plus medication.
Neither route is better than the other. 
The important thing is to do what you need to do in order to live a fulfilling life.
Let me stress that you are not alone. Even if it’s someone you met on Instagram, they deal with it too, or are willing to chat when you need it.
Live your best life folks ❤️
.
.
.
.
.

☃️SATURDAY☃️ Who doesn’t love a good #buddyread ?! #bbrwemetindecember 
This is such a cute story and I’m looking forward to some lighter December reading. Because I typically read darker dramas or thrillers. .
SYNOPSIS:
Following a year in the life of a twenty-something British woman who falls hard for her London flat mate, this clever, fun, and unforgettable romantic comedy is the perfect feel-good holiday read.

Two people. One house. A year that changes everything. 
Twenty-nine-year-old Jess is following her dream and moving to London. It’s December, and she’s taking a room in a crumbling, but grand, Notting Hill house-share with four virtual strangers. On her first night, Jess meets Alex, the guy sharing her floor, at a Christmas dinner hosted by her landlord. They don’t kiss, but as far as Jess is concerned the connection is clear. She starts planning how they will knock down the wall between them to spend more time together.

But when Jess returns from a two-week Christmas holiday, she finds Alex has started dating someone else—beautiful Emma, who lives on the floor above them. Now Jess faces a year of bumping into (hell, sharing a bathroom with) the man of her dreams…and the woman of his. .
.
Cute!
.
.
I hope everyone who celebrates Thanksgiving had a wonderful one and everyone else, I hope it was a great day. .
.
.
.
