☕️WEDNESDAY☕️ I picked this book up on a whim. The cover caught my eye and so I read the back. I connected with it so I got it. .
SYNOPSIS:
An “insidious, suspenseful tale” (J.T. Ellison) with a “shocker of an ending you won’t see coming” (Michele Campbell), Because You're Mine by Rea Frey, the author who “brings to mind Jodi Picoult” (Booklist) and “will appeal to readers of Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen” (Sally Hepworth) is a novel about how the truth will set you free.

But it’s the lies that keep you safe. 
Single mother Lee has the daily routine down to a science: shower in six minutes. Cut food into perfect squares. Never leave her on-the-spectrum son Mason in someone else’s care. She’ll do anything—anything—to keep his carefully constructed world from falling apart. Do anything to keep him safe.

But when her best friend Grace convinces her she needs a small break from motherhood to recharge her batteries, Lee gives in to a weekend trip. Surely a long weekend away from home won’t hurt?
Noah, Mason’s handsome, bright, charismatic tutor—the first man in ages Lee’s even noticed—is more than happy to stay with him.

Forty-eight hours later, someone is dead.

But not all is as it seems. Noah may be more than who he claims to be. Grace has a secret—one that will destroy Lee. Lee has secrets of her own that she will do anything to keep hidden.
As the dominoes begin to fall and the past comes to light, perhaps it's no mystery someone is gone after all…

Because You're Mine is a breathtaking novel of domestic drama and suspense. 
Prepare to stay up all night. -per @goodreads .
.
I’m very much a mood reader. I don’t plan reads, I just pick up what strikes my fancy next. So I have no idea when I’ll get to this one. It might be the next book I read! Who knows.
.
.

Are you a mood reader? Or are you super planned out with your reads?
.
.

.
SYNOPSIS: 
The heart-pounding debut from the creator of the hit Scandinavian television show The Killing.

If you find one, he’s already found you.

A psychopath is terrorizing Copenhagen.

His calling card is a “chestnut man”—a handmade doll made of matchsticks and two chestnuts—which he leaves at each bloody crime scene.

Examining the dolls, forensics makes a shocking discovery—a fingerprint belonging to a young girl, a government minister’s daughter who had been kidnapped and murdered a year ago.

A tragic coincidence—or something more twisted?

To save innocent lives, a pair of detectives must put aside their differences to piece together the Chestnut Man’s gruesome clues.

Because it’s clear that the madman is on a mission that is far from over.

And no one is safe. .
.

So I’ve really jumped onto the #pumpkinspice bandwagon. The #PSL is delicious and mild and I don’t care who hates it lol. .
.
.
I put this book aside a few months ago and I’m so glad I picked it back up. 
@mlouuuise you definitely have good taste in books baby sis.
.

Small synopsis if you don’t know: an agoraphobic woman watches her neighbors comings and goings and then sees something she shouldn’t. .
.
As @subakka.bookstuff points out, the author utilizes the “unreliable narrator”. Though I can see where that may be irksome for some, I don’t actually mind it! 
Sometimes I feel like it adds to the suspense layering. .
.
What I especially like about this book is the fairly accurate depiction and description of agoraphobia, which I have. Hint: it’s not just fear of open spaces. I related immensely to her wishes of being able to do anything, much less leave her home. I too am lucky to have a husband who has always supported me emotionally and financially, so I don’t have to worry about anything other than being well. 
I won’t give too much away but I really did enjoy this book. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5
.
.
.

Everything looks perfect, always just so... Do you know people like that? Well it’s definitely not me. I’m lucky if I wash my hair, our home rarely has an empty sink, my kid always looks like a hobo. .
.
But Jack and Grace always seem so ... perfect. Or do they?
.
SYNOPSIS:
Everyone knows a couple like Jack and Grace: he has looks and wealth, she has charm and elegance. You'd like to get to know Grace better. But it's difficult, because you realize Jack and Grace are never apart. Some might call this true love.

Picture this: a dinner party at their perfect home, the conversation and wine flowing. They appear to be in their element while entertaining. And Grace's friends are eager to reciprocate with lunch the following week. Grace wants to go, but knows she never will. Her friends call—so why doesn't Grace ever answer the phone? And how can she cook such elaborate meals but remain so slim?

And why are there bars on one of the bedroom windows?

The perfect marriage? Or the perfect lie?
.
.
I’m on a thriller kick y’all. I just can’t stop! It’s all I want to read. .
.
.

👤SATURDAY👤
.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
This is a five star read for me. I’m a true crime junkie and John Douglas is just a master in that field. This book combines procedural technique with accounts from the many, many criminals he’s sat with and talked to. If not for Douglas and his team, we wouldn’t have the term “serial killer” nor the in depth access to profiling these criminals. The man is a genius when it comes to noticing everything and using it. From Manson he learned how to give certain people the feeling of power, and how to identify who needed that feeling. 
Douglas read that David berkowitz (son of Sam) had insecurity issues. So he showed him a recent newspaper featuring BTK (not yet identified) and said “this guy uses your name in his letters to the police, he wants to feel powerful like you”.
Berkowitz sang like a canary.
.
.
.

Whether or not you like this genre or would ever read it, the research definitely has affected everything about how we track, profile and interview criminals. Whether or not we want them to, they exist. And it takes people like John Douglas, Ann Burgess, and the late Robert Ressler (the very three that the show Mindhunter is predicated upon) to do the dirty work and figure out what makes these people tick, the goal being to identify said characters before they commit heinous crime. .
.
Warning: this book is graphic in its detail when discussing its cases. I highly recommend and like this book but it is a tough read in some ways.
.
.
.
.

☕️FRIDAY📖
.
Have you read this book? 
It’s one of my favorite pieces of satire. As a teenager and young adult I read mostly classic dystopian stuff, some classic satire. And this still stands out as one of my favorites. It’s odd, hard to get through for some. But I was much more patient in my younger years. .
.
SYNOPSIS:
The novel is set during World War II, from 1942 to 1944. It mainly follows the life of Captain John Yossarian, a U.S. Army Air Forces B-25 bombardier. Most of the events in the book occur while the fictional 256th Squadron is based on the island of Pianosa, in the Mediterranean Sea, west of Italy. The novel looks into the experiences of Yossarian and the other airmen in the camp, who attempt to maintain their sanity while fulfilling their service requirements so that they may return home....
.
.
.
A CATCH 22— A catch-22 is a paradoxical situation from which an individual cannot escape because of contradictory rules or limitations. ... Catch-22s often result from rules, regulations, or procedures that an individual is subject to, but has no control over, because to fight the rule is to accept it.
.
.
I’ve always enjoyed that concept 😏
.
Happy Friday my dears, may your weekend be brilliant ❤️
.
.
.
.
.

🔥MONDAY🔥

This was the only Book of the Month I got. The others really didn’t appeal to me, and quite honestly neither did this one. 
I was put off by the “magical realism” label.
But I researched the book and then the term.
Both seemed right up my alley. 🔥
Magical realism differs from fantasy in that the magic occurs in a realistic setting. It is simply accepted as fact within the setting. Examples are One Hundred Years of Solitude, and even the Harry Potter series. 🔥
BOOK SYNOPSIS:

Lillian and Madison were unlikely roommates and yet inseparable friends at their elite boarding school. But then Lillian had to leave the school unexpectedly in the wake of a scandal and they’ve barely spoken since. Until now, when Lillian gets a letter from Madison pleading for her help.

Madison’s twin stepkids are moving in with her family and she wants Lillian to be their caretaker. However, there’s a catch: the twins spontaneously combust when they get agitated, flames igniting from their skin in a startling but beautiful way. Lillian is convinced Madison is pulling her leg, but it’s the truth.

Thinking of her dead-end life at home, the life that has consistently disappointed her, Lillian figures she has nothing to lose. Over the course of one humid, demanding summer, Lillian and the twins learn to trust each other—and stay cool—while also staying out of the way of Madison’s buttoned-up politician husband. Surprised by her own ingenuity yet unused to the intense feelings of protectiveness she feels for them, Lillian ultimately begins to accept that she needs these strange children as much as they need her—urgently and fiercely. Couldn’t this be the start of the amazing life she’d always hoped for?
.
.
.
What’s a book that you were surprised to have liked?
.
.
.
.
.
.

A few weeks ago my sister and I hurriedly set up a photo shoot for a contest that I was entering.
Here’s the thing.
My sister put crap into her car and came over to help me because. Just because. 
I’m not great at helping out. I’m flaky, I don’t keep my word, I can’t keep promises....
My mental health issues keep me from a lot of things. 
And I fail a lot of people. Including my family. 
But damn if I’m not blessed to have them in my life anyway to do things like help me with Instagram photo shoots. Shoutout to my family. Particularly my sisters who have been there for me since they were little when I began this war against mental illness. 
We are not perfect to each other. We fight. We gossip.
But we love each other. Fiercely, boldly, we all have our strengths within our relationship. 
They both teach me how to be more human, about unconditional love and what that feels like. Before my son came around, it was my sisters who made me utter the words “I’ll never let anything or anyone hurt you”. Of course that’s not how life works. But when you love someone as much as I love them, any pain they go through guts you. 
So what do I wish for you my insta friends?
........................................................................
Love so deep that it’s visceral, unbreakable bonds, the beauty of bleeding with someone.
Love is all there is in this world worth a damn.
.
.
.
.

I got it in just under the wire. 
September is ovarian cancer awareness month. 
I completely forgot and I’m kinda sad about that because I lost someone so important last year to this insidious disease.
Teal is their color, so here’s my #teal stack for #ovariancancerawarenessmonth . .
.
One thing we found out in our journey is that our family carries the BRCA gene mutation. So that’s my advice today. If you notice a cancer trend in your family, especially of reproductive cancers (both male and female) or breast cancer, bring up the BRCA mutation. Get tested. .
.
In the spirit of the person I lost and miss every day, I ask that you love each other. Show kindness everyday. And mostly, embrace life, find something to be happy about. Some people would give anything for life, just life, period.
Happy Saturday folks, be well❤️
I know it’s the last two days of the month but if you’d like to participate in this challenge tag me with #istackteal .
.
.
.
.

I love this author. I was so glad to get a copy of this seemingly quirky read. Got to check one off my lust list. I saw that term floating around #bookstagram and thought, that’s perfect! Lust List. Book hungry we are. .
.
.
@goodreads BOOK SYNOPSIS:
Elsa is seven years old and different. Her grandmother is seventy-seven years old and crazy, standing-on-the-balcony-firing-paintball-guns-at-men-who-want-to-talk-about-Jesus-crazy. She is also Elsa's best, and only, friend. At night Elsa takes refuge in her grandmother's stories, in the Land of Almost-Awake and the Kingdom of Miamas where everybody is different and nobody needs to be normal.

When Elsa's grandmother dies and leaves behind a series of letters apologizing to people she has wronged, Elsa's greatest adventure begins. Her grandmother's letters lead her to an apartment building full of drunks, monsters, attack dogs, and totally ordinary old crones, but also to the truth about fairytales and kingdoms and a grandmother like no other. .
.
Seems adorable. Ove made me laugh and cry. I don’t hold this to that expectation but I wouldn’t be surprised.
.
.
.
.

I saw this book referenced in another book and it piqued my curiosity. 
Per @goodreads :
Past midnight, Chyna Shepard, twenty-six, gazes out a moonlit window, unable to sleep on her first night in the Napa Valley home of her best friend's family. Instinct proves reliable. A murderous sociopath, Edgler Foreman Vess, has entered the house, intent on killing everyone inside. A self-proclaimed "homicidal adventurer," Vess lives only to satisfy all appetites as they arise, to immerse himself in sensation, to live without fear, remorse or limits, to live with "intensity." Chyna is trapped in his deadly orbit. 
Chyna is a survivor, toughened by a lifelong struggle for safety and self-respect. Now she will be tested as never before. At first her sole aim is to get out alive--until, by chance, she learns the identity of Vess's next intended victim, a faraway innocent only she can save. Driven by a newly discovered thirst for meaning beyond mere self-preservation, Chyna musters every inner resource she has to save an endangered girl...as moment by moment, the terrifying threat of Edgler Foreman Vess intensifies.

You guys, I’m thoroughly enjoying this book. I think it’s because it’s representative of my life. Or the one I try to keep away from, on the fringes thereof. 
The upper-middle class stay at home moms. 
Do not misunderstand! Moms need to stick together, for it does take a village.... but that’s the thing. They don’t. They are mean and judgmental and sometimes vicious. They care way too much about things that don’t matter and way too little about things that do. At least in the circles I’m close to.
The online moms are my favorite. They are from all over and share my particular set of issues. My son has SPD, so he’s on the autism spectrum.
I digress.
This book has all the funny gossip and goings on of the world I kinda sorta belong to and it’s funny and annoying and addicting. Can’t. Stop. Reading! @abbiwaxman you are amazing ❤️
.
.
.
.
.

Per @goodreads :
Fallon meets Ben, an aspiring novelist, the day before her scheduled cross-country move. Their untimely attraction leads them to spend Fallon’s last day in L.A. together, and her eventful life becomes the creative inspiration Ben has always sought for his novel. Over time and amidst the various relationships and tribulations of their own separate lives, they continue to meet on the same date every year. Until one day Fallon becomes unsure if Ben has been telling her the truth or fabricating a perfect reality for the sake of the ultimate plot twist.

Can Ben’s relationship with Fallon—and simultaneously his novel—be considered a love story if it ends in heartbreak? .

Meet the #bookstagrammer !
Hi y’all! 
So, my name is Amanda, but everyone close to me calls me Mandie.
.
.
I’m gonna be 40 in a few days here!😳
Not gonna lie, freaking out about it a little. But life is good, so I’m grateful for every day.
.
.
.
I’m married with an amazing 4 year old son who is a legit miracle. He has a sister who passed away at 17 weeks named Ava, and I had 11 (I think?) miscarriages since I was 24.
Through Ava, we found out I carry a Balanced Reciprocal Translocation. So a baby was unlikely for me. But God had other plans ❤️
.
.
.
I’ve been reading since I was 3. My momma figured it out one day and then I was allowed to go to bookstores and the library and read as much as I wanted. Which was a lot!
.
.
.
Prior to finding the amazing #bookstagram community I read only classics. Steinbeck was hands down my favorite author, dystopian literature my favorite genre (think 1984, A Brave New World).
And oh of course, Jane Austen 😍😍😍😍.
But now if you were to ask, I’ve realized that I hate modern romance, and love drama or more serious reads (Ask Again, Yes ; A Woman is No Man).
.
.
I struggle with mental illness and take medication for it and have zero shame.
.
.
I drink a lot of coffee and I love my family.
So that’s me in a nutshell:) Love to all❤️
.
.
.
.

This seems like a really good read. 
Per @goodreads :
Memphis, 1939. Twelve-year-old Rill Foss and her four younger siblings live a magical life aboard their family’s Mississippi River shantyboat. But when their father must rush their mother to the hospital one stormy night, Rill is left in charge—until strangers arrive in force. Wrenched from all that is familiar and thrown into a Tennessee Children’s Home Society orphanage, the Foss children are assured that they will soon be returned to their parents—but they quickly realize the dark truth. At the mercy of the facility’s cruel director, Rill fights to keep her sisters and brother together in a world of danger and uncertainty.

Aiken, South Carolina, present day. Born into wealth and privilege, Avery Stafford seems to have it all: a successful career as a federal prosecutor, a handsome fiancé, and a lavish wedding on the horizon. But when Avery returns home to help her father weather a health crisis, a chance encounter leaves her with uncomfortable questions and compels her to take a journey through her family’s long-hidden history, on a path that will ultimately lead either to devastation or to redemption.

Based on one of America’s most notorious real-life scandals—in which Georgia Tann, director of a Memphis-based adoption organization, kidnapped and sold poor children to wealthy families all over the country—Lisa Wingate’s riveting, wrenching, and ultimately uplifting tale reminds us how, even though the paths we take can lead to many places, the heart never forgets where we belong. .
.
.
.
.
.
.

@ireadandsip recommended this book for me and I finally ordered it after looking for it locally.
It sounds really good.
Summary from @goodreads :

When Lauren and Ryan’s marriage reaches the breaking point, they come up with an unconventional plan. They decide to take a year off in the hopes of finding a way to fall in love again. One year apart, and only one rule: they cannot contact each other. Aside from that, anything goes.

Lauren embarks on a journey of self-discovery, quickly finding that her friends and family have their own ideas about the meaning of marriage. These influences, as well as her own healing process and the challenges of living apart from Ryan, begin to change Lauren’s ideas about monogamy and marriage. She starts to question: When you can have romance without loyalty and commitment without marriage, when love and lust are no longer tied together, what do you value? What are you willing to fight for?
.
.
.
.
Marriage is tough y’all, if yours is easy then I am so happy for you. But for most people it’s two people with different ideas about everything trying to build a life together while fighting over who takes out the trash more. 
Ha! Is it worth it? Damn right. Is it work? Damn right. .
.
.
.
.
.

I picked this up on a whim whilst surfing Amazon. 
I saw the movie years ago and knew it was a book. 
It is a book apparently with fairly poor reviews, a number of which allude to the authors selfishness and whining about being a young mother.
But I think a lot of times we are judged for simply speaking ugly truth.
Is being a parent always fun and a walk through a field of sunflowers?
.
.
No. Sometimes it sucks. That’s right I said it lol. 
Everyone’s experience is different and it’s always a blessing to have these babies. ALWAYS! 
But it’s a tough, sometimes thankless job. 
There’s a raw side to things that not everyone wants to say.
So I wanted to read this book for myself, to see if the author was just speaking her truth. 
Happy Saturday everyone! I hope it’s wonderful.
.
.
.
.
.

Peter. Poor peter. My gosh i wanted to take him lol.

Highly recommend if you’re looking for some gritty substance.

I picked this up on a whim and am looking forward to reading it. 
Description on @goodreads :

Jo and Bethie Kaufman were born into a world full of promise.

Growing up in 1950s Detroit, they live in a perfect “Dick and Jane” house, where their roles in the family are clearly defined. Jo is the tomboy, the bookish rebel with a passion to make the world more fair; Bethie is the pretty, feminine good girl, a would-be star who enjoys the power her beauty confers and dreams of a traditional life.

But the truth ends up looking different from what the girls imagined. Jo and Bethie survive traumas and tragedies. As their lives unfold against the background of free love and Vietnam, Woodstock and women’s lib, Bethie becomes an adventure-loving wild child who dives headlong into the counterculture and is up for anything (except settling down). Meanwhile, Jo becomes a proper young mother in Connecticut, a witness to the changing world instead of a participant. Neither woman inhabits the world she dreams of, nor has a life that feels authentic or brings her joy. Is it too late for the women to finally stake a claim on happily ever after?

In her most ambitious novel yet, Jennifer Weiner tells a story of two sisters who, with their different dreams and different paths, offer answers to the question: How should a woman be in the world? .
.
.
Ok guys, I must not like contemporary romance because I’m not really enjoying “The Bride Test”.
I seem to veer towards drama or historical fiction or anything quirky and/or endearing. 
I’m tempted to put it down and pick it up later but I’m 100 pages in. What do y’all think? Trudge on? 
Ugh. 
Maybe I have a case of the Monday’s ...😏
.
.
.
.
.
.

Do you have any treasured things from your grandma? 
I have so few things even though she raised me. I have a good relationship with my aunts and uncles but there was a bit of resentment at my place in the family. 
Not quite daughter, not quite granddaughter. Somewhere in between.
On my end however, she was everything. I woke to breakfast on the table at 8 am, tv while we folded. Some gardening, lunch at noon and then a nap for me while she watched her one soap opera. .
.
.
I digress.
.
.
.
Those two white candy bowls are from her house. My momma grabbed them for me amidst the silly fighting that was going on over ornaments and plates.

I just finished the last 20 pages or so of this book and I’m weeping. 
A blithering, blimey mess.
.
.
This book got personal for me. 
It took me all the way back to 1984.
. .
My momma gave me a box and told me to put whatever toys I could fit into it and to hurry.
It was the day we left my fathers house and never went back. 
It was the day that like Isra, my mother swallowed the fear that had been beaten and shamed into her and said “this isn’t for you, it’s for [her]” -pg 336...
.
.
.
My mother married my father the month after she turned 18. But the beatings and threats started even before then.
.
.
.
She took the abuse because she was from a traditional catholic family that didn’t believe in divorce.
“What did you do to anger him or deserve it”, was a common theme in those circles. 
My momma tried to tell her momma but was brushed off.
And she lost her nerve. The one person who should have protected her, told her to go home to her husband.
.
.
.
.
But something happened with me that my mother never speaks of, only that it gave her the strength to leave. She knew she had to get me out. .
.
I later found out that while we were packing, my father woke up, hung over as usual, but my mother poured him a glass of milk and sweet-talked him back to sleep.
.
.
She was 22. 
At 22 I was still going on yearly ski trips with my boyfriend.
.
.
I remember things from that day vividly, the last left turn that took us forever from the house on Longfellow street. .
.
My mother made it, unlike Isra.
.
.
Yes this story is about the Arab culture. But many cultures teach similar lifestyles.
.
. 
I’m proud to know a woman as brave as my mother and I don’t know what I would have done in her shoes. But I thank God every day that she had so much courage. My life is different because of that brave girl so long ago.
.
.
I love you momma. Thank you for your courage.
This is a five star read by the way, from me⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
.
.
.
.
.

No matter what you’re going through, be kind to yourself.

Kafka is sooo good. If all you’ve read is “The Metamorphosis”, you’re missing out! .

I reread Metamorphosis last night on a whim. It’s a story that has always stuck with me. Its beyond tragic and odd as can be. The premise being that the main character finds himself turned into a large bug.
Kafka took that strange and silly premise and wrote a masterpiece.
The apple! Oh that just burned me up.

“Oh honey, your food not decayed to your liking? I’ll send daddy to the neighbors trash can. Love you!”

.

I love this paragraph that Michelle McNamara writes about becoming a momma.
.
.
.
I too have a difficult history with my mother. It took years to forgive her for many, valid issues I had. And then when I knew I would never get any apologies or even acknowledgement of the past, a past which broke me into a thousand slivers, I let it go for my own peace and gave her grace. .
.
.
Michelle and I didn’t have similar mothers , but it seems that we had similar experiences upon becoming new mommas. The realization that no matter what transgresses in the future, that new baby is your world and you want everything for them.
And there’s a realization that it’s really freakin hard!
.
.
.
.
.
After I had my son, with my husband never leaving our sides, and also taking care of our newborn because I was out of commission from almost deadly complications, I thought of my own momma.
18 years old with a newborn, all by herself most of the time, with an abusive husband.
And then I bawled.
.
.
.
.
I wanted to go back in time, be her friend, love her, help her.
My God she must have felt so alone.
And yet she took care of a preemie newborn, figuring things out along the way. 
As I write this, I can scarcely see through my tears.
.
.
.
I knew then that I would never again hold any ill will towards my mother. Only love. 
She was so damaged from that part of her life, I can’t imagine what that experience was and still may be for her. 
Perhaps I reminded her of it too much. And perhaps the naturally practical and bold human that I am, just didn’t mesh with the sensitive, almost little girl qualities that my momma has.
Whatever the case, I don’t care. I will love and honor that woman with everything I am as long as I have her.
.
.
.
.
.

Only a few pages in and I’ve found “Gone Girl” to be fairly fast paced, intriguing off the bat.
.
.
.
So I was trying to #read and #mom simultaneously and I took my coffee and my book out when my son grabbed the sidewalk chalk.
An absolutely unsuccessful endeavor, I thought “what am I doing??, in a year or so he’ll be in school and I’ll miss these moments desperately”!!!
.
.
.
Down went my book and I grabbed a red hunk of chalk to start in on a rainbow. My beautiful boy drew a person with legs as long as he could draw them until room ran out.
.
.
.
Ok, full disclosure, I’m not mom of the year. I found myself only half present when I was answering some texts. Mom guilt is real y’all.
And I don’t know about you, but I never feel like I’m failing him or neglecting him... my sons needs are met. He’s fed, clean, has access to creative outlets, is loved beyond reason.
But i feel guilty when I’d rather be reading or find myself on my phone rather than participating and playing with him.
Now, I’ve read ample articles and have even discussed it in therapy, he’s an only child and learning to play alone is crucial, for anyone, but especially for him.
Plus, being a stay at home parent means I am on duty 24/7. So I’m spent. All of my energy is used on caring for this unique boy who is somewhere on the autism spectrum.
.
.
.
Sorry, this was long.
Perhaps my ultimate point is, as parents we are doing our best. We must give ourselves grace.
It’s probably time to take my own advice;)
Have a great Friday folks. .
.
.
.
.

“Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, 
And sorry I could not travel both 
And be one traveler, long I stood 
And looked down one as far as I could 
To where it bent in the undergrowth; ...”
.
.
.
Robert Frost holds an extremely precious place in my heart.
He was my uncles favorite poet, so before I could really comprehend the content, I was reading the poetry. .
.
My uncle was killed in a car accident in 2005. His name was/is Robert.
When I read Frost these days I try to read it in my uncles voice and glean what he might have loved about it. .
.
.
.

Ok moms out there, I want to know how you get in your reading time??
.
.
I’m currently reading three books, and I’m a fairly fast reader, but I’m only halfway finished with two of them, and ten pages into this newest book. .
.
.
.
I am keenly aware that my son will never be this little again, that I should and do savor every moment before he starts school.... but sometimes i don’t want to put the book down!
.
.
.
“You wanna pay wiss me mommy?”
“Yes of course I do my angel!”
..... five minutes later I’m still buried in that book🤦‍♀️.
.
.
So how do y’all do it? I don’t even work outside the home so you’d think I’d have more time. But my little doesn’t nap, is constantly grazing and so picky that I’m constantly in the kitchen whipping something up. That part actually takes me away from him the most. Trying to find him something that he’ll eat.
.
.
Sigh. Maybe I should just be satisfied with the ten minutes of reading time I get here and there. 
My son will be 4 on Friday and time isn’t slowing down. .
.
.
These moments with him are fleeting and too soon I’ll have more time to myself than I want.
.
.
.

“Far over the misty mountains cold
To dungeons deep and caverns old
We must away ere break of day
To seek the pale enchanted gold.....”
J.R.R. Tolkien , The Hobbit
.
.
To my dismay, I have two copies of “The Hobbit” in this edition, but I am missing “The Return of the King”.
It is another book that has gotten lost along the way. In this journey of sorts that we all take, the path, the road, life.
.
.
In my childhood, my mom and I moved every year, sometimes twice. 
After high school I moved westward to California, a year back I moved home to live with my grandparents full time.
A marriage, a divorce, a new love, a new marriage....A baby! 
I wonder just where that copy got lost. 
Wherever it is, I sincerely hope it’s making someone’s library more well-rounded. .
.
.

I finally got my hands on this book without having to order it online.
Shoutout to @halfpricebooks for holding it for me, much appreciated.
.
.
.
Though many may see it as macabre, I love true crime. I think in part, I feel safer knowing the dark parts of humanity in depth. It is a flawed concept I am sure, but I do feel like I’m a little more aware than I would be otherwise.
.
.
So Ann Rule knew Ted Bundy personally and gives some incredible insight into what he was like if you were just sitting, having coffee and chatting. 
Because there is always a public show that these monsters engage in. And perhaps a duality. A desire to be of society, knowing that they never can be fully. .
.
Anyhow I’m looking forward to this #read . Happy Saturday everyone, make it count❤️
.
.
.
.

Who doesn’t love a good sonnet?
Two of my favorites in this pic. Three if you count the coffee.
.
.
The vintage Louis Sherry box came from my grandparents house when they were liquidating, and dividing their things. Things got cut-throat.
Over the years, aunts, uncles and cousins had taken various items.
.
My grandparents home was the only solid thing I’d ever had, so I was so sentimental that I couldn’t bring myself to take even a trinket. I didn’t want to contribute to any changes to it.
But my mom brought that box home to me after things had been rifled through and fought over. .
.
I guess no one wanted an old box. But I remember it sitting on my grandmas dresser holding baubles of no particular value.
I’d go through and hold the buttons or pins. I miss that life everyday.
.
.
My lovely vintage book came from my momma who has long known that books make the best gifts for me❤️ . Elizabeth Barrett Browning is a lovely writer. I love this book.
.
.
.
.

Gettin real here. 
How many of you suffer from mental health issues? 
I do. My specific diagnoses are: panic disorder with agoraphobia and ptsd as well as anxiety induced OCD, and ADD.
It really hit when I was 25, and then again I hit rock bottom when I was 32. 
It has been a long road back to a state of health.
So I’m a momma. Lately with depression hitting I have a tough time doing regular things. I have to do things in a specific order so it takes me a while to get my son and I ready to get out. And I also have to relax a while before I start that arduous process.
I’m afraid my son is suffering because we don’t get out as much as we should, or I’m not the mom he deserves.
But my cousin reminds me that above all he knows that I love him and the most important thing is that I’m here for him. He will be in school soon enough and these days to ourselves will be gone.
I am enough. 
And so are you.
If you suffer from mental health issues you are not alone. 
Tell me your story.
#booknerd #coffeeoftheday

“Make it a rule never to give a child a book you would not read yourself.” – George Bernard Shaw
I have always had this rule for the children in my life. And luckily so did my momma. I still remember the first real “chapter” book I read when I was 4. Black Beauty. 
I fell in love with stories. I never read board books or children’s books after that, unless to another child. 
Reading became akin to my very soul. 
I still remember my very first cup of coffee too;) but that’s another story❤️.
Happy #humpday everyone, be well, drink well, read well.

I once asked my uncle to summarize the “The old man and the sea”. Without pause he said, “keep on keepin’ on”.
He’s more well read than anyone I’ve ever met in my life, somewhat eccentric, but certainly one of my literary references.
I was 18 and his answer has stuck with me ever since.
Deceptively simple, but Uncle David is not a simple man. 
I once had to write an analysis in college about that very book. And I included my uncles answer in my paper.
I got an A , but also my professors all got to know me because of my writing style. 
Straightforward with a personal edge. 
I digress. I shan’t ruin the story in any way, further than the personal one I just told. 
Give it a read. It’s a quick read, have a carafe of coffee near you;)
.
.
.

The very first line-
“I am always drawn back to places where I have lived, the houses and their neighborhoods” - drew me in instantly.
It’s personally relatable. I still love the area that my grandparents home is in. I still consider it my neighborhood even though I haven’t actually lived there in 20 years. 
The house was sold as per my grandparents will, in 2015. 
But I still drive down those streets and say things like “that’s where Ryan and I dug for treasure”.
🔹
Now, if you have seen the movie and are expecting that upon reading, you will either be surprised or disappointed. 
There is some dialogue in common and some scenarios and descriptions. But overall it is pretty different! 
I happen to love both the book and the movie. For who can find fault with the great Audrey❤️
🔹
In my cup? I’m finishing my decadent packet of @redflannelcoffee . I’m semi-lucky to be the only #coffeedrinker in the house. I don’t have to share 😏
.
.

True story. .
My momma started playing Scrabble with me when I was 5. 
I was a fairly young reader and my mom was a really young mom. And it was just us. 
So we played games. 
Now, my momma was and is by no means cruel, but she never gave me the easy win. She thought that to give this smart little thing she had on her hands an edge, she’d have to play her like anyone else.
.
Fast forward to when I’m 8. I’m advanced for my age. And I start winning. By a lot we will just say.
Welp, my mom, she stopped playing me. Not a sore loser but she said it did hurt her 22 year old ego to lose so badly to an 8 year old. .
.
That story still makes my husband laugh. 
This scrabble board is sooooo old. At least 18 years old I think. It’s still all together but it’s seen some games. .
Ah, and my mom finally started playing Scrabble with me a few years ago. 😊
.
.
.

Coffee in a fancy cup and some antique books. Life is good.
My momma always indulged my love of literature and even though she had very little notion of what I read, she’d hunt down vintage and antique books for me. 
Did I mention that I love my momma?
She was young when she had me, sheltered me from her own domestic abuse and loved me no matter how “odd” I was. 
I have written her some poems and she frames them. She frames my sub par art. My momma is proud of me.
My mother is the strongest, most beautiful woman that I know. 
If one day I can have even an ounce of the kindness and love she has for everyone, I’ll count myself lucky.

Journaling is important if you are a writer. Those nonsensical ideas and whimsies often turn into a solid direction.
Also, if you have a writers heart, journaling is cathartic. It is how you emote, how you make sense of your world. Some nights, I’ll wake up and write a single sentence that has been lingering, because I need to put it somewhere. It aches until I do.
Just write. Even if it looks and feels like drivel. Never stop writing, dreaming, thinking. 
Also, there is rarely a cup of coffee far from my hands

My hair is getting too long, my #balyage needs to be toned, I’m chubby from too many late night snacks and mid-day donuts....
But damn, I like me, and I love my life.
I’m the momma of a rainbow baby, I’m 39, and I am loving this stage in my life. 
I don’t miss my 20’s. Except for maybe my great metabolism 😂😂. I have debilitating mental illness but it is in check most of the time. I’m a #mentalhealthadvocate . If my story can help someone, I’m always glad to tell it.
Never be embarrassed or afraid to seek help. And if you don’t have insurance or money, there are grants, low cost places to go. If you are really in need, #dm me and I can try to research resources for you in your town or city
Ok I’m off of my soapbox. 
Be kind, for you never know if someone is struggling.❤️

I’m a dreamer, and I’ve lived a thousand lives in different lands, and times, for I’m a reader of words.
And I’m a momma who still stops dead in her tracks to stare at the moon. The big difference is that I’m holding a tiny hand. A hand that is akin to my very soul. I grew up in a family of readers, dreamers, storytellers.... and now I have a son to pass it all on to. 
I am of the firm belief that there is nothing simple minded about loving the small things life hands us. In fact it shows that you are open-minded enough to notice and appreciate these tiny, everyday gifts. A nice day when the air is so fresh that you feel alive just drinking it in...the smell of fresh coffee...., a dandelion that is full of wishes waiting to be made... the moon on a clear night. 
My son looks up and says “sky”. “Star light, Star bright, first star I see tonight....” we say. 
Wishes come true, for I hold a tiny hand that was never meant to be. 
Make galaxies in your coffee today, enjoy a nice thunderstorm if you’re lucky enough to be privy. Love the simple things❤️.
.
.
.

#journaling . Of late, writing is all I’ve had to hold on to sanity. It’s like washing your mind of the thoughts and fears that pervade to the point of sleeplessness.
Cancer touches almost everyone. It’s tentacles are ubiquitous and far reaching.
I recognize that my family and I are no different, that our pain does not trump anyone else’s.
But I’ve never been so sad in my life. This woman that is leaving us, is the one person who I was never prepared to lose. She taught me unconditional love, kindness, that faeries are real, and that I am beautiful. 
The fact that my son will not know her is death upon my soul. To not know this magical human being is too much for me. 
I know that this is happening. Soon.
But I wish it weren’t.
I wish it were 1995 again and she was setting up my birthday bonfire in Oceanside, s’mores, cocoa for when the night came.
.
.
.

I have a fairly large personal library, but this vintage copy of “Shakespeare’s poem and sonnets”  stands out as one of my favorites.
It’s a 1957 copyright with gorgeous details, and illustrations.
Though it is stunning, it happens to be my favorite because it is from my momma. 
She and I are vastly different creatures and I know she was always a bit perplexed by this strange, introverted, little bookworm she had. 
But she always tried so hard to pick out things that I’d love. This was from 2004, and she hit it out of the ballpark. 
She also knows that i am more fond of his sonnets than I am of his plays. Good job momma. 
I love my momma.
PS- I hate that this pic is off centered but Theodore kept running into me. Literally. Running and smashing into me. So they all look pretty bad. 🤷‍♀️#momlife .

Yea... how bout everyday. I have a three year old rambunctious little boy. 
He legit goes to the kitchen when we wake up , to watch me make coffee. He likes to scoop coffee grounds into the French press and watch momma pour the hot water in.
Then he stirs the “bloom” and we put the lid on and wait our three minutes. And then he likes to push the coffee down.
And y’all he’s been able to operate a keurig for a while now. **disclaimer: any coffee preparation my three year old son participates in is heavily supervised**😊
When the coffee is in a mug, he knows just how much cream his momma likes. 
These are rituals that he will remember. And that I will hang on to as he grows. 
We chose to keep him out of daycare and it’s going by too fast.
Yes it’s tough and I need a lot of “liquid patience”! But my goodness I know that every single moment is special and I just hang on to them. 
Sometimes I gasp during a moment and hold back tears. Because I know he will never be as small as he is right now, and I will never get this day back. 
Never, ever did I think I could love someone this much or that my heart could almost break from being overfilled. 
Y’all have a wonderful morning/Monday folks. I’m going to continue holding this sleeping boy in my arms until he wakes up and picks out my mug for the day❤️.
.
.
.

Waxing philosophical. This is 39 folks. Im perpetually tired, I am probably addicted to caffeine, I’m lucky if I get my hair brushed, but I’m oh so grateful for this life that I get to live. Technically not until August 6, but it’s there. It’s approaching.
I reflect on my 30’s....
I had a battle with mental illness and survived. I’m now an advocate for mental illness.
I made some lifelong friends, my two besties came out of my thirties and I can honestly say it’s because I’m a better friend as I get older.
I had a stillborn baby girl who we named Ava, when I was 33.
When I was 35 I had a miracle baby who we named Theodore.
I really did find myself in this decade, as cliche as that may sound. 
Here’s to the last year of my thirties ☕️. Yep that’s coffee, I don’t drink alcohol. Never tasted it, never want to🤷‍♀️.
Love to all, enjoy your day❤️❤️❤️.
.
.
.

There seems to be the erroneous notion, that the great classics in literature are overrated.
I challenge that notion vehemently. The vast majority of them are excellent reading.
And they should be taken into context for the time that they were penned. What was going on politically, economically, socioeconomically..., what were the authors personal circumstances? 
And what impact, if any, did the books publication have at the time it was released? 
Fitzgerald is worth reading. The Great Gatsby has been over marketed, but it is still an excellent novel. You can’t help but hate the f**k out of Daisy. At least I can’t.
What about you? Lol. **photo credit to owner of pic **
.
.

Gosh yes. I love my simple life. 
I strive to keep it that way. A lot of moms have their kids in activities that make them have to use the calendars that measure by the hour... that’s ok, I’m not that mom.
I love that we wake up and say, “what shall we do today? The world is our oyster”.
Lots of days end with coffee shops, because that’s where I like to be. And it’s so special that I take my son with me. He wasn’t supposed to be. I wasn’t supposed to be able to have children. 
So I’m grateful for every day. And I’m glad I’m able to see the importance the little things. .
.
.

Travel. If at all possible travel. It’s become much more difficult for a lot of Americans to get out, I won’t get political but s**t is expensive! 
When I was younger I could get on a plane for $200 round trip and spend a summer somewhere. But I’m almost 40, so things have obviously changed considerably in my lifetime. Never in American history has it been so expensive just to survive.
But I hope that changes. And I hope we are able to give my son the experiences I had. Because the places and spaces I’ve seen have shaped my views. I’m an avid reader and travel has enhanced my visions of the worlds I read about.
Narnia seems far more real ;)
.

Yes please❤️. Pluviophile: (n) , lover of rain. 
I’m happiest when it’s raining and I’m cozy. I used to have a book in my hand, likely a dystopian novel or some classic the likes of Dickens.

My world has changed. And oh how happy I am. There are still books in my hands on rainy days, but there is another set of tiny hands to help turn the pages. And they have titles like “12 Little Monkeys” or “Love You Forever”. Though the literature has changed, my love of rainy days with a cup of coffee in my midst and a pile of books to read, has only grown with the addition of my own little boy to share it with. I lead a charmed life😊.
Pluviophile...❤️ #obscurewords .
.

Y’all know I’m a book lover. Theres little I love more than being in a bookstore full of used books, wondering their stories. Did someone get this as a gift? Was it donated from a divorce or something more sad? 
I love when books have inscriptions, I instantly snatch those up. 
One of my books says “Dear Holly, Happy Birthday , love grandma -1966.... it’s one of my favorites. What a story that old book must hold. 
Happy Wednesday folks😘. .

Lovely day and a lovely Saturday snack. #latergram 
I met up with a friend whom I hadn’t seen in 25 years. Such a beautiful day. That’s the thing about Local Coffee locations, the ambience is perfect for meetups. The coffee is fantastic and the drip is free to refill so you can caffeinate till you’re too jittery to write🤗. .

Coffee and sweets, @lapanaderia is a cool little cafe with baked goods and some really yummy brunch/lunch picks. They have your standard lattes, cappuccinos etc., on this day I opted for a simple cup of black drip. 
I really like the atmosphere here and the food is great too. The ONLY small gripe I have is that there are no free refills on drip coffee, which isn’t terrible, but also not typical. .
